HEADLINE: MINORITY BUSINESS SET BACK SHARPLY BY COURTS' RULINGS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22

 BODY:
After being nurtured for a decade by state and local governments that set aside a portion of their contracts for minority businesses, thousands of such companies have closed or are foundering in the aftermath of court rulings that the racial preferences are unconstitutional.
At least two dozen cities, from Philadelphia to Portland, Ore., have suspended the set-aside programs voluntarily or under court orders. So have many states, including New York, New Jersey and California. And similar programs are being challenged in court or are under administrative review in most of the 32 states, 200 cities and countless counties and public authorities that have them. 
 "We're talking drastic," said Ralph C. Thomas 3d, executive director of the National Association of Minority Contractors in Washington. "Thousands of minority businesses went under or were neutralized, and thousands of strong businesses became weak. Most of the minority community's business comes from government programs, and when these programs are struck down, they no longer have a place to sell their goods and services."
 
The Phone Stopped Ringing
 Minority contractors, state and local officials, and others involved in these programs say the court rulings are not the only reason for the plight of minority businesses. Various experts cite the nationwide recession, the tax squeeze on state and local governments, the persistence of racism and the relative inexperience of many minority entrepreneurs, who set up their companies expressly to take advantage of such programs.
But many minority companies saw their business fall to almost nothing as soon as courts ruled that the preference programs were unconstitutional.
Carole E. Robinson, whose small company was supplying $450,000 a year worth of toilet parts, refinishing products and fire extinguishers to Philadelphia city agencies, said her phone suddenly stopped ringing on April 5, 1990, the day a Federal court here struck down the city's set-aside program. Her annual sales are now $45,000.
The wave of suspensions and cancellations began with the United States Supreme Court's ruling in January 1989 invalidating a city law in Richmond that set aside 30 percent of public works contracts for minority companies. In a vote of 6 to 3, the Justices held that the law violated the right of white contractors to equal protection of law.
The Court did not outlaw such programs, but it said they must have a well-documented basis to withstand constitutional challenges. Among other things, the Court said discriminatory business practices must be proved to exist before a government could set aside contracts for minority companies, and then the remedial program must be narrowly designed to address the discrimination.
The ruling did not affect Federal set-aside programs, which continue to pump billions of dollars a year into businesses owned by minority members and women. Congress has broad discretion under the Constitution to decide what the country needed to promote racial equality, the Court said.
 
Rewriting the Laws
 A wave of new set-aside programs, remodeled according to the Court's criteria, has begun to move across the country, but it remains to be seen whether the new programs will survive legal challenges. Opponents of such programs, including construction trade associations and conservative policy analysts, say the revised programs are as poorly conceived as the old ones.
Hubert Beatty, executive vice president of the Association of General Contractors, which has 32,000 members, mostly small businesses, said his organization had always opposed set-aside programs, even ones designed to assist small businesses without regard to race. "We are not a racist organization," he said. "We believe that the open, competitive bidding system can work fairly to the advantage of all."
As in many other cities, black entrepreneurs in Philadelphia have been hit hard by the upheaval in set-aside programs. After the city's 1983 law was revoked, these struggling companies saw their share of the city's contracts shrink to 3.5 percent in the fiscal year 1991, which ended June 30, from 25 percent in 1990. In the same period, the value of city contracts awarded to minority companies in open bidding shrank to $21.3 million from $65 million.
In October 1991, a Federal appellate court here reinstated the city's law, pending a second review by the district court. But city officials say that in the intervening 19 months many of the 1,421 businesses taking part in the city's program shriveled like Ms. Robinson's or failed completely. The program is in chaos, but officials say they are starting to gear it up again.
Black entrepreneurs created most of these companies to participate in the city's affirmative action program, and without it, they say they could not compete against more experienced, better-financed white-owned companies.
Black business leaders here and around the country say that racial barriers prevent minority members from obtaining business loans and performance bonds, as well as entering into partnerships with white companies.
Many of these entrepreneurs, like Ms. Robinson, had never competed in the open market. When the set-aside law was revoked, she suddenly had to compete with major industrial suppliers and manufacturers, and the big companies placed bids that were 20 percent below her wholesale cost. "We weren't able to be competitive in any way, shape or form," she said.
 
'That's Discrimination'
 Other black business leaders here saw signs of racism, after the law was revoked last year, in the abrupt way white contractors stopped sharing city contracts with minority subcontractors. "If a white contractor can use you when there is a law on the books and as soon as it's ruled unconstitutional, they drop you, that's discrimination," said John H. Simon, president of the United Minority Enterprise Associates, a trade association for black building contractors.
He said that a third of the association's 300 member companies went out of business within a month of the April 1990 court ruling and that most others were struggling to survive.
Jihad A. Ali, who started a construction company here in 1986 with $500, said the minority business program was the only way he could have stayed in business. "Without it, I would have just been another handyman," he went on. "There has to be a program to make up for 400 years of injustice in our country's history."
Set-aside programs were first adopted by Federal agencies in the Nixon Administration, and by the late 1980's they had spread around the country. (New York is one of the few major cities that never had such a law.) Black-owned businesses, the primary beneficiaries, flourished. Their number increased by 38 percent, from 308,000 in 1982 to 424,000 in 1987, and they saw a 100 percent increase in gross receipts, from $10 billion to $20 billion, according to the Census Bureau.
But studies by state and Federal agencies, summarized in a 1986 report by the United States Civil Rights Commission, found that the set-aside programs failed to help minority businesses compete in the open marketplace. The studies estimated that minorities' bids ranged between 5 and 10 percent higher than competitive market bids.
 
Seeking Better Management
 The report also concluded that the programs were costly to administer, poorly monitored and vulnerable to fraud and abuse. Up to 25 percent of the companies, it said, were illegal front operations for white companies or minority brokerages that obtained contracts but did none of the actual work. The commission, which came under intense criticism for its opposition to set-aside programs, never officially endorsed the report.
Such criticisms have been shared by people who do not oppose the programs in principle. "The criticism of these programs is right on the mark," said Charles Royer, director of the Institute of Politics at the Kennedy School of Government and a Democratic Mayor of Seattle in the 1980's. "But we have a responsibility to rectify discrimination, and I don't know what the alternative is except having better-managed programs."
Many cities are devising new programs in response to the Supreme Court's 1989 decision. Chicago, Tampa, Fla., and Seattle have done studies to meet the Court's standards by documenting that minority companies have suffered from discriminatory business practices.
Atlanta's new program, enacted in September, is intended to help minority members and women obtain performance bonds for construction work, enter joint ventures with established companies and get help obtaining prompt payment. The new program also gives incentives to white contractors who use black companies in private projects.
These improvements are the silver lining in the Supreme Court's decision, said Franklin M. Lee, chief counsel for the Minority Business Enterprise Legal Defense and Education Fund, an advocacy group in Washington.
"A lot of minority firms have bitten the dust," he said, "but I think ultimately we will be better off because the Supreme Court has forced jurisdictions to take a hard look at why minority firms are not succeeding the way they should be."

HEADLINE: Brutal Impasse: The Yugoslav War A Special Report.;
Yugoslav Ethnic Hatreds Raise Fears of a War Without an End

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The six-month civil war in Yugoslavia has killed thousands of soldiers and civilians, wrecked Eastern Europe's most promising economy, created half a million refugees and stirred enough hatred to incite generations of future conflict. But it has not yet produced a decisive military result.
The Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army and its allies, the Serbian militias and irregulars, are bogged down after seizing control of a third of the separatist republic of Croatia and have recently withdrawn from several forward positions. Meanwhile, the hurriedly organized Croatian army is beginning to score some minor victories, raising hopes among politicians in Zagreb, the Croatian capital, that the lost lands may some day be regained. 
 Analysts say that with neither side able to land a knockout blow, and with neither apparently willing to negotiate, the elements are in place for a protracted struggle between Serbia and Croatia, the two largest Yugoslav republics.
"This is a recipe for war without end," said John Zametica, a fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. "It's going to get much worse. So far, we've had a bit of a tea party compared to what's coming."
Many diplomats and observers fear the war could worsen as a result of Germany's successful campaign to extend diplomatic recognition to Croatia and Slovenia, the other republic that declared its independence in June. This week Bonn prodded its more reluctant allies in the 12-nation European Community to agree to recognize by Jan. 15 any independence-minded Yugoslav republic that respects human rights, established borders and the peaceful arbitration of differences.
The German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has argued that sanctions against Serbia, coupled with diplomatic recognition of Croatia and the political support it implies, will slow or stop the violence. Croats generally view recognition as a means to buy better weapons or to obtain military protection from the West.
 
Fears About Recognition>
 American diplomats, among others, said they opposed recognition because it could prompt the Yugoslav Army to begin a fresh offensive before Croatia imports new weapons, or could lead to new clashes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the republic that shares borders with Croatia and Serbia.
Already Croats, Serbs and Muslims are arming themselves in Bosnia, where the ethnic segments of the population are separated village by village and street by street. [Bosnia announced on Dec. 20 that it would seek independence, a step the armed Serb minority in the republic has declared it will not accept.]
The Yugoslav Army, on paper, has the weapons to prevail in the battle for Croatia, but it has performed badly, both because of poor leadership and a lack of reliable infantry. The army's strategy has been to blast away at urban areas with long-range artillery and at times with fighter-bombers.
Croatian troops, fighting to protect their homeland, are generally seen as more motivated, although they lack air power, armor and long-range artillery to support frontal assaults against the dug-in army forces. Armed with small weapons and whatever heavier weapons they can capture or smuggle in despite a United Nations arms embargo, the Croats are primarily waging a guerrilla struggle in the fields and mountains, using mines, antitank weapons and small-arms fire for house-to-house fighting. They have been increasingly successful at shooting down army planes with Yugoslav-designed antiaircraft cannons.
The main issue is geography: The millions of Serbs living outside Serbia live in geographically disparate areas. To link them up in one nation, the army must take large swaths of territory within Croatia and retain control over the Bosnian lands in the middle.
 
The Antecedents
Nationalism Is Used For Political Ends
 Yugoslavia was born in 1918 when the independent nation of Serbia was willingly joined by Croatia and Slovenia, both of which were previously part of the Austro-Hungarian empire.
The border between Serbia and Croatia had been the dividing line between East and West for centuries. Serbs lived under the Turkish Ottoman empire, practiced the Orthodox religion and wrote in Cyrillic while Croats were primarily Catholic and rendered their common language in the Roman alphabet.
Tensions building throughout the 1930's exploded after the German defeat of Yugoslavia in World War II. A Nazi-installed puppet state in Croatia built concentration camps in which Serbs, Jews and gypsies were killed. Civil war broke out, and massacre followed massacre on all sides. Hatred and distrust linger to this day.
Marshal Tito, the partisan leader, emerged as Yugoslavia's leader after the war and subdued nationalist feelings for the next three decades with a combination of adroit maneuvering and repression. Tito's death in 1980 left the country without a successor or system of government, and his former colleagues in the Communist Party began turning to nationalism in the late 1980's as means of winning power.
 
Few Casualties in Slovenia
 Until this year, Yugoslavia consisted of six republics, each of which had a constitutional right to secede, although procedures for the move have never been spelled out. Two republics, Croatia and Slovenia, unilaterally declared independence on June 25, beginning a breakdown in central government authority and leading to conflict.
The Slovenes immediately threw up international border crossings, prompting the Yugoslav National Army to intervene. With compact borders and almost no minorities, Slovenia prevailed in fighting that left fewer than 50 dead. Slovenia's desires for independence will almost certainly be met next month because of the republic's strong ties to the West and the peace that reigns within its borders.
Croatia's escape from Yugoslavia, though, has proved far more complicated. Many of the republic's 600,000 Serbs, about 12 percent of the population, have declared that they will not remain as a minority in an independent Croatia.
Fears among Serbs living outside Serbia were abetted by Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, a former Communist who rode to power in the republic's first multiparty elections on a platform of Serbian pride and nationalism. The Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, won a similarly nationalistic campaign in the spring of 1990 and did little after taking office to ease the Serbs' fears that they would soon lose their jobs and be harassed.
 
Stockpiling Weapons
 By the summer of 1990, the largely Serbian region south of Zagreb called Krajina began an insurgency against the new Croatian government. Serbs in Slavonia, the prosperous agricultural land in the east of Croatia, were less well organized. Still, each Serbian village there had barricades and local militias by April of this year.
Initially, the links between the Yugoslav Army and Serbian irregulars were covert. As spring turned to summer, the army became increasingly open its support of the Serbs, fighting side by side with them. The Serb irregulars stormed across the Danube in July, taking the first towns on the Croatian side of the river in a fierce battle. Some Croatian territory nearby fell without a shot being fired.
In fall, the Croats took a gamble. They barricaded the Yugoslav Army barracks on their territory and captured significant supplies of ammunition and some tanks when several surrendered.
 
The Army
Problems of Funds And Competency
 Of the main actors in the Yugoslav conflict, the army has perhaps the most obscure intentions. It has at different times announced that its intent is to protect Serbs in Croatia, fight fascism, free comrades in barricaded barracks and preserve Yugoslavia.
Most observers believe that the army's true goal is to preserve its pensions and perks. About half of the federal budget went to the army before the fighting broke out, with disproportionate shares contributed by Slovenia and Croatia, the two richest republics.
Gen. Anton Tus, the former army officer who now leads the Croatian army, explained the motivation of the Yugoslav Army this way: "We have a state, if it hasn't been fully recognized, and now we are creating an army. Our enemy doesn't have a state, but they exist as an army trying to create a state to belong to."
 
Relying on Irregular Troops
 Before the war, the Yugoslav Army had 169,000 regular troops, of whom 70,000 were professional officers and 95,000 were conscripts. The fighting in Slovenia in the summer brought a wave of desertions by Croats and Slovenes. The army responded with the mobilization of Serbian reservists, an estimated 100,000 of whom evaded the draft. Those who were inducted seemed to have little stomach for battle; Western correspondents have seen army reservists refusing to leave their armored personnel carriers to engage the enemy. As a result, the army has been forced to rely on irregular troops who are enthusiastic about combat but undisciplined.
The army has shown little ability to coordinate its air power, armor and infantry and appears to have growing difficulties in maintaining its tanks and planes. Command and control appear to be weak. On one recent occasion, the army leadership acknowledged that the Croatian city of Dubrovnik was shelled by rogue local units acting without authority.
"They're having terrible manpower problems; no one wants to fight," said Milos Vasic, military writer for the Belgrade magazine Vreme. "Practically every day we have incidents of reserve troops coming back from the front on their own."
 
Vukovar as a Symbol
 The 86-day siege of the Croatian city of Vukovar near the Danube became a symbol of the army's incompetence. While the civilian population stayed below ground in shelters, the army poured in the artillery. The aim was to reduce casualties, but the effect was to create more hiding places for Croatian defenders, who inflicted heavy casualties in house-to-house fighting. General Tus said Vukovar fell on Nov. 17 only when the Croats decided that the amount of ammunition being used to defend the city outweighed its strategic value.
[It is not clear exactly how the army will be paid in the coming year. Ante Markovic, the federal Prime Minister, finally resigned on Dec. 19 after rejecting a proposed budget that earmarked 81 percent of Government revenue for the military. Under the proposal, a looming deficit would be bridged by printing money.]
 
The Croats
Rejecting Prospect Of Land for Peace
 Political figures inside and outside the government of President Tudjman agree that his hold on power is safe only as long as he does not give up any of the territory taken by the Serbs and the army. These days, the Croats are eager to offer local Serbs complete political autonomy and other concessions within an independent Croatia. Mario Nobilo, a senior adviser to Mr. Tudjman, said talks about trading land for peace were out of the question.
"Too many people have died," Mr. Nobilo said. "No one in Croatia would survive politically if they did that."
Croatia began organizing its military force only this year. It lacks most of the essentials needed for effective fighting, including an experienced officer corps, air power, trained troops and effective communications.
A United Nations arms embargo has severely limited Croatian military options. Some Croatian politicians dream of buying aircraft or tanks once European nations accord diplomatic recognition. General Tus, the commander, has a wish list that is more modest: antiarmor and antiaircraft weapons.
 
The Serbs
A Nation Called 'Greater Serbia'
 Most observers agree that the Serbs hold the key to the conflict's duration.
Mr. Milosevic faces competitors on the right. Vojislav Seselj, a former human rights advocate, heads a party with hopes for a "Greater Serbia," a nation with borders that would include most Serbs and an outlet to the sea.
Mr. Seselj's followers are doing a lot of the fighting and may demand a greater share of political power in return. European diplomats see in this the seeds of a possible civil war in Serbia. Croatian strategists acknowledge that their best chance for a quick end to the war would be major political unrest in Serbia.
Mr. Milosevic is facing other pressures. A trade embargo has led to long lines and severe shortages of gasoline, and the fevered printing of money to pay for the war has ignited hyperinflation. Many Belgrade residents grumble that the Serbs living outside the republic have dragged Serbia into an unwise conflict.
Nonetheless, there appear to be sufficient numbers of young men who hate Croats, or believe the government's claims about leading a crusade against resurgent fascism on its borders.
 
'Collective Psyche' of Serbs
 Some observers with the European Community argue that the Serbian-dominated army could be deterred by one or two shows of military force. Mr. Zametica, the analyst in London, said such action was unrealistic.
"No one in the West understands the Serbs," he said. "They have in their collective psyche certain characteristics, such as defiance, and an attitude that 'if necessary we will take on the entire world.' "
Even if Mr. Milosevic eventually agrees to a peace treaty, it is not clear that the Serbs in the Krajina region and elsewhere will follow. Two Serbian regions in Croatia have already declared themselves independent republics.
 
The Possibilities
More Casualties, But Some Hope
 Every day after the mist lifts, the Yugoslav Army looses an artillery barrage on the eastern Croatian city of Osijek. The shells fall on the hospital, the town square and apartments, typically killing a half-dozen people, usually civilians. The intent appears to drive civilians out of a city that was 66 percent Croatian before the war. Thousands have left, but many stay, living in shelters.
At night, small groups of Croatian fighters fan out from Osijek toward the army lines for hit-and-run attacks. About 100 miles east, the poorly trained troops of Croatia's army begin a frontal assault against heavily fortified positions south of Zagreb. They shoot at the enemy, and one another, taking heavy casualties but little territory.
The outlook is that these two forces will continue to pound each other. Most analysts expect the Croats to improve over time. Their goal of reclaiming the heavily fortified territory held by the army inevitably means fierce fighting and heavy casualties.
Mr. Vasic, the military writer, expressed the hope that the economic facts of life might finally hit home. With Serbia's economy in ruins, the Serbs in Croatia may soon decide that it is better to make peace and focus on restoring the tourist industry.
"This is the Balkans," he said. "But we cannot rule out the possibility of a rational approach."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Could've, Should've, Would've: Abrupt End to Cuomo Dream

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"LITTLE BIG MAN" was Thomas L. Berger's novel about a hero whose stature exceeded his height and whose innocence vanished as he navigated conflicting cultures. It could also be the characteristically ambiguous title of Mario M. Cuomo's abbreviated Presidential campaign biography.
Mr. Cuomo's version ended abruptly Friday with a question mark: 
 Was his stature magnified by a principled decision to give up the Presidency to save his state from insolvency? Or was Mr. Cuomo diminished because, having framed his internal debate too narrowly, he relinquished an opportunity to contribute more to the nation and, consequently, to his constituents in New York?
The Governor had crafted two statements Friday. One, a preface to the campaign, was an eloquent rationale for his candidacy. The other was an afterword in which he concluded that while he could have been a contender, he could not, morally or politically, have run for President by running out on New York.
"Short of being a priest, government is the ideal place for him because it provides an opportunity to do good the way he sees it," said his friend and adviser, Fabian Palomino. "He'd rather lose for the right reasons than win for the wrong ones."
Which is why the unconventional alternative that the Governor chose Friday was, in retrospect, so consistent and unsurprising.
Four years ago, Mr. Cuomo's Presidential aspirations were even shorter-lived. At a Christmas party, when he denied even imagining himself in a national campaign, a skeptical reporter retorted: "I may never get a sable coat, but I can still dream about it." To which Mr. Cuomo replied: "The difference between you and me is that if I don't dream about it I won't be disappointed."
But as Bill Moyers once said about Nelson Rockefeller, if Mr. Cuomo had lost his ambition, he also remembered where he put it. Earlier this year, the Governor and Vincent Tese, his economic development commissioner, began drafting a national recovery plan.
On Oct. 7, four days before he publicly acknowledged that he had begrudgingly told a supporter that he would think about running, he phoned Robert Shrum, a media consultant whose advice he had solicited four years earlier. Mr. Cuomo chatted with Mr. Shrum's wife, Marylouise Oates, about her novel, "Making Peace." Then the Governor ungrudgingly told Mr. Shrum that he was considering a Presidential campaign.
"Without any plans to make plans," he said later, "I made a plan."
By Thanksgiving, Mr. Cuomo had all but decided to run. He had still not completely made peace with himself, though. He was already reconciled to retaining the governorship, regardless, but only if he could assure the state's solvency by closing this year's deficit and, he hoped, next year's, too.
During budget negotiations, as he had consistently on the death penalty, he took the less politically popular side of a fundamental national debate: preferring to prune payments to social-service providers and to pare school aid -- a cut that would mean higher local taxes -- rather than to slash benefits to the poor.
But, all along he figured Republican leaders of the State Senate would capitulate because, facing legislative elections themselves in 1992, it was also in their best interests to deal with the deficit early. Last week, he declared that if the Republicans held the budget hostage to his Presidential ambitions, then he would have a moral obligation to run. The Republicans called his bluff.
For weeks, Mr. Cuomo had weighed his obligations as Governor with the risk that his political message would not transcend New York's deteriorating financial condition and that the state of his state would become a predominant campaign issue; and political liability. To preach fiscal responsibility and economic change while presiding over the collapse of New York's credit would be an "ugly contradiction," he said, regardless of how much blame the Federal Government deserved for compounding the state's financial problems.
Mr. Tese and Mr. Palomino were lunching at Angelo's in Manhattan. With the deadline for entering the New Hampshire Presidential primary only hours away, Mr. Cuomo weighed the evidence for the last time. The scales wobbled, then tipped against his candidacy.
If a Democrat doesn't win next year, said his son Andrew, then in 1996 his father "might be right back where he is now." But, as the Governor himself said, 1996 is eons away.
Meanwhile, he remains an almost-ran, an immigrant ditch digger's son who defied the odds to get elected Governor and who risked disappointment this year by daring to dream. He left a winner, or at least as the untested Democratic front-runner, belittled by some but a bigger man in his own eyes, which, to Mario Cuomo, is the audience that counts most.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: Cardinal Urges U.S. to Welcome Haitians

 BODY:
John Cardinal O'Connor made an emotional appeal during yesterday morning's Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral for the United States to provide a safe haven for thousands of Haitian refugees.
"We can at least not deport the 7,000 Haitians at Guantanamo Bay until there's stability again in Haiti," he said during the service, referring to refugees at the American naval base in Cuba who may be forcibly returned to Haiti. 
 "Our circumstances here are very difficult, and there's a very deep recession, but the suffering here can't be compared to the suffering in Haiti."
Since the coup that overthrew the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, on Sept. 30, thousands of Haitians have been killed, according to human-rights officials, and many thousands more have fled.
After the Mass, Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of the Archdiocese of New York, held a news conference with Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York and several local Haitian-born leaders.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Salomon Client Is Back

 BODY:
The Massachusetts Treasury decided late Friday to resume some trading with Salomon Brothers, joining a growing list of former clients who are returning after having suspended business in the wake of the Treasury market scandal.
Joseph Malone, the state Treasurer, said the decision to resume business with the Wall Street firm was based on the state's belief that Salomon executives had corrected the firm's internal problems and instituted effective safeguards to prevent illegal bidding. 
 But the state is not ready to resume full ties with Salomon. While the Massachusetts Treasury will trade stocks and other fixed-income securities through the firm, it will not yet resume government securities trading, the area where the legal infractions occurred.
Massachusetts suspended all business with Salomon on Aug. 21, after the firm disclosed that it had been involved in illegal bidding in Federal Treasury auctions. Salomon admitted that employees on its government trading desk had submitted numerous illegal bids, at times using customers' names to purchase securities without authorization.
A number of other clients have restored ties with the firm. On Friday, the California Public Employees Retirement System, the large pension fund known as Calpers, resumed trading with Salomon's government trading desk, after announcing its decision to return late Thursday. And earlier this month, the World Bank resumed business with the firm. Both clients had suspended their trading with Salomon after the Treasuries scandal began to unfold.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Additional Rate Cuts Are Seen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Many credit market analysts say chances are good that interest rates will fall further. They say the Federal Reserve, as it demonstrated on Friday when it slashed the discount rate a full point, is clearly eager to finish the task of stimulating the economy.
It has been so long since short-term interest rates were at their current low levels that there is little wonder that credit market participants feel locked in an unfamiliar, unsettling time warp. 
 The Fed's decision last week to cut the discount rate to 3 1/2 percent brings that symbolically important rate to its lowest level since 1964, the first full year of the Johnson Administration.
 
Funds Rate Falling, Too
 The Fed followed up that move by indicating that it had lowered its target on the overnight Federal funds rate by half a point, to 4 percent. Wall Street economists say the funds rate has not been that low since 1963, when John F. Kennedy was in the White House.
It is not necessary to retreat so far to find the last time the Fed cut the discount rate by a full point. In December 1981, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman at the time, lowered the discount rate to 12 percent, from 13 percent.
But the magnitude of last week's cut was much larger, analysts said, because the discount rate, the rate the Government charges banks for loans, was much lower when the reduction was made.
 
 
Only One Cut Was Bigger
 After examining the record, economists said only one discount rate cut had been bigger proportionally than the 22.3 percent reduction achieved last week. The record cut was 25 percent recorded in 1934, with the country deep in the Depression. The Fed cut the discount rate to 1.5 percent, from 2 percent, and subsequently to 1 percent. It seems unlikely that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues would care to be forced to equal or better that feat.
In announcing the rate cut last week, the Fed predicted that its move, in conjunction with previous reductions, "should provide the basis for a resumption of sustained economic expansion."
Analysts were not so certain and noted that by leaving the discount rate a full half-point below the funds rate, the Fed gave itself some latitude to move rates even lower if their forecast goes awry.
 
Helps 'at the Margin'
 "This move helps, but only at the margin," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Manhattan.
On the positive side, Mr. Fine and others noted, the cuts in the discount rate, the funds rate and the 1 percent drop in the prime lending rate at many banks, to 6 1/2 percent, should speed the extensive repairs that corporate and individual balance sheets still need.
"A lot of debt service will be saved over the next six months," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors.
"What the Fed did is a little late in coming, but I think six months from now it will result in an economy that is expanding, albeit slowly."
The downward momentum that resumed in the fourth quarter is likely to remain for some time, however, the analysts said, and the Fed may be forced to respond with further rate cuts.
 
Employment Is Seen as Key
 Norman Roberston, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh, said last week's rate cuts, no matter how bold, were not likely to provide much stimulus over the near term to either consumer spending or manufacturing.
"Once employment stabilizes, then people may start to take advantage of lower rates, particularly in the housing sector," he said. And Mr. Robertson suggested that by waiting so long to make such a decisive move, the Fed may have done more to undermine confidence than to shore it up.
"The most worrying thing now is that the Fed has signaled we are confronted by something of an economic crisis," he added.
Whether Congress interpreted the rate cuts as a panicky step on the Fed's part will do much to determine the ability of the central bank to continue to push interest rates lower, analysts said.
A sense of deepening crisis might stir Congress to enact a fiscal stimulus package far larger than the Fed wants. Should that occur, short-term rates would probably not fall much further, and long-term bond yields would almost certainly move higher.
Indeed, analysts said the Fed probably diverged from the quarter-point cuts in the funds rate, which have been the hallmark of Mr. Greenspan's gradual approach for two and a half years, to reduce the odds that Congress would adopt a package that balloons the Federal budget deficit.
"This may have the effect of making the fiscal package a touch smaller than what it might have been," said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston. "But it does not signal the end of the need for monetary relief."

HEADLINE: Seeking to Give a New Life To a Dying Soviet Industry

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
Until recently, the colossal Leninetz military conglomerate focused on building high-quality radar for Soviet fighter planes. But with the cold war over, Leninetz finds its world turned upside down.
So it is focusing on making refrigerators, razor blades and other consumer goods and is eagerly looking to Western companies for help. 
 After decades of being pampered by Soviet central planners, Leninetz and more than 1,000 other military enterprises find themselves in a struggle for survival. To stay afloat, companies that made tanks, radar and missiles have plunged into civilian production and are struggling to learn to make tractors, radios, smoke alarms and children's sleds.
 With the breakup of the centralized Soviet Government, these enterprises are desperately seeking expertise and money from their former cold war enemies, and several big American companies and a few prominent investors are lending a hand.
"Unfortunately, the Soviet system didn't allow us to engage in much consumer-goods production," said Anatoly Turchak, general director of Leninetz. "We fell behind the West in making consumer goods, so we need a lot of Western help in this area to make our people's lives more comfortable."
As the economy plunges deeper into crisis, the once-mighty Soviet military-industrial complex could be facing the greatest woe. By some estimates, more than a million of this sector's estimated seven million workers could soon be on the street.
"With life already difficult in our cities, we directors of military enterprises shouldn't contribute to the army of unemployed," said Mr. Turchak, whose enterprise has 50,000 employees. "Layoffs could contribute to a social explosion."
Indeed, with Russia, Ukraine and nine other republics of the former Soviet Union establishing the Commonwealth of Independent States and with the transition to a free market producing layoffs and inflation, the old Soviet military-industrial complex has become a breeding ground for a conservative backlash. This backlash has raised fears of a coup and of a renewed cold war because some conservatives assert that military enterprises should continue making sophisticated weapons instead of toys.
With central authority fragmenting and fears about the former Soviet Union's nuclear weapons growing, many Western experts say it is all the more important for Western companies to help prevent the military-industrial complex from careening into disaster and desperation.
"The need for Western investment and know-how was very acute before the recent political events, and the need remains very acute," said Dean LeBaron, chief executive of Batterymarch Financial Management, a Boston-based company that has set up an investment fund to help old Soviet companies convert to civilian production. "We're working to help convert Soviet military brainpower to other areas."
 
'Not Ready' Now
 Huge sums are needed to retrain hundreds of thousands of workers and buy new equipment. The machinery that made radar for fighter-bombers is vastly different from the mass-production equipment needed to turn out refrigerators and radios.
"We need several dozens of billions of dollars to complete our conversion, but we're not ready to absorb that amount right now," said Vladimir Sidorovich, an economist advising the State Military-Industrial Commission. "Still, we could use one billion dollars for starters."
Mr. Turchak, who is 43 and as dynamic as any American manager, has invited dozens of Western portfolio managers and industrial executives to Leninetz's headquarters in the hope they will see investment opportunities. Leninetz has signed a joint venture deal with the Gillette Company of Boston to manufacture 750 million razor blades a year, and it is discussing a multibillion-dollar plan to work with Westinghouse, A.T.& T., I.B.M. and other foreign companies to build air-traffic control systems for Soviet airports.
Leninetz is by no means the only Soviet military company to woo Western partners. The Sukhoi Design Bureau, famous for developing fighter-bombers, is working with the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation of Savannah, Ga., to build a supersonic corporate jet. The Tupolev Aviation Corporation is working with the Pratt & Whitney Company, the East Hartford, Conn., jet engine manufacturer, to develop large passenger aircraft.
"Ideologically there is nothing better in the world than to find ways for people from cold war countries to collaborate on peaceful projects," said Jack Tymann, general manager of Westinghouse's electronics systems division.
The need for outside help is evident in a grimy, poorly lighted Leninetz plant, where 80 workers stand awkwardly beside a crude assembly line that makes refrigerators. Some use screwdrivers, tools that gave way to automation decades ago in most Western appliance factories.
The refrigerators are not large or stylish enough for Western markets, Mr. Turchak acknowledged. But with Western help, he added, Leninetz can adopt modern design and production techniques to make sleek refrigerators that will be best sellers.
His goal is to produce 350,000 refrigerators a year to be sold at home and abroad. In addition, using workers who used to make military electronics, he aims to manufacture far more than a million vacuum cleaners a year. Lenenitz has also become a leading toy producer.
The changes are part of a conversion plan the old central Government began in 1989 to prepare 420 military factories for civilian production. That plan was woefully inadquate for many reasons, among them that Soviet-American arms agreements and the nation's budget crisis had reduced military spending far faster than anticipated.
Because the official policy has been to direct conversion from on high, "very little gets achieved," said Julian Cooper, director of Russian and Eastern European studies at the University of Birmingham in England. "The successful conversions that have occurred have been mainly through local initiative: enterprises getting together among themselves or making foreign contacts."
Mr. Turchak sees another problem: making the ruble a convertible currency will open the domestic market to Western goods. He worries that consumers will turn to long-coveted Western-made products and shun inferior domestic goods. The 11 republics that formed the commonwealth had indicated earlier that they favored maintaining the Soviet ruble as their common currency.
"Our products could turn out to be uncompetitive in our home market," Mr. Turchak said. "That's one reason we need Western partners: they will help us make products that achieve world quality levels."
 
Had Been Top Industry
 Military industry executives like Mr. Turchak said they had one big advantage that might enable them to attract Western investment: the military sector traditionally had the nation's best managers, best technologies and most disciplined work force. While Soviet televisions frequently catch fire and Soviet furniture is uniformly ugly, even Westerners agreed that Soviet fighter-bombers and booster rockets were a technological tour de force.
"If you're going to invest in the Soviet Union, either in individual projects or as part of a fund, the military sector is probably the best place," said Kenneth E. MacWilliams, president of Prudential Equity Management Associates, a division of Prudential Insurance that is reviewing possible investments in the former Soviet Union.
The Military-Industrial Commission, which represents more than 1,000 enterprises, is working closely with Batterymarch Financial Management to attract Western investors. By the end of this year, Batterymarch hopes to persuade investors to put up $250 million in a fund that will invest in civilian projects by military companies.
To exploit the huge demand for televisions, one Batterymarch project would expand picture-tube production by the Moscow Electric Vacuum Device Works. Another Batterymarch investment would help the Kiev Aircraft Production Association make 115-seat Tupolev passenger aircraft.
And Batterymarch has agreed to invest more than $10 million for Leninetz to build a new plant that wouldproduce 350,000 refrigerators. Leninetz estimates that demand is 10 million refrigerators a year, while only 6 million are produced.
"A project like this will not only help my country, but can make money for Western investors," Mr. Turchak said.
Despite such projects, many Western companies are not jumping in. "There is so much that has to happen in that country before you have a viable investment," said Brad Bell, treasurer of the Whirlpool Corporation. "There isn't a firm handle on what their costs are or on what products are profitable."
But Mr. LeBaron of Batterymarch says it is not too early for Westerners to invest. "The former Soviet Union, he said, "needs to find a way, for the benefit of all of us, including the American people, to earn its way in the global economy. If it fails to do that, the alternative is unattractive to contemplate."

HEADLINE: A Retailing Hub Grows In Virginia's Countryside

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALE CITY, Va.

 BODY:
Williamsburg and Mount Vernon may have their historic charms, but Virginia's biggest attraction is Potomac Mills, a sprawling cut-rate shopping mall dating to 1985.
The nation's first shopping mall to combine dozens of manufacturers' outlets and discount retailers under one roof, Potomac Mills peddles the oddly sized, the slightly irregular, the out-of-season, the overstocked and the deeply discounted to 12 million shoppers a year. 
 Although the nation has long had discount and outlet hubs -- Freeport, Me.; Reading, Pa., and North Conway, N.H., for example -- most stores in those places are either in shopping strips or free-standing. Potomac Mills and several succeeding projects have combined the discounts with the appeal of suburban-style shopping malls. The stores are generally Spartan, with few salesclerks in sight. The reward for those who venture 20 miles south of Washington: savings of 30 percent to 70 percent off regular retail prices.
Nationally, a nagging economic slump and a shopping season shortened by a late Thanksgiving virtually assured that most retailers would have a disappointing Christmas season. But at Potomac Mills, merchants anticipate record business. The reason, said Lynne C. Mitchell, marketing director at Potomac Mills, is simple: "People are looking to spend less."
While 1991 retail sales were growing by an anemic three-tenths of 1 percent nationally through November, Potomac Mills saw an 8 percent increase over the comparable 1990 period, with a strong Veterans Day weekend. About 2,500 tour buses visit the shopping center each year.
Herbert S. Miller, the 47-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Washington-based Western Development Corporation, which is the developer and owner of Potomac Mills, promotes discount shopping with fervor.
"In 1990, traditional retail sales grew 3 percent, while value and discount retail grew by 11 percent," he said, noting that discount retailing, including chains like Wal-Mart, now accounting for more sales than regular retailing.
Since Potomac Mills arrived in rural Prince William County, Va., it has been drawing an increasing number of shoppers, spawning satellite shopping centers for a mile around.
The complex now has 1.2 million square feet -- equal to about 21 football fields -- enclosing stores like IKEA and Waccamaw Pottery and outlets of big retailers like Nordstrom's; Sears, Roebuck and Macy's. Those who want a second day of shopping can spend the night at the Potomac Mills Days Inn.
But Western Development, like a shopper on a spree, is hungry for more. Potomac Mills will expand next year by adding 440,000 square feet to include outlets for J. C. Penney, Spiegel, Marshalls and Phar-Mor and yielding a mall the size of 28 football fields. Separate buidings nearby include Pier One Imports, soon to be joined by Wal-Mart and Sam's Wholesale Club.
Potomac Mills' success encouraged Western Development to building Franklin Mills in Philadelphia at 1.7 million square feet; Gurnee Mills, between Chicago and Milwaukee, with 1.9 million square feet, and Sawgrass Mills in Broward County, Fla., with more than 2 million square feet.
In the works are Auburn Mills in Michigan, to draw shoppers from Detroit, Ann Arbor and Flint, and Ontario Mills in California, to serve Los Angeles, San Bernardino, and Anaheim. "Our projects are so large and powerful because we want to be market dominant," Mr. Miller said. "Our objective over the next 15 years is to be in the top 17 markets in America, reaching 83 percent of the population."
On a recent Saturday, crowds flowed through Potomac Mills.
Sylvia Burnette's tour bus had come up from North Carolina. As she slumped onto a wooden bench in one hall, she said she planned to return again, better prepared. "Next time I'm bringing more money," she said, and added, "You got to have on your walking shoes."
Two stores, Everything for a Dollar and Dollar Bills, stock only merchandise that sells for $1. On the other end of spending spectrum is First Choice, which carries designer fashions -- like Escada sweaters that after the markdown sell for at least $250.
For those accustomed to, say, Nordstrom's usual attention to customer service, the bare, unattended expanse of the Nordstrom Rack store can be jarring. Yet, a woman from the nearby town of Woodbridge, who said she "lives at Potomac Mills," called her session at the racks worth the effort.
"It's like looking for a needle in the haystack," she said. "But I've found a few needles, so I'm not complaining."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Can General Motors halt its decline just by getting smaller? Many expert are not so sure. Time and again in the last decade, G.M. has closed plants and laid off workers, each time proclaiming that a "leaner and meaner" company was ready to take on the world. G.M., the experts say, needs more than a trimmer waist; it needs a change of mentality. [Page A1.] 
American Express has cut its ties with Laura Ashley after the retailer tried to discourage customers from using the American Express card because of the fees. [D2.]
 
The Economy
 Chances are good that interest rates will fall further, many credit market analysts say. They say the Federal Reserve, as it demonstrated on Friday when it slashed the discount rate a full point, is clearly eager to finish the task of stimulating the economy. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D1.]
After being nurtured by state and local governments that set aside a portion of their contracts for minority businesses, many such companies have closed or are foundering after court rulings that the racial preferences are unconstitutional. [A1.]
The head of the S.E.C. has sharply shifted course in several policy areas recently in what senior officials at the agency see as an effort to promote the Bush Administration agenda during an election year. [D1.]
Virginia's biggest attraction is Potomac Mills, a sprawling shopping mall that was the first to combine dozens of manufacturers' outlets and discount retailers under one roof. [D4.]
 
The Media Business
Books are selling well this holiday season, and people in the publishing industry are breathing a wary sigh of relief. Publishers and booksellers had been unsure how the holiday season would go, given the state of the economy. But now, people in publishing say there will be plenty of books waiting under trees this Christmas. Esther B. Fein: Publishing. [D1.]
Metromedia and New Line Cinema offered a bankruptcy reorganization plan for Orion Pictures that would merge some operations of Orion and New Line. [D9.]
It looks and reads like a independent magazine, but it's really a marketing tool. The company-sponsored publication can be found at more and more corporations as they move to reinforce their relationships with their customers. [D10.]
Tabloid television is booming. Programs like "A Current Affair," "Hard Copy" and "Inside Edition" are getting better ratings. [D10.]
Veja, a giant newsweekly in Brazil, is the crown jewel of a media giant that is Latin America's largest publisher. [D10.]
Pizza Hut has scrapped its four-year-old ad campaign for a more aggressive approach. The soft-sell slogan "Makin' It Great" is being supplanted by a hard-charging appeal to "Hit the Hut." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]
 
International
Colombia and its foreign oil partners have discovered an oil field that might be the largest find in the Americas since the Prudhoe Bay discovery in Alaska in 1968. [D1.] The Venezuelan national oil company has surpassed Exxon as the world's third-largest oil enterprise. [D8.]

The Director General of GATT is gambling for high stakes with his take-it-or-leave-it plan for bringing five years of global trade negotiations to a conclusion. News Analysis. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Publishing;
Booksellers Surprised by Strong Sales

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
Books are selling well this holiday season, and people in the publishing industry are breathing a wary sigh of relief.
Publishers, booksellers and others who follow the industry had been unsure how the holiday season would go, given the state of the economy. But now, people in book publishing say that although this has hardly been a boom year, there will be plenty of books under trees this Christmas. 
 "There's a general feeling that the season is pretty good -- nothing to shout about, nothing to complain about," said Joyce Meskis, owner of the Tattered Cover bookstore in Denver and president of the American Booksellers Association. "Given the retail environment around us, we're all pretty grateful."
While clothing, jewelry and gift shops have been trying to entice shoppers with aggressive pre-Christmas sales and discounts -- and are still posting poor results -- bookstores have been experiencing real growth.
 
Leading Retail Sector
 Bookstores have shown the greatest gains of all retail sectors this year, said William Lofquist, an analyst with the Commerce Department who follows the publishing industry. For the first three quarters of 1991, the dollar value of retail sales at bookstores was up 8 percent over the year-earlier period, while retail sales at all types of stores were up only 1 percent in the period. The next-most-successful sector was music stores, where sales grew 5.5 percent.
Even taking into account price increases of approximately 4 to 4.5 percent, Mr. Lofquist said, bookstores still experienced a real growth rate of about 4 percent before the heavy holiday buying season began.
"It's just staggering that bookstores are doing this well in this economic climate," he said. "Books seem to still be cushioned. It takes dire economic straits for them to fall out of favor."
At one time, books were considered recession-proof because of their variety and relatively modest prices. This year, though, many in the industry had begun to lose faith.
Indeed, the news is not all good. Publishing executives said that for the first time in memory, a stagnant economy was taking its toll on the book business. Sales are coming later than usual and the growth rate is not as great as people had hoped. But the effects of the recession have been minimal so far.
Certain books, nearly all of them nonfiction, have defied expectations and sold better than anticipated. Among the most often mentioned are Susan Faludi's "Backlash" (Crown Publishers), James B. Stewart's "Den of Thieves" (Simon & Schuster), and Art Spiegelman's "Maus II" (Pantheon).
But the books that are doing well vary from store to store: In some, high-priced art and photography collections are flying off the shelves, while in others, they remain untouched.
Erma Bombeck's "When You Look Like Your Passport Photo, It's Time to Go Home" (HarperCollins), for example, is a winner at Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton stores, but a dud at several wholesalers.
Almost without exception, works of popular fiction by long-bankable authors, like Sidney Sheldon and Danielle Steel, are selling at levels below expectations.
Although Ms. Steel's "No Greater Love" (Delacorte) and Mr. Sheldon's "Doomsday Conspiracy" (William Morrow) are on several best-seller lists, neither has climbed to the No. 1 spot on The New York Times list, as most of their previous works have.
Wholesalers and booksellers say the disappointing sales of the two books provide the most glaring examples of a generally weak popular fiction market this holiday season.
"A number of the expected big titles like Steel and Sheldon have been disappointing," said Judy Hayman, hardcover buyer for Bookazine, a wholesaler. "The popular-fiction, commercial-fiction category is pretty slow. That customer is either dropping out of the market or buying light."
Picking up the slack in that genre, however, is "Scarlett" (Warner Books), the sequel to "Gone With The Wind," which continues to shatter sales records despite generally horrible reviews.
" 'Scarlett' is simply a phenomenon; there is no other way to describe it," said Robert Wietrak, director of merchandising at Barnes & Noble Inc., which owns both the Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton book chains. "It is doing twice as well as what our No. 1 book did last year, which was Charles Kurault's 'A Life on the Road.' I've never seen any other book like it."
Fearing that this would be a difficult holiday season, many publishers and booksellers revised their marketing strategies.
Book signings by famous authors, many of whom shunned such public appearances in meatier days, are at an all-time high and are being held later in the season than unsual. And more publishers are providing bookstores with "shelf talkers," cards that hang off shelves to highlight particular books.
The Borders bookstore chain has increased the number and visibility of its remainders tables of books from previous seasons, and it is doing swift business in that area, said Joe Gable, general manager of the Borders store in Ann Arbor, Mich. "We can barely keep the remainder tables stocked," he said.
Bantam Doubleday Dell started a promotion to "tickle the backlist" of non-current books, as Stuart Applebaum, a vice president in the publicity department put it, "to get a little excitement going in the marketplace."
For example, the company has tempted readers with a one-time offer of Robert Ludlum titles in paperback off the backlist for $3.99, rather than for the current price of $5.99.
"Better to be creative to deal with a different market," Mr. Applebaum said, "than to moan."

HEADLINE: Policy Shift Is Seen at the S.E.C.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard C. Breeden, has sharply shifted course in several policy areas recently in what senior officials at the agency see as an effort to promote the Bush Administration agenda during an election year.
The moves, some of them opposed by other commissioners, include proposed regulatory breaks for small companies, a delay in new rules governing corporate shareholder battles and new efforts to control what Mr. Breeden sees as excessive litigation by shareholders. In each instance, Mr. Breeden has moved closer to the White House position than where the agency stood earlier this year. 
 The agency has also postponed several highly sensitive decisions until after Election Day next year.
"Since Labor Day there has been a clear shift on a number of public and a number of nonpublic matters," said Edward H. Fleischman, the longest- serving among the current commissioners and the only other Republican. "We have turned about 120 degrees in the last eight weeks alone."
Richard Y. Roberts, the lone Democratic commissioner among the four members said: "You sense that something is in the offing. In some areas we've shifted from a gear to neutral, and in some instances we've shifted from neutral to reverse."
The fourth commissioner, Mary L. Schapiro, is a registered independent.
Mr. Breeden said on Friday in an interview that his positions did not reflect any policy shifts but rather the declining economy and his long-held views. "In an election year, the level of partisan combat goes up, so any government program can be perceived as part of that controversy," he said. "We run an independent operation and where we're consistent with the Administration, we're consistent with the Administration."
But officials inside and outside the agency see two political motives: the coming Presidential election and Mr. Breeden's own aspirations to a Cabinet post. Mr. Breeden, a 42-year-old former White House aide and assistant to then-Vice President Bush, continues to enjoy good access to senior Administration officials. And he has made little secret of his desire to move to a higher position.
The shifts come at a time that the White House has been seeking to exert more control over what traditionally has been an agency with a reputation for independence -- with some notable exceptions.
"I can't remember a time in the 1960's or the 1970's that the Commission was as politicized as it is now," said James D. Cox, a professor of securities and corporate law at Duke University. "It opens itself up to the constituency that's most organized. In this case, it's industry that's best organized. The other constituency, the small investor, is not very well organized. And that's who suffers."
In a speech earlier this month, President Bush's counsel, C. Boyden Gray, questioned whether the existence of independent agencies was Constitutional and said the White House had been making an effort to get the S.E.C. "integrated into the policy-making apparatus."
"The S.E.C. has a lot to offer and they should be a part of the team, so to speak, when it comes to issues affecting the financial health of the U.S. economy," Mr. Gray said at the American Enterprise Institute.
 
A Delay in Proxy Rules
 One clear example of the recent shifts is the agency's treatment of proposed changes in the rules governing corporate shareholder battles. The issue has been under study for three years, and earlier this year Mr. Breeden defended the proposed changes in the proxy contest rules as urgently necessary and "quite modest."
Mr. Fleischman and Mr. Roberts said they had expected Mr. Breeden to have the rules pushed through the commission by Thanksgiving.
The proposals, disclosed in June, would make proxy statements available to the public much earlier and would sharply reduce the high regulatory cost imposed upon dissident groups. They would also make it easier for challengers of a company's management to obtain lists of shareholders.
But Mr. Breeden put off the possibility of new rules having any real effect until after Election Day. The postponement came after a complaint by the Business Roundtable, an organization representing the nation's largest corporations, to senior Administration officials. The officials included Mr. Gray and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who was said to be siding with the group.
Mr. Breeden acknowledged in the interview that he had discussed the rules with Administration officials. But he said his primary reason for delaying final action on the regulations was the unusually heavy volume of comments received by the commission about them.
Mr. Gray, who was Mr. Breeden's boss when they worked for Vice President Bush, served as a lawyer and lobbyist for the Business Roundtable before joining Mr. Bush's staff.
 
Carrying the Bush Banner
 In some policy areas, Mr. Breeden has begun to carry the Administration's flag quite visibly.
Picking up on the views of Vice President Dan Quayle that lawyers have burdened society with frivolous litigation, Mr. Breeden recently began to attack the plaintiffs' securities bar, accusing its members of generating unnecessary litigation and taking excessive fees. He called for securities law changes that would make it harder for shareholders to bring suits.
The shareholders' lawyers had historically been encouraged by many former S.E.C. chairmen and enforcement officials, who viewed them as playing a significant role as "private attorneys general" supplementing the agency's efforts by helping to enforce securities laws.
Meanwhile, Mr. Breeden, mindful of the problems that the sputtering economy and the tightening of credit have presented the White House, has lately proposed that the S.E.C. place high priority next year on finding ways to make it less expensive for small business owners to raise money in the capital markets.
Many other S.E.C. officials, however, worry that such steps may hinder their new attempts to combat fraud in "penny stocks," the kinds of financial instruments often used by small companies seeking to go public.
In the past, the S.E.C. has often rebuffed overtures from the White House. But Mr. Breeden has proved a receptive chairman. Unlike his recent predecessors, he views his appointment not as the pinnacle of his career but as a steppingstone. His term expires in 1993, a few months after the swearing-in of the President.
Mr. Breeden's receptivity to White House proposals also reflects a kind of political fence-mending in the wake of the Congressional defeat of the Administration's banking legislation. It had been at Mr. Breeden's direction that agency staff assisted one of the Treasury Department's political enemies, Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, in drafting legislation that would have maintained strong barriers between commercial banks and affiliated investment banks.
Mr. Breeden was prompted to assist Mr. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, because of Mr. Breeden's own views on the legislation and in deference to the committee that control's the S.E.C.'s budget and legislative agenda. But for his efforts, Mr. Breeden has been bad-mouthed by some Administration officials who have laid some blame for the legislation's failure on him.
Said one high-level official, who insisted on not being identified, "There are people in the Administration who are blaming him for getting things wrong."
Assessing the recent shifts at the S.E.C., Joel Seligman, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School who has written a book on the history of the commission and is in the middle of co-writing a 12-volume treatise on securities regulation, commented, "To try and politicize the S.E.C. and make it part of the Administration could not seem more inconsistent with the function of the agency."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Media Giant Dominates Life in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
After Time, Newsweek, U.S. News & World Report and Der Spiegel, what ranks as the world's fifth-largest selling newsweekly?
If the question were phrased in Portuguese, nearly a million Brazilians would probably respond: Veja. 
 "We're the biggest in town," said Roberto Civita, publisher of the powerful magazine that Brazilian politicians pick up with trepidation every Sunday afternoon. "When we started, in 1968, it was a big failure. My father kept asking me, 'When are we going to sell this thing?' "
 
Politically Independent
 But Veja's formula of full-color layouts and politically independent articles paid off handsomely. Long Brazil's largest-selling magazine, Veja (pronounced VAY-jha) saw its sales exceed 940,000 copies in October, up about 10 percent from a year earlier, Mr. Civita said.
"It's as if Time sold more than TV Guide or Reader's Digest," said Mr. Civita, the majority shareholder of Grupo Abril, a media company that is Latin America's largest publisher. He attributed the growth in part to aggressive marketing.
Grupo Abril stands out in a nation where governmental incompetence often obscures entrepreneurial excellence. Despite a deep recession and high inflation, Abril's payroll expanded to 11,000 this year and revenues are expected to increase by 10 percent, to $880 million.
Befitting Brazil's continental size, Abril executives like to use grand images to describe their expanding, international empire.
Every week, they say, Abril's distribution trucks make the equivalent of three trips around the world. Here in Sao Paulo, Abril's printing complex consumes enough electricity to power a small city.
Indeed, Abril now dominates markets in Portugal for women's magazines and for children's comic books.
The company's book divisions publish Time-Life books in Portuguese and about 40 percent of Brazil's telephone directories.
In addition, Abril has started selling Disney comic books in Spanish, first to Spain in 1989, and now to 18 Latin American nations.
"Spanish -- that was the big barrier," said the 55-year-old Mr. Civita, whose Italian-born father, Victor, started Abril here in 1950 with Donald Duck comic books in Portuguese.
 
Looking to Television
 Expanding beyond the printed word, Abril has moved aggressively to capitalize on Brazil's position as the nation with the fourth-largest number of households with television sets -- 28 million -- trailing only China, the United States and Japan.
"We already have half of the magazine market in Brazil," said Mr. Civita, whose 120 magazines dominate the newsweekly, women's, men's, business, fashion, sports, automobile and home-decoration fields in Brazil.
"Look at Brazil this way," he said, sketching a pyramid on a sheet of paper. "Think of 30 million households. Five million households read. Twenty-five million households don't read anything. Nothing."
Last year, TV Abril started broadcasts here of the MTV Network in 1990. And this year, Abril entered the pay television market, offering viewers here a choice of a sports channel, two movie channels, the Cable News Network, a classic movie channel and a culture channel.
"Ted Turner told me, 'If you don't buy TNT, I am not going to sell you CNN,' " Mr. Civita recalled.
Abril's pay television service, TVA, is going head to head with Globo, a highly successful network. Globo offers similar fare on Globosat -- a selection of sports, news, movie and entertainment channels.
 
'Enormous Impact'
 As important as these other media operations are, it is Veja that provides the most prestige and influence for Mr. Civita and his company.
"A cover story in Veja has enormous impact," said Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a Sao Paulo senator and center-left congressional leader. "Simply put, everyone reads it."
A measure of Veja's political heft came in October after Mr. Civita was named Brazil's "Person of the Year" by the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce of New York.
Heading a long list of congratulatory notes in Veja's letters page the following day were two from political figures who often receive skeptical coverage in the magazine: Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's President, and Marcilio Marques Moreira, Brazil's Economy Minister.
 
Publisher's Responsibility
 Mr. Civita said publishing a magazine read by the entire political, business and cultural elite of a leading developing nation entailed "a clear responsibility to open the heads of as many people as possible."
"Brazil has been going the wrong way on a one-way street for so long," he said. "For 30 years, we have been saying that we have to have family planning;, we have been saying that nationalism and xenophobia were keeping Brazil behind."
Today, with Brazil in a deep recession, Brazilians are turning in greater numbers to Veja.
"Our advertising has dropped in half in the last two years," Mr. Civita said. "Despite of the crisis, the magazine is growing. The more chaos we have, the more the readers have a desperate need to know."

HEADLINE: A Tax Cap, to Cap Costs

 BODY:
When President Bush unveils his health care reform plan next month, listen carefully for two simple words: tax cap. If you hear them, Mr. Bush will have taken a politically bold step as part of serious reform. If you don't, you can be sure his plan is merely fanciful.
A tax cap is a limit on the insurance premium that employers can provide tax-free to employees. Premiums in excess of the cap would be counted as taxable income to workers. 
 Why is the cap essential? Because there are only two ways to control medical costs. Either the Government imposes price controls on doctors and hospitals, as in Canada -- an improbable choice for a Republican President. Or it impels consumers to make cost-conscious choices. That's where tax caps enter the story.
Typically, employers offer workers a choice between high-cost fee-for-service plans and lower-cost managed-care plans, like health maintenance organizations. Under fee-for-service, patients choose their doctors, doctors choose treatments and the insurance company foots the bill.
Because doctors are paid for every service, they provide lots of services, some wasteful. Workers don't protest because they see little of the cost. Nor do many workers switch to managed care or other lower-cost plans. One reason is that premiums, no matter how high, are entirely tax-deductible. For many families that means that 30 percent or 40 percent of the extra cost of lavish or wasteful care is offset by lower taxes.
Unlimited deductibles, in short, produce a system where few care about costs -- a sure ticket to inflationary disaster. That's why Congress must cap the tax deduction. The cap would not be so strict that it denied basic coverage. And workers who wished to buy more costly coverage would be free to do so. But the extra cost would come from their pockets.
Health care, of course, involves more than tax caps. The President is deciding between options to expand public clinics, encourage managed care, open up Medicaid to the uninsured, limit malpractice settlements and promote insurance coverage by small-business employers. Some of these options are designed to insure some of the uninsured; but none will contain costs if Mr. Bush sidesteps the issue of tax caps.
The budget director, Richard Darman, knows this, and has been pushing for a tax cap. He also recognizes that a tax cap would be a wise way to raise some of the billions needed to pay for health care reform.
One advantage is that it would hit the rich more than the poor: tax deductions are worth twice as much to families in the 31 percent bracket as they are to families in the 15 percent bracket. Thus a tax cap might help Republican candidates blunt the attack of Democrats who accuse Mr. Bush of serving the rich -- offsetting, politically, the anger of upper-income voters who would lose a tax break.
A tax cap isn't enough to rescue the medical care system from its present mess. But it's the only way, other than price controls, to drive doctors and patients to low-cost solutions of medical problems.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
'Stop the World'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS; William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
In the early days of the 1992 Presidential campaign one slogan has made its mark.
"Put America First," Gov. Douglas Wilder called his program when he started campaigning for the Democratic nomination in August. Pat Buchanan proclaimed "America First!" when he announced his Republican candidacy. 
 Only in a country with so little historical memory would a politician use the phrase America First. For it was first used by the group that delayed this country's playing its full part in opposing Nazi savagery.
The America First Committee in 1940-41 was on the whole an idealistic movement. Some of its members were simply pro-German. Most, whether right or left politically, believed sincerely that America could and should be isolated from the troubles of the world.
However high-minded its motivation, America First's argument was disastrously wrong. Of that history leaves no doubt.
If America First had succeeded in blocking Franklin Roosevelt's efforts to aid Britain, Hitler would surely have overwhelmed Britain -- and then the Soviet Union. A Nazi colossus would have stretched from the Atlantic to the Pacific. The notion that America could have gone happily on, untouched by such a world, is laughable.
"Stop the World, I Want to Get Off" is no more sensible an idea today. The world is a far smaller place than 50 years ago. The United States is much more dependent on international trade and economic interests abroad. Nuclear weapons give this country inescapable international security interests.
As a campaign slogan, America First has undoubted appeal. Many Americans feel, with reason, that President Bush has forgotten their economic plight in his fascination with foreign problems. The end of the cold war makes it hard to justify an enormous standing army and vast commitments for new weapons systems.
Some of us have long believed that American globalism was overdue to be deflated. Our international pretensions have so far outpaced our economic base that we are in danger of following the old pattern of a great power's rise, overreach and decline.
But such concerns hardly mean that the United States can suddenly and totally withdraw from its international role. For a campaigner to suggest that it can is either cynical politics or ideology gone mad.
Think about some of the problems in the world today and ask whether it would be in the interest of the United States to walk away from them.
The collapse of the Soviet Union raises the possibility of hunger and chaos there this winter on an enormous scale. Would Americans really be ready to turn away from that suffering, to offer no help in reorganizing the republics' economies? Not the Americans I know.
One of the most significant U.S. contributions to the international scene in the last 20 years has been concern for human rights. Congress first raised the issue. President Carter made it a part of our foreign policy. Today the world cares about the state of human rights -- in Kenya, in Burma, in Yugoslavia, wherever. Pat Buchanan wants to forget all that. Will he persuade Americans to stop caring?
Then there is the Middle East, still a tinderbox, still the world's largest source of oil. The United States is the only power that can hope to lead Israel and its neighbors to peace. It would be not only irresponsible but against our own urgent interests to give up that effort.
It is not just Pat Buchanan and Douglas Wilder who suggest to campaign audiences that the United States can turn away from the burdens of the world. Senator Tom Harkin, in his calls for the country to look inward, sounds close to isolationist. Of all the competing Democrats, only Gov. Bill Clinton has given much attention to foreign policy.
The Democrats, whoever is nominated, will run to a great extent on domestic issues. Rightly so: A middle class impoverished by the voodoo economics of Ronald Reagan and George Bush is looking for new policies at home.
But promising to forget the rest of the world is another thing. The United States tried that in the 1920's and 1930's. We and the world paid a frightful price.
