HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The Hut Turns Up the Heat In the War of Pizza Chains

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
IN another skirmish in the pizza wars, Pizza Hut Inc. has scrapped its four-year-old advertising campaign for a more aggressive approach.
In television commercials by BBDO New York, which begin on Thursday, the nation's largest pizza chain will introduce twin themes replete with urgent calls to action. 
 For Pizza Hut's burgeoning delivery service, the singer Aretha Franklin will belt out a tune, "Deliver Me," based on her 1960's soul song "Rescue Me." And for its sit-down restaurants, the soft-sell slogan "Makin' It Great" is being supplanted by a hard-charging appeal to "Hit the Hut."
The delivery spots are "a great way to put the fact that we deliver into the consumer's vocabulary," Bob Perkins, Pizza Hut's senior vice president of marketing, said in a telephone interview from its headquarters in Wichita, Kan. And the entreaties to "Hit the Hut," he added, are intended to inject excitement and energy into efforts to "give consumers a reason to go to Pizza Hut tonight."
Separate pitches for Pizza Hut's two businesses make sense, said Charlie Miesmer, BBDO's vice chairman and executive creative director, because "they really appeal to different people at different times."
Customers "in their late teens and early 20's, who would not go into a fast-food place, sit down and order a pizza, love to pick up the phone and order," he added.
Since January, advertising for Pizza Hut, a Pepsico Inc. subsidiary, has emphasized delivery service in a challenge to Domino's Pizza Inc. Though second in overall sales behind Pizza Hut, Domino's is first in delivery sales, which account for about a third of the country's $10 billion to $15 billion annual appetite for pizza.
Industry analysts estimate that Pizza Hut has captured about 25 percent of the delivery market, to Domino's 45 percent. Pizza Hut spends an estimated $75 million on advertising annually, 50 percent more than Domino's ad budget.
Pizza Hut's strategy "strikes right at the heart of Domino's competitive position," said Nancy Kruse, a principal in Technomic Inc., a Chicago-based fast-food consulting company. Pizza Hut "hits a real hot button with consumers," she added, "whose attitude toward home delivery is, 'I want it when I want it.' "
To counter Pizza Hut, Domino's dumped its longtime agency, Group 243 in Ann Arbor, Mich., in favor of Grey Advertising Inc. in New York. In September, Grey introduced a campaign with the theme, "Nobody knows like Domino's how you like pizza at home," which plays down the emphasis on fast delivery in favor of product quality.
Pizza Hut's decision to change its advertising "has nothing to do with Domino's," said Mr. Perkins, who joined Pizza Hut in May from Chiat/ Day/Mojo Inc., a former Pizza Hut agency.
"If I would have been here earlier," he added, "we would have brought this out three months before Domino's."
Complicating the Pizza Hut-Domino's battle is the spoiler role played by Little Caesars Enterprises, which stresses lower-priced menu items in humorous commercials by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York. One spot, recently lauded by Bob Garfield, Advertising Age's ad critic, spoofs the penchant of pizza commercials to venerate those long, gooey strings of mozzarella known as "cheese pulls."
Ms. Kruse, the industry consultant, said Little Caesars was "getting an extra push because consumers are so value-conscious due to the recession." To keep pace, ads for Pizza Hut and Domino's also feature lower-priced pizzas.
Absent from BBDO's new Pizza Hut ads are the direct attacks on Domino's that caused controversy earlier this year; one spot showed actors portraying Domino's deliverers secretly eating Pizza Hut pies.
While "it's not that we'll never tweak them again," Mr. Miesmer said, the belief was that "this time around, we should say something a little more directly positive" about Pizza Hut.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 24, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, the Advertising column yesterday referred incorrectly to the 1960's soul song "Rescue Me," on which Pizza Hut has based the song for its new advertising campaign. Although the song heard in the commercials, "Deliver Me," is sung by Aretha Franklin, she did not sing "Rescue Me."

HEADLINE: The Revolution: A Case for Optimism

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Soviet and East European studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Winter has arrived in Russia, preceded by a flurry of demands that the outside world do something, anything, to help post-Soviet democracy succeed. Yet the most lurid descriptions of what could lie ahead -- unguarded nuclear weapons, hungry children, demagogues in search of an opening -- may only make help seem futile. A convincing case for Western aid must include reasons for thinking it would work.
The argument for optimism begins with all the things that should already have gone wrong if the pessimists were right. Many experts "knew" that no Russian politician could accept Ukrainian independence (and some of them knew that Baltic independence was out of the question, too). More broadly, the collapse of the Soviet state is supposed to have let loose uncontrollable nationalisms allowing peoples that most Americans have never heard of to start killing each other with abandon. 
 Instead, the presidents of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia two weeks ago found a formula that cools off nationalist hotheads. In agreeing on a post-Soviet commonwealth, they recognized the reality of independence while preserving close relations. In this framework, accepted by 11 republics on Saturday, the issues that were supposed to be intractable -- whether territory or minority rights -- become far more manageable.
The Russian Government has also made progress in defusing ethnic problems inside its own borders. The Tatars, who pose the single most serious secessionist challenge to Russia itself, recently reached agreement with Moscow on increased economic autonomy, including rights to their huge oil reserves. The Tatar prime minister called it the most constructive negotiation with Russia since 1552.
Foreshadowing disaster of a different kind, rumors have spread in Moscow for months that disgruntlement in the military would soon bring another coup attempt. Anger that thousands of officers were living with their families in "tent cities" mingles with anxiety at the looming breakup of the armed forces into separate republican units.
But far from becoming an independent political force, the high command responded to the latest crisis by showing that it will, and wants to, take its cue from strong civilian leaders. This was the message of their support for Boris Yeltsin as he sought to ease Mikhail Gorbachev from office. The August coup taught the army the danger of putting itself on the wrong side of the barricades. The recent ouster of Gen. Vladimir Lobov as chief of the general staff, after his complaints about what republic independence would do to the army, showed that the military establishment will no longer protect those in its ranks who have not gotten the message.
What produced these results was not just unexpected reasonableness. It was the exercise of power. The changeover from President Gorbachev to President Yeltsin, dramatic in so many ways, represents the eclipse of a leader whose interests were served by keeping problems unresolved, in favor of one who knows that he has to offer real solutions if he is to survive. Mr. Yeltsin has shown, moreover, that reaching consensus is not simply a matter of the endless meetings that his predecessor favored. His warnings that Russia will, where necessary, act on its own have changed the terms of negotiation with smaller republics. In this way, he rebuts those who, in forecasting disaster, have assumed indefinite drift.
All this progress, the pessimists insist, will soon be swept away by economic catastrophe. The Soviet economy is cracking up, but it is not true that economics simply trumps politics. To the contrary, the agreement to create a post-Soviet commonwealth was a political achievement with real economic consequences. It removed one of the main obstacles to implementation of the radical economic program that Mr. Yeltsin unveiled at the end of October: the fear that uncoordinated moves to the market in different republics would produce havoc.
For the sake of this agreement, which included acceptance by all sides of a single currency, the Russian Government postponed its planned liberalization of prices until January. The delay will further increase shortages inside Russia, as more goods are held back in hopes of selling them at a higher price later. But Mr. Yeltsin is now more likely to push his program through than he was when Russia had to face doing so on its own. Economic hardship, moreover, is eased by political cooperation: as its part of the commonwealth pact, the Ukrainians quickly announced increased food deliveries to Russia to fill gaps created by the delay.
Meanwhile, inside the Russian Government -- and out of the headlines -- seemingly mundane preparations continue for the transition to capitalism. The legislature, for example, has just approved a wholly new tax system to replace the old one, which was designed for a planned rather than a market economy. Similarly, Mr. Yeltsin's deputies are at work on creating an effective social safety net, made urgent by the prospect of sharply higher prices and mass unemployment.
In the hurricane now sweeping through the old Soviet economy, such measures can hardly take hold soon enough to prevent great hardship. Foreseeing this, pessimists talk of Weimar-style outcomes: the failure of a democracy when it cannot secure the people's livelihood. The U.S. Ambassador, Robert Strauss, has referred to "any number of first-class demagogues" waiting to put themselves at the head of an angry anti-capitalist mob. He is far too charitable. The Russian politician making the loudest effort of this kind, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, is a laughingstock. His recent effort to woo the military featured the feeblest possible appeals: Does anyone really worry that junior officers will be moved to mutiny by promises of free life insurance or even a personal orderly?
Only one proven "first-class demagogue" is operating in Russian politics today, and his name is Boris Yeltsin. He is now in the position, admittedly awkward for demagogues, of having to produce results, but thanks to his own efforts he also has the power to do so. The Government of Russia -- the country's most important democratic force -- is better able to act, and to see its actions through, than at any time since Mr. Yeltsin took office a year and a half ago.
His virtuoso performance in driving Mr. Gorbachev from power has silenced those who two months ago complained that the hero of August was out of his depth. He has at the same time made it harder for aspiring demagogues to rally people against him. Among the frustrated rabble-rousers, Mr. Yeltsin's own Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, has for weeks been seeking a pretext for a dramatic break with his boss. Even if he finds one, the threat he poses should not be exaggerated. He has no organization, no electoral track record and few allies of any standing.
As strong as he is, Mr. Yeltsin is taking an enormous gamble by beginning the new year with economic shock therapy. To succeed, he clearly needs outside assistance, and not simply the short-term humanitarian help that is on the agenda of the international conference that the U.S. has called for January. Mr. Yeltsin's objective goes far beyond feeding hungry mouths; he has to bring a vast moribund economy to life on a completely new basis. Market prices will by themselves increase the supply of goods for sale, but unless imports are available to help revive manufacturing and stabilize the consumer market, capitalism will seem no more than a system of extreme scarcity.
Many arguments for Western assistance to Russia start and end with the importance of nurturing democracy, as though billions could be committed out of fellow feeling. They don't have to be. Russia's democrats have the political strength to make use of our help and complete the revolution they have only just begun.

HEADLINE: Federal Regulation Growing Despite Quayle Panel's Role

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
While environmental and consumer groups have criticized the White House Council on Competitiveness as being anti-regulatory, some conservatives say the office, headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, has proved to have little muscle. In fact, there has been an unabated growth in Federal regulations during the Bush Administration.
Conservatives note that nearly 4,900 Federal regulations are currently being written -- as against 4,000 being considered at any one time in the Reagan years -- and that a vast majority of them will never be examined by the council, a panel with six high-ranking members and only six full-time aides. 
 The sharp growth is also evidenced by the number of entries in the Federal Register, a daily publication that records Government actions, the number of Federal officials employed in regulatory agencies and the cost of administering regulations.
 
Debate About Regulations
 There is substantial debate in the country about the need for many of the Federal regulations. Conservatives say the rules should be kept to a minimum unless their benefits exceed their costs and unless Congress has specifically called for their enactment. Consumer and other groups say the competitiveness council is intervening for political reasons into decisions that should be left in the hands of individual agencies.
President Bush has already signed many pieces of legislation that will lead to new regulations, among them the Clean Air Act, the Americans With Disabilities Act and laws on airplane noise, oil spills and food labeling. President Reagan signed relatively few regulatory bills in his eight years in office.
The costs of these regulations can be enormous. For example, the Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the annual cost to the nation of environmental regulations was now $123 billion and was expected to reach $171 billion by the year 2000. The Clean Air Act alone will cost industries at least $25 billion a year. At the end of the Reagan Administration, the cost of environmental regulations was placed at $102 billion.
In part, the council's recent visibility is a response to this trend, which the panel itself addressed at meetings as long ago as last May.
The question asked by conservatives is whether the council is countering the trend or is simply being symbolically used to appeal to the more conservative elements of the Republican Party. The council also gives extra stature to the Vice President's job.
"If you say that the purpose of the council is really to slow the flow of regulations and keep them under control, I think you would have to say it has failed, because the flow of regulations has accelerated markedly," said James C. Miller, who played a crucialrole in the anti-regulatory efforts in the Reagan Administration.
 
'Really Surprises Me'
 Several independent analysts agreed.
"My own view is very much that the Bush Administration is a very heavily regulatory Administration, to an extent that really surprises me," said Robert Poole Jr., the president of the Reason Foundation, a policy research institution in California that favors letting businesses solve social problems. "The institutional capacity for really deregulating just does not seem to be there in the Bush Administration."
President Bush set up the Quayle council to do a job similar to the one he carried out as Vice President, when he headed a Task Force on Regulatory Relief. But at the same time, Mr. Bush, who promoted himself as an environmental President, pressed for enactment of the new Clean Air Act that has directed the Environmental Protection Agency to impose about 55 new regulations costing tens of billions of dollars.
The council's intervention in various rules relating to that act, as well as other areas of health and safety, has led to complaints that it has overstepped its bounds. Its actions are under investigation by seven Congressional committees, controlled by Democrats, that have registered several complaints: that the council is a conduit for business interests; that it lacks authority to make regulations; that its actions, taken behind closed doors, violate laws on open government, and that some of its members have conflicts of interest because of their financial holdings in companies covered by the regulations they have promoted.
 
Some See Broad Effect
 Nobody disputes that the council is changing the course of some major regulations, as when it persuaded the Food and Drug Administration a few weeks ago to issue new proposals reducing the time taken to approve new drugs. And some analysts say that by picking its fights for maximum effect, and winning enough of them to retain credibility, the council has a broad effect on agencies, which become more restrained in their proposals.
"The bottom line is that the Competitiveness Council does an excellent job," said Thorne Auchter, who headed the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in the first Reagan Administration and is now executive director for the Institute for Regulatory Policy, a research organization in Washington.
But other conservative analysts say the council has suffered many defeats along with its victories.
Sometimes the council's limitations, which include its lack of experts in the areas it examines, present problems. The most celebrated case this year involved the council's proposals to redefine wetlands in a way that would open more land to development. The scientific merits of its recommendation have been sharply questioned. And after an outcry by advocates of wetlands preservation, the council's action is now being reconsidered.
At issue in the dispute over the council's actions is the kind of regulation that all sides agree is the most important aspect of Federal policy making, even though the regulatory process normally does not get the public attention that is generated when Congress debates and enacts laws.
"What happens after the passage of legislation is often more important that what happens during enactment," said C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel. "We are engaged now in a lot of knockdown fights over the Clean Air Act, where Congress left discretion to the agency."
 
The Next Verdict
 The next verdict on the council's effectiveness is expected in January, when the Environmental Protection Agency issues new rules for industrial permits limiting pollution.
Last spring, when it reviewed the proposed regulations, the council penciled in about 100 changes. In a battle of legal counsels, environmental agency lawyers are arguing that a council proposal to sharply limit the states' authority to challenge pollution permits would be illegal. The council is seeking a contrary ruling by the Justice Department.
At the same time, the council has demanded a new assessment of the rule's financial effect on industries. The rule, required to take effect in November, has been delayed while this bureaucratic contest is resolved.
In the eyes of its critics, notably Public Citizen, an organization founded by Ralph Nader that has mounted a vigorous campaign against the council, its machinations have been potent indeed. "The Quayle Council has a stranglehold on the regulatory agency rulemaking process," Public Citizen said in a report issued in September.
The report detailed how the council, working closely with the White House Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, reviews major regulations and pressures Federal agencies to soften their economic effect on businesses. But conservatives counter that office on regulatory affairs is far less effective now than it was in the Reagan Administration. It has no politically appointed administrator and relatively little influence, they say.
An article in October in the monthly magazine National Review said that "O.I.R.A.'s influence almost disappeared for two years" under Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. By the time the council stepped in to reinvigorate the office, argued Warren T. Brookes, the columnist who wrote the article, "most of the regulatory horses were out of the barn and running amok."
To some extent, the weakening of the office of regulatory affairs served to concentrate power in the Quayle council, which as one influential Administration official put it, "stepped in to fill the vacuum."
But the weakening of regulatory affairs office, on balance, probably hurts the effort to control regulations more than the increase in the council's visibility helps.
Mr. Miller, a director of the budget office in the Reagan Administration, and before that the head of regulatory affairs office, said in an interview that the record shows that the Bush Administration has relaxed the anti-regulation standards of the Reagan years.
Mr. Miller said he laughed when he read a recent editorial in The New York Times that said the Quayle council was more powerful than Mr. Bush's Task Force on Regulatory Relief.
The council, whose official members are the Treasury Secretary, the Commerce Secretary, the Attorney General, the director of the White House budget office, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers and the White House chief of staff, has just six full-time staff members, plus several influential participants with other White House staff assignments, like Mr. Gray.
The number of people writing regulations in 1992 is now estimated by the Center for the Study of American Business, based at Washington University in St. Louis, to be about 122,000, topping by a few hundred the previous high reached at the end of the Carter Administration.
Melinda Warren, an analyst at the center, said the Environmental Protection Agency's budget for regulatory matters had increased 31 percent in three years and its staff had grown 23 percent.
The council's staff estimates that it has reviewed 50 or 60 major regulations this year, a number that staff members frequently complain has stretched their capacities. And the staff says, the senior members of the council, including the Administration's top economic policy makers, have actually had to decide only two issues: one involving wetlands, and the other involving incineration of wastes at municipal landfills. The rest are worked out in lower-level negotiations.
 
'The Regulatory President'
 The National Journal, a respected weekly magazine published in Washington, went so far in November to label Mr. Bush "The Regulatory President."
"There is no question that the Bush Administration has taken a hatchet to some regulations," wrote Jonathan Rauch in the article. "However, if you look at the forest rather than the trees, the picture changes markedly."
The council "is simply not in a position to seriously evaluate the steady steam of regulations that E.P.A. develops," said Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington.
Council members do meet regularly with agency officials, and memorandums fly back and forth at regulatory deliberations. But because the council is so small, it usually reacts to regulatory proposals mainly after affected parties object to them -- by which time it can be too late.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the White House Council on Competitiveness. (The New York Times) (pg. A14)
 
Chart: "Regulating Competitiveness"
 
Some disputes dealt with by the White House Council on Competitiveness in the past few years.
 
WETLANDS
 
The Council has proposed changing the definition of wetlands, a step that scientists and environmentalists say would remove protection for millions of acres of valuable habitat. After objections to the change were raised, the comment period for the proposal has been extended.
 
CLEAN AIR PERMITS
 
The council proposed more than 100 changes to a proposed rule governing permits for air pollution emissions. One of the changes would sharply limit the rights of the states to challenge the permits. Lawyers from the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Justice Department are still debating the issue.
 
GRAND CANYON AIR QUALITY
 
The Council proposed that emissions from a power plant near the Grand Canyon be cut 70 percent, rather than 90 percent as proposed by the EPA. After agreeing at first, the EPA reversed course, and by changing the methods of controlling and measuring the pollution was able to achieve the 90 percent reduction.
 
WORKER EXPOSURE TO FORMALDEHYDE
 
The Occupational Health and Safety Administration had negotiated with labor and industry a limit on workplace exposure to formaldehyde, which can cause cancer. The Council said that the need for the regulation had not been proved, but OSHA insisted and in the end the limits were adopted.
 
AIRCRAFT NOISE
 
The Federal Aviation Administration tightly controlled access to its rulemaking team by airlines during the development of a regulation phasing out noisy airplanes. Lobbyists for aircraft leasing companies attempted to get the council to obtain changes in the rules that would reduce the costs of the regulations to leasing companies. But the final rule did not contain the changes sought by the companies.
 
DRUG TESTING
 
The council and the Food and Drug Administration have jointly proposed a new system of approving new drugs that would cut the time required and would put some testing in private hands. Many scientists within the agency say they are upset by the proposal. Final action has not been taken.
 
ENERGY REGULATION
 
The council has supported changes that would reduce the powers of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which regulates wholesale electricity sales and natural gas transmission by pipelines. The changes have not been adopted.
 
LAWYERS
 
Vice President Quayle, in a speech to the American Bar Association, proposed sweeping changes to the civil legal system that were developed in part by the council's staff. Lawyer's groups and consumers groups oppose the changes, whose prospects are uncertain.
 
RECYCLING
 
The E.P.A. proposed last year that new municipal waste incinerators remove 25 percent of incoming garbage for recycling before burning the rest. The Office of Management and Budget called this an Rarbitrary rule, and the council agreed. Florida, New York, and the Natural Resources Defense Council have said they would sue the EPA for failing to follow its initial proposal.

HEADLINE: Bush's Campaign Advisers Split With White House on Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
President Bush's new team of campaign aides and his White House budget advisers are split over how the President should handle the politically sensitive economic issue as he prepares to enter the 1992 campaign year, officials said.
Managing the friction between the two sets of advisers has become an early and important test for Samuel K. Skinner, the new White House chief of staff, as he moves to exert a control over policy like that wielded by his predecessor, John H. Sununu. 
 One group of advisers, primarily concerned about the campaign, wants Mr. Bush to come out as soon as possible with the major outlines of his economic growth package to use as a political weapon without getting involved first in negotiations with Congress.
The other group, arguing that it would be fruitless to put forth a policy that Congress will refuse to enact, wants the President to proceed more slowly and to negotiate in private with Democratic lawmakers before making public his own proposals.
This debate, which one official said has produced a "swirl of mini-conspiracies, sideshows and jockeying," has emerged as the White House tries to merge its policy and budget teams with the new campaign apparatus named by Mr. Bush this month.
The President met in the Oval Office with Mr. Skinner and other top domestic policy advisers today and planned another strategy session for Thursday before taking off on a post-Chistmas trip to Texas and a politically perilous visit to Asia.
 
Narrow and Wideer Issues
 At its simplest, the fight is over the narrow issue of how Mr. Bush should handle the few weeks before he delivers his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28. But the debate reflects a larger issue, a growing sense in the Administration and the Bush campaign that by late spring, one of two things must happen: either the economy must rebound or the President must be positioned to make a persuasive case that he tried to make that happen and the Democrats in Congress made it impossible.
In the search for an economic remedy, Mr. Bush is reviewing a range of options, including a small tax rebate, a tax reduction for the middle class, an investment tax credit and incentives for home buyers. The President's effort has been complicated by the uncertainty over how and when the economy will be affected by the lowering of interest rates announced last Friday by the Federal Reserve Board.
Administration officials and Republican strategists said the outcome of the debate over the economic package would do much to set the tone for Mr. Bush's early campaigning next year, and would also reflect the extent to which the White House and the campaign organization were beginning to merge.
Hoping to stop the President's political slide and put him on the offensive, the campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, and others are arguing that Mr. Bush should present his economic proposals soon after returning from Asia on Jan. 10, officials said.
According to this group, which includes Vice President Dan Quayle and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, the President would then begin an all-out campaign to promote his ideas before the State of the Union Message, and largely forgo protracted negotiations with Congressional Democrats.
These advisers believe Mr. Bush's current political problems can largely be traced to the bruising 1990 budget negotiations in which the President abandoned his "no new taxes" pledge to win an agreement limiting Government spending.
On the other side of the debate are Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, who is maneuvering to reassert his authority under Mr. Skinner, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Both Mr. Darman and Mr. Brady are urging Mr. Bush to stick to an earlier planned schedule and unveil his proposals in the State of the Union Message, officials said.
 
Quiet Talks Favored
 Arguing that Mr. Bush must try to reach some accommodation with Congress for any of his ideas to stand a chance of passage, Mr. Brady and Mr. Darman have counseled the President to engage in quiet discussions with Congressional leaders in the coming weeks and not take the political offensive against the Democrats, officials said.
"It's becoming increasingly obvious to everyone that the budget deal is going to have to be broken," one official said today. "The question is, do we do that by renegotiating it with Congress and going for another bipartisan arrangement, or do we come out in a more aggressive campaign stance, make our proposals and take them right to the country?"
Some Administration officials see January as a month that is, as one put it, "fraught with political peril."
"In the effort to convert the Asia trip into a domestic policy trip, they've added a group of businessmen, half of whom are fervent protectionists and all of whom will be free to criticize the President whenever they want," one official said.
 
A Variety of Activities
 Mr. Bush returns from Asia to a series of Democratic town meetings on health care on Jan. 14, and then the Administration plans an international conference on Soviet aid on Jan. 20.
"We face the prospect of having the news dominated by our foreign trip, their concern about health care, unscripted leaks on the budget, a conference that focuses on how much money we're going to give foreigners, and then a State of the Union with wildly high expectations," said one apprehensive official.
The economic proposals have been the subject of a series of Cabinet meetings and smaller strategy sessions in the Oval Office publicized by the White House as evidence that Mr. Bush is engaged on domestic issues. Administration aides have also been meeting on their own, officials said.
Mr. Darman has been conferring with Senator Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, and with some Democrats, including Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
On the other side of the debate, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp was the host of a strategy lunch last week attended by Mr. Gingrich; Representative Vin Weber, Republican of Minnesota; Representative Mickey Edwards, Republican of Oklahoma; William Kristol, Mr. Quayle's chief of staff, and two Reagan Administration supply-side economists, Lawrence Kudlow and Steven J. Entin.
The discussion of political tactics comes amid major organizational efforts in the White House and in the campaign.
"Teeter and Skinner are very much aware of the need for a series of initiatives and a fresh-looking policy apparatus throughout the year," one official said. "The way to do that in the White House is primarily by being less budget-dominated and technocratic, which is clearly threatening to Darman. Skinner has made it clear he wants to cut Darman down some, and Darman has sent back the message that he does not intend to be cut down."
Mr. Teeter has been consulting with Mr. Skinner on virtually a daily basis since the former Transportation Secretary took office a week ago, officials said, to discuss campaign strategy, among other things.
"In the short term, we don't want to get humiliated in New Hampshire," an official said. "Then, how we gain some momentum and get voters to feel they are voting for something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard G. Darman, left, the budget director, is urging President Bush to unveil his tax proposals in the State of the Union Message. Robert M. Teeter has been consulting with Samuel K. Skinner, the new chief of staff, about the President's campaign strategy, officials said. (The New York Times) (pg. A13)

HEADLINE: Texas Flood Ruins Homes and Spirits

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Pearl Crawford had only slim hopes for this Christmas to start with. Now she has none.
Ms. Crawford and her four children are among the 133 families who were flooded out of their homes last week in the Rochester Park neighborhood when the rain-swollen Trinity River spilled its banks. 
 "There really weren't many presents anyway, and we just left with the clothes on our backs," said Ms. Crawford, an unemployed single mother who relies on welfare to support her family.
"Whatever the Lord has in store for us, we'll be living with," said Ms. Crawford, "I do hope we'll be blessed with something more than we've had."
 
13 People Reported Killed
 The Associated Press reported today that 13 people had died as a result of flooding that was scattered across much of North and Central Texas. The search continued for four people still missing after being swept away by floodwaters.
After touring hard-hit areas in Bastrop County, Gov. Ann Richards said today that she was preparing a request for Federal disaster relief money. Governor Richards used a helicopter to tour the county, just east of Austin, where county officials estimated that $12 million to $15 million dollars of damage had been done to agricultural and residential property.
Here in Dallas, Rochester Park, a predominantly black neighborhood of the poor and working poor southeast of downtown, suffered substantial property damage though no one died.
This morning Ms. Crawford sat with dozens of her neighbors in a hallway of a Y.M.C.A. building that had been converted into a disaster relief center. They were calculating the toll both in damaged property and damaged lives.
 
40 Families Sent to Hotels
 In a room that normally serves as a day-care center, caseworkers from the American Red Cross interviewed flood victims to determine what emergency help they required. So far, 40 families have been sent to hotels while the rest have found shelter with friends or relatives.
On the walls of the day-care center, paper snowflakes and candy canes cut out and colored by children served as a reminder of what is supposed to be a joyous season. Down the hallway, families picked over a pile of donated clothes.
For many of those at the Y.M.C.A. today, flooding has become an uncomfortably familiar ritual.
"I'm 72 years old," Alice Sanders said, "and I don't need to be doing this.
"I've lived around here since 1955, and we had a couple of little ones along the way, but this is the third time in two years that we've gotten real wet."
 
Record Crests at River
 Rochester Park sits alongside the Trinity River, which passes through much of the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area before it reaches this neighborhood of small bungalows, sprawling brick houses and public housing apartments.
In the last 20 years, Dallas-Fort Worth has had one of the fastest growing populations in the country, and as suburbs have stretched far out into what used to be countryside, the Trinity has been dammed and levied in so many places that it is now practically a man-made waterway, an urban river.
Forced to absorb ever-greater runoff as new areas have been paved, the Trinity reached record crests in the spring of both 1989 and 1990. The current flooding is modest in comparison, taking the river to a crest of 44.8 feet compared to the record of 47.1 feet set in 1990. The water has been receding since Sunday morning.
One of the relatively few places in the metropolitan area where the river runs untamed is Rochester Park. After the spring 1989 flood, the Dallas City Council voted to build a levee through Rochester Park and in November of that year a $8.5 million bond issue was approved for its construction. City officials have repeatedly told Rochester Park residents that when the levee is completed late next year or at the beginning of 1993 floods should be a thing of the past.
 
Promises of Drier Future
 But promises of a drier future had little weight today at the Y.M.C.A.
"It seems they are just using our neighborhood to store their water," said Cynthia Fowler, 67. "They have so many flood gates and dams and stuff everywhere you'd think they could manage it better."
Rochester Park was one of only a few neighborhoods in the Dallas-Fort Worth area to experience flooding last weekend. But minor flooding has become so common in Rochester Park that warnings went unheeded this time.
Ms. Crawford acknowledged today that the police had circulated through her neighborhood on Saturday, telling residents to make evacuation plans, and, then later, alerting them that flooding was imminent.
"We just kept an eye on it but didn't do much until it got to be nighttime," Ms. Crawford said.
As the water raced toward her two-story public housing apartment, she took a television set and a few valued possessions to the upper floor.
"The police were saying that we should be out at midnight, and people were starting to leave, so about 10:30 we decided we'd better go," she said. "I haven't been back since.".
Her four children, ages 7 to 17, are staying with a sister of Ms. Crawford's, and Ms. Crawford has been at her mother's house.
For Christmas, Ms. Crawford said, her only hopes were "that we can just be together for the day."

HEADLINE: Bush Spikes Holiday Speech With Politics

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
In a new sign of his concern about his re-election campaign, President Bush today issued a politically redrafted Christmas message that sounded more like a campaign speech than the customary holiday greeting from the White House.
"Just last week, I signed a transportation bill that will put hundreds of Americans back in good jobs," said Mr. Bush, who has been trying to persuade voters that he cares about their problems and is not just interested in foreign affairs. 
 The message, which is offered to radio and television stations for broadcast, was originally written by Anthony Snow, one of Mr. Bush's speechwriters, as an inspirational text using previous messages as a pattern, officials said.
But late last week, one official said, "word came down" that the message was to be reworked by Samuel K. Skinner, Mr. Bush's new chief of staff, and Robert M. Teeter, his campaign manager, to give it more political heft.
The message did contain words of inspiration for the holiday season. "Each day we can light the darkness by helping someone in need, working to see that no elderly person goes to bed hungry, that no homeless person spends another night shivering on the streets, that no child sits alone, unloved, unknown," Mr. Bush said.
He added, "Americans have the talent and power to do anything, and so when history remembers Christmas 1991, let it remember that we promise to bring God's light to our brothers and sisters in need."
But a large portion of the 600-word message was devoted to political themes as Mr. Bush extolled his record in foreign affairs and defended his performance on domestic issues.
"It was about one year ago in the interest of world peace that I decided Saddam Hussein's aggression would not stand, even if force had to be used," he said. "We tried diplomacy and economic embargoes, and then we moved against the brutal dictator and liberated Kuwait. When our troops returned home, we felt whole, proud of their courage, confident in ourselves."
At another point, Mr. Bush said: "This year, we unleashed a revolution in education. And I can tell you, by the end of this decade we will have the world's best schools, and our children will lead the next generation to a better future. And next week, I'll travel to Asia to fight for open markets and more opportunities for American workers, because exports abroad mean more jobs right here at home. Let there be no mistake. My No. 1 priority is jobs and economic growth, and I'm confident that we will succeed."

Economists can go cross-eyed studying dry statistics like housing starts, industrial production and the money supply in their obsessive search for telling signs on the economy. But next year they might want to consider a different indicator: the demand for Christmas trees is noticeably lower this year. B5.

MAXWELL QUITS THE DAILY NEWS
Kevin Maxwell resigned as publisher and chairman of The Daily News, apparently bowing to the pressures created by the evidence of his role in the collapse of the media empire founded by his father, Robert Maxwell. His resignation signals the end of the Maxwell family's nine-month involvement in The News. A1.
 
CITY JAILS CHIEF RESIGNS
The head of New York City's jail system, Allyn R. Sielaff, resigned hours after his department was rebuked for its handling of a $1.9 million contract awarded to a firm that had been represented in negotiations by a close friend of Mayor David N. Dinkins. His resignation ends a 20-month tenure that began with high praise for his innovation. But after a prison riot that state officials said he mishandled, his management policies came under steady criticism. A1.

HEADLINE: How Bad Is It? Well, Just Count the Trees.

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Regional economists can go cross-eyed studying dry statistics like housing starts, industrial production and the money supply in their relentless search for telling signs on the economy. But next year they might want to consider a different indicator: the demand for Christmas trees, those most sacred of objects, is noticeably lower this year, signaling a truly Scrooge-like existence for many families.
An informal survey of tree sellers in the New York region found that sales are off 20 to 50 percent compared with last year. And prices have had to be kept as low as last year's, or in some cases lower, to insure that even that poor sales record is met. 
 "I'll bet it's a good indicator," said the economist Edward S. Hyman, president of the International Strategy and Investment Group in New York, who once used wrapping-paper sales in his analyses..
Business is "slow, very slow," said Christopher McKay, who manages the McKay Farmstand in Aquebogue, L.I. At this time last year, Mr. McKay said, he had only a few trees left. This year, even though he ordered about 150 fewer trees, he still has about 100 left -- and he has already resorted to cutting his prices in half.
Mr. McKay's situation is not unique. Several grocers along upper Broadway said that although they had ordered a third fewer trees than last year, they still faced losing money on the 10 to 20 percent of their inventories that they expected to have left over after Christmas. And they even tried to spur sales by being more accommodating than usual with deliveries. Signs in front of the Good Nature store on Broadway and 98th Street advertised trees for $15, or $5 less than the store paid for them.
 
Counting on Last-Minute Rush
 The weak economy seems to be the cause of consumer reticence and increased haggling. "A lot of people say 'recession, recession,' and expect prices to be cut in half," said Artie Bridges, who sells trees from Canada on a vacant lot at First Avenue and 84th Street in Manhattan. This year, he said, a tree that was selling for $40 would have gone for $50 last year. Prices in the region vary widely depending where trees are sold and their type and height.
Believing that customers might be tempted in these hard times by smaller, cheaper trees, Mr. Bridges stocked up on some in the four-foot range. But he found that many customers simply expected the big trees to cost less. And that annoys him, he said, because people would not think of walking into a Mercedes showroom and demanding Chevy prices just because the economy was bad.
Now, with sales down about 20 percent, he is hoping for a Christmas Eve rush to get rid of his last 100 or so trees.
The recession blues have not hit every tree seller so hard. Tree farms, where customers can choose and cut their own trees, particularly in Connecticut and the Hudson River valley, seem to be faring much better than street-corner stands.
At Silverman's Farm in Easton, Conn., for instance, sales are up about 35 percent this year, Bob Sabia, the manager, said. His trees are selling for $30 apiece. And Fred Battenfeld, in Red Hook in Dutchess County, said he had sold as many trees as he wanted to at $30 apiece, or $2 more than last year.
 
Price Is Bottom Line
 Michael Pochan, secretary of the Connecticut Christmas Tree Growers Association, said his informal survey of the largest growers in the state indicated that sales would be higher than in previous years. His theory is that people want "something living, something to cheer them up."
But in Manhattan, price seems to count for more than a tree's soothing qualities. The Plant Shed, on West 96th Street, has been selling trees that are six feet and under for $29.99 since the season started, and on Sunday it extended that offer to trees of all sizes. Of the 1,000 trees the store ordered from its Pennsylvania wholesaler this year, it has sold 940, or about 300 more than last year.
Jay Casiano, the store manager, attributed his success to rock-bottom prices and good service.
"We're trying to fight the recession," Mr. Casiano said. "Everybody is in a bad mood. Everybody wants to shoot Bush." He hopes his Christmas tree sales will help take the edge off other parts of his business, like phone orders for flowers, which are down 30 to 40 percent from previous years.
But for some tree sellers, nothing seems to be working. One tree farmer in Connecticut says he has sold only 300 trees this year, compared with 1,000 last year. Part of his problem is that new tree farms have opened up in the area. But he also blames the economy.
"This was by far the worst year I can remember," said Louis Wasserman, the owner of Medridge Tree Farm in Sandy Hook, Conn., who has been in the business for a decade. "You want a tree farm?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: "A lot of people say 'recession, recession,' and expect prices to be cut in half," said Artie Bridges, in cap at center, who sells Christmas trees from Canada on a vacant lot at First Avenue and 84th Street in Manhattan. He has had to reduce prices this year to keep sales from falling too sharply. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Case of Holiday Jitters On Electronics Stores

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
In the week before Christmas, Wall Street grew afraid that stereos and television sets and videocassette recorders did not cost enough.
That fear, brought on by reports of poor profit margins caused by price-cutting, has sent some formerly hot growth stocks into something approaching free fall, despite a general stock market increase brought on by lower interest rates. 
 "Everybody is suddenly getting the willies about the consumer electronics industry," Philip Muldoon, an analyst for the Ohio Company, said yesterday as the share price of Sun Television and Electronics, a chain based in Columbus, fell as low as $10, before rallying to close at $13, still down $1.375 for the day.
Sun, as it happens, has not released any bad news about Christmas, and Mr. Muldoon said the company continued to assure him that all was going well. But other companies have put out bad news, and yesterday investors were not in a mood to wait and see.
The selloff of the consumer retailers started on Thursday, when the Best Buy Company, a Minneapolis-based chain of consumer electronics stores, reported sharply higher earnings, just as bulls had expected, for the quarter ended Nov. 30. The catch came near the end of its news release: "December comparable-store sales are currently running below the prior year. An increased promotional environment has intensified pressure on gross profit margins. Both of these trends are reflective of the weakening economic environment and will likely impact earnings in the fourth quarter."
In other words, Best Buy said it was being forced to cut prices on its products, and that would hurt profits. The Wall Street reaction was swift. Best Buy fell $7.25, to $14, that day, a level that has held. At yesterday's closing price of $13.875, the shares are down 61 percent from a high of $35.375, reached Nov. 14.
When Best Buy crumbled, Good Guys began to shake, with its shares falling $4.50 over the final two sessions of last week, to $19. Good Guys Inc., based in San Francisco, had been a Wall Street star, based on rapid growth. "In the three years through Sept. 30, its sales were up at a compound annual rate of 142 percent a year, and its earnings per share rose at a 136 percent rate," said Donald Trott, an analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds. On Friday, he recommended selling the stock, pointing to the pressures of price competition.
 
California Worries
 After markets closed on Friday, Good Guys put out its own bad news. Sales were higher, and the expansion into Southern California was going well, said Robert A. Gunst, the company's president. "We have, however, had to be more aggressive in our promotional sales during this Christmas season than had been expected," he added. That put pressure on profit margins, and meant that earnings per share for the current quarter would be below those of a year ago, he said.
A negative article in Barron's over the weekend, forecasting that Good Guys would be damaged by California's deteriorating economy, added to the pressure, and yesterday the stock traded as low as $13.75, before closing at $14.75, off $4.25 for the day.
The collapse of Good Guys in only a couple of weeks -- it closed Dec. 6 at $27 -- is a measure of the revenge Wall Street can take. "It's a broken growth stock," Mr. Trott said. "When you break the earnings momentum, you get a compounding on the downside."
Good Guys had reported profits for the most recent fiscal year of $11 million, or 93 cents a share. At its peak price of $30, in September, it was trading at 32 times those earnings, and even now it is trading at a 16 multiple, a figure that assumes some growth.
At the heart of the problem for Good Guys is aggressive discounting by Circuit City Stores Inc., the largest company in the industry. Its shares have fallen $2.125, to $21.50, since the bad news hit Best Buy. Mr. Trott says the loss was relatively mild because Circuit City had not been viewed as a high-flying growth stock.
The high-flying nature of most of the stocks, at least before the past week, serves as testimony to the willingness of Wall Street to believe high-growth stories, even in industries known to be littered with problems. Much of the growth for the companies has been brought on by competitors' going out of business, but the possibility that such problems might spread seems to have been brushed aside by many investors. The executives of Best Buy and Good Guys were not so believing, however. A number of executives sold shares in November, at prices ranging from $22.375 to $25.25 at Good Guys and from $31.94 to $34.25 at Best Buy.
Even after the recent falls, these stocks rank as big winners for the year, with Best Buy up 147 percent, Good Guys showing a gain of 66 percent and Circuit City up 69 percent. Sun Television went public at $10 a share in July, and buyers at that offering now have a 30 percent gain.

HEADLINE: OPEC Divided on Meeting To Address Weak Oil Prices

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALGIERS, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Oil prices have plunged deeply since OPEC last met at the end of November, bringing tension within the cartel to a crucial stage.
With prices now down $5 a barrel since then, to around $17 a barrel, Algeria called today for an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Itwarned that if the group did not trim its production by at least two million barrels a day soon, prices could tumble further, to $10 a barrel, under the combined impact of worsening recession in the United States and other industrialized countries and the organization's runaway production. 
 But so far Saudi Arabia, by far OPEC's largest producer, has opposed an emergency meeting and resisted appeals to reduce its enormous production of 8.5 million barrels a day, or 35 percent of OPEC's output, arguing that the unexpected oil price plunge resulted from the actions of market speculators.
Today the Nicosia-based oil newsletter, the Middle East Economic Survey, quoted senior Saudi officials as having given a negative reply to an inquiry about an emergency OPEC meeting by the group'ss president, Jibril Amino, the oil minister of Nigeria, who polled the group's 13 members.
Speaking in an interview here today, Algeria's energy minister, Nordine Ait Laoussine, said, "We think the organization should move immediately to cut its production by at least 10 percent -- otherwise we will face an even greater collapse, which none of us can afford."
Nigeria, Iran and Libya have also expressed alarm over the impact of the fall in their anticipated revenues because of the oil price decline. Analysts and industry officials fear that unless action is taken to trim production, currently 24 million barrels a day, prices may touch record lows in the spring, particularly because earlier expectations of a quick end to recession and strong winter demand for oil have failed to materialize.
"Market speculation can move prices by $1 a barrel one way or the other, but a fall of $5 a barrel over a few weeks indicates a much more structural problem," Mr. Ait Laoussine said.
The price of North Sea Brent crude, a benchmark for oil prices, has fallen from $22.50 a barrel in early November, before OPEC met in Vienna, to $17.40 a barrel just before last weekend. The OPEC average oil price has fallen too, from close to $21 a barrel to around $16 a barrel.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange light, sweet crude oil has fallen from about $23 a barrel in early November to as low as $18.30 in trading today.
"Such a fall in price was supposed to happen in the spring, not now," said Peter Gignoux, chief oil trader in London for Shearson Lehman Hutton. "For this time of year, $17 a barrel is a very low price."
 
Not Viewed as Critical
 Saudi Arabia continues to maintain that while it is not in favor of very low oil prices, it does not see the present situation as critical.
A majority of oil experts and industry executives, however, maintain that the price drop is highly unusual, because winter demand normally lifts oil prices. They also say that the depth of the recession has combined with a steady rise in production to depress prices.
"This goes against all the rosy predictions of higher prices by OPEC during its November meeting," John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, said in a telephone interview. "It is a big and surprising fall in oil prices. By any standards, this is dramatic."
But Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates, which significantly increased their output after the Persian Gulf crisis, have been reluctant to consider a rollback in output or an emergency OPEC meeting, which by itself could raise prices.
Some political analysts say their reluctance carries political dimensions; that it may reflect the desire of some producers not to take measures that would help oil producers that were viewed as having sympathized with Iraq during the gulf crisis, like Algeria and Libya.
But Mr. Ait Laoussine of Algeria cites facts in arguing for a price increase: "We are far below the OPEC price target of $21 a barrel," he said. "There are indications that the recession in industrialized countries like the United States, Western Europe and even in Japan is going to get worse. It is clear that certain OPEC countries have been too optimistic in their forecasts."
He also noted that the oil production and exports of the former Soviet Union's various republics had steadied despite the political chaos there. He also noted that there is a chance that Iraq may resume exporting oil in the next quarter, further adding to the oversupply of the market. Iraq will meet with United Nations representatives in early January to consider ending the embargo on its oil exports imposed in August 1990, after it invaded Kuwait.
Moreoever, Mr. Gignoux of Shearson Lehman Hutton said, the United States, whose oil output has dropped to 7.5 million barrels a day, is "drowning in oil inventories."
None of these facts coincide with OPEC's calculations of just a few weeks ago, which counted heavily on continued shortages of oil to justify the fact that the group was pumping oil at maximum capacity.
OPEC's economic experts expected that oil demand would drop by early February and had scheduled a meeting for the group's Market Monitoring Committee on Feb. 12 in Geneva to take stock of the situation.
But events seem to have overtaken these assumptions. Experts now say if OPEC does not act earlier, it risks seeing oil prices closer to $10 a barrel by February, which would bring prices to the lowest level since they crashed in 1986 to between $8 and $10 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Prices Advance Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The rally in the fixed-income markets continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose and interest rates fell.
Traders said that business was brisk during the morning and that the market's mood was not clouded by a report that personal-consumption spending had risen by seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, a much bigger increase than had been expected. 
 Economists said the size of the gain was skewed by cold weather, which drove up spending on utilities. Excluding that category, spending was up a more modest four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
More Signs of Weakness
 "The rise in consumption was almost entirely due to increases in purchases of nondiscretionary services," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "And the personal income numbers were absolutely ugly."
The Commerce Department also reported that personal income fell by a tenth of 1 percent in November.
In addition to those signs of economic weakness, Mr. Liro and other analysts said that the final results of the University of Michigan's consumer confidence survey for December had showed that consumer attitudes slumped further from levels recorded in November.
The overall decline was somewhat startling, Mr. Liro said, because a reading taken at midmonth showed that consumers were feeling a bit better than they had in November.
 
Bonds and Notes Higher
 The reports, coupled with the aftermath of the Federal Reserve's significant cuts on Friday in the overnight Federal funds rate and the discount rate, helped to push prices higher, particularly for longer-term notes and bonds.
"People are searching for yield," one government bond trader said. "The Fed's move finally woke people up to the magnitude of the weakness that we have and to the fact that inflation probably won't be a threat for the next year to 18 months."
Market participants said the sharp rise in stock prices helped to accelerate the move into higher-yielding bonds and notes.
The sharp fall in short-term rates last week was reflected in the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.75 percent, down sharply from the average rate of 4.14 percent at last week's sale. It was the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the auction on May 15, 1972, when the rate was 3.699 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 3.85 percent, compared with an average rate of 4.19 percent at the auction a week ago.
The six-month bill rate was the lowest since the rate averaged 3.796 percent on March 6, 1972.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10522/32 , up 3/4 point to yield 7.51 percent, compared with 7.57 percent late on Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 10417/32 , up 21/32 , to yield 6.86 percent. And the new 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 10011/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 4.81 percent.
 
Holiday Schedule
 Yesterday the Public Securities Association, a trade group, said it had recommended that trading in a number of fixed-income securities, including government securities, mortgage-backed securities and bankers' acceptances, conclude at 1 P.M. today in observance of Christmas Eve. Financial markets will be closed tomorrow, Christmas Day.
The association also said that it had recommended that trading should conclude by 2 P.M. on Dec. 31, New Year's Eve.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very slow, according to dealers.
Prices of most corporate bonds rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point. Prices of the most widely quoted municipal bonds improved by about 3/8 point in thin trading.

HEADLINE: Trade Plan Criticized, Stalling World Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
A last-ditch effort to conclude five years of contentious world trade talks successfully hit two serious snags today, as the European Community declared a compromise proposal to be unacceptable, and American industries offered little support.
The European Community's trade ministers strongly criticized a compromise trade agreement proposed on Friday by Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 "Insofar as the Dunkel paper calls into question the foundation of the community's agricultural policy, the paper is not acceptable and therefore has to be modified," the ministers said in a statement issued in Brussels, The Associated Press reported.
The trade ministers' action was especially significant because they have historically been more committed to free trade than European agriculture ministers, who also play an important role in forming the community's food-trade policies.
 
Swift U.S. Criticism
 The possible compromise on a 108-nation trade agreement also drew criticism from American industries that would be hurt like sugar beet farmers and steel producers. Industries that would benefit gave it scant support mixed with raw hostility.
The entertainment industry, for example, is complaining that it did not get enough.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat and staunch supporter of free trade on the House Subcommittee on Trade, said Congress could refuse to approve such a deal because it lacks corporate support, coupled with a weak economy.
The draft agreement released late on Friday in Geneva "really doesn't mean progress; it just means they've reshuffled the cards," Mr. Matsui said today, adding, "I don't see it going anywhere, and certainly none of our industries can be particularly cheered by this."
 
Film Industry's Concerns
 Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America and a lobbyist important to the approval of any deal involving copyrights and royalties, said that he would oppose the proposed pact in Congress unless it was changed.
He said that Mr. Dunkel's proposal, while allowing film copyrights to stay in force longer than some American trade partners had sought, was inadequate because it would take years to go into force, would not protect corporate ownership rights to movies and would condone foreign quotas that limit the broadcasting of television shows.
Representative Sam M. Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Trade, and Representative Don J. Pease, an Ohio Democrat also on the committee, both said in interviews last week that enthusiastic support from the entertainment industry would be needed for a deal to move through Congress.
The United States has an annual trade surplus of $3.5 billion in film, television and home video, Mr. Valenti said.
But most large corporate lobbying groups declined to give an immediate reaction today, saying they needed to read the lengthy legal text.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told a small group of business leaders today that Mr. Dunkel's proposal was closer to the American position on the crucial issue of agriculture subsidies than to the European Community's position, an executive who attended the meeting said. He insisted on anonymity.
The GATT talks, which began in Uruguay, foundered last year on the subsidies issue, and there is general agreement that a continued impasse could defeat the agreement because farm groups on either side of the Atlantic could block ratification.
 
Farm Groups Speak Out
 The American Farm Bureau Federation said today that the proposed pact would only partly meet its goals of substantially cutting the use of export subsidies and obtaining a significant opening of foreign markets. Steven A. McCoy, the president of the North American Export Grain Association, said that as the likelihood of a major breakthrough on agriculture faded, support from farm groups was waning.
But he and most other trade specialists, both in favor of and opposed to the proposed agreement, cautioned that it was much too early to declare the world's trade talks dead.
"People are shell-shocked, the process is going through a second round of deadlines, and there's almost a Never-Never-Land attitude, where people aren't sure whether they're looking at a final deal or the beginning" of more talks, Mr. McCoy said.
Dire warnings that the world's multilateral trade talks were near collapse have been issued repeatedly, before and after they broke down a year ago in Brussels over Europe's agricultural subsidies.
Even if a GATT agreement does survive, its timetable is now so stretched that it could affect progress on a free-trade agreement with Mexico, the other main negotitating assignment of Mrs. Hills's office. The trade representative said at a news briefing last week that most of the agency's officials had gone to Geneva for the talks there.
Although widely described as comprehensive, Mr. Dunkel's draft does not address the question of opening markets for services like international telephone calls, for which the negotiations will extend into April.
