HEADLINE: Some See Trend in the Low-Key Christmas of '91

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Staggered, or at least left stumbling, by the recession, more and more Americans this holiday season are toting up their financial well-being and are shunning freewheeling consumption. That mood, experts say, is causing a significant shift in American gift-giving that it is likely to color spending practices for Christmases to come.
Talks with about 70 shoppers, merchants and store clerks in Seattle and Columbus, Ohio, found Americans with pocketbooks of all sizes expressing boredom, distaste -- even disgust -- with the spending frenzy of Christmases past. 
 Many said they now favored traditional over trendy, and frugality above all else. Husbands and wives have agreed not to buy each other presents, and many families have placed limits on gifts for aunts, uncles, nephews, nieces, cousins and second cousins to rein in spending.
While store executives and other retailing experts have recognized that such cost consciousness has all but killed this year's holiday sales, they are only now beginning to consider an even more-sobering thought: Even when the good economic times return, the spending sprees may not.
"It seems like the 70's and 80's practice of frivolous, excessive spending at Christmas is out, if not completely over with," said Philip Johnson, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a consumer research company in Chicago. "That kind of spending may never come back."
A national survey Dec. 15 by the company echoed what the Seattle and Columbus interviews disclosed about favoring flannel nighties over fur coats and shopping at outlet centers instead of department stores. Of those polled by Shapiro, 61 percent said they would spend less on Christmas gifts this year. That was the highest level since the Christmas spending polls began 13 years ago.
Mr. Johnson said he believed that the dour outlook would extend beyond this one bad season, because four out of five people surveyed said they felt good about spending less.
"They're not buying, and they're happy about it," Mr. Johnson said. "If it feels good not to spend, why wouldn't they continue this pattern?"
Few retailers totally endorse Mr. Johnson's conclusions. Most of them insist, as Kenneth A. Macke of the Dayton Hudson Corporation did not long ago, that Santa will always come, bringing with him sales and profits.
Still, some are beginning to wonder. Asked whether three disappointing holiday sales seasons in a row indicated a fundamental change in consumer spending patterns, Lasker M. Meyer, vice chairman of Houston-based Specialty Retailers Inc., said: "That's a very good question. I don't have an answer yet. I think probably retailers have higher expectations for Christmas than are reasonable."
Mr. Meyer, long experienced in retailing's ups and downs, described his expectations for Christmas 1992 as conservative.
 
Shopping 'Doesn't Seem Fun'
 Jane Shafer, 28 years old, dropped into a Seattle mall not to buy anything but just to take her three young children, including newborn twins, to see Santa Claus. "Shopping just doesn't seem fun anymore," she said, adding that as her husband's commissions from medical equipment sales have shrunk, so, too, has her holiday shopping list. "I am worried about money because of the new kids," she said.
Backing up their premise that the penurious shopper is here to stay, Mr. Johnson and retail consultants point to the mind-boggling success of retailers like Wal-Mart and the Gap. They have soared by selling basics at low prices, at the expense of department stores and other merchants with high overhead expenses.
"For many Americans, the recession is permanent," Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant, wrote in his latest newsletter. "Consumers have changed their priorities. In light of higher taxes and the uncertainties of employment and world affairs, they have cut back their wants and needs."
All of this is likely to put additional pressure on the nation's retailers, some of whom are struggling to survive and all of whom have long relied on the holiday season for most of their revenues and profits.
Even those who have not been mauled by the economy are trimming the fat in ways that could well endure beyond this Christmas.
 
The Shoppers
Turning Against The Buy, Buy, Buy
 Mary Palmer, a Redmond, Wash., mother of three who makes dolls on the side, is spending about half the amount of money on gifts as she did last year because of a drop in her family's income. Instead of rushing from store to store, Mrs. Palmer is arranging for her family an inexpensive gift but one she considers priceless: time together.
They joined their neighbors in trimming an outdoor Christmas tree. And they are borrowing a cabin belonging to Mrs. Palmer's sister in the Cascade Mountains, where they will ski and sled.
"They're getting our attention this year instead of our money," Mrs. Palmer said of her children. "Ultimately, I believe the kids are going to remember these kinds of things more than any sporting equipment, computer game or sweater I could get them.
"I'm just tired of buying and buying and buying. I always felt letdown on Christmas Eve when I was frantically trying to wrap everything I had bought, and being somewhat financially pinched this year gave me the perfect excuse to get away from all that."
Helen Evenson, a 78-year-old former Boeing employee in Seattle, whose retirement income has shrunk as the interest paid on her savings has declined, is opening savings accounts for many of her 13 grandchildren instead of buying them toys.
Other formerly avid shoppers are saving money by exercising old talents, making presents for members of their extended family or offering to do chores and tasks instead of presenting gifts.
 
Sticking to the Practical
 In Columbus, Cathy Tran bought her 5-year-old son, Gregory, a soft blanket for his bed instead of a new toy that would quickly lose his attention. Although her husband has a lucrative -- and seemingly secure -- job selling computer engineering equipment, the family's 11-year-old daughter, Karen, will probably get an outfit for school from the Limited, and the oldest son, Jeff , will not get a 16-bit video game system costing more than $150, but will receive a new game for the old 8-bit system the family bought a couple of years ago.
"We have enough toys at home," Mrs. Tran said. "We really have enough of just about everything, and I'm not just going to buy, buy, buy because it's Christmas. It's gotten to be too much of a circus."
Mrs. Tran reports that her attitude is rubbing off on some of her children. Pushing a big cart through the wide, strangely deserted aisles at the new Target discount store in northwest Columbus, Mrs. Tran worried about what to get her 8-year-old, Larissa. "We told her we'd get her Roller blades but she said just to wait until she outgrows her rollerskates first," she said. "None of my kids is bombarding me with lists this year."
Larissa is not atypical, according to Chad Rager, a Santa Claus in the Northland Mall in northeastern Columbus. He reported that children's Christmas wishes this year largely reflect the caution they have probably heard their parents express.
"Instead of sitting here and reeling off a list of 10 or 20 presents," he said, " most kids are asking for one or two things."
"I think they appreciate that their folks may be feeling financially tight right now."
 
Generational Worries
 Rhonda and Vernon Granberg, who were shopping in a Seattle mall, said they feel secure about their own finances but worry a little about the fate of their children. Their two sons have jobs and their daughter, who just graduated from college, is looking for one. But the cost of housing in Seattle has kept all three at home.
"It's almost impossible for younger people just starting to make it," said Mr. Granberg, who is in the shipping business. "I think jobs are harder to find, those that are available are minimum wage, housing is unaffordable and the prices of food and clothing keep going up."
Mrs. Granberg said: "Everything is changing, and nobody knows where the changes are taking us. The war we went through this year was something we never thought would happen, but it did. Everybody says Boeing is stable and healthy, but who really knows?"
It has been more than a year since Lora Lonadier's husband, Jay, who is 27, lost his job as the manager at a Lerner's women's clothing store in Columbus. Now, sometimes with help from her father, the couple try to make ends meet on the $11,000 to $12,000 a year Ms. Lonadier earns as a librarian.
 
Homemade, Not Bought
 "I feel like a juggler," Ms. Lonadier, who is 28, said as she carefully filled a container with the leftovers of a chicken-and-broccoli Chinese lunch her father bought for her in the food court of a small shopping strip. "It's just always too close for comfort, and I live in constant fear that one week we're going to come up short."
This Christmas she is fashioning ornaments and refrigerator magnets out of cookie dough and making wall hangings, table runners, placemats and doilies to give as gifts. She will buy gifts only for her nearest and dearest and only on sale in discount or outlet stores, although she has shopped at the Lazarus department store because she has a Lazarus credit card.
Unable to find work in the retail business, Mr. Lonadier has started pursuing a master's degree in education at Ohio State University. With student loans covering the tuition, they can just pay the mortgage on the house they bought shortly before Mr. Lonadier lost his job, and their credit cards help to stretch out payments.
"I just don't see how things are going to get better for them," said Clyde Sullivan, Ms. Lonadier's father, as he watched her carefully save the luncheon leftovers. "'Whenever I'm with Lora, I try to buy her a meal or some groceries or things like that, but it's hard because she's got to have her pride, too."
After paying their monthly bills, Mr. Sullivan and his wife, Marylou, have little discretionary income left over from the Social Security check and the small pension he receives from the university, where he coordinated the stocks of medical supplies for several years. "As soon as the money comes in, it seems to go right back out the door," he said.
Mr. Sullivan and others doubted that the Government and the Bush Administration could find any way to revive the flagging economy. "Every Government official who stands up on TV and says the recession is over ought to be shot," said Molly Hague, a retired church secretary at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.
Her friend Ann Slabaugh said she was angry at Congress for giving itself a pay increase, angry at President Bush and Congress for raising taxes, and angry with the Federal Reserve for lowering interest rates, which has forced her to dip into her savings because the interest she earns is so low. "Even Alan Greenspan admitted that he may have made a mistake," Mrs. Slabaugh said. "I can't afford his mistakes."
 
The Retailers
A Slump in Morale On the Sales Floor
 Tracy Bradham is on the front lines of the war retailers are fighting this holiday season. She is the first face customers see when they walk into the J. C. Penney store in Westland Mall in Columbus. As an Ultima II cosmetics sales associate she probably has more contact with potential customers than anyone else in the store because, she says, many shoppers just take a few steps inside and decide to leave.
She also hears more and more complaints. "I saw this for $3 or $4 less at Pay 'N Save," said one woman, waving an $18 Christmas decoration in Miss Bradham's face before setting it back on the shelf and walking out of the store.
Miss Bradham, 20, who works for Revlon, Ultima II's parent company, and not Penney, has heard it all before. "Everybody's looking for a bargain this Christmas," she said. "They come in here to get ideas, and then they go buy the things somewhere else for cheaper. They like to point it out, too. It must make them feel better."
 
Promoting a Bargain
 In this environment, making a sale takes a lot of Miss Bradham's ingenuity. Spotting a potential shopper lingering near pallets of eyeshadows, blushes and lipsticks that comprise Ultima II's 1991 holiday promotion, Miss Bradham moved in for a sale. She explained that the five lipsticks in the box would cost a total of about $55 if purchased separately, but the customer could get them plus other cosmetics in a set valued at $300 for a mere $25 if the customer spent $12.50 on other Ultima II products.
Miss Bradham's ploy is to suggest a purchase of mascara -- the one item that is not in the promotion and costs $12 plus tax. "If everybody's out looking for a deal this year and I've got a deal to sell, they're not going to know about unless I tell them," she said.
This apparently is not an attitude shared by many of her colleagues. Miss Bradham was the only person to pitch a sale to a browser who walked through more than two dozen specialty stores and six department stores in three malls one recent day.
Younkers, the Midwestern department store chain based in Des Moines, has spent two years developing a program to train its sales associates to sell harder. Perhaps not coincidentally, Younkers is one of the few retailers this holiday season reporting gains that outpace the rate of inflation.
Thomas Gould, the president of Younkers, attributes his stores' relative success to a strategy of selling more to its customers. "It's not that we have more customers, in fact, we probably have fewer," Mr. Gould said. "We just make sure we're selling more to those customers who are coming in."
 
Lacking the Selling Instinct
 But most of his competitors pay only lip service to such a notion. Retail service has long been a source of complaints, but this year's cranky consumers seem to have especially suppressed the selling instincts of most store clerks, who idle away their hours chatting with each other, rearranging merchandise, lurking around the cash registers and generally doing anything to avoid shoppers.
"I stood in the middle of one department at Marshall Field's for almost 15 minutes, wondering where everybody had gone," said Gladys Patterson, a 73-year-old shopper in Columbus. "Finally I just gave up."
Consumers said they were frustrated, too, by the shallow selections in most stores. Retailers have ordered carefully this season to avoid having too much merchandise left over, and some shoppers are finding that stores are sold out of the gifts they would like to buy.
Dora Ashworth, a 54-year-old retired machinist in Seattle, gave up on finding a red angora sweater for her daughter. She did find one at Nordstrom in Northgate Mall. But it cost $299, and she did not want to spend more than than $100. "They don't have what you want, and if they do, they want an arm and a leg for it," Mrs. Ashworth said.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Closing Up Shop on a Time Gone By

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J.

 BODY:
YOU might say Al Samaha was born with retailing in his blood. His father was a traveling candy salesman. His mother had a women's apparel store here. Even his birth in 1928 occurred in the store's stockroom, which doubled as the family's apartment.
But an awful lot has changed during the depersonalization of American retailing -- the malling of America, the chain-storing of every commercial corner, the decline of downtowns, the rise of mail order, and the eruption of superstores called marts with vast staffs of ill-informed salesclerks on perpetual break. Not to mention the natural aging of the owners of those Ma and Pa stores. And the disinterest of their children in working six days a week. All of which explains the presence of the man in the black suit. 
 "Do I look like a mortician?" says Stephen G. Mazur, who is, in a way. He puts little businesses like Mr. Samaha's to sleep.
The personable Mr. Mazur is hired for his considerable merchandising expertise to oversee two-month Quitting Business sales, minimizing the owners' leftovers and maximizing their profits while gently guiding these typically old-time operations into commercial oblivion. Such a sale is not big news because, beyond the owner's family, it obviously doesn't affect our lives any.
Business is great for Quitting Business sales these days, what with the recession, corporate downsizing and a general fear of the future inhibiting investments. In recent times, Mr. Mazur has driven his Lincoln Town Car from a drugstore in Westport, Conn., to a lumberyard in Kentucky to a stationery store in Plainfield, N.J., to a music store in Alton, Ill., to a party-goods store in Fords, N.J.
In October, he arrived at Mr. Samaha's Dainty Apparel Store here on Cookman Avenue, where boarded-up windows have outnumbered thriving businesses ever since what the local newspaper calls "the 1970 racial unpleasantness."
"I'm burned out," said the 63-year-old Mr. Samaha, who planned a career in chemistry until his mother sought his temporary help 47 years ago. "I want time to rest."
Through G. A. Wright Inc., a promotional clearing house in Denver with some 200 subcontractors like Mr. Mazur, Mr. Samaha subscribed to a detailed, carefully timed strategy of closing his store, involving a sudden sale, escalating discounts, special red signs and an incredibly complex contest for $2,000 in prizes. With points awarded for regular purchases, extra points awarded for extra purchases on special days and bonus points for stopping by, contestants can amass millions of points.
"I never thought my customers would go for such a thing," said Mr. Samaha. "But they're flooding in."
Mr. Samaha had a mailing list of 3,000 faithful customers, inscribed over the years in two tattered notebooks coded for the tastes of each woman, many of whom still favor white gloves for an afternoon's outing. When Dainty Apparel received a new shipment, the clerks would phone their clients with word of a particular new outfit. Knowing such preferences, clerks also advised forgetful husbands on last-minute gifts. This was called personal service.
Mr. Mazur arrived with his own mailing list of 19,000 area residents. The computer had already discarded men-only and low-income addresses. Had Mr. Mazur been closing a hardware store, the computer would have dropped all female-only households and apartment dwellers, where do-it-yourselfers do not abound.
"My job," said Mr. Mazur, "is to maintain traffic." He juggles discounts, new mailings and ads and strenuously promotes contest competition. It is a demanding, sometimes emotional regimen of 16-hour days and late-night deli salads downed in motel rooms while hand-addressing next week's mailing. Mr. Mazur, who is understandably single, visits his Chicago home so infrequently that bees have built a huge hive in his laundry-room vent.
He is also a counselor. "When they finally decide to close," he says, "owners don't really realize what they're getting into, or out of. For them, it's the end of a family's way of life. I've seen so many. I work hard trying to move every item. But much of my time is spent as a sympathetic ear, preparing the owner for that last afternoon in an empty store when there's nothing left of these years but dustballs."
Saturday was Dainty Apparel's last afternoon. The staff of four shed some tears. Emma Vitale's 109.7 million bonus points won the grand prize of a color television. Some leftover bridal gowns went to charity. And another storefront was boarded up.
This morning Mr. Mazur checked out of his motel for the first time since Oct. 10 and aimed his car back toward Chicago. January is looking very good, Denver reports.
In a week or so, Mr. Mazur will be back on the road to the next Quitting Business sale that is not big news because, beyond the owner's family, it obviously doesn't affect our lives any.

Mazur, right, helps Al Samaha, Dainty Apparel store owner, in a going-out-of-business sale. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Eased Rule For Loans

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
In an attempt to encourage more lending, the four Federal agencies that regulate banks and savings and loans are preparing new rules that would make it cheaper for institutions to make home-construction loans.
The Office of Thrift Supervision, which supervises the nation's savings associations, was the first of the four agencies to announce today that it would cut in half the amount of money that savings and loans must put aside as a cushion against possible losses from low-risk residential construction loans. 
 The Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of Currency are expected to issue similar proposals soon for the banks that they regulate.
 
Easing 'Credit Crunch'
 The move by the four agencies, which has been coordinated by the the Treasury Department, is the latest move in the Bush Administration's broader effort to ease what it sees as a "credit crunch" that has inhibited an economic recovery.
Under the Treasury's guidance, the agencies have put pressure on their examiners to ease lending guidelines for banks and savings associations and have issued new guidelines intended to give institutions more latitude in making loans.
The examiners have come under criticism from President Bush and the Secretaries of Commerce and Treasury as a leading cause of tight credit by applying loan guidelines too strictly.
 
Capital Requirement Halved
 Banks and savings associations must now put aside $8 as capital for every $100 in home-construction loans. But when the new rule is given final approval, expected in the spring, it will permit banks to set aside $4 for every $100 in home construction loans in which an owner has already put up at least 5 percent in earnest money for the home. The 5 percent is intended to reduce the riskiness of the loan.
"It may significantly modify what's available to homeowners," said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. "There is a lack of available credit for new-home construction."
Mr. Ryan has taken a leading position among regulators in responding to the tightening of credit by lenders and is widely speculated to be among the Administration's top choices as the new head of the Office of Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates many of the nation's banks.
Robert L. Clarke, the Acting Comptroller, was denied a second term by the Senate Banking Committee last month. He is expected to step down in February.
Administration officials said they had also been considering a plan that would encourage more lending and shore up banks' balance sheets by lowering the costs of purchase-mortgage-servicing rights, which are finding their way into the portfolios of banks that buy failed savings institutions.
Such rights are contracts bought or held by banks and savings associations under which institutions manage a portfolio of mortgages -- processing the monthly payments, distributing the proceeds among investors and handling foreclosures.
The Comptroller of the Currency, the regulator ofnationally chartered banks, now permits up to 25 percent of such contracts to constitute capital. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of Thrift Supervision allow up to 50 percent.
An interagency task force has been considering a plan that would move the level of the Comptroller of the Currency to 50 percent, which would be helpful to some of the nation's largest commercial banks, including Citicorp, the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and the Norwest Corporation, all of which have large portfolios of purchase-mortgage-servicing rights.
In another move aimed at reducing the costs at savings associations, the Office of Thrift Supervision today proposed to remove all barriers to interstate branching by federally chartered savings associations.
The O.T.S. now permits savings associations to open branches across state lines for Federal institutions in limited instances and to acquire troubled institutions. When such branching is allowed, current restrictions often make it expensive to open the new branches because they require separate companies with separate boards.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Incomes Off, Spending Up Last Month

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Americans' incomes shrank last month as layoffs mounted, but rising expenses pushed up spending and curtailed savings, the Commerce Department reported today.
 Personal incomes fell one-tenth of 1 percent from October, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.88 trillion -- the first monthly drop in incomes since July, when they fell three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Consumers' spending rose a surprising seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.95 trillion last month. The spending is closely monitored as a possible source of growth since consumers account for two-thirds of economic activity.
 
 
Weather Was a Factor
 But Richard Berner, an economist for Salomon Brothers in New York, said much of the increase was a result of cold weather in many regions last month, which pushed up spending for natural gas and electric service.
 Excluding the utility spending, which is a largely unavoidable expense, consumption rose only four-tenths of 1 percent in November.
 "It's not a strong picture," Mr. Berner said.
 The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the drop in personal income reflected the economy's problems. "It reflects the flat and sluggish economy that we find ourselves in," he said.
 Asked at a briefing whether the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate cut on Friday was sufficient to stimulate the economy, Mr. Fitzwater said: "We would leave it to the Fed to make a judgment.
 "But we think they are on the right track. We believe there is room for declining interest rates. But we won't try to dictate that at this point."
 The Commerce Department report showed that savings suffered in November, with the seasonally adjusted annual rate dipping to $200.1 billion from $232.6 billion in October and from $216 billion in September.
 One of the leading causes for economists' fears that the nation is headed back into recession is anxiety among consumers about their jobs in the face of rising layoffs.
 The most stunning announcement came last week when the General Motors Corporation said it was closing 21 plants and eliminating 74,000 jobs over the next four years.
 But Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said more than simply negative psychology was at work in retarding the economy's struggle out of recession.
 "Rather, it is bound up with real economic conditions: slow real income gains and weak balance sheets," he said.
 
 
Aftermath of the 80's
 Not only weak growth in job opportunities and wages are at play, but also high indebtedness and declines in the value of homes are revealing the fragility of the 1980's boom in consumption spending, the economist said.
 "The reality is that consumers are overspending -- personal consumption expenditures are growing much faster than real disposable incomes," Mr. Richards said.
 Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has testified before Congress several times, and again last week, that more savings are a prerequisite for building capital that can be invested in new production.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fannie Mae Study Finds Phony Bids

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that phony bidding was common in its huge debt market, but the mortgage financing company declined to impose financial penalties on the 53 banks and Wall Street firms that buy its securities.
Releasing the conclusions of a four-month investigation, the Government-created company known as Fannie Mae said that all the institutions that buy its debt had inflated orders and submitted false information about their customers' demands to win a larger share of the market. 
 The company, the main source of credit for the nation's home buyers and corporate America's largest seller of debt, decided to put all of the members of its debt-selling group on probation and begin a series of auditing and record-keeping measures aimed at deterring and monitoring abuses. Any new violations for 12 months could result in suspension from the group.
In October, a smaller sister company, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, imposed similar measures and fined 17 banks and Wall Street firms about $1 million.
Fannie Mae said its investigation had found no evidence that the improper bidding practices had "caused economic harm to home buyers or Fannie Mae," although it said nothing about whether some bidders were hurt by the inflated bids of others.
"We couldn't come up with a justification for money fines based on our analysis of the selling action," said Frank D. Raines, the vice chairman of Fannie Mae, who headed the internal investigation. "The violations took a variety of forms, so it was difficult for us to see a fair fine structure."
The investigations by Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the Securities and Exchange Commission were prompted by this year's bidding scandal at Salomon Brothers Inc. in the Government securities market. The mortgage financing companies were also motivated to look hard at their markets to ward off any attempts at tighter regulation by the commission. They had a particular interest in preserving their exemption from many securities laws and expensive securities registration requirements.
 
Awareness of Employees
 Mr. Raines said the investigation had found that Fannie Mae employees were generally aware of what he called "salesmanship puffery" among the purchasers of debt, but that it had not found that employees knew that companies had been fabricating customers and sales.
"That occurred in more than a handful of instances," he said.
But the debt purchasers are still not entirely off the hook financially for their reported misconduct. In letters sent to them last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission asked the companies to settle cases stemming from the phony bidding practices.
Most of the firms have not yet responded to the letters, which ask each one to agree to pay an unspecified civil fine, sign an administrative order to "cease and desist" from future violations, and agree to new procedures assuring that violations do not recur.
In a letter sent Friday to the chief executives of the 53 companies, which include all of Wall Street's largest commercial and investment banks, James A. Johnson, the chairman of Fannie Mae, said the new record-keeping and audit program was intended "to protect the integrity of the process."
These are the companies that make up Fannie Mae's debt-seller:
Amsouth Bank; Bank of America; Bank of Boston; Bank One; Bear Stearns; BT Securities; Carroll McEntee & McGintley; Central Bank of the South, and Chemical Securities.
Citicorp Securities Markets; Commerce Bank of Kansas City; Continental Bank; Craigie; Dean Witter Reynolds ; Dillon, Read; Discount Corporation of New York, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
A. Webster Dougherty; FBS Investment Services; First Boston; First City Bancorporation of Texas; First Fidelity Bank; First Chicago Capital Markets; First Tennessee Bank; Fuji Securities; Goldman, Sachs, and J.J.B. Hilliard.
W.L. Lyons; Kemper Securities Group; Kidder, Peabody; Aubrey G. Lanston; Lehman Government Securities; Marquette Bank Minneapolis; McDonald & Company; Mellon Bank, and Merrill Lynch Government Securities.
Morgan Keegan; J. P. Morgan Securities; Morgan Stanley; National Bank of Commerce; NCNB Capital Markets; Nomura Securities International; Norwest Investment Services; Paine Webber, and Prudential Securities.
Salomon Brothers; Security Pacific National Bank; Shawmut National; Smith Barney, Harris Upham; South Carolina National Bank; Stephens; Trust Company Bank; United Missouri Bank of Kansas City, and Vining-Sparks Securities.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Paying the Tab For Retirees

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
A FEW companies have announced that they will take big deductions against profits to comply with a new accounting rule for medical benefits promised to future retirees. Starting in January 1993, all large employers must estimate and report their obligations to future retirees in an effort to charge all costs of current personnel against revenues.
Going a step further, a handful of employers have decided to set aside cash, although this is not required. 
 Benefits consultants say that many executives, recalling their experiences with pensions, were concerned that by allocating cash they might freeze their obligations to retirees, making it difficult or impossible to change their minds later. And some would rather spend the money on their businesses.
The amounts are enormous and hard to predict because among the uncertain factors are medical inflation trends and the future cost of money. The General Motors Corporation, for example, gave itself an $8 billion latitude when it announced that it would write off $16 billion to $24 billion.
For most companies, the bulk of the cost goes to catch up for prior years when retiree medical costs were written off on a pay-as-you-go basis. Under the new rule, these catch-up amounts can be taken in one huge amount or spread out over 20 years. The International Business Machines Corporation has already taken a charge of $2.3 billion; the General Electric Company took $1.8 billion. As a result, they will have much more modest amounts to report in future years.
But most actuaries expect the Chrysler Corporation, which announced an obligation of $4 billion to $6 billion, and G.M. to spread their amounts over the 20 years. Assuming that most employers will take the 20-year path, the General Accounting Office estimated that the total to be reported in 1993 would be at least $412 billion.
Only 91 employers, or 7 percent of the 1,385 responding to a survey by the William M. Mercer consulting firm, said they were "prefunding" their retiree health coverage. Most companies putting money aside said they would get tax advantages by adding to underfunded pension funds or Voluntary Employee Benefit Accounts, or VEBA's, which had been negotiated with labor unions.
But Donald G. McKinnon, a Mercer managing director in Stamford, Conn., said many employers that have enough union members to be interested in the funds "also happen to be companies for whom cash is a scarce commodity."
He said a few companies had considered covering the future costs by buying life insurance, which would build up tax-free interest and pay off when employees died. But there would be "even a heavier cash drain with the insurance than with the VEBA," Mr. McKinnon said.
Bruce Vander Els, a managing consultant in Philadelphia with the A. Foster Higgins consulting firm, noted that many companies could not get tax breaks. They would not qualify if they had fully funded pensions, or lacked enough unionized employees to justify a collectively bargained employee benefit account.
He added that some companies could get tax breaks in nonunion benefit trust funds if they limited their retiree benefit promises to a fixed dollar amount, as opposed to the usual open-ended benefit, and thus eliminated the medical inflation factor. But in a recent survey by Hewitt Associates, a consulting firm, only 3 percent of the 922 employers surveyed said they had switched to the fixed-dollar approach.
In the survey, 78 percent said they intended to make future retirees pay more of their own medical bills. Only 1 percent said they were eliminating all retiree health coverage.
Trying a different tack, the Proctor & Gamble Company got a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service permitting the use of an employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP, financed by tax-deductible contributions, for the purpose of financing future retiree costs. But the I.R.S. later issued a statement intended to discourage other companies from establishing similar ESOP's.
Most of the regional Bell telephone companies, several electric and gas utilities, and a handful of other public companies have indicated that they plan to use voluntary employee benefit accounts.
Howard C. Weizmann, executive director of the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, which lobbies in Washington for employers, banks and insurers, said that most members of the group had been reluctant to establish employee benefit trust funds. As a result, he said, members of Congress are not rushing to open a wider tax loophole for these funds.
"The push for change will come if it turns into a victims issue," Mr. Weizmann said, "if there are tons of victims and Congress sees that a lot of people are losing retiree benefits. That isn't happening."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Tough Choices Ahead For Phillips President

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Wayne W. Allen took over yesterday as the president and chief operating officer of the Phillips Petroleum Company, in the midst of a program to make the world's 28th-largest oil company a little smaller and more profitable.
Mr. Allen, 55 years old, has spent 30 years at Phillips, which is based in Bartlesville, Okla. He was most recently senior vice president for exploration and production. He replaced Glenn A. Cox, who retired. 
 Mr. Allen takes office at the close of a rough year. Phillips's net income for the first three quarters of the year totaled $56 million, down from $232 million for the comparable period last year.
Phillips, with a relatively high debt burden, wants to sell at least $500 million in assets over three years, and has already sold three tankers. It tried earlier this year to sell its Woods Cross refinery in Utah, but took it off the market because the company did not receive any acceptable offers.
The sales program is "going fine," Mr. Allen said in a telephone interview yesterday, despite the fact that "nothing of real high value" has been sold yet. "We want full value for our assets, so if it doesn't meet the hurdle, we withdraw it," he said.
The company is also waiting for a turnaround in natural gas prices. It produced more than a million cubic feet a day in the United States in the last quarter. "We've had quite warm winters, and the U. S. economy has been rather slow," Mr. Allen said. "All of those things are impacting the price."
But the weather will eventually turn colder and the economy will pick up, he added, and "natural gas itself being a premium fuel and very friendly to the environment we'll see a response. Down the road, that will be a good business."
The company also says it is well set up for an increasing emphasis on clean air, because of its position in natural gas and in natural gas liquids, of which it is the leading American producer. Some of those liquids are useful in making reformulated gasoline, Mr. Allen said.
The new president said he was determined to pare the headquarters staff, which now totals more than 5,000. Earlier this year, Phillips said it would cut 140 headquarters jobs.
Phillips's strategy has drawn praise from analysts.
"They're working hard to improve their financial condition, and they're making progress," said Eugene L. Nowak of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Of the slow asset sales, he said: "I think Phillips, like a lot of other people, is trying to avoid fire sales. They're not in a position where they're forced to sell anything, so I think they're calling their shots."
Mr. Allen, a petroleum engineer, is a graduate of Oklahoma State University, with a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and master's in industrial engineering. He has served as Phillips's regional manager in Britain and the Ivory Coast.
In 1982, he received the National Order of the Republic of the Ivory Coast, for his work in developing the oil resources there.

HEADLINE: Which Students Are Worst At Science?

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
EVERY few years, a new study rolls out announcing once again that American students know less math and science than even students in the poorest countries. And every time, the reports result in a national orgy of self-flagellation and cries for new rounds of reform in American schools.
The latest comparison, conducted by the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., and involving 20 countries, will be reported on Feb. 3. The betting is that the United States will, as always, rank at or near the bottom. 
 But this time, a growing and vocal collection of revisionists has begun arguing that the comparisons are invalid. The entire United States population, they contend, is consistently being compared with other countries' elites. No wonder Americans are found wanting.
These critics stress that they in no way mean they find nothing to improve in American schools. But, they say, it is disingenuous to use international comparisons to whip up the population to demand school reforms.
"The rankings of nations in international test comparisons are meaningless," said Dr. Iris Rotberg, a program administrator at the National Science Foundation who is on leave to work as a senior scientist at the RAND Corporation's Institute on Education and Training in Washington.
Dr. Harold Hodgkinson, the director of the Center for Demographic Policy in Washington and a former director of the National Institute of Education, said that the tests were flawed and not very helpful.
Dr. Daryl Chubin, a senior associate at the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment in Washington, said, "The international comparisons have been over-interpreted.
"In this country and in particular in this era of educational ferment, anyone who has new numbers will use them to champion an argument," he added. "We're talking about the rhetorical use of rank numbers. In the absence of good data, you get along with whatever you can."
Proponents of the tests argue that the comparisons are useful benchmarks and that it would be a mistake to throw away discomforting findings because of methodological obstacles.
Archie Lapointe, the director of assessment at the Educational Testing Service, said that the criticisms have "a kernel of truth." But, he said, the data show what sort of achievement is possible, albeit often among the very best, selected students, and give Americans goals to aim for. And the elite students, Mr. Lapointe added, "are those with whom we will compete in the future."
In response to its critics, Mr. Lapointe said, the Educational Testing Service is being "much more careful about how we report the data." For example in the forthcoming report it will explicitly describe the different student populations in the body of the text rather than in footnotes and appendices, as was done previously. "Every time we say Israel, we will say, in parentheses, Hebrew schools," he said, to convey to readers that most Arab students were not included.
Dr. Diane Ravitch, Assistant Secretary of Education for Educational Research and Improvement, warned that it was dangerous to dismiss the international comparisons. "None of the assessments are perfect, that's true," she said, but that is no excuse for disregarding them. Every time an assessment is done, she said, "U.S. students have placed at or near the bottom."
"The consistency is so strong that you cannot ultimately ignore it and say it means nothing," she added. "When you come up with the same results time and time again, you have to say there's something there."
Dr. Harold Stevenson, a psychology professor at the University of Michigan, agreed. "One of the things that is convincing is that there have been so many studies with different populations, different cities, different tests and they consistently came out in the same direction," he said. Dr. Stevenson, who conducts a study comparing children's math and science achievement in selected cities in the United States, China and Japan, added that he finds that "U.S. children are behind as early as the first grade."
His view was supported by Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers. "It would be appropriate to raise this question if we had reason to believe that American students are doing well and all of a sudden international comparisons come along and say we are at the bottom," he said. "But I think it's silly to try to shoot holes in international comparisons when there is a huge body of evidence that we are doing terribly."
Among the recent implicit and explicit uses of international comparisons are President Bush's stipulation, as an educational goal, that the United States should rise to first place in the math and science comparisons by the year 2000. A 1989 report calling for reforms in mathematics education, put out by the National Reseach Council, stated: "Children can succeed in mathematics. Many do in other countries and some do so in this country."
Critics say that the international tests of mathematics and science achievement have all suffered from what Dr. Hodgkinson called the "major problem." By high school, most countries have already dropped the poorer performers from their schools. American high school students thereby end up being compared with other countries' select few.
"If you are comparing 16-year-olds you are going to compare the top 70 to 80 percent of Americans with maybe the top 30 percent in European countries," Dr. Hodgkinson said. "If a nation has only the top 5 percent in the comparison, it will do a lot better than any other nation's top 70 percent."
 
Some Schools Are Excluded
 There is an uneven playing field even when younger groups are compared, Dr. Hodgkinson noted. He said that many countries vie for top honors in these international comparisons by purposely excluding schools or districts or groups of students who they know will pull their scores down. "In many countries, to look good is very good for international prestige," he said. "Some restrict the students taking the test to elite schools."
Dr. Harold Howe, a senior lecturer emeritus at Harvard University who was the United States Commissioner of Education from 1965 to 1968, agreed. "Every country is highly motivated to make themselves look as good as possible," he said. "It is very hard in an international population where you don't control the detailed process of selecting the sample and administering the test to be sure that the process is watertight."
Mr. Shanker argued, however, that many tests of younger students do reflect representative samples of students in different countries.
Dr. Rotberg said that different countries varied substantially in the way that mathematics and science are taught. "In European countries, students who will go on to universities specialize right away," she said. They study mathematics and science intensively in high school rather than taking a broad range of courses. "This means there is a relatively small group of students and a very demanding curriculum," she said. "That will show up on test scores."
Karel van Wolferen, the author of "The Enigma of Japanese Power," said it should be no surprise that Japanese students do well on standardized tests. Only a small proportion who pass qualifying tests go on to the top high schools, where they spend their time training for college entrance exams, he said. Mr. von Wolferen, who recently established the Institute for Independent Japanese Studies in Washington, said that Japanese students "are educated -- or trained, I would hardly call it education -- to pass exams."
 
Memories of Sputnik
 The international comparisons began in the 1960's, when Americans had Sputnik fresh in their minds and were afraid they would lose the space race to the Soviet Union. They were conducted by the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement, a group based in the Netherlands. These tests, Dr. Rotberg pointed out, compared the 80 percent of Americans who attended high school with 9 percent of West Germans, 13 percent of students in the Netherlands and 45 percent in Sweden who attended the highly academic and selective final years of high school in the 1960's. "It is not surprising that U.S. students did not do well in these comparisons," she said.
More recent comparisons by the international association have similar drawbacks, Dr. Rotberg said. For example, she said, in a 1987 report, Japan ranked first among 20 countries in eighth-grade mathematics achievement and Hong Kong ranked in the middle of the various countries assessed. But, she said, by 12th grade, when 15 countries are compared, Hong Kong ranked first.
The reason, Dr. Rotberg proposes, is not so complicated: by 12th grade, Hong Kong has eliminated all but 3 percent of its students from taking mathematics, while in Japan, 12 percent of students take mathematics in 12th grade. So, Dr. Rotberg said, Hong Kong's elite is being compared with broader ranges of students in other countries, making its pre-eminence inevitable.
Some American scientists say they have long been suspicious of international comparisons because the results belie their own observations. Dr. Ponzy Lu, a chemist at the University of Pennsylvania who went to high school in England and did postdoctoral work in Germany, said that he saw no evidence of American inferiority in science when he assessed students who study under him.
Foreign students have to meet much higher standards than Americans to enter American graduate schools, he said. At the University of Pennsylvania, Americans who score at the 50th percentile on their Graduate Record Exams are usually admitted, while foreign students must have scores above the 90th percentile, Dr. Lu said. But even so, the foreign students range from "absolutely awful to fantastically good," which means, Dr. Lu said, that "the standardized test scores don't mean much."
 
Emphasizing the Basics
 Dr. Rotberg agreed and cautioned that Americans' love of testing can result in a misplaced emphasis in teaching information that is easy to test in multiple-choice exams.
"I think that focusing on tests will make it much more difficult to make changes that need to be made," Dr. Rotberg said. In particular, she advocated placing more emphasis on teaching students basic concepts of science, scientific methodology, how to understand the science behind major issues in public policy -- like arguments over global warming -- and how to do independent research.
Dr. Hodgkinson said the emphasis on international comparisons masked the fact that many American schools were in fact doing a good job. The top 10 percent of American students are scoring 14 points higher on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests than they were 10 years ago, he said. There has been no decline in Graduate Record Examination scores, he said, adding that "if high schools are doing so miserably, you would hardly expect colleges to recoup that."
Dr. Howe expressed concern at the assumption often made by politicians and educators that if test scores are low, then the problem is in the schools and can be fixed by yet another round of curriculum reform or infusion of money.
Low test scores, "are not just a measure of schools," he said. "They are a measure of the entire society. The environment in the home and the kinds of social and medical services available to kids are extremely important in affecting the kinds of lives these children are able to lead and the kinds of scores they get.
"The main problem with the school reform movement in the United States is that we have the basic assumption that we can fix the schools so the schools can fix the kids, no matter what is wrong with the family and the community."

HEADLINE: A Strong Vote for One China

 BODY:
The most democratic vote for a legislature ever held in China took place Saturday -- in Taiwan. With its recent gains in economic development and political liberalization, Taiwan deserves serious attention in Washington. But as the vote itself makes clear, that attention is best based on the premise of eventual reunification between Taiwan and the mainland.
The election's big winner was the Nationalist Party, or Kuomintang, which has ruled Taiwan since the island was recovered from Japan. The Kuomintang had little interest in democracy during its half-century of domination by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. But the Generalissimo's son, Chiang Ching-kuo, began a process of liberalization that his successor, President Lee Teng-hui, has accelerated. 
 President Lee's policies, long resisted by the Kuomintang's reactionary old guard, were vindicated by Saturday's results. The Kuomintang won more than 70 percent of the vote. That margin testifies to public support for the Kuomintang's "One China" doctrine, holding that eventual reunification with the mainland is inevitable and that Taiwan's independence is inconceivable. The main opposition party, the Democratic Progressives, openly backed independence, and lost support.
Washington has publicly ignored Taiwan since it normalized relations with Beijing in the 1970's, as if to compensate for its foolish 25-year boycott of the mainland regime. Taiwan, home to more than 20 million Chinese and one of Asia's most successful economies, is too big to ignore.
It deserves U.S. support for its application to join, without prejudice to China, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. And it deserves America's sympathy in the event of future bullying from Beijing, which still insists on its right to impose unification by military force.
Taiwan's voters support One China, democratically reunited. Americans can applaud, and morally support, that choice.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Economical Wetlands Plan Along Hudson Is Timely Again

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A panel of scientists appointed by the National Research Council recommends that "the United States undertake an ambitious long-term program of ecological restoration" (news article, Dec. 12). Such a restoration project has been proposed right in New York City, along the Hudson River from 42d Street to Battery Park City. 
This section of Manhattan, to the west of the new Route 9A to be built in place of West Street, is publicly owned land whose fate is as yet undetermined. A lumbering West Side waterfront panel finally decided in November 1990 that the area should have an elaborate four-mile "esplanade," with plenty of room for commercial development, but the trouble was that the price tag was a minimum of $500 million (1990 prices). Since neither the state nor the city Correction
Because of an editing error, a letter on Dec. 16 by Allen Bromberger misstated that corporations will now have to pay tax on donations to nonprofit organizations. The nonprofit groups will have to pay the tax.
has money like that, nor is likely to for a long time to come, the plan was quietly shelved.
All along, a citizens group called the Wetlands Restoration Project urged an entirely different, much more beautiful and far less costly scheme: the transformation of that area into a tidal wetlands much as it would have been when Henry Hudson saw it 400 years ago. By letting nature do most of the work and all of the maintenance, such a project could no doubt be done for about $40 million -- which is just about half the money due to be paid the local governments by Washington if the land is suitably "scenic," as a lush and verdant wetlands certainly would be.
Now, as the National Research Council report makes clear, is the time to revive this wetlands project and get state and local officials actively working for its completion. As the scientists forcefully argued, this should be "a high priority task" for our city.
 
KIRKPATRICK SALE
New York, Dec. 12, 1991
 
The writer is an adviser to the Wetlands Restoration Project.

HEADLINE: Airlines, Let's Face It, Have Gone Into Tailspin

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Flights of Non-fancy" (editorial, Dec. 9), on airline deregulation, is myopic. We economists check the patient -- the airline industry -- almost continuously, and declare him trim and active. We conclude he must be in good health. But take a step backward and look at the larger picture. 
 Economists supported airline deregulation because the industry seemed to have none of the characteristics requiring regulation. There was no evidence of cost advantages for big companies over small ones. We thought that it would be as easy for new companies to enter markets as for others to exit. There seemed every reason to expect competition to drive airlines to provide what customers wanted while they strove to minimize costs. The airlines seemed in principle no different from bakeries or variety stores.
We were wrong. After a flurry of innovation -- introduction of the hub and spoke system, intensive use of peripheral airports, no-frills service and entry of small new competitors -- unexpected patterns started to emerge. Through control of reservations systems, in which size conveys substantial advantages, through frequent-flier kickbacks, which skim off the profitable business traveler, and through monopolistic domination of hubs, which offer a limited supply of takeoff and landing slots, big airlines were able to absorb or destroy most of their small competitors and some giant rivals. The number of airlines has shrunk since the mid-1980's.
Yet the economist continues to declare the patient well simply because the pulse beats, even when almost every piece of the earlier prognosis has proved wrong. There is every reason to doubt that the airline industry is in a steady state that can be sustained; it continues to sink. Eastern and Pan American have died, leaving unfunded pension commitments that the taxpayer probably will be forced to pick up. Other major carriers stagger along with negative profit and negative net worth.
The evidence points to a future of a small oligopoly of airlines. Through domination of hubs and reservation systems (and with implicit collusion), they will be able to raise prices not just to the level needed to make a normal rate of return, but higher.
Why don't we admit that deregulation is not working as we thought it would? Let us deliberately put into place the elements of a new regulatory system: further regulation of reservation systems, price or quantity limits to monopolistic practices at hubs, price or quantity limits to scheduling during peak-load hours, the elimination of kickback schemes.
Surely, auctions of takeoff and landing slots, slot pricing based on local concentration of ownership or other schemes are likely to be preferable to the fare and route regulation that we had formerly. Unless economists take the initiative in promoting the new regulatory system, we will have no right to complain when the prize patient enters political intensive care.
 
BERNARD WASOW
Assoc. Professor of Economics
New York University
New York, Dec. 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Airlines, Let's Face It, Have Gone Into Tailspin;
Free Market Zealots

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was disappointed by your Dec. 9 editorial proclaiming airline deregulation a success. Deregulation has produced in the United States: 
 * Five major airlines, 25 percent of the national fleet capacity, are in bankruptcy, including the two to which deregulation gave birth -- America West and Midway (Midway ceased operations this year, along with Eastern and Pan American).
* After 200 bankruptcies and 50 mergers, we now fly the oldest and most repainted fleet of aircraft in the developed world.
* The market share of the four largest airlines has grown by 14 percent in five years, to two-thirds -- a rate of concentration unparalleled in American business history.
* More than 50,000 airline employees have lost their jobs since Jan. 1.
* All the United States passenger airlines together are now worth less than Japan Air Lines individually.
Deregulation was supposed to produce more competition. But under deregulation, 13 major railroads folded into 7; 2 bus lines became 1, and two-thirds of the general freight trucking companies disappeared with no significant new entry.
From the late 1970's, Congress and the White House deregulated a host of industries. Free-market economists assured us that if we amputated the dead hand of regulation and sewed on Adam Smith's invisible hands, we would prosper in nearly textbook levels of perfect competition. Not since the Bolshevik Revolution has the discipline of economics embraced an ideology with such passion.
At first, airline deregulation looked like a masterpiece of public policy. Airlines lowered fares, tapping the elasticities of demand and filling seats that otherwise would have flown empty, thereby enjoying record profitability. Air Florida and People Express emerged, to drive first prices, and then themselves, through the floor. But now all the major new airlines are dead, or nearly so.
The implicit thesis of the theology of laissez-faire is that unconstrained human greed will produce a better society. Under the stars and stripes of the free market, corporate raiders were freed to devour healthy companies and suck them dry of capital, leaving them wounded, unable to produce a new product or compete better in a global marketplace.
Savings and loan deregulation will cost every taxpayer $5,000, minimum. Local telephone rates have risen sharply. Yet free-market economists insist consumers save billions.
Your editorial is not only misguided but also misleading. You ignore the prederegulation trend of declining fares and increased traffic. Yes, fuel and inflation-adjusted air fares are lower than in 1978. They fell every decade under regulation as well, and were falling at a faster rate before deregulation. Yes, more travelers are flying than ever before. That is also true every year since 1938.
The world is rightly rejecting the socialist alternative. But the ravages of too free a market should be as manifest. Take for example the illicit sale of narcotics, sex and gambling, markets tenaciously driving toward freedom. Only one who has a theological libertarian passion for free markets would prefer the anarchy created by the total absence of government.
 
PAUL STEPHEN DEMPSEY
Prof. of Law, University of Denver
Denver, Dec. 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Rate Cuts Push Dow Over 3,000

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices leaped yesterday in what traders saw as a continued reaction to Friday's sharp cut in the discount rate and, hard on its heels, a cut in many banks' prime lending rates. The Dow Jones industrial average surged past the 3,000 barrier for the first time in more than a month to 3,022.58, up 88.10 points, or 3 percent.
The percentage gain was the best since Aug. 21, when stock prices rebounded after the failed coup in the Soviet Union, with the Dow also rising 88.10, to 3,001.79. 
 Trading was surprisingly heavy for a day that many expected to be a slow pre-Christmas session, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange hitting 229.2 million shares. That compared with more hectic trading on Friday, when 318.4 million shares changed owners on a day when various options contracts expired.
 
Supported by Credit Markets
 A firm bond market along with lower interest rates gave stocks early support. Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose and interest rates continued to fall. [Page D11.]
The dollar also tumbled further in reaction to the widening interest-rate gap between the United States and Europe.
The breadth of the market was overwhelmingly on the buy side as advancing issues on the Big Board outnumbered declining ones by more than 3 to 1, with gainers totaling 1,410.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also had a big day, gaining 9.78 to finish at 396.82. The Big Board composite index rose 5, to 218.13, and the American Stock Exchange composite added 3.71 to end at 370.93.
Trading on Nasdaq took the composite index 8.14 points higher, to 543.90, while the Russell 2,000 index, a barometer of small stocks, gained 1.83 to close at 177.90.
 
Limit on Program Trades
 According to exchange rules, program trading was restricted in the afternoon when the Dow rose 50 points. Other factors may also have been at work. David Chao, the head trader in New York for County NatWest Securities, noted that for investors who had sold stock short, or sold borrowed stock in the hope of replacing it with stock bought later at a lower price, yesterday was the last day to buy to take a loss this year for tax purposes.
A gain or loss is registered on the settlement date, which is five business days after the transaction.
Traders said the market had little reaction to the November personal income and consumption spending data released earlier in the day by the Commerce Department.
Analysts at MMS International said the weaker-than-expected income and stronger-than-expected consumption would not change the market's perception of the economy.
The most-sought-after shares were the cyclical stocks and the utilities, with transportation issues up handily, Mr. Chao said.
The combination of falling interest rates, a strong bond market and weak overseas markets encouraged investors, traders said.
Elsewhere in the market, the share price of Summcorp common stock rose 4 1/2, to 35, in over-the-counter trading, after NBD Bancorp said it had reached an agreement to merge with Summcorp. The deal is valued at $323 million and calls for NBD to exchange 0.9 share of its common for each Summcorp share.
According to traders, the share price of Telefonaktiebolaget L. M. Ericsson, a worldwide telecommunications company that had been down in recent months, surged in heavy American trading. It said it would sign an initial contract next year to develop and install a cellular mobile system in metropolitan Tokyo. Last week, the company said it planned to cut its overall costs by 15 percent in 1992, which helped the stock. It gained 2 points, to 18 3/8.
American Cyanamid, after saying on Friday that it would restructure its global chemical businesses by combining them in a new corporate entity, advanced 2 1/4, to 62 1/2. William Young, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, repeated the firm's strongest "buy" rating. Traders said he thought the chemicals unit would eventually be spun off to shareholders.
Orion Pictures edged up 3/8, to 2 1/4, on 3.1 million shares. Metromedia and New Line Cinema said they had tentatively agreed to propose a reorganization plan for Orion, which sought Federal bankruptcy protection several weeks ago.
Syntex rose 4 1/4, to 46 7/8, after the company announced it had received clearance from the Food and Drug Administration to market Toradol tablets for treating pain. The injectable form was approved in May 1990. The company said the new oral medication is expected to be widely available in pharmacies in March 1992.
On a strong "buy" rating by David Webber of Alex. Brown & Sons, traders said, Synergen rose 2 7/8, to 59 1/8. Mr. Webber raised his earnings estimates for the company.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 25, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about Monday's stock market activity referred incorrectly to the taxation of stock market profits and losses. Monday was the final day for an investor who had shorted a stock to repurchase it for the purpose of claiming a loss in 1991; other transactions that create a gain or loss may be made through Dec. 31.

HEADLINE: Ever So Cautiously, Skirts Creep Down

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
In testing longer skirts for the spring season, designers managed to avoid a possible disaster. Their approach was low-keyed, and calf-length skirts made up no more than 10 percent of most collections.
Twenty years ago, when the mini abruptly gave ground to the midi or calf-length skirt, the uproar was ferocious. Women refused to give up the freedom that above-the-knee skirts provided. They said the longer skirts were dowdy and old-looking. They insisted that designers were dictating to them and they refused to go along. 
 The protests were far stronger in this country than in Europe, where women have traditionally been far more in thrall to fashion than Americans. In the short run, women made their point by avoiding skirts of any length. Thus, the pants era was ushered in, dominating fashion for the next few years. Gradually, however, clothes became more formal, midi skirts won acceptance and the avant-garde slipped into ankle lengths.
Now, short skirts have had a five-year run, and many designers believe it is time for a change. But they are not rushing blindly into the new regime; they are proceeding with extreme caution.
 
Test Ground for Long Skirts
 Spring is not the best time for a big change in fashion, most designers believe, especially in a shaky economic period when customers are not in a mood to buy. So the spring collections were treated as a test ground to determine what kind of long skirts were viable. Some designers ignored the chance -- they kept everything short.
Still, there is a feeling that a change is due. And the majority of collections did offer a variety of longer styles as designers sought a style that was seductive, practical and esthetic.
Some designers tried a middle ground, offering long, full skirts that buttoned over shorts or minis. It was a form of hedging or having your cake and eating it too. Others emphasized seductiveness by splitting long, slender skirts up the side, front or even back to show plenty of leg, as high as the thigh. The reasoning for this variation is that the skinny, split skirt that provides a glimpse of leg is even more provocative than the brief skirt that conceals practically nothing. This view must be the most prevalent because this is the type of longer skirt that is seen most frequently.
Another approach is the uneven hemline that slants from above the knees to below them, the degree of dip varying with the style. Designers feel this, too, has a provocative look. So do thin, almost see-through fabrics that show the legs in a shadowy way.
Some of the most successful styles, however, do not pursue the seductive angle too aggressively. They simply make full skirts that end around mid-calf level, that look easy to move in and do not clutch the body. When they are successful, they look comfortable, relaxed and beyond reproach.
While their steps are tentative now, designers will pursue the grail of a length change more aggressively in their fall collections. The climate will be more appropriate. Who can resist the argument that long skirts will keep you warm? Women may be more receptive to change. Still, the mini will not disappear. Designers will do their best to keep a balance.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Further; Price of Gold Rises Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled further yesterday in reaction to the widening interest rate gap between the United States and Europe, but a late rally on Wall Street helped the currency partly recover.
Gold prices rose slightly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery fetched $359.30 an ounce, up 70 cents from Friday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold fetched $359.50 late in the day, up $1 from Friday. 
 Foreign-exchange traders said dollar sellers battered the currency through much of the day, accelerating the slide of late last week that resulted from higher interest rates in Germany and falling rates in the United States.
On Thursday, Germany's central bank raised key rates in a move to stem inflation. On Friday, the Federal Reserve announced a big cut in its lending rate to banks to stimulate the economy.
Both moves caught many currency-market strategists unprepared. Lower interest rates in the United States make the dollar worth less, and higher rates in Germany make the mark more valuable.
"A lot of people got the one-two whammy last week," said Zlatko Glamuzina, senior dealer at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia. "Whoever had a long dollar position paid the piper the second time around in one week. That's a big no-no."
But the dollar's slide was eased late yesterday afternoon by a powerful rally on Wall Street.
"The late action in the stock market pulled the dollar out of its depths," said Jerry Egan, a trader at the Bank of Boston's foreign exchange desk.
In Tokyo, markets were closed for the Emperor's birthday. In London, the dollar fetched 126.50 yen, well below Tokyo's late Friday rate of 128.32 yen. Later in New York, the dollar fetched 126.65 yen, down from 127.55 yen Friday but higher than an intraday low of 126.20 yen, a level not seen since October 1990.
The dollar fell to 1.5135 German marks in Europe, down from 1.5335 late Friday. In New York, the dollar fetched 1.5130 marks, down from 1.5340 late Friday but above its intraday low of 1.5062 marks, a level not seen since last February.
Gold rose in London to $359.40 a troy ounce, from $358.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $359.50, from $358 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.84 an ounce to close at $359.77.

HEADLINE: Colleges Wary of Easing Curbs on South Africa

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Not many years removed from the days when students were erecting mock shanty towns and staging protests against apartheid, a handful of universities and colleges are now taking tentative steps toward liberalizing their policies banning the investment of endowment funds in companies doing business with South Africa.
But, like the process of dismantling white rule in that country, campus officials and shareholder groups are moving slowly and cuatiously to loosen the restrictions. 
 "Nobody wants to be the first," said Jean Mayer, president of Tufts University, who has emerged as the most vocal supporter of reinvestment as a prod to keep negotiations for a new government going forward. A convention of political parties to draw up plans for an interim government and a new constitution opened Friday in Johannesburg.
"Everybody is slow because they are afraid of giving their students the wrong message," added Mr. Mayer, who supported Tufts's decision in 1989 to divest completely. "In particular, they are interested in making sure their black students don't think it's a reversal of their commitment to civil rights."
Indeed, those who attended a meeting in October of 29 colleges and universities interested in tracking South African developments declined to identify which members had raised their hands in an informal poll to see which institutions were actively reconsidering divestment.
Divestment policies were established after much deliberation, and any changes "will be done in a long, careful, thoughtful fashion," said Laurel Harvey, chairwoman of the steering committee for the Colleges and Universities Research Consortium on South Africa. "This is not something universities are going to respond to with a knee-jerk reaction."
But Mr. Mayer urges quick action, arguing that violence provoked by unemployment levels exceeding 30 percent is far more threatening to the South African negotiations than the reversal of divestment policies. "Unless there is reinvestment soon, then all the political progress is going to be wiped out," he said.
Mr. Mayer said he changed his mind this year when racist laws were erased from South Africa's constitution. "The idea wasn't that we were going to divest until there was a perfect democracy," he said.
In another case where divestment is being questioned, the board of regents at the University of Wisconsin has asked the State Attorney General to review a state ruling prohibiting investment in companies with ties to South Africa. But the regents' motives are more legal than political, according to Daniel Gelatt, chairman of the board's business and finance committee.
The Bush Administration's decision to lift economic sanctions this summer happened to coincide with the university's regular process of bidding for the services of investment advisers, said Mr. Gelatt, so the question of whether the original ruling was still justified was raised.
"My impression is that the changes in the apartheid laws have reduced the implicit employment discrimination" that was the basis for the state's divestment law, he said. The regents' action is "as much an issue of control over our investments as it's an issue about South Africa," he added.
But Donna E. Shalala, the university's chancellor, said she would oppose any reversal of the policy while negotiations on a new government are under way.
"I think it's too early," she said. "There's not 'one person one vote' in South Africa. Blacks are still disenfranchised in South Africa, and that was the whole point of divestment."
Just how much of an economic lift colleges and universities would give South Africa by reversing divestment is questionable, said D. Reid Weedon Jr., senior vice president of Arthur D. Little in Cambridge, Mass. Mr. Weedon heads a program that for 15 years has monitored the behavior of American companies in South Africa for institutional investors with selective divestment policies.
"At this stage of the game it doesn't make all that much difference because the companies that have stayed have hung in there even though a lot of universities have sold their shares," Mr. Weedon said. Of more importance, he added, will be the decisions of 143 state, city and county governments that restrict their business and investment ties with South Africa.
Several colleges and universities have scheduled meetings to discuss re-evaluations of their investment policies. And university officials on both sides of the issue said they were less fearful of causing new student protests than they were of negatively influencing the ongoing talks in South Africa.
"I don't think there is the emotional fervor on campuses about South Africa that there was four or five years ago, but I may be wrong," Mr. Mayer said.
Indeed, some students at Tufts are planning protests and petition drives early next year before a meeting on the issue by university trustees.
There is also agreement that the time may be nearing when the subject of reversing divestment might be discussed freely.
"There's a clear sense that things are happening in South Africa," Ms. Harvey said, "and it's only a question of time."
