HEADLINE: In Uncertain Times, College Students See a Bleak Future After Graduation

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Once they stood as splendid sanctuaries, with Gothic towers and heavy mantles of tradition that conveyed a soothing stability. But America's college campuses have come to bear the same fault lines as American society, and in uncertain times like these even self-possessed students like Michael Idinopulos, a philosopher-in-training at the University of Chicago, feel shaken.
There is a sense among students that they have no room to make mistakes, said Mr. Idinopulos, a senior from Cincinnati who intends to study the complex philosophy of mathematics in graduate school, if he gets there. 
 "If we're not the best," he said, "we don't get the jobs. If we sleep with the wrong person, we end up with AIDS. If we don't come up with a financially sound policy for the future of this country, we'll suffer the consequences."
In interviews with more than 65 students at colleges throughout the Middle West, whose students mirror the majority on campus, a powerful sense emerged that instead of feeling privileged, many of today's college students feel boxed in by anxieties and limitations.
Their days are filled with the same struggle, triumph and horseplay as have always characterized students' lives, and the old pressures of grades and romance remain strong. But the campuses have become complicated by tough issues like AIDS, acquaintance rape, racism, alcoholism and other real-world troubles that make some college newspapers read like big-city tabloids.
Such anxieties are reflected in many aspects of the way today's students live and study. But most striking is how many students, worried about the economy, said they did not expect to live as well as the previous generation.
"My parents got married and bought a little house when my dad was still a student," said Lida Poletz, a senior majoring in journalism and Russian at the University of Minnesota. "I'm not going to be able to do that."
It is not preoccupation with wealth so much as worry about landing a job, any job, that tends to be an overriding concern. Hard times influence what and how these students study more than do intellectual passion or political commitment. Even decisions to help volunteer organizations sometimes are made with an eye toward how such activities would perk up a dull resume.
Many students first focused on their post-college lives soon after they entered college. John Kramarczuk, a junior at the University of Minnesota who is majoring in history, has long planned to teach high school. Tiffany Swanson, an international studies major in her junior year at Bradley University in Peoria, Ill., has made up her mind to become a defense contractor.
Dana Owens, a senior at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, first thought he wanted to be a social worker. But he switched to journalism and wants to be a television news announcer so he can accurately represent news about minorities that he said is often misinterpreted.
"I just want to give a positive black perspective to some of the news," said Mr. Owens, who next June will be the first in his family to graduate from college.
Meeting expecations so shapes their lives that some students see college as an obligation rather than an opportunity. Christina Damas of Mahomet, Ill., just outside Champaign, is a senior English education major at Illinois State University. To help pay bills she works as an assistant in a dormitory on the campus at Normal, about 40 miles east of Peoria, enabling her to see first hand how much pressure there is for students to do well, look right and be first.
Recently, she said, there has been a problem in the dorm with students vomiting in bags and throwing them down the garbage chutes. She believes it is not from excessive drinking, but rather a sign of eating disorders that come with intense anxieties about appearance, especially among young women.
"We must be a depressed society for someone to do that," she said.
Few students said they read newspapers regularly or venture into literature beyond course requirements. When they bought a book that was not required for class, it tended to be something simple: the comic characters Calvin & Hobbes top many a campus bookstore's bestseller list. Generally, the students' view of the world comes through television. The TV also provides much of their entertainment, from afternoon soap operas to home video games that have become a standard study break.
Weekends are still reserved for parties, especially at schools where the fraternity system is strong like Bradley University. Students there say the weekend begins on Thursday night, and parties consist of hundreds of people crowding into a fraternity house, where they stand shoulder-to-shoulder, plastic cups of beer sloshing over expensive sweaters.
 
Of Parties Past
 Michael Sperling, a senior from Northbrook, Ill., was president of his fraternity, Alpha Epsilon, last year. He said that before kegs were banned, some fraternity on campus would have a 10-keg party at least once a week and it was not unusual to find the upstairs rooms at a fraternity house filled with people smoking marijuana. He said about a third of the guys at a party would have sex with a woman before the night ended.
Tricia Hackett, a political science major from Chillicothe, Ill., said she got drunk at fraternity parties in her first two years at Bradley and would allow a guy to walk her back to her room. Now that she is a junior, she considers herself lucky that she did not get into real trouble then. "A guy who normally is a pretty nice guy," she said, "at 2 in the morning after 15 or 20 beers turns into a different animal."
Studies show college students to be firm middle-of-the roaders in politics and social views, but idealism is not dead on campus. Many volunteer to help the needy, and it is not unusual to meet someone like Julia McCullough, a nursing major at Bradley, who recently spent a night huddled under a blanket in front of Bradley Hall to raise money for the homeless.
But most students interviewed had never attended or participated in a political protest, on campus or off. Such mass professions of allegiance to an idea are out of sync with the narrow focus these students take.
"We're living in difficult, confusing times," said Michael Newirth, a senior English major who a D.J. at the University of Chicago's radio station, WHPK. Turning down the studio speakers on which the group My Dad is Dead was sounding off, he added, "I still personally believe in the abstract concepts of America that I was raised with but the events of the last few years have made that difficult."
Mr. Newirth, from Port Washington, L.I., openly expresses his tastes in music at the station and hopes to be a writer of short stories later in life. Both activities invite forwardness, but he said he has not participated in protests or demonstrations in his four years at college because he doesn't think he has any answers.
"I'm only one individual; I feel uncomfortable suggesting what others should think," he said.
 
Thinking About the Economy
 Such self-restraint may seem excessive, especially in light of past campus ferment, but students now acutely feel the uncertainties of contemporary life. Foremost among them are the doubts raised by an out-of-gas economy in which the students' degrees appear to have little worth.
"I work part time in my parents' bar and what I hear mostly from the guys there is that they think college and a lot of education is just a waste of time," said Walley Wargolet Jr., a business management major from Milwaukee who is a senior at the University of Wisconsin, Parkside, in Kenosha. "They see this country as filled with thinkers and not doers."
Annette Hayes of Inkster, Mich., a finance major at Wilberforce University, a historically black university in Wilberforce, Ohio, said: "I get worried about it especially when I see white people, with white-collar positions, losing their jobs. I look at myself and think, 'What chance do I have?' "
As always, some students possess confidence and hope that cannot be diminished by headlines. That is the case for some at the counterculture holdout of Antioch College, in Yellow Springs, Ohio, where women are womyn, freshmen are first-year students and the American flag cannot be flown, by student consensus, from September till May.
"I'm not as scared about the economy contracting as I am about the contraction I see in society," said Mark Swanholm, a fourth-year student from Stillwell, Kan., majoring in international communications. "David Duke is much more of a threat to me than not being able to earn $50,000 a year."
Jon Rodriguez, a second year communications major from San Francisco, countered, "Yeah, but if you have the money, you have more say in changing political structures."
Down the road and across an ideological chasm from Antioch, the students at Cedarville College, a Baptist liberal arts college, attend compulsory chapel for 45 minutes a day. Michelle Polish, an accounting major from Fraser, Mich., has wanted to work for a major accounting firm since she was a freshman. She thought it would be great to make a lot of money, and to work in a sophisticated city environment.
But this semester, the start of her last year in school, when the real world started to look surprisingly near, she said she has grown frightened of ending up "just a number" in a big firm. A few job interviews confirmed her fear. "They seemed so rigid, so unapproachable," she said.
Now she thinks she will work for a small accounting company for about five years, around which time, she said, she would be ready to give up her career and start raising a family.
Such ideas were expressed regularly in the heartland. When a group of students at Wright State University in Dayton got together in a dorm room recently, a freshman, Shannon Nutt, said she planned to become an elementary school teacher and was not bothered by dim salary prospects. "My salary isn't going to be the main one anyway," she said.
For many, college is limbo, a time of focusing on the future while lingering imnpatiently in the present. At Bradley University, four young women living together in a stage-set college apartment, knee-deep in electronic gear and wash-and-wear clothes, talked with unsettling weariness about the future.
"We were watching TV and talking about cars and how much they've changed," said Karen Casaccio, a junior from Bloomingdale, Ill. She recalled the boxy station wagons her father used to own, and compared them uneasily to the all-purpose vehicles sold now that look, she said, "like spaceships."
"It's very scary to look at where the world is going to be in 30 or 40 years," Miss Casaccio said. "Everything is so technical and so complicated, I wish I was in my 50's right now."

NATIONAL 7-11
 
BLUE-COLLAR RECESSION
For all the talk of a "white-collar" recession, blue-collar workers have lost more jobs and endured far higher rates of unemployment. And an increasing number of blue-collar workers are facing the harsh truth that although the economy will come back, their lost jobs are probably gone for good. 1
 
WHEELS ACROSS AMERICA
While millions of Americans whoosh across the continent in jetliners during the holiday season, those of more modest means go by bus. Yet bus travel appeals not only to people with little money but also to those with lots of time, a fear of flying or a taste for adventure. 1
 
THE NEW NON-ISSUE
Whether sleeping on grates or in shelters, or begging from shoppers, the homeless seem to be everywhere this winter. Everywhere, that is, except in the campaign for the Presidency, where they are referred to only obliquely, if at all. 9

HEMOPHILIACS AND AIDS
The virus that causes AIDS has infected almost every hemophiliac born before 1985. And now hemophiliacs are angrily questioning whether the AIDS disaster among them could have been lessened with earlier warnings about blood products. 7

HEADLINE: Some Take the High Road, Some the Bus

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Dec. 22

 BODY:
At 6:45 A.M., most of the 47 passengers aboard Bus 5412 were still in a somnolent sprawl: heads back, mouths open, limbs colliding. Richmond was a memory and the long, neck-stiffening miles of the Carolinas were yet to unfold.
Then the inky horizon began to glow pink, and the driver, Emmett Diggs Jr., brushed aside talk of discomfort with a hushed tribute to a bus journey's virtues. 
 "Bea-uuuuu-tiful sunrises," he said.
While millions of Americans whoosh across the continent this week by air, the less fortunate get stuck on the bus.
For them, the holiday season often begins with frayed nerves, bouts of fatigue, smoky waiting rooms with hard plastic seats and lines that stretch for hours.
The distance between the croissant counter at National Airport outside Washington and the Burger King inside the city's bus station is one more measure of class differences in America and the routine discomforts endured by those of modest means.
But bus travel is more than just a cheap way of getting places. It is at the center of an American subculture that appeals not only to people with little money but also to those with lots of time, a fear of flying or a taste for adventure.
About a half-million Americans will travel by bus this week. Some have never had a financial choice. Others forgot to make plane reservations in time. Still others, traveling between small towns have no other choice. And some people, pressed by the recession to economize, are taking buses for the first time.
It is an experience that cries out for a chronicler. Country music has immortalized the pickup truck, and folk singers the freight train, but far fewer poets have turned a phrase about 19 fuming tons of Americruiser.
A 18-hour, 725-mile ride from Washington, D.C., to Jacksonville, Fla., brings encounters with all kinds of bus riders: blacks who migrated to Brooklyn and are returning to the small towns of the South; a newlywed soldier from Fort Bragg about to meet his in-laws for the first time; a Greek Orthodox priest reading Hans Kung; a Long Island man who was bumped from the first leg of a plane trip to Ecuador, hoping to get the second leg out of Miami.
Louise Bishop, 66, first made the ride from Walterboro, S.C., to New York City in 1944. Then she settled in Brooklyn, found work in a factory, and has been making the 800-mile bus trip for holidays and funerals ever since.
This time, she bought a $189 round trip ticket at the last minute to see her Aunt Mabel, who is in a nursing home.
"After awhile it begins to get to you," she said as the darkness rolled past, explaining that recent surgery kept her from sleeping, and the enforced idleness sometimes made her feet swell. But she quickly added: "This isn't a bad ride. I shouldn't say that."
 
Sharing More Than a Ride
 People on a bus bestow surprising gifts.
Air travelers will occasionally exchange business cards. Where but on a bus, however, would a traveler find Carolyn Beachem, 32, offering up a can of Libby's Potted Meat Food Product.
People on a bus get excited.
"I love it, man!," said Mohan Naraine, 37, a Guyanese man from Queens who marveled at the peacefulness of the Carolina countryside. "You don't see these things in New York. So much room! And so quiet!"
People on a bus like 3-year-old Joey Vega have adventures. He said: "I like the bathroom. You pull the lock and the big light comes on. It's fun."
This was not a widely shared view.
"That restroom stinks," said the fourth driver of the run, Alan Bratton, as he neared the Florida line, handing a can of air freshener to a passenger.
There are also the lines. Greyhound is hoping to start a reservation system next year, but for now bus travel is a first come, first served proposition. The line for the 1:35 A.M. bus heading south from Washington had 76 people, including an elderly woman who had been standing for two hours complaining of high blood pressure. When the bus pulled in, 20 seats were available.
If the overflow is large enough, as it was that night, Greyhound tries to run an extra bus. If not, passengers must wait for the next departure.
And bus travel is not always as cheap as it sounds. Greyhound's round trip fare from New York to Miami is $203. Amtrak's $155 round trip is cheaper, but it is filled far in advance. Last weekend, American Airlines had a $338 round trip with limited availability and a $1,000 full fare on coach.
 
Decrease in Passengers
 Greyhound, which has enjoyed a monopoly since it acquired Trailways in 1987, does offer an advantage to families with children under 11: each child riding with an adult who pays full fare travels free in the month of December.
With the recession on, business is off. Greyhound emerged from bankruptcy proceedings only last month, and has been operating with replacement drivers since its unionized drivers went on strike in March 1990. Liz Dunn, a company spokeswoman, said Greyhound expected 460,000 passengers from Dec. 20 through Dec. 26, down by about 10 percent from last year.
Amtrak expects about 505,000 passengers to ride trains over the same period, virtually unchanged from last year. The American Transport Association predicts that 11.2 million Americans will take airplanes, a figure that is up by about 1 percent.
"We think we are getting some passengers who would normally travel by air," Ms. Dunn said, but added that it was not enough to replace those "who are choosing not to travel this year because of the economic conditions."
Ms. Dunn said that as air travel had become more affordable, Greyhound had come to serve an increasingly poorer clientele. Marketing surveys show that 46 percent of its passengers earn less than $15,000 a year and 19 percent earn more than $35,000.
 
$99 One Way, Anywhere
 This year, Greyhound offers a $99 one-way ticket anywhere, with a seven-day advance purchase.
Mason Smith grabbed it in Brunswick, Me. Estranged from his parents, Mr. Smith, 18, said he supported himself by washing dishes in a diner while he finished high school. The school librarian packed him a bag of Christmas cookies and he promised his coach he would return in time for the next basketball game.
Then he stuffed the remainder of his cash reserves -- a $5 bill -- into his sock for safekeeping, and headed off to surprise his grandparents in St. Petersburg, Fla.
Twenty-four hours later, he was bouncing along in the Carolinas, weary but content, in the back row alongside his new friend, Ray Titone, a 28-year-old truck driver on his way to visit his fiancee in Savannah.
They both wore rings in their left ears and billed caps.
"Me and him got so much in common," said Mr. Smith, a touch of amazement in his voice. "He likes Syracuse; I like Syracuse. He likes the Hurricanes, I like the Hurricanes. It's quite funny."
Savannah brought an exchange of addresses, and Mr. Smith rode the next 12 hours alone, hoping that his grandparents would be happy enough to see him to pay for a plane home.
He arrived at 3:00 A.M., and was met by his grandparents' neighbors, he said the next day by telephone. Too excited to sleep despite 40 hours of travel, he waited at their house until 7:00 A.M., sneaked next door and rang the bell.
How did it feel to be there?
"Great. Paradise. Can't describe it," he said.
Then he added what might be called the bus traveler's motto. "If I had to do it again," he said, "I would."

HEADLINE: END OF THE SOVIET UNION;
GORBACHEV PLANS TO GIVE UP POWER TO YELTSIN TODAY

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Driven out by political rejection and the plummeting economy, Mikhail S. Gorbachev plans to announce his resignation as President of the defunct Soviet Union on Wednesday in a television address to the nation, his office said today.
Immediately after, the launching codes for the Soviet nuclear arsenal are to be handed over to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, according to the transition plan for shifting Soviet power to the new Commonwealth of Independent States. 
 As Mr. Gorbachev prepared to leave the Kremlin, officials of the new commonwealth order met to discuss the horrendous economic problems they share. They also discussed the risks attending the plan of Russia, the dominant republic, to begin shifting Jan. 2 to consumer price rises and other painful free-market necessities. [Page 6.]
 
Fighting in Georgia
 At the same time, civil conflict raged for a third day between the Government and opposition in Georgia, one of the former Soviet republics, not in the commonwealth, whose volatile political vendettas formerly were policed by union troops.
Tonight, as the red Soviet flag still fluttered brilliantly in the Kremlin floodlights, a retrospective on Mr. Gorbachev's career was shown on state television.
His successor as the former empire's dominant politician, President Yeltsin, told reporters that in their transition meeting on Monday, Mr. Gorbachev had given him Kremlin archive documents, including some drawn up under Stalin.
These documents were described in a Tass press agency report as "casting light upon crimes against people of the Soviet Union and other countries." No other details were offered.
 
11th Hour Warnings
 Mr. Gorbachev was still warning in eleventh hour news interviews against "huge perils" he sees along the commonwealth path being taken by 11 former Soviet republics newly dedicated to independence within a loose association.
But the Soviet leader appeared ready to accept his fate, which will include as retirement benefits his 48,000-ruble annual salary. This is luxury remuneration under old Communist standards but, under the degraded economy of Mr. Gorbachev's reform years, it translates to less than $10 a week in the hard-currency world market to which the new commonwealth aspires.
The 60-year-old Soviet leader, whose reforms made possible the freely shifting politics to which he must now succumb, will also receive a Moscow apartment, a dacha retreat, two cars and 20 bodyguards. His pension, worked out by Mr. Yeltsin and other onetime rivals within the party who now are the leaders of the commonwealth, includes free care at the elite hospital system left as one of the legacies of the Communist hierarchy that Mr. Gorbachev once dominated.
The benefits, however, amount to so much hemlock to Mr. Gorbachev. The occasion is a bitter defeat as he retains worldwide respect for his daring nuclear disarmament initiatives even as he is shunned at home by the remnant republics of the union he fought to maintain.
Mr. Gorbachev personally thanked and shook the hands of his Kremlin staff today in cleaning up his affairs. "I wish you all great happiness and success," he told them.
After six years and nine months in office, Mr. Gorbachev seemed reflective in one newspaper interview about some of the critical might-have-beens of his tumultuous, liberating, crisis-bedeviled tenure.
"I expected a blow from the party's conservative circles and, therefore, I kept them close," he said in explaining why the conspirators who seized him last August in the hard-line coup that failed included his closest military and cabinet advisers. "Work among them was also under way," he told the Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper. "This is the reason why I did not quit the post of the party general secretary, whose tight grip I always felt."
 
Dismisses Coup Speculation
 Mr. Gorbachev dismissed the likelihood of another military coup attempt.
"The people will not accept it and the army will not move to stage it," he told the newspaper. "The sole danger emanates from the street, if disaffected people will take to the street and political prostitues and profiteers will prod them to action."
On the eve of his resignation, which Mr. Gorbachev termed "unavoidable"in one of his interviews, financial ministers tabulating the Soviet Union's debt announced that it would grow another five billion rubles this month and top the trillion-ruble mark for the year. The republics in the new commonwealth must still decide how to apportion this debt, which they have agreed in principle to honor.
A thicket of economic problems awaits the new commonwealth. Russia, the richest and largest republic, already is exercising the upper hand in seeking to set the currency and other free-market policies that the weaker, poorer republics, such as the central Asian nations, will find hard to resist.
A final session of the Soviet Parliament was attempted but had to be adjourned overnight after deputies could not bring themselves to vote immediately on a resolution stating that the "the U.S.S.R. as a subject of international law and geopolitical reality has ceased to exist."
"This is treason and betrayal," complained a deputy, Vavil Nosov.
The commonwealth went forward nevertheless, with republic prime ministers meeting here to prepare for a meeting of their presidents on Dec. 30 in Minsk, Byelorussia, the commonwealth headquarters.
That session will take up major differences that remain on creating a common military defense command and on controlling the Soviet Union's nuclear weapons. Kazakhstan, one of four republics with strategic missiles on its soil, is balking at a Russian proposal that all strategic missiles be moved to Russia. It has agreed in the meanwhile that President Yeltsin should be the individual controlling the nuclear button but with the assent of all four republics needed for a decision to launch.
The new politics and jealousies of the commonwealth are already becoming clear. President Leonid Kravchuk of Ukraine complained that the West, in paying special attention to Russia, was slighting the other independent and equal states that had arisen with the fall of the union.
 
Death Toll Climbs
 In Georgia, the civil conflict continued to take lives and rip up the government center in the heart of Tbilisi as President Zviad Gamsakhurdia's defenders engaged in artillery, machine gun and rifle battles with rebel national guard units.
The death toll estimates varied from 30 to 80. The rebels, led by former Prime Minister Tengis Sigua and a national guard officer, Tengis Khitovani, claimed they were blocking the advance of reinforcements and would maintain the attack until the resignation of Mr. Gamsakhurdia.
Opposition critics complain that by introducing press censorship and other restrictions, Mr. Gamsakhurdia has been building an autocracy. But the Georgian President, whose popularity with the masses was established in a landslide election victory last spring, says his critics are merely coup plotters and opportunists.
President Yeltsin said that he had rejected President Gamsakhurdia's plea for a meeting because the Georgian leader had committed human rights violations in using military force against the Ossetian minority in their nationalism drive.
Commonwealth members, Mr. Yeltsin said, wanted to create "volunteer inter-republic security forces" in order to avoid appealing to the United Nations to handle such troubles.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 28.40 More, To 3,050.98

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday in an abbreviated pre-holiday session, led by large industrial stocks still being swept along by the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cut on Friday.
The Dow Jones industrial average added 28.40 more points to its 88-point leap on Monday, adjourning for Christmas at 3,050.98. The Dow traded far higher during the day, at one point momentarily surpassing its record close of 3,077.15, set on Oct. 18. 
 The rally of the last three days demonstrates growing confidence in an eventual economic rebound, traders said. Since Friday, the Dow has gained 136 points, or 4.7 percent.
 
S.& P. 500 at a Record
 Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another blue-chip indicator and perhaps a more meaningful gauge since it tracks a larger number of big issues, set a record closing high of 399.33, up 2.51 points. Its previous record, 397.41, was set Nov. 13.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was surprisingly heavy for the short session, which ended at 2 P.M., as shares changing hands totaled 162.4 million, compared with Monday's 229.2 million. Stocks that gained completely overwhelmed losing ones for the second day this week. There were 1,275 issues up and 437 down.
In the bond market, Treasury issues posted slight gains in a shortened session. [Page 56.]
John Brooks, a technical analyst with Davis Mendel & Regenstein in Atlanta, said people had to be impressed with the market. "Any thoughts of Monday's market being a flash in the pan was thrown out the window yesterday," he said.
"The advance and decline issues, again over 1,200 on very strong volume, indicates that prices may yet go higher," he added. "It is apparent that everyone is responding to this year's discount rate cuts, particularly the one percentage point cut on Friday."
 
Broader Indexes Higher
 The Big Board composite index rose 1.52 points to close at 219.65, while the American Stock Exchange index gained 2.52 points for a finish at 373.45. Trading on the Nasdaq was equally active as the composite jumped 5.66 points, to 549.56.
Smaller issues were also subjected to heavy buying by investors, as evidenced by the Russell 2,000, the barometer of small companies, up 1.65 points, to 179.55.
Early in the session, stocks rose in active trading as investors continued to get caught up in the enthusiasm generated by Friday's cut in the discount rate and by a stronger than expected rise in the November durable goods data, which traders say bodes well for economically sensitive issues.
The morning's gains were fueled by carry-over buying from Monday's session and a stronger-than-expected durable-goods report that suggested there might be life in the manufacturing sector after all.
 
Report on Durable Goods
 According to many economists, the 1.2 percent rise in durable goods hints of an economic recovery on track, but some say that while the trend is basically up, it may not be enough to guarantee a solid recovery.
The market first successfully tested the 3,040 level on the Dow, after failing for the first hour of trading to break that ceiling firmly. The next test was at the 3,060 level on the Dow.
The Dow managed to break through the 3,060 level for about an hour before retreating at the end.
Mr. Brooks believes that the next test for the market will be at 3,100 on the Dow, a big pyschological barrier.
 
Basic Industries Lead
 Traders said that if one did not believe that the large industrials were leading the market all they had to do was look at companies like Allied Signal, up 3, to 41, and Alcoa, up 2 1/4, to 64 1/4, to be convinced. One trader said, "You can't get any more basic than those two."
Elsewhere in the market traders said Cray Computer stock tumbled 5 1/8 to close at 5 3/4 in heavy trading after the company lost its only customer. Late Monday the company said Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory had decided to switch to another computer system that was being offered by a competitor, Cray Research, which is not affiliated with Cray Computer. Yesterday Cray Research stock rose 3 1/4, to finish at 37 3/4.
Merck, which said on Monday that it and SmithKline Beecham had signed a letter to co-promote a new anti-cholesterol drug called Zocor or Simvatatin, rose to a high of 161 before finishing at 158 7/8, off 1 1/8.
Traders said Steven Kernkraut, an analyst with Bear, Stearns, increased his rating on Charming Shoppes to a "strong buy" from a "buy," saying that the shares are undervalued compared with other retailers. The stock rose 1 7/8 to close at 22 5/8.
Hilton Hotels rose 3/4, to 38 1/8, as Steven Eisenberg, an analyst at Oppenheimer, reiterated his long-term buy recommendation, noting that lodging fundamentals were slowly becoming better and that business at the company's gaming tables improved greatly this year.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
 For all the talk of a "white collar" recession, it is blue-collar workers who have been hardest hit by the current economic slump, losing more jobs and enduring far higher rates of unemployment. Five times as many blue-collar jobs have evaporated, and jobless rates are more than twice as severe. [Page 1.] 
 New orders for big-ticket durable goods rose 1.2 percent in November, to $124.7 billion, the second straight monthly rise, the Government said. Some economists took it as an encouraging sign, while others cautioned that durables orders often swung wildly from month to month. [47.]
Some Manhattan retailers said business was strong, while several others said profits were flat to down from last year. Nearly all agreed that consumers are buying less. [47.]
 
Companies
Oil refineries can meet the deadlines specified by the Clean Air Act for less-polluting gasoline and diesel fuel, according to an independent consulting firm. The conclusion stands in stark contrast to the protests of oil companies. [47.]
Some of the biggest U.S. airlines confirmed that they are raising most domestic fares by 2 percent on Jan. 3. [47.]
Walt Disney's rules on employee appearance and hygiene for Euro Disneyland, near Paris, have caught the company in a legal and cultural dispute. [1.]
General Motors acknowledged that it paid merit bonuses and increased the pay of much of its salaried work force just before it announced widespread job rductions and plant closings. [50.]
 
Business Technology
Gathering the sun's energy in space and beaming it to earth for electric power is a long-harbored dream, but technology is moving toward that goal. [49.]
Microwave beaming of electricity from space seems destined to find smaller-scale applications fairly soon. [49.]
 
International
Secretive Maxwell units in Liechtenstein appear to hold a key to the unresolved question of how much money the family still has -- and whether there might be more for debtors to recover. [47.]
 
Markets
Stocks rose sharply in an abbreviated session, led by large industrial stocks still being swept along by the Fed's rate cut. The Dow rose 28.40, to 3,050.98, and the S.&P. 500 set a record. [47.]
Uncovered Nasdaq short sales fell 2.2 million, or 0.7 percent, to 332.5 million for the month ended Dec. 15. [53.]
The Treasury bond market closed with slight gains, rebounding from a spate of selling early in the day. [56.]
Cattle prices soared, continuing a rally that started on Monday, and wheat prices hit contract highs. [57.]
The dollar rose in a quiet session as the market took its cues from a Government report on business orders to factories. [57.]
 
Today's Column
America's frustration with Japan's growing trade surplus is threatening to boil over again. Economic Scene. [48.]

HEADLINE: Wilder Runs on a Record of Achievement, and Thwarted Efforts

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Like all Presidential candidates, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder says he is running on his record.
In one sense, it is a record of huge achievement, the record of a man who overcame poverty and racism to become the first black ever elected governor in the United States. 
 But it is also the record of a man who, once he took office here in January 1990, found himself trapped in a national economic recession that thwarted his efforts to start new programs and squeezed much of the life from existing ones. In the two years since, he has been forced to spend most of his time searching for ways to keep the state budget out of the red.
 
Leader on the Job
 Unlike senators and other politicians who run for President, a sitting governor who becomes a Presidential candidate brings along a detailed, and current, record as head of state. Voters can look at that record and find clues about his abilities as an administrator, a delegator and an initiator, as well as his skills in attracting qualified aides.
Critics contend that Mr. Wilder's record for his first two years as Governor is one of few accomplishments. They say he has spent too much time out of state running for President rather than running the Commonwealth of Virginia.
Mr. Wilder counters that although he inherited an economic mess that was one of the worst in the nation and although he has lacked the money for new programs he has more than met the greatest governing challenge of his first two years.
He boasts that at a time when at least half of the nation's other governors were raising taxes to balance budgets wracked by the recession, he has avoided a tax increase and has balanced his state's budget by shifting money and cutting staff and programs.
"He was dealt a lousy economic hand right from the start," said Robert D. Holsworth, a political scientist at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond. "But he played it like the fiscal conservative he claims to be and he gets credit for that. He cut and trimmed and he didn't raise taxes. Now he can legitimately make that part of his campaign credentials."
 
Budget Turnaround
 Virginia ranks near the bottom in the amount it taxes its residents, but Mr. Wilder says the burden is still too heavy. He said in an interview that cuts and trims are the best solution to a deficit and that he managed to cut and trim "without slicing through any arteries."
So proud is Mr. Wilder of his achievement, in which he erased a $2.2 billion deficit in a $26 billion budget, that he is making it a centerpiece of his run for the Presidency. He contends that the way he has handled Virginia's budget troubles is a good measure of his governing skills.
"The Democratic Party won't win the White House again until it stops offering up tax-and-spend nominees," he said.
In the first two years of his four-year term as governor -- under Virginia law he cannot run for a consecutive term -- Mr. Wilder has frequently promised better schools, better health programs, better housing and better highways. He has also called for greater efforts to control crime and drugs and to improve opportunities and jobs for blacks and women. So far he has had to put almost all of these initiatives on hold.
But when it comes to assembling an administration, he is credited with attracting a record number of blacks and women to state positions.
A third of his appointees to major executive and administrative jobs have been women, including two of eight Cabinet members. He has appointed two blacks to his Cabinet and filled one of every four top executive and administrative posts with a black.
Mr. Wilder was required by the Virginia Constitution to balance the budget. To make up the predicted deficit of $2.2 billion, he shifted some of the revenue from the lucrative state lottery, assumed higher revenue from state investments than was originally forecast, cut construction money for dozens of programs, froze the budgets of most agencies, let attrition and layoffs reduce the state work force and canceled raises for state workers. He cut his own salary of $108,000 by 2 percent.
The effect of the budget cuts is now being felt across Virginia in the form of crowded schools, abandoned highway projects, fewer services for the needy and government paychecks that have not kept up with inflation. Yet unlike some states, Virginia has not had to close schools for a few days to save money, nor are its main highways in bad shape. So far, only several hundred workers have been laid off.
Generally, state agencies had been scheduled to receive budget increases of 11 percent this year to keep up with inflation and population growth. But Mr. Wilder's cuts reduced that to 8 percent. The size of the work force was frozen at about 100,000 employees through attrition and several hundred layoffs. Increases in welfare payments were also frozen, as were services for the mentally impaired.
Capital expenditures were sharply scaled back, particularly work on a major new highway running through the state's undeveloped rural areas south of Richmond.
Mr. Wilder cut state aid to local schools by 5 percent, or about $100 million, resulting in more crowded classrooms and a decline in school construction. Teachers salaries were also frozen. He cut $50 million in aid to the state's college system, one of the best in the Southeast. Many schools then raised tuition to offset the loss.
Mr. Wilder's critics predict that most of the budget-balancing steps will come to haunt him in 1992 when he will again face declining revenue as well as rising costs and demands for state services. They say he will not be able to turn to those same areas for further savings without harming many programs and agencies. This time, they say, he will be forced to accept a tax increase or new bond issue.
"He's used a lot of smoke and mirrors and it's going to catch up with him," said Steve Haner, the director of the Republican caucus in the Virginia Legislature. "As starters, you can't rob Peter to pay Paul with lottery revenues and you can't assume higher returns on investments when interest rates actually are declining."
 
More Cutting Proposed
 The Governor said he was aware he might face new budget problems. Though he is running on his anti-tax record, he indicates a willingness to trim even in that area, if necessary.
"We've got more hard times coming in Virginia," he explained. "I would rather squeeze the budget harder than raise taxes, and I will propose no raise. But I would not automatically veto a new tax bill from the Legislature, so long as it had genuine bipartisan support."
There is some talk of an increase among legislators, who are fully aware that Virginia ranks 43d in the proportion of personal income that residents pay in state and local taxes.
The Wilder record for the past two years on the environment is not as easy to read.
He has opposed efforts to weaken laws designed to clean up the Chesapeake Bay and has been a leader in the national effort to restrict the use of an agricultural insecticide, carbofuran, which harms birds. But under his administration, the state has been criticized by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for not cleaning up toxic waste at a state fuel depot.
"He has taken some good environmental stands," said David W. Carr Jr., the chief lawyer for the Southern Environmental Law Center, an advocate group based in Charlottesville. "But over all he hasn't been as aggressive as we would have liked."
Mr. Wilder's budget-balancing effort has cost him considerable support among Virginia voters.
According to several independent polls, his approval rating is around 25 percent, an unusually low figure for any governor. In fact, as he begins his quest for the Presidency, he is the most unpopular chief executive of Virginia in modern history.
The budget cuts are a main factor but far from the only factor.
Poll takers say another significant factor is Mr. Wilder's decision to run for President, which many voters view as an abandonment of Virgina at the moment when the state most needs his full attention. Several newspaper columnists in the state have proposed a bumper sticker that would proclaim "Wilder for Resident," since in 1991 the Governor has been out of state more than one of every three days.
Mr. Wilder has acknowledged that one of the risks in a Presidential candidacy is that it can detract from work back at the state capitol.
But Mr. Wilder plunged in anyway, as has another governor, Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "I will not let my candidacy hurt my state," Mr. Wilder promises.
 
Effect in Fall ElectionsUnease in State
 Mr. Wilder's declining popularity was a factor in this fall's state elections. Hardly any Democratic candidates asked the Governor to campaign for them. Republicans campaigned as much against Mr. Wilder as against their opponents, some successfully. Republicans gained eight seats in the 40-seat State Senate, cutting the Democratic margin to four seats.
One re-election victim was an important Wilder supporter, State Senator J. Granger MacFarlane of Roanoke.
"He did what he had to do and history will show it was a real feat of leadership," Mr. MacFarlane said of the Governor's performance over the past two years.
Thomas R. Morris, a University of Richmond political scientist, offered a broader view.
Mr. Wilder inherited what may have been the worst economic situation any Virginia Governor has faced in almost 50 years, Mr. Morris said in an interview. He credited Mr. Wilder with making hard decisions to balance the budget but added that those decisions, in a sense, made it easier to judge the Governor by what he had not done than by what he had done. Then he concluded:
"His greatest strength thus far has not been governing but winning elections with historical biracial coalitions. He is the only black in all of American history who has managed to get himself elected governor of a state. Nothing he has done in the 22 months since has transcended that victory."

HEADLINE: Homelessness Rises, but Not as Issue

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Early in the 1988 New Hampshire primary campaign, almost every Democratic Presidential candidate accompanied Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston on a visit to a city-run homeless shelter. Once there, the Democrats talked with residents of the city's Long Island Shelter while television cameras captured the candidates' concern and beamed the images to neighboring New Hampshire.
So far in this campaign, no candidate has visited the center, though all have invitations from Mayor Flynn. Only one, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, has expressed an interest in making such a visit. 
 Whether sleeping on grates or in temporary shelters, or panhandling from shoppers, the homeless seem to be everywhere this holiday season, everywhere but in the campaign for the Presidency, where they are referred to only obliquely, if at all.
 
Putting an Issue to Sleep
 The virtual disappearance of homelessness from the political debate is a study of how changes in the economy, perceived shifts in public opinion and a new mix of candidates can drive into the shadows what had been a major issue. And the issue of homelessness is receding even as the problem appears to be getting worse.
"A number of people are concerned about the homeless issue, but not many people down in Washington are effectively dealing with it, particularly the candidates for President both on the Republican and Democratic sides," Mayor Flynn said.
Homelessness would more likely have been raised in the campaign if the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who often spoke about the problem in 1988, had become a candidate. Mr. Jackson, who said recently that he planned to sleep in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House, on Christmas Eve to dramatize the plight of the homeless, declared this week that he was "disappointed" that the issue had received so little attention .
So far in the current campaign, no Democratic candidate has issued a position paper addressing homelessness; the subject rarely comes up in speeches and it was not mentioned by any candidate in the nationally televised debate almost two weeks ago.
The only candidate who has put forward a plan for dealing with the homeless has been Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist who is challenging President Bush in the Republican primary in New Hampshire. Mr. Buchanan has suggested that the homeless be forcibly removed from the streets each night and taken to temporary shelters, or jailed if they persist in trying to sleep in public.
"In places like New York, a lot of these homeless folks are stabbing people to death," Mr Buchanan told reporters this week. "I think they shouldn't be wandering the streets frightening women and people."
 
'There Is Great Concern'
 While the candidates seem to be saying little about homelessness, it is perhaps the nation's most visible poverty issue. For the most part, problems of the poor, including welfare dependency, births out of wedlock, hunger and lack of health care, exist as abstractions or television images for many. But everyday the homeless confront people who live and work in cities.
"People that I talk to in my city and opinion polls show that there is great concern by the American public about homelessness on the street," said Mayor James Scheibel of St. Paul, who is chairman of the United States Conference of Mayors Task Force on Hunger and Homelessness.
But that concern is not always for the well-being of the homeless.
Some advocates for the homeless acknowledge that a backlash against the homeless in recent years is growing. They say that cities as widely situated as Santa Monica, Calif., Atlanta and New York have placed restrictions on begging or sleeping in public.
The number of the homeless is expected to rise as the nation's economy continues to falter, though precise numbers are difficult to come by. A 1991 survey of 28 cities that was made public two weeks ago by the mayors conference showed that requests for emergency shelter had risen by an average of 13 percent over the last year. Mr. Scheibel said it was the ninth consecutive year in which the survey had found an increase in such requests.
Yet, although the number of homeless people has gone up, the economic and political climate for a public discussion of the issue has undergone drastic change since the last Presidential campaign.
In the robust economic climate of 1988 the issue for Democratic candidates was fairness and compassion for people at the bottom of the economic ladder. They tried to position themselves as candidates who would not forget about the poor and the homeless.
But with the recession increasingly eliminating or threatening the jobs of blue-collar and white-collar workers, Democratic candidates are talking about the problems of the middle class rather than those of the homeless.
"Last time, homeless people were so illustrative of what was happening in the economy," said Lorraine Voles, spokeswoman for Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, one of the Democratic candidates this year. "This time, the economy is so much worse, you can take your pick -- white collar out of work, blue collar out of work. There are so many other groups that illustrate the economic woes."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
AMERICA'S frustration with Japan's growing trade surplus is threatening to boil over again. The common complaint, echoed both in Congress and the Administration, is that the cheap dollar is not curing the United States trade deficit.
But contrary to the politicians' claims, argues Paul Krugman, an international economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology whose views were published recently by Science magazine and the Institute for International Economics, the cheap dollar has worked better than people realize. He calls stagnating productivity, not the trade deficit, America's top economic problem. 
 The United States trade deficit, correctly defined as the current account deficit, which includes tourism, shipping, financial and other services as well as merchandise, has all but disappeared. The deficit, as Mr. Krugman puts it, went up and down the hill with the dollar in the 1980's, only more slowly.
In the first half the 80's, the dollar appreciated by an astounding 50 percent. The trade deficit, which had bobbed around zero for most of the 60's and 70's, zoomed to 3.6 percent of the gross national product in 1987, two years after the dollar started falling from its zenith.
"By early 1991," Mr. Krugman writes, "about half of this divergence from the historical norm had been eliminated, due in large part to a sharp rise in the dollar value of the yen and the mark."
As it turns out, Mr. Krugman's estimate for the 1991 current account deficit, which he put at 1.7 percent of G.N.P., or roughly $80 billion, was too pessimistic. The deficit is likely to come in at one-half of 1 percent of G.N.P., around $25 billion this year, according to economists at J. P. Morgan.
The Morgan economists expect the deficit to be around $30 billion next year. Relative to the size of the economy, that is not far above its level in the late 70's, when the dollar's value relative to the currencies of its trading partners was roughly where it is now.
Japan's surplus also shrank sharply from 1988 to 1990 -- from a peak of 3.6 percent of Japan's G.N.P. in 1987 to 1 percent last year, its long-term average. The fact that Japan's surplus has been swelling this year neither portends a major reversal, Mr. Krugman said, nor is it a sign that Japan's economy does not respond to price changes.
Part of last year's decline in Japan's surplus was because of one-time events. Japanese exports are fetching higher prices because the yen has strengthened since last year, and the prices of oil and other imported commodities have fallen.
Japan is expected to run a small surplus, about 1 to 2 percent of G.N.P, most of the decade, economists say. One reason is that its surplus with the United States, its largest trading partner, is not likely to vanish.
Why hasn't everyone noticed the extent of the adjustment? Partly because most people focus on the merchandise trade deficit, which is still close to $70 billion, rather than on the broader current account balance. It is also that many focus on the absolute size of the deficit, not its size relative to the economy.
"What people don't realize is that a $70 billion deficit today is the same as a $30 billion deficit in 1980, Mr. Krugman said.
Two important conclusions emerge. One is that the current United States deficit -- as well as the Japanese surpluses -- are economically sustainable. Japan's foreign assets are no longer exploding, Mr. Krugman said, and neither is the United States' foreign debt. "It would take generations to run up a Latin America size debt," he said.
The second conclusion is that having nearly balanced trade is not the same as having a clean bill of economic health. The deeper problem, that Japanese investment is outstripping that in the United States, remains. Productivity in the United States, which determines how fast living standards can rise, is rising only about 1 percent a year, against 4 percent in Japan.
United States productivity began to stagnate in the early 1970's, long before the nation began running huge trade deficits. Now that those deficits have dwindled, productivity is still stagnating. "The whole point is that flexible exchange rates guarantee that any country, no matter how poor its productivity performance, will find something to export," Mr. Krugman said.

HEADLINE: Haitian Refugees in Cuba Will Get Gifts a Day Late

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In the wake of a mushrooming barrage of criticism and embarrassing publicity, the Air Force will play Santa's helper to thousands of Haitians held at a United States refugee camp in Cuba, the Department of Defense said today.
But organizers of the drive to bring some holiday cheer to 7,000 Haitian refugees said the Defense Department's decision came too late to get 16 tons of toys and clothing donated by New Yorkers to the camp by Christmas. They said the gifts, collected through a drive on two black-owned local radio stations, will not be delivered until Friday because of delays by officials in the administration of President Bush.. 
 "Like the Grinch, he almost stole Christmas," said Percy Sutton, chairman of the board of Inner City Broadcasting, which owns the two radio stations that organized the relief drive. "The Bush Administration has had some reservations. And because of those reservations we can't get down there before Christmas."
The last-minute announcement of the airlift, which followed consultations between senior Defense Department and White House officials, comes amid growing criticism of the Administration's policy toward the Haitian refugees being held at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay. Some prominent blacks have characterized the Government's earlier decision to send the Haitians back to their homeland as racist.
 
Santa or Scrooge?
 Administration officials have "to decide whether they want to be Santa Claus or Scrooge," Charles Moses, an aide to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said before the Defense Department announced its decision to have an Air Force plane land at Guantanamo.
Spokesmen for the Administration and the Defense Department denied that the decision and its timing were caused by public criticism, an example of which was the Page 1 headline in The New York Post -- "Scrooge!" -- over a photograph of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. "We weren't embarrassed into doing this," said Judy Smith, a White House spokeswoman. "We're doing this because it's the right thing to do."
Defense Department officials said the delay in arranging the flight was unavoidable, caused by the unusual circumstances of the airlift request. "It just didn't follow normal procedures so it took a little longer," said Major Bryan G. Whitman, a spokesman for the department.
Three weeks ago, Guantanamo was visited by a group headed by Mr. Sutton, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat who has been a leading advocate of efforts to obtain asylum for the 7,000 Haitians being held in a tent city at the base. The Haitians were plucked from boats by Coast Guard cutters after fleeing their homeland, which has been torn by violence in the wake of a September coup that overthrew the elected Government of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The Administration, in arguing for forced repatriation, insists that the Haitians are economic refugees. But leaders of the Haitian community in the United States and their supporters say the refugees are fleeing political persecution and should be given asylum.
Mr. Sutton said that, during his group's visit to the camp, the Haitians and military commanders asked them to help bring some Christmas cheer to the refugees. "They're the most bored people on earth," he said in a telephone interview. "They have no entertainment, nothing to do. So we decided to do something nice for them."
That led to appeals for toys, clothing and canned goods, broadcast on Inner City's radio stations, WLIB, 1190 on the AM dial, and WBLS, 107.5 on the FM band. Response, Mr. Sutton said, was "overwhelming," with the public and advertisers donating to what became known as Operation Hope. At least 16 tons of goods were dropped off in two weeks at seven collection sites, he said.

HEADLINE: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Post Steeper Drop in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The declines in yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts gained momentum in the seven days that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that specializes in covering interest rates.
"The downturn will continue," said Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher. He added that he expected cuts to continue into February, now that the prime lending rate has been cut by a full percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent, by most leading commercial banks. The prime rate serves as the benchmark rate for loans to many small businesses and consumers.
 
Widespread Cuts
 In the last week, the New York commercial banks cut yields on money market accounts by an average 23 basis points, to 3.88 percent; on three-month certificates by 28 basis points, to 3.76 percent, and on six-month certificates by 32 basis points, to 3.85. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 At savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 4.67 percent, down by 11 basis points, for money market accounts; to 4.52 percent, down by 20 basis points, for three-month certificates, and to 4.70 percent, also down by 20 basis points, for six-month certificates.
In the case of money market accounts and three-month certificates, the largest cuts were made by the Bank of New York, which lowered its yield by 52 basis points on its money market accounts and by 62 basis points on its three-month certificates.
 
Midlantic Moves Ahead
 Midlantic Banks Inc., based in New Jersey, was the leader in cutting the yield on six-month certificates, which it lowered by 75 basis points.
The Monitor, based in North Palm Beach, Fla., said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area had been cut by 32 basis points, to 4.08 percent, on money market accounts, and by 26 points, to 4.18 percent, for six-month certificates.
In addition, The Monitor said its index for the week for regional banks outside the New York area was 4.34 percent for money market accounts and 4.37 percent for certificates of deposit.
By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 3.75 percent, compared with 4.14 percent a week earlier, while the six-month bill averaged 3.85 percent, compared with 4.19 percent the previous week.

HEADLINE: Laughter Greets Gifts For Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
After Santa left, they just hugged the red and green packages, courageously planning to save them until Christmas Day. But when Duane Ortega made the big bold move by opening his present on Monday, pandemonium erupted.
"Aiee! Aiee!" the 32 toddlers screeched in the East Harlem gymnasium. The wrapping paper seemed to moan before their relentless efforts. Four-year-old Vladimir Ramos, his face ablaze with wonder, pulled the cord on his new See N' Say. "I am a cow," it said. "I go moooooo." Then he jumped aside because Mark Moreno, 5, was coming by with his new yellow truck. Mark took a pit stop by Albert Ramierez, 3, who was staring blankly at a box containing an orange horse named "Pokey." 
 "That's Gumby's friend," he told him in Spanish.
The youngsters, who are part of the Children's Aid Society's Head Start program, are among the thousands of children who received Christmas and Hanukkah presents this year through the seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "For the majority of these children who come from such very poor homes, these are the only gifts they'll get," said Dallas-Lee Dexter, the program's director. "We also give them coats, hats and gloves, but at this time of year few things are as essential as that toy or doll that lets them know they are not forgotten."
 
Fewer Toys This Year
 The Children's Aid Society said it has collected 15,000 gifts this year and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies said it will give away about 16,000 presents. Still, the agencies report that there are not enough to go around. "We had 31,000 requests for those 16,000 toys," said Jackie Ewbanks, who runs the federation's toy drive.
Reflecting the tough economic times, Marianne Chierchio of the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn said toy donations have fallen sharply this year. She said one company that in the past had provided enough gifts to fill several rooms gave barely enough this year to fill an office, and that a bank that traditionally collects hundreds of toys at its various branches got only four this year.
To try to make their supply come a little closer to demand, the charities said they buy gifts with money from the Neediest Cases. Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases has enabled millions of people -- through two world wars, through the roaring 20's and the Great Depression, and through the booming 80's and the slumping 90's -- to find that best part of themselves and lend a helping hand to New York's sick, poor and disabled. Last year, at least 15,580 individuals and organizations contributed a record $4.4 million to the Neediest Cases.
The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected is passed on to the seven charities. The money buys food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without clothes. It also helps provides holiday gifts for the city's poorest children.
 
A Mother's Smile
 Often, the presents provide as much relief to parents as joy to children. "My kids are asking every day 'Why isn't Santa Claus coming?' because the tree is empty of presents," Margaret Estremera explained Monday, as she was picking up presents from Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Airlines Set A 2d Round Of Fare Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Some of the biggest United States airlines confirmed yesterday that they were raising most domestic fares by 2 percent as of Jan. 3, the second round of price increases within a week.
Last Thursday, the airlines said they were raising their bargain advance-purchase fares, which require Saturday-night stay-overs, by $20 round trip. The increases are part of a strategy to stem the multibillion-dollar losses they have reported as a result of the Persian Gulf war and the recession. In the slowdown many carriers cut fares to stimulate travel. 
 "As you're well aware, the economy hasn't been kind to the airlines," said Jim Faulkner, spokesman for Northwest Airlines in Minneapolis. "All of us are looking at ways to make sure our prices reflect our true costs."
United Airlines initiated the latest fare increase, and disclosed it on Monday by inserting the new pricing structure into the computerized reservation system that enables travel agents to book tickets on all airlines. Northwest, American and Alaska Airlines followed suit.
Lynn Martenstein, a spokesman for Chicago-based United, said yesterday, "We are doing it because it reflects an adjustment of fare levels to more compensatory pricing."
With the increase, a full-fare Chicago-New York round-trip coach-class ticket, for example, will rise from $838 to $854. A 21-day advance purchase discount fare from Minneapolis to New York will go from $358 to $365.
At Alaska Airlines, a Seattle-based carrier that flies primarily to the West Coast, officials said they had been pondering a fare increase for several days and decided to match United's increase when they learned of it.
"Have you looked at the economic situation in the airline industry?" said Harry Lehr, the airline's vice president for planning. "That's why we're doing it. We need the money."
It was unclear when or whether other big airlines would match the latest increase, but there were indications that they would. At Houston-based Continental Airlines, which instigated the fare rises last week, a spokesman, Ned Walker, said the carrier was undecided, but a 2 percent increase "seems to make sense."
At Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines, a spokesman, Robert Harper, said a decision would be made later in the week. Officials at Trans World Airlines did not return telephone calls.
The airline industry lost a combined $5.9 billion in 1990 and 1991. Three of the weakest carriers financially, Eastern, Midway and Pan Am, perished in bankruptcy court this year. Continental has been operating under bankruptcy protection for much of 1991, and T.W.A. is expected to seek that status sometime next year as part of an arrangement with its lenders.

HEADLINE: Ho-Ho-Hum at Finer Stores, Too

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
A Christmas Eve walk through some of Manhattan's toniest shopsfound store owners still hoping for a Merry Christmas, but acknowledging that they were not having a watershed day.
And while some retailers maintained that business was strong, several said profits were flat to down from last year. Nearly all agreed that individual consumers were buying less. 
 At James Robinson Inc., the silver and antique jewelry dealer that has been on 57th Street since 1953, its owner, Edward Munves Jr., said business was flat this year. But, echoing some other luxury-goods sellers, he added that the real shock wave hit in 1990, when business fell about 15 percent.
"That was the year we lost Wall Street," said Mr. Munves, whose family started the store in 1912. "We lost a lot of lawyers and advertising people who we just did not see at Christmas."
Mr. Munves believes the 1990's will be different. "People should be saying this is normal. The 1980's were not normal," he concluded, aware that his company was not likely to match 1989, its superstar year, very soon.
Mr. Munves said that one thing that had helped his store was that people who bought silver and antique jewelry often felt they were acquiring something of long-term value. "They are changing one set of assets for another," he said.
Mr. Munves said that sales this year might end up even or slightly ahead of 1990. "But instead of buying a $700 place setting" to give as gifts, he said, customers now "are giving two or three pieces" that total $300.
Of course, there are winners in this recession, too. "We have a bankruptcy lawyer who has bought tremendously," Mr. Munves said, without divulging names. "There are always people making money in any economic downturn."
At E.A.T. Gourmet Foods, the restaurant and takeout store on upper Madison Avenue, Eli Zabar, whose family owns the Zabar's food store on Broadway and who started E.A.T. in 1973, said that for the first time he could remember, customers were asking for discounts.
"I can't remember ever seeing that before," Mr. Zabar said, as he watched his staff wrap the store's trademark extravagant gift baskets.
Roughly 90 percent of the gift baskets, which cost between $50 and $350, are bought by corporations. Most of those accounts cut back this year, according to Mr. Zabar. "Almost everybody is giving less," he said. "Even when they can afford it, the culture is anti-heavy buying."
Mr. Zabar said that six years ago, E.A.T. started a gift shop next door. He said that volume at the shop was up, in part because the store had shifted its focus from high-priced gifts like furniture priced at $300 to much less expensive items. Store executives now hope that buyers will buy several low-priced items, but that their cumulative bills will be higher.
Mr. Zabar said the move had succeeded and that volume was up. But he conceded that profits were flat. The labor costs of handling more small items is higher than for fewer more expensive items, he said.
 
Absence of the Wealthy
 Allen Milstein, who publishes The Fashion Report, an industry newsletter, said that store owners were "on prayer rugs, wearing them thin praying for customers." He estimated that business on 57th Street was off 20 percent to 25 percent from last year.
"The difference between this recession and the 1930's is that the Ginger Rogers and the Fred Astaires have stopped shopping," he said, referring to the very wealthy, who can afford to buy, but are not.
At jewelers like Harry Winston Inc. on Fifth Avenue, both the recession and the luxury-goods tax are hurting business, according to Ronald Winston, who runs the company.
Mr. Winston says that even those who can afford to buy are waiting until the tax on items over $10,000 is repealed. 'It's decimating the business," he said.
But for Harry Winston, the problem extends beyond the United States. Mr. Winston said that while business in Japan was great -- "A customer walked in recently and bought a $1 million necklace. I haven't see that in New York." -- the recession has hurt the jeweler in Europe.
"When America sneezes, Europe catches cold," he said, quickly correcting himself: "No it gets pneumonia."
 
Sales Per Customer
 At the Hermes fashion boutique on 57th Street, best known for its leather goods, Chrys Fisher, the president and chief executive, said that overall volume was up this year compared with 1990, though he gave no figures. But Mr. Fisher noted that sales per customer were down. Several retailing experts believe that sales in high-end stores may be off as much by 25 percent per customer.
Hermes not only carries $3,000 handbags, it has quietly adopted a strategy of offering lower-priced items too, like $35 bottles of cologne that permit customers to spend relatively little and take home a gift with the Hermes cachet.
If customers are catching on to such bargins, it is not only at Hermes. Diana Brainerd, a financial relations executive, noted that when she was shopping at Saks Fifth Avenue several days ago, the line for gift certificates seemed particularly long.
"Lots of the people were without shopping bags," she said. "I think they were giving gift certificates because they would rather have the money spent after Christmas, when people expect better sales."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The recession and growing fears about the economy have affected upscale retailers, too. Eli Zabar, whose E.A.T food shop supplies gift food baskets for a number of corporate customers, spoke of smaller orders and flat profits this Christmas as he inspected gift baskets being prepared for delivery. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: November Durable Goods Orders Up 1.2%

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In a sign that some economists took as encouraging, new orders for big-ticket durable goods rose 1.2 percent in November, the second straight monthly rise, the Government said today. But other analysts cautioned that durables orders often swung wildly from month to month.
Still, the announcement by the Commerce Department surprised many analysts, both because the rise, to $124.7 billion, marked the first back-to-back increase since April and because many economists had forecast a drop of more than 1 percent. 
 New orders for durable goods -- items like cars, refrigerators and computers that are expected to last more than three years -- are a significant barometer of manufacturers' views of the future. An increase in orders can signal gains in both production and jobs.
Orders for military goods -- always a volatile statistic -- plummeted 38.9 percent last month after a 50.3 percent jump in October. Excluding the military area, durable goods orders increased 4.1 percent in November.
But another element of the report, unfilled orders, which is also considered a predictive indicator, fell last month. Some pessimistic analysts chose to stress the decline in backlogs, while others saw grounds for optimism in the higher orders figures.
"Over all, if you look at these numbers and the low, low interest rates, it looks like what we might be seeing here is the beginning of a turnaround," said Michael L. Penzer, vice president and senior economist at the BankAmerica Corporation in San Francisco.
Mr. Penzer said the most heartening figure was November shipments of nonmilitary goods, which rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $118.5 billion.
"That's very positive for fourth-quarter gross domestic product," he said, referring to the Government's measurement of goods and services produced within the nation's borders.
But the decline in unfilled orders, to $491.4 billion, was the third in three months. The decline could signal a reduction in production lines and jobs. Indeed, the Labor Department reported three weeks ago that manufacturers lost 33,000 jobs during the month and the Federal Reserve found that industrial production had fallen four-tenths of 1 percent.
"We know the economy is going to hell in a handbasket and this is more support for that," said Richard D. C. Trainer, chief economist of the Bank of Tokyo in New York. "As these unfilled orders continue to slide, it doesn't look good for future production and hiring."
On Monday, the Federal Reserve reported that consumer spending had risen by seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, even though income levels declined from October. Consumer spending is expected to be off this month from the usual high levels associated with the holiday season, one factor that prompted the Fed last week to slash interest rates boldly.
 
Revised October Figure
 November's 1.2 percent gain in orders for durable goods represented a $1.4 billion increase, compared with a revised 2.6 percent increase in October orders that had previously been reported as a 3 percent gain. In September, orders had dropped by 4.3 percent.
The latest figures showed an across-the-board increase in demand for most products, with the limited exception of instruments and stone, clay and glass products.
Shipments of durable goods, a coincident indicator, increased in November by seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $127.2 billion, reaching their highest level since October of last year.
Transportation equipment orders were up 3.9 percent last month after an 11.2 percent increase in October. A significant increase in aircraft orders made up for lackluster orders for new cars and for military ships and tanks.
