HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Edge Up in Light Trading

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Treasury bond market closed with slight gains yesterday, rebounding from a spate of selling early in the day.
Securities dealers said the sharp rise in bond prices that had occurred since the Federal Reserve's sharp cut in short-term rates last Friday was the catalyst for some selling yesterday by traders who wanted to lock in profits. 
 By 1 P.M., when most trading stopped in the American market, the 8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2021 were offered at 105 3/4, up by 2/32 point, to yield 7.51 percent. On Thursday, before the Fed's move, the bellwether 8 percent issue was offered at about 104, to yield 7.65 percent.
 
Some Early Selling
 The Commerce Department's report yesterday of a much stronger-than-expected 1.2 percent increase in orders for durable goods, items expected to last three years or more, spurred some early selling. Despite the gain, most of which reflected aircraft orders, analysts at Reid, Thunberg & Company, an advisory firm in Wilton, Conn., said, "The trend of the U.S. economy remains flat."
Because many traders and investors are absent during the holiday season, analysts do not expect much movement in bond prices for the next several trading sessions.
"I expect we will mark time for a while and see what Congress does," said one trader whose firm does not allow public comment. He said continued increases in bond prices and declines in yields would be most likely if Congress refrained from any new spending or tax cuts.
Inaction by Congress would help the bond market, the trader added, because it would reduce the chances of a brisk economic recovery that would revive credit demands and put upward pressure on rates.
Although the fear of inflation and the volatile prices of long-term bonds have kept their yields from declining as much as short-term interest rates in the last few years, investors are under increasing pressure to buy bonds rather than shorter-term notes if they want to keep earning the interest rates to which they became accustomed during the 1980's.
Yields on intermediate-term notes have now fallen below the rates assumed in many corporate and government pension plans. The new 6 1/8 percent Treasury notes due in five years, for example, were offered yesterday at 100 17/32 , unchanged on the day, to yield 6 percent. At last week's auction, the five-year issue sold with an average yield of 6.24 percent, down from about 7 3/4 percent for comparable issues a year ago.
In the short-term market, rates rose modestly, as banks and securities dealers prepared for the turmoil in financial markets that often occurs in the last days of the year.
Traders do not expect overnight bank loans to trade at the same 100 percent rate reached on last Dec. 26, but they expect the abnormal flows of money around the end of the year could cause overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market to trade around 13 percent on Dec. 31 and on Jan. 1.
The rate is high enough temporarily to keep interest rates on securities and deposits due in one month higher than those due in three months or more. For example, one-month Eurodollar deposits were offered yesterday at 5 percent, while three-month deposits were 4 1/2 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises in Slow Day And Gold Falls in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in a quiet pre-Christmas session as the market took its cues from a Government report on business orders to factories.
Gold prices slipped on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with gold for current delivery falling 20 cents, to $359.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $359.25 an ounce, down 25 cents. 
 Dealers said the dollar got support from the Commerce Department's report that factory orders for durable goods rose 1.2 percent in November. Along with a revised 2.6 percent advance for October, it was the first two-month rise since the spring.
The report raised hopes that the economy might be getting stronger and that further interest-rate cuts would not be needed. Higher American interest rates make dollar-denominated investments more attractive and bolster the dollar.
Simon Fischer, vice president of foreign exchange at ABN-Amro Bank in New York, said dealers had expected a decline in the durable goods numbers.
Dollar traders were particularly encouraged that orders for nonmilitary capital goods, excluding aircraft, were up 1.1 percent.
The dollar also got support from Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.40 points yesterday on top of a gain of 88.10 on Monday.
The dollar also closed marginally higher in trading overseas. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8760, from $1.8775 late on Monday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.8735, less expensive than late Monday's $1.8820.
The Japanese yen fell against the dollar in Europe and New York. The dollar settled in London at 127.30 yen and in New York at 127.55 yen, higher than Monday's 126.65 yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.25 yen, down 1.07 from Friday's close. The Tokyo market was closed on Monday for a holiday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5205 German marks, up from 1.5130; 5.1995 French francs, up from 5.1715; 1.3490 Swiss francs, up from 1.3437; 1,152.00 Italian lire, up from 1,147.00, and 1.16055 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15785.
In London, gold was quoted at a late bid of $359.80 an ounce, up from $359.40 late on Monday. In Zurich, gold rose 30 cents, to a closing bid of $359.80. Overnight in Hong Kong, gold fell 12 cents, to $359.65.
Silver gained. On the Commodity Exchange, it rose to $3.903 an ounce, from $3.899 late on Monday. In London, silver rose 2 cents, to $3.91.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle Prices Extend Rally; Wheat Up on Export Hopes

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 24

 BODY:
A surge in the stock market sparked optimism for a turnaround in the economy and sent cattle prices soaring today in a shortened session. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.40 points, to 3,050.98, after an 88-point leap on Monday.
Meanwhile, recent declines in the dollar prompted hopes for a revival of the wheat export business, sending prices to their highs for the current futures contracts. 
 On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures continued a rally that started on Monday, as traders were wary of going into the Christmas holiday on the short side of the market.
Beef-packing companies have been buying cattle only sporadically in the last two weeks, instead preferring to curtail operating hours and trim beef production, analysts said.
But the slow buying may have caught them short of cattle for pending production, which could prompt greater sales activity at higher prices in the primary cattle feeding areas of the Plains states.
Live cattle futures for February delivery jumped 1.025 cent, to 70.900 cents a pound.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, prices for soft red winter wheat extended a rally. Traders banked on the theory that the recent skid in the value of the dollar would make wheat more attractive to foreign buyers.
Tight wheat supplies in American bins further fueled the gains, traders said.
"The last time we had a supply situation in wheat as tight as it is now was in 1973 when prices went to more than $6.00," a grain trader said.
Wheat for March delivery rose 2.25 cents, to $4.00 3/4 a bushel, but earlier in the session set a contract high of $4.01.
Trading on both exchanges ended at 1 P.M., Eastern time, for the Christmas holiday and will return to normal hours on Friday.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, energy futures closed mixed in an abbreviated session.
February crude oil futures gained 19 cents to close at $18.97 a barrel. January unleaded contracts closed 0.94 cent higher, at 53.93 cents a gallon, while January heating oil contracts slipped 0.05 cent, to 51.79 cents, erasing early gains in late activity. The market also closed at 1 P.M., Eastern time.
The spot December gold contract fell 20 cents, to $359.10 an ounce, on the Comex.

HEADLINE: New Tradition For Kwanzaa: Marketing, American Style

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
THE wind whistled Christmas as it toyed with scores of shoppers in Harlem who braved low temperatures and high prices to carry out a modern holiday ritual of giving and getting. There were expensive video games to buy, dolls to overdress and lines to wait in to see a department store Santa.
But at the same time in Harlem, as in thousands of other American neighborhoods in which blacks live, another wind blows strong this yuletide season. It is Kwanzaa, an elegantly African and aggressively American holiday of affirmation. 
 For 25 years blacks, cautiously and few in the beginning, have been looking to Kwanzaa to help them rededicate themselves to their teachings, culture and traditions. During Kwanzaa, eggnog gives way to ginger beer; caroling finds harmony with African chants, and Christmas stockings dangle next to the royal designs of West African kente cloth.
"It's not a substitute for Christmas," said Dereca Blackmon, a young black film maker who is making a Kwanzaa documentary. "It is not a substitute for anything. It's a movement to something."
Kwanzaa was established in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga, now chairman of the black studies department at California State University at Long Beach. In formulating the holiday, he drew on themes he found to be common in many celebrations and rites in African societies.
Starting on the day after Christmas and ending on the first day of the new year, Kwanzaa, which is an East African word meaning "the first fruits of the harvest," is greeted by millions of blacks as a time for reflection, rejoicing and appreciation. And particularly in recent years, it has also become a time for Kwanzaa business.
Earlier this month, 30,000 people attended a three-day, noon-to-midnight Kwanzaa Holiday Expo '91 at Manhattan Community College that included 200 black vendors. Two floors of the college were transformed into a bustling African bazaar. The air was filled with an audio rainbow of African, African-American and Caribbean music and was thick with the spicy scents of foods for sale. Many of these foods were of the down-home Southern variety, but some were dishes from Africa and the Caribbean.
But it was the merchandise -- all with a decidedly Afrocentric flair -- that moved the throngs of people through a maze of stalls and stands. Products at the expo were exhibited or sold under names like Unity Gallery, In the Black Products and Ujamaa Now. A Hoboken, N.J., coffee company with new African partners has just introduced a Kwanzaa blend that proudly proclaims itself "100 percent African coffee." And Zahmu, a Philadelphia singer-songwriter recently released a single record titled "It's Kwanzaa Time."
"Black people are becoming more educated about themselves," said Yusuf Muhammad, who was doing a brisk business at the fair, marketing African-print neckties and casual clothing under the name Kareem Enterprises. "They want things that say something positive about their heritage." Throughout the New York City, at nearly every stand, shop and storefront in which there is black commerce, there are products aimed at the black consciousness and pocketbook.
Still a far cry from anything approaching the commercialism that grips much of Christmas, the marketing of Kwanzaa has pleased some people who say the holiday is getting wider exposure. The giving of modest gifts, like ethnic toys, books by or about blacks and anything in kente cloth, is as much a part of the holiday's ritual as the feast on the eve its final day.
But it has not pleased everyone.
A black woman with an 8-year-old daughter called in recently to WLIB radio's morning talk show that broadcasts live from the Apollo Theater to voice the uneasiness she was feeling about what she described as Kwanzaa's "creeping commercialism."
The woman, who did not give her name, said she believed too much emphasis was being placed on its "buying aspect."
"A lot of us left the whole Christmas vibration because of that buying," the woman said.
Dr. Karenga, the founder of the holiday, who was a guest on the show, told the woman that she posed a "delicate question." But, he said, he didn't believe the economics generated by the holiday were overshadowing its cultural contributions. "One of the major problems we had is pretending we're not in America," he said.
Dr. Karenga, who was in Manhattan as a guest of the Expo '91 promoters, said that commercialism was as American as the Fourth of July and that blacks should not shrink from being entrepeneurs, even if it meant producing kente-cloth wrapping paper and Kwanzaa greeting cards. One of the principles of Kwanzaa is to encourage what is known as ujamaa, or cooperative economics; in other words, blacks working together to create and maintain their own stores and shops for the good of the entire community.
"I don't think blacks are afraid of the commercialization of Kwanzaa so much as the co-opting of Kwanzaa," said Eric V. Copage, an editor of The New York Times Magazine and the author of "Kwanzaa: An African-American Celebration of Culture and Cooking," recently published by Morrow.
Mr. Copage said that blacks might have a reason to be fearful, too, "considering the omnivorous nature of capitalism and the fact that few blacks have their hands on the throttle of that engine."
Just how many blacks actually celebrate the holiday is hard to determine. But by most estimates it poses a tempting market. Cedric McClester, the author of "Kwanzaa: Everything You Always Wanted to Know but Didn't Know Where to Ask" (Gumbs & Thomas, 1985), wrote that more than 13 million Americans observed Kwanzaa in 1984, a figure that includes people who celebrate Kwanzaa as well as Christmas. Current numbers are difficult to come by.
But there is anecdotal evidence that an increasing number of blacks in the United States, and even some abroad, are either participating in Kwanzaa or giving it an approving nod. Dr. Karenga, who travels throughout much of the United States, said he has not visited a city that does not hold a Kwanzaa celebration of some kind.
In New York, the Mayor's Office of African-American and Caribbean Affairs announced a citywide schedule of events as early as Nov. 5. Already there have been a special concert of traditional African music, an education forum on multiculturalism and an museum exhibition of African handicrafts in honor of the holiday. A series of Taste of Kwanzaa food celebrations took place in all five boroughs.
Still to come are numerous Kwanzaa observances scheduled in homes, churches and civic centers this week and next. At the American Museum of Natural History, a three-day Kwanzaa festival begins on Friday, complete with a re-created African village and authentic African foods.
On Monday, the museum's Hall of Ocean Life will be the scene of the Kwanzaa 25th Anniversary Gala Celebration, from 7 to 11 P.M. (tickets, $100; (212) 219-4510) featuring dancers, a magician and a dinner with foods from northern and southern Africa. The kente-print-trimmed invitation suggests "Afrocentric attire preferred, or black tie."
Mr. McClester has helped produce several of New York's largest Kwanzaa celebrations, including the Expo '91, through the New York Urban Coalition, for which he is a spokesman. "I have consciously tried to market the holiday," he said. "Kwanzaa needed to be sold. It was in the confines of a few nationalists."
His latest contribution is the creation of Nia Umoja, a kindly, Afrocentric Santa Claus figure who gives youngsters not only gifts but direction as well. "It is ludicrous to just do Santa in blackface when there are black characters children can relate to," he said.
But more important than Santa substitutes, market plans and black vendor shows, Mr. McClester said, are the Nguzo Saba, which are the seven principles of the holiday, the essence of Kwanzaa.
For each of the celebration's seven days, a candle is lighted and placed in an African-styled holder called a kinara. Each candle represents a principle that gives focus to Kwanzaa and, according to some of its observants, gives blacks a code for survival.
Like the word Kwanzaa itself, the principles all have Swahili names: umoja (unity); kujichagulia (self-determination);, ujima (collective work and responsibility); ujamaa (cooperative economics); nia (purpose); kuumba (creativity), and imani (faith).
"Kwanzaa is a philosophy for life," said Dr. Karenga. "It is a value system."
Zahmu, a Philadelphia singer-songwriter who also works as a computer trainer, said he read a book by Dr. Karenga about Kwanzaa and found himself, in almost a dreamlike state, setting the holiday's spirit to music.
With an investment of $3,000 of his own money he has produced 500 copies of the single "It's Kwanzaa Time." Zahmu's cheery lyrics have combined to help make the song something of a hit in black bookstores in Philadelphia and some inner city schools in the area.
"Nguzo Saba, they are the principles to be our guide," he sings to a pulsating urban beat, "a formula for families to keep the children strong, to build a mighty nation, take us where we belong."
"What is clear is that Kwanzaa is an irresistible holiday," said Kinshasha Holman Conwill, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, which held its annual pre-Kwanzaa celebration and workshop last week with African storytellers and artisans.
"It is more than an alternative," she said. "It is central to many people and to their holiday celebration. And even for those who do not consciously celebrate it, it is an important cultural touchstone."

HEADLINE: (Christmas) Greetings From the President of the United States

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
WHITE HOUSE followers have never been short of material, from handwritten notes to taped conversations to the tell-all memoirs of erstwhile Presidential confidants.
But Presidential Christmas cards have rarely been seen by more than their 150,000 or so recipients and, of course, their families and friends. Now Presidential holiday sentiments are open to public view at an exhibit of official White House Christmas cards, dating from 1961 to 1990, at Sunnyside, the historic home of Washington Irving here in Tarrytown. The exhibit is sponsored by Historic Hudson Valley, a preservation association. 
 "What's interesting about these cards is that they reflect what else was going on at the White House at the time," said James Archer Abbott, assistant curator of the Historic Hudson Valley group, at a recent lecture on Presidential Christmas cards.
For instance, the Christmas card sent by Ronald and Nancy Reagan in 1981 may shed light on the web of power in that Administration. The card, a reproduction of a painting by Jamie Wyeth, commissioned by the Reagans, was a night scene of the White House. The only light burning in the Presidential mansion is in Mrs. Reagan's dressing room.
In other years, Mrs. Reagan emulated Mrs. Kennedy's choice of cards showing White House rooms that illustrated the Administration's restoration efforts.
Mrs. Kennedy's influence on Mrs. Reagan extended beyond her choice in Christmas cards, Mr. Abbott said. "When Mrs. Reagan asked who did this or who bought that piece of furniture, if the answer was Mrs. Kennedy, she always wanted to do it the same way," he said.
As much as the Reagans paid homage to the Kennedy style, the Nixons did not. "The Nixons were responsible for dismantling most of what Mrs. Kennedy had done with the White House," Mr. Abbott said. "All they needed was to be told that something was done by Mrs. Kennedy and they did just the opposite."
The Christmas cards of Richard and Pat Nixon were also a departure from those of previous Democratic Administrations. They sent what might have been the most austere cards in White House history.Instead of using the snow scenes tranquil landscapes favored by the preceding Johnson Administration, the Nixons used Presidential portraits from the White House art collection, grandly presented with engraved gold overlays, in a cardboard folder.
"It seems odd to have a somber-looking Lincoln wishing you a very merry Christmas," Mr. Abbott said. The Nixons didn't sign their cards, but used a gold seal that read, "The President and Mrs. Nixon, Christmas, 1970." The three Republican Presidents since the Nixons followed that style; Democratic Presidents and wives used full names cards.
President Nixon also broke with tradition by mailing his cards in faux-velvet envelopes; the standard envelope had been plain white with a gold Presidential seal. "The velvet envelopes disappeared along with Mr. Nixon," Mr. Abbott said.
Throughout history, all Presidents sent out informal Christmas greetings of some kind. It wasn't until the Eisenhower Administration that the official White House Christmas card appeared. The cards were originally intended to be sent to White House staff members but are now sent to more 9,000 people. A smaller card goes to more than 160,000 friends and supporters of the President.
At first, Dwight D. Eisenhower included an informal photograph of himself and his wife, Mamie, sitting on the South Lawn of the White House. Later, President Eisenhower, who painted as a hobby, started to send reproductions of his own watercolors depicting favorite scenes in Europe and Colorado.
The first card sent by President John F. Kennedy and Mrs. Kennedy showed ducks swimming across the White House pond, symbolizing that for the first time in 50 years, young children were in the White House. The ducks belonged to their daughter, Caroline.
Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter's cards were reflective of their informal style. Their first Christmas card was a simple pen-and-ink drawing of the White House.
Later Carter cards focused on nostalgic 19th-century scenes, which were also popular with Gerald and Betty Ford. "This was no doubt an attempt to take people's minds off the recession and difficult economic times during that period," Mr. Abbott said.
The cards sent by Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson were usually scenes with two little girls -- representing their daughters, Lynda and Luci -- frolicking in the snow with their dogs. One card was a night scene of the White House decked in holiday greenery as guests arrived for a Christmas party. "They represented the Johnson White House as the center of Texas hospitality, which was the case not only at Christmas but during their entire Administration," Mr. Abbott said.
On their cards, the Johnsons also wrote a long greeting, effusive with warm wishes for the holiday season. Their last card included a postscript on their Administration and their regret over its conclusion. "It expressed their sadness about leaving the White House," said Mr. Abbott. "They wanted people to know that they did their best and joined the rest of the country in wishing for a peaceful new year. It was a nice way to go out."
George and Barbara Bush's cards have all been upbeat in tone. Their 1991 card features the most festive room in the White House, the Yellow Oval Room. This jewel-like room, with gilded furnishings and bright yellow wallpaper, is in the family's living area and is reserved for the most celebratory occasions. The Bushes' previous cards included a view of the decorated South Portico of the White House in 1989 and the Oval Office complete with Christmas tree and presents in 1990.
The Christmas card exhibit will be on display at Sunnyside, on West Sunnyside Lane, Tarrytown, through Dec. 31. Admission is $3. The cards come from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Nash Castro. Mr. Castro is a director of the White House Historical Association and a trustee of Historic Hudson Valley.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
New Hat for Wenders: Daffy and Lighthearted

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
When it comes to making movies, Wim Wenders is not your average wild and crazy guy. Antic fun for its own sake is not something for which he is known. The German-born director's more recent films ("Wings of Desire," "Paris, Texas," "Hammett") have been schematic and dour, with hard surfaces encasing centers as soft as chocolate-covered cherries.
For much of its nearly three-hour running time, "Until the End of the World" is something else, a daffy, eccentric road movie that pursues its own inscrutable lighthearted logic through 15 cities in 8 countries on 4 continents. 
 "Until the End of the World" has less to do with Mr. Wenders's own early road movies, "Alice in the Cities" and "Kings of the Road," than it does with the kind of elegantly slap-dash improvisations that Jean-Luc Godard once made with (and for) the incomparable Anna Karina. Though it is set in 1999, the movie looks like a mint-condition artifact of the 1960's.
As the film opens, a narrator informs us that an Indian nuclear satellite has swung out of orbit and threatens to crash to earth to destroy all life. The rest of the world is in a panic but, the narrator goes on, "Claire couldn't care less."
Claire (Solveig Dommartin), who sometimes wears a black wig that emphasizes her resemblance to the young Anna Karina, is waking up in a strange place, as has been her habit of late, this time at a chicly decadent party in Venice. On the drive back to Paris, Claire becomes the willing bag lady for a pair of loutish but gentle thieves who have just robbed a bank in Nice.
She agrees to transport the loot to Paris in exchange for a one-third cut. She then picks up Sam Farber (William Hurt), an American on the run, though from whom or what Claire doesn't know. Again she couldn't care less. She's attracted to Sam for his sad eyes and his taste in music, an audio tape of songs sung by pygmy children in Cameroon.
Claire's patience is tried when Sam makes off with a large part of her money. She tells her lover, Gene (Sam Neill), a novelist based in Paris and a man whose patience is inexhaustible, that she's going after Sam.
In this fashion the chase begins: Sam, followed by Claire, followed by a bounty hunter (Sam is said to be involved in industrial espionage), a private detective, the bank robbers and Gene, who wants to protect Claire and who, in passing, provides the film's narration. Money for travel arrangements never seems to be a problem. By 1999, the recession is clearly over.
The trail leads from Paris to Lisbon, Berlin, Moscow, Beijing, Tokyo and San Francisco. It finally ends with all the characters in the Australian outback, where what amounts to another movie begins. This one involves Sam's father, Henry (Max von Sydow), a brilliant scientist, and Sam's blind mother, Edith (Jeanne Moreau).
In his underground laboratory, Henry has been perfecting a camera that will allow the blind to see. It records the impulses of a brain when it contemplates an image, then feeds those impulses into the brain of the blind person, providing the equivalent to sight. More than that, though, it's a device for "sucking out the dreams" of almost anybody.
It is one of Mr. Wenders's more comic conceits that Claire and the others who participate in the doctor's experiments quickly become dangerously addicted to the taped images of their dreams. They lie listlessly about the outback all day, not eating or tending to fundamental hygiene. Instead they either dream of dreams or watch those dreams on portable video monitors.
Each addict isolates himself from the others. It's the video age as a real-life nightmare. Time and the world of commonplace responsibilities have come to a halt. Only Gene continues to believe "in the magic and the healing power of the word."
There's much more to the movie, not all of it logical, much of it absurd and some of it (the last sequence, for example) funnier than even Mr. Wenders may know. The film's center is characteristically squashy.
What is appealing about "Until the End of the World" is its looseness. It appears to be composed of musiclike riffs, and with the exception of Mr. von Sydow and Miss Moreau, nobody seems to take it too seriously until the name of Greenpeace is mentioned. As often happens with Mr. Wenders, it's not always possible to tell whether he knows when he's gone over the edge.
The members of the cast are attractive and, above all, game. Shooting the film in so many far-flung locations in such a short time must have been its own nightmare. The futuristic gadgetry is kept modest in scale so the actors never have to battle the special effects.
"Until the End of the World" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has some vulgar language.
 
Until the End of the World
 
Directed by Wim Wenders; screenplay by Mr. Wenders and Peter Carey, based on an original idea by Mr. Wenders and Solveig Dommartin; director of photography, Robby Muller; edited by Peter Przygodda; music by Graeme Revell; production designers, Thierry Flamand and Sally Campell; produced by Jonathan Taplin and Anatole Dauman; released by Warner Brothers. At the Festival, Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. Running time: 157 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: Christmas Harvest

 BODY:
At most of his stops on this cold morning, the driver, named Lex, picks up bread. The best comes from the Union Square Cafe -- sourdough rye, the kind with thick crust and big holes, still squeezably fresh. A place called Michael's Muffins and the new Au Bon Pain outlet in the Port Authority Bus Terminal offer sweeter items. Muffins, croissants and fruit pastries ought to bring class and taste to the humblest homeless shelter's coffee urn.
Upstate farmers finished reaping their crops weeks ago, but the big season for City Harvest hit its peak this week. The nonprofit group's seven trucks ply daily routes on New York City streets, picking up leftovers from restaurants, corporate cafeterias, caterers, fashion shoots and movie locations -- anywhere a host might overestimate appetites. City Harvest distributes these gleanings to soup kitchens, shelters, food pantries. 
 City Harvest is a good idea, as worthy as it is simple, and it bears continuing witness to two disturbing facts: A shocking number of people go hungry in the city each day, even as a shocking amount of food goes to waste.
This service, in operation since 1982 and supported mostly by private financial contributions, collects and distributes more than 10,000 pounds of food daily, or nearly four million pounds a year. Yet it has no warehouse. More than 100 receiving agencies easily consume all that the trucks bring each day. When 50,000 pounds of potatoes arrived from Maine, City Harvest gave them all away in hours.
Toward noon, the truck pulls up before the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church in Chelsea. In the social room, volunteers are stringing Christmas lights above long tables set for the noon meal. Lex enters, a huge sack of bread slung Santa-like over his back, to warm greetings from a minister and a director of the community dinner program. In the back of the truck the load of bread looked massive. In this room it looks small indeed: 120 people are expected for dinner.
City Harvest's managers believe the need can be matched by a so-far untapped supply of leftovers. They had no trouble signing up the 260 regular commercial clients whose bounty now fills their trucks, along with canned goods collected by schoolchildren and other groups. The list continues to grow despite the recession.
These weeks are the busiest, as office parties and holiday feasting yield up uneaten hors d'oeuvres, cold cuts and baked goods. Hunger, however, takes no holiday; and every day, throughout the year, City Harvest offers the people who need it most a taste of Christmas.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Checking It Twice

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
It turns out that the sweat socks President Bush bought on his recent shopping spree weren't Christmas gifts for Barbara Bush. Mr. and Mrs. Bush have a longstanding policy of not exchanging Christmas presents.
"They have everything they need, and anything they want they can get," explained Anna Perez, the First Lady's spokeswoman. 
 I, too, am blessed with everything I need. So I don't want any gifts. But my wife says I ought to give "gifts" in my column "to those less fortunate who make mistakes."
"And don't just think your usual way," she continues, warming to the task. "Go beyond male marginalia -- a little of this and that. Escape from the prison you males call reality. Make a wish list. Give things leaders should have but don't because of their narrow sense of realism and lack of imagination and courage."
"You don't know what you're talking about," I say. "Your political ideas could only be comforting to Martians."
"Well, it might be that my ideas will get as much reaction as any of the foreign policy columns you write," she insists, bordering on total irrationality.
"You don't know what you're talking about," I say, suspecting she didn't hear this point a moment ago. "I'll lose all my credibility and effectiveness. (Pause.) But O.K., O.K., if you promise never to ask me again, I'll use my first Christmas column, at the end of my first year in this job, to present your list of miracle gifts."
What follow are my wife's gifts plus my commentary in parentheses:
To scientists and economists: the know-how and political backing to plug up the holes in the ozone layer so we don't burn up from ultraviolet rays, and to save the rain forests so we can continue to breathe. No other gifts will mean very much unless this is done, and soon. (I just knew you'd start out with something vaguely reasonable.)
To American automotive executives: the knowledge to make cars as good as Japan's. And part of making a better car is tying executive salaries to profits. If they don't make any profit, they don't get paid so much, or they even get fired. (You're joking. They'll lay off every plant worker before they take big pay cuts.)
To U.S. legislators: the guts to flat-out ban all handguns and semiautomatic weapons. Every moron knows there is no constitutional right to have these weapons. Every moron knows a ban will save lives. Anyone who stands in the way of a ban should fry under the ozone hole. (Most politicians will choose the ozone penalty.)
To all American leaders: the realization that American children are being lost in a tragically inadequate education system, and the dedication to make fixing the system a major national priority. The decline in the ability to read, write, speak, compute and function in the sciences is a national crime. (All right, you've got a point here, but you can't do much without first restoring the American family, fighting teachers' unions, etc., etc.)
To black American leaders: the good sense to stop abstract battles about "rights" and start concentrating on doing something about community safety, education, teen-age pregnancy and the like -- as a lot of blacks are trying to do in their own neighborhoods. (Not likely.)
To their white counterparts: the conscience to confront growing prejudice against blacks and other minorities, and the courage -- despite the political winds -- to help those who need help. (Also fat chance.)
To all who would ban abortion: the decency to remove themselves from other peoples' bodies and beliefs. (They'll put a contract out on you for that one.)
"Look, I'm running out of space," I say.
"Well, I've got more . . . Teaching English as the first and must language, using old army bases for the homeless, a cure for AIDS . . ."
"You've had it," I say.
"The kids have some ideas for gifts too," she says.
"They don't know what they're talking about either," say I, recovering my columnist's voice. "And besides, I've had enough of these Christmas miracles."
"The point is they're not miracles," she says. "The problem is you guys just think they are. Barbara Bush should give George Bush . . . Wait, I'm not finished . . ."

HEADLINE: Burmese Troops Reinforced as Civil Unrest Grows

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The military Government of Myanmar, alarmed by rebel attacks within 50 miles of the capital and large anti-Government demonstrations by students in two cities, is reinforcing troops in several regions to counter widening civil unrest, according to Administration officials and independent experts on the country, formerly Burma.
Neighboring Bangladesh put its frontier forces on high alert today after Burmese troops attacked a Bangladesh Army base, killing at least one soldier, the Bangladesh Government reported. 
 The movement of Burmese troops comes amid reports that Gen. Saw Maung, the leader of the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, may be ill and under pressure from within the junta or from Gen. Ne Win, who ran the country for more than a quarter of a century and is still a power behind the scenes. Foreigners returning from Yangon, formerly Rangoon, have reported that General Saw Maung has suffered some form of breakdown.
Foreign Minister Raul Manglapus of the Philippines said that when he went to Myanmar in early December on behalf of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, he was told that he could not meet General Saw Maung because the junta leader was undergoing surgery.
 
At Religious Festival
 On Saturday, General Saw Maung appeared on Burmese television attending a religious festival in the company of the head of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, whom many consider to be the closest to General Ne Win and the real power in the junta. But General Saw Maung did not speak, and several who saw the program said that it was difficult to make a judgment about his health. Burmese exiles said that the film might have been an old one.
Mr. Manglapus told reporters in Bangkok after his visit that Burmese generals seemed obsessed by fears of "Nuremberg-type trials" for their suppression of a democracy movement in 1988. In 1990, after national elections were won by the National League for Democracy, the military refused to hand over power. Mr. Manglapus said that the generals told him that a civilian government might bring them to court.
There have been reports that General Saw Maung has been troubled by the repeated crackdowns, the isolation to which Mynamar has been subjected internationally and warnings from the few remaining nations giving aid that the junta must improve its record on civil rights.
The most recent such warning came last week from Japan. South Korea is reported to be withholding about $22 million in development projects.The United States has cut all aid links to the Burmese Government.
 
Attacks by Karen Guerrillas
 Josef Silverstein, a Rutgers University historian and expert on Myanmar's ethnic minorities, most of whom have been in rebellion for four decades, said that attacks led by ethnic Karen guerrillas in late November and early December in the Irrawaddy Delta between Yangon and Moulmein were "a major shock" to the military Government, which reported killing more than 570 rebels, indicating large confrontations. The rebels said they killed 500 troops.
"The attacks were organized by Karens, but what came as a surprise was that that Burmans and Arakanese and Mons also joined in against the army," Professor Silverstein said, referring to other ethnic groups in Myanmar. "It took the army by surprise. The military has been particularly vicious since then."
Mr. Silverstein said that the Karens and armed student groups claimed to be moving small units around the country. Students were also active in mounting demonstrations in Yangon and in Mandalay on Dec. 10, the day on which the National League for Democracy's leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, would have received her Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo. She has been under house arrest since July 1989.
Administration officials believe that the recent movement of Burmese troops to the Arakan area near Bangladesh is precautionary. David I. Steinberg, a Georgetown University specialist on Burma, said that the Bangladesh-Burmese border has always been a sensitive one for Burmese governments because the Arakan region has a large Muslim population that has always been thought of as being outside the national mainstream.
 
Many Cross Borders
 Many Bengalis crossed into Burma over the last half century and Arakanese have from time to time fled into East Bengal, now Bangladesh.
The Burmese Army is thus facing Karens in the east and south, Arakanese in the west and Kachin rebels in the northeast along the border with China.

HEADLINE: Without Presidency to Shoot For, Cuomo Takes Aim at Republicans

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In the four days since he announced that he would not run for President, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo seems to have sharpened the vitriol he directs at the Republicans who control the New York State Senate, whom he depicted as forcing him to renounce a presidential candidacy because they would not agree with him on a solution to state's budget woes.
The Governor has stepped up warnings that he will use his veto power to be a player over the coming months in state lawmakers' reapportionment of both their own districts and those of the New York Congressional delegation. 
 And with a view towards next fall's legislative elections, he has employed unusually ominous language to condemn the Senate Republicans for, in his description, their failure to cooperate in mapping out a 15-month plan for solving New York's considerable budget ills.
 
Solution Elusive
 "If they don't do it, they're dead politically," Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference Monday night. "If they don't do the 15 months, they're going down. Why? Because they're going to have such trouble doing the budget in daylight, in April, May, June, July, they're going to get killed when they are revealed to the world. They are going to get badly burned."
The Senate Majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino, has lashed out at many of Cuomo's proposals and appeared to almost taunt the Governor by dismissing the rhetoric. Asked Monday whether he was concerned about the Governor's threatening his party's hold on the Senate, Mr. Marino rolled his eyes and said, sarcastically, "Oh, I'm scared stiff."
By any standard, the bitterness surrounding these talks is remarkable and has shown no signs of letting up, even without Mr. Cuomo's national ambitions dragged in as a complicating factor.
After a month and a half of talking, the Governor and legislators have taken no steps to lessen the combined $5 billion deficit New York faces in its current and future budget.
They have not even agreed whether they should pass a straightforward package of spending cuts to close the $875 million gap in the $30 billion budget for the fiscal year that ends March 31, or devise an elaborate 15-month plan to attack both that deficit and the much larger one in the 1992-93 budget.
A four-hour meeting today between Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders produced no accord.
 
Republicans in Favor
 The 15-month plan trumpeted by the Governor had the obvious attraction of freeing him to hit the campaign trail, and in the days after Mr. Cuomo first floated the idea in mid-November, many of the Republicans who control the State Senate derided it as a gimmick.
But now the Republicans have become the most vocal proponents of the plan, which could blunt the impact of many spending cuts and arguably help them to maintain their 35-26 majority in the Senate when they run for re-election next fall.
Mr. Cuomo, who is not up for reelection next year, and Saul Weprin, the new Speaker of the Assembly, where Democrats maintain a much more comfortable margin, have both expressed considerable skepticism in recent days that the 15-month budget can be agreed to.
Whatever the merits of the longer plan, they say, the Legislature should concentrate now on immediate deficit-reduction.
The inaction here also carries the serious risk that Wall Street rating agencies will step in with their own version of a censure, a drop in the state's credit rating. That could add millions of dollars to the taxpayers' cost of borrowing money and wreak havoc for New York City and hundreds of other localities and school districts whose costs of borrowing are tied to the state's rating.
"I don't want to exercise brinkmanship at the expense of all the localities and the school districts," Mr. Weprin said Monday night after the second of two inconclusive meetings that day on the budget.
Vladimir Stadnyk, managing director for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, one of the major bond rating agencies, said in an interview that he could not give "a date or a time or a place" for when his agency might next issue a formal comment on the state's credit.
But he warned, "I would say that given the lack of progress, it makes me concerned that permanent solutions won't be forthcoming anytime soon, and given that fact, the probability of one-shots, temporary solutions, et cetera becomes greater. If that is the case, then the likelihood of a ratings change increases."
New York State's Standard & Poor's rating has been A since 1989, when it was downgraded from AA minus.
 
Focus on Social Service
 The crux of the dispute remains how to apportion hundreds of millions of dollars of spending cuts. The Senate continues to insist that the cuts focus on social-service programs, which have risen in some cases by nearly 20 percent in the past year, in part because of the recession.
"What's killing the state is that it is overburdened with Medicaid and welfare costs," said Mr. Marino, a Republican of Oyster Bay.
"That is what we've been saying over and over and over again, and apparently they're not listening."
But both the Governor and the Assembly have criticized many of the Republicans' proposals for cutting these services as assaults on New York's most vulnerable citizens.
"When they say cut spending, they mean cut spending on an unemployed worker who has run out of unemployment benefits and who is now on home relief for 60 days," said Mr. Cuomo, referring to the welfare program for people who do not qualify for Aid to Families with Dependent Children. "He should lose his home relief. They call that a legitimate cut in spending."
The Governor and the Assembly have raised the possibility of cuts in the state's $8 billion school-aid budget next year. But Senator Marino, whose party derives its core support from suburban areas where concerns about property taxes have turned school aid into political lifeblood, has backed a budget without any cuts in aid this year or next.
"I said the number was zero," Mr. Marino told reporters on Monday. "Zero. Do you understand that?"

HEADLINE: Accepting the Harsh Truth Of a Blue-Collar Recession

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
For all the talk of a "white collar" recession, it is blue-collar workers who have been hardest hit by the current economic slump, losing more jobs and enduring far higher rates of unemployment. Five times as many blue-collar jobs have evaporated, and jobless rates are more than twice as severe.
More and more, blue-collar workers are facing the harsh truth that though the economy will no doubt come back, their lost jobs are probably gone for good, given the relentless advance of automation and international competition. Last week's announcement by the General Motors Corporation that it plans to shut 21 assembly plants and shed more than 70,000 jobs over the next few years -- only about a third of the cuts will come from the salaried ranks -- was just the most recent indication that the squeeze on blue-collar factory workers will continue. 
 So in places like Haverhill, Mass., a struggling industrial town in the state's northeast, workers are starting to train for new occupations, which offer brighter employment prospects but often pay far less.
 
Losing a Way of Life
 When Robert Harrington, a machine operator, was laid off in July, he lost a $37,000-a-year position and a standard of living he may never recover. After 20 years, his job in a nearby plant that prints and binds telephone directories was eliminated in a cost-cutting program.
By September, Mr. Harrington was not only out of a job, he was also divorced. Instead of a spacious colonial home, he now lives in a two-room apartment with his 15-year-old son, Robert. After he deducts his rent, utilities and other expenses from his unemployment check, Mr. Harrington figures that he lives on $12 a day. These days, a night on the town is a chicken fajita at McDonald's.
Mr. Harrington is studying in a federally financed program to be a paralegal, or lawyer's assistant. If he lands a job, he will earn at least $10,000 less than in his old blue-collar job.
"The money will be less, but I was looking for something that is recession proof," said Mr. Harrington, who is 38. "I don't want to go through this again."
 
Traditional Target for Cost Cuts
 The unemployment rate in blue-collar occupations -- a broad category covering more than 30 million Americans, from skilled craftsmen to manual laborers, with varied talents, incomes and circumstances -- stood at 9.1 percent in November, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. By contrast, the white-collar unemployment rate was 4.1 percent.
Since the peak of economic activity in July 1990, the blue-collar unemployment rate has increased by two percentage points while the white-collar rate has risen by one point. And the number of blue-collar jobs has fallen by more than a million, as desk jobs over all have declined by about 200,000.
Of course, white-collar professionals like bankers and lawyers, who once considered themselves immune to recessions, have also lost jobs. Those layoffs have been well publicized, and many occurred early in the economic downturn, reinforcing the image of the white-collar recession.
"But the traditional American way of cutting costs is to lay off blue-collar workers in times of recession, and that remains overwhelmingly the case," said Erica L. Groshen, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who has studied the impact on workers in various occupations.
 
'Joe Middleman' As Odd Man Out
 In a series of interviews in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Michigan, blue-collar workers, regardless of occupation, expressed the concern that the hold they once had on middle-class status was increasingly precarious. "I am the working man -- 'Joe Middleman,' " said Gary Aldous, an out-of-work carpenter from Torrington, Conn. "But we seem to have an economy now that produces two classes, the rich and the poor. It seems as though this country is trying to eliminate people like me in the middle."
The pinch on blue-collar workers has been tightening for years. From 1980 to 1990, after adjusting for inflation, the wages of blue-collar workers fell by 6.3 percent, while white-collar salaries rose 3.9 percent. "Even a strong economy did not arrest the decline of earning capacity of blue-collar workers," said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
The manufacturing sector, heavily blue collar, suffered more in the 1981-82 recession than this time around. In the previous downturn, 2.2 million manufacturing jobs were lost. Many of the cuts were made in the name of fashioning a lean and newly competitive corporate America that could hold its own against foreign rivals. The streamlining process succeeded in making American producers more vigorous and, recently, manufactured exports have been one of the few sources of strength in the American economy.
Yet the process of squeezing more production from fewer workers is by no means over. This time, companies began shedding factory jobs 18 months before the recession began. Since January 1989, companies have eliminated 1.2 million manufacturing workers. "Manufacturing employment has been hard hit in this recession and for years before," said Thomas Nardone, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
Fewer Auto Sales, Fewer Auto Parts
 Howard Miller, a 53-year-old machinist of Jackson, Mich., went to work for Jackson Drop Forge in 1958, which made forged steel parts for companies supplying the Big Three auto makers. He worked there until the place finally shut down in November 1990, laying off its last 60 workers.
A member of the United Automobile Workers Union, Mr. Miller made more than $10 a hour, and when the forging plant was busy, he made $28,000 a year. But this year, such jobs have been scarce, as the Detroit auto makers are struggling and thousands of companies that supply the auto industry are retrenching again.
Unlike workers for the Big Three, who thanks to their labor contracts collect more than 90 percent of their wages when laid off, workers for the subcontractors have no such safety net. Mr. Miller's state unemployment payments of $226 a week ended last May. His wife, Geraldine, died in June of a prolonged kidney ailment.
Mr. Miller owes the hospital $1,700 and the funeral parlor $2,000. His 1988 Buick was repossessed in July. His house was paid off years ago, but he is behind on his property tax payments. A neighbor helps by cooking him meals and baking him bread. Mr. Miller used to bowl for recreation, but, he said, "I don't do anything anymore."
Mr. Miller worked for two months this fall for a nearby company that repairs industrial machinery. As a part-time worker, he was paid $4.50 an hour, with no benefits. But the weakening economy brought that job to an end in November, and his prospects are bleak. There is very little forging work left near Jackson these days. The few machinist jobs available in the region require applicants who can handle computer-controlled equipment, a skill Mr. Miller does not have.
The auto parts industry, with more than 650,000 workers, is America's largest manufacturing employer. But with increasing competition from Japanese suppliers, which are building new factories in America and hiring young workers, "the domestic parts industry is where the next shakeout is going to be," said Sean McAlinden, a labor economist at the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. "And there's no retraining solution for the older workers in that industry."
 
A Union Carpenter, Trying to Scrape By
 During the 1980's real-estate boom, Ron Richnavsky, a 29-year-old carpenter from Harwinton, Conn., had all the work he could handle. A union carpenter, paid $17.50 an hour plus benefits, he made up to $50,000 a year. In 1988, he and his wife, Linda, bought a $135,000 four-bedroom house for themselves and their three daughters, Nicole, Amanda and Danielle. "At the time, I was making good money," he said. "We thought we could handle it."
Mr. Richnavsky has had some work this year, but not nearly enough. He is about six months behind on his mortgage payments of $1,200 a month, and the bank is threatening to foreclose, he says. His wife makes $130 to $150 a week in her part-time job as a waitress. His unemployment benefits amount to $300 a week. "We can scrape through," he said, "as long as I don't pay the mortgage."
 
Blinded by the 80's
 Like so many other Americans, Mr. Richnavsky admits that he got caught up in the prosperity of the 1980's, assumed it would continue and took on too much debt. "When times are good, you don't think," he said.
Mr. Richnavsky has thought about seeking training in another field -- "some kind of computer training," he said -- but not seriously. As a journeyman carpenter, he is a skilled craftsman who should be in demand when construction activity picks up.
The amount of work may never again reach the superheated pace of the 1980's. The current 30 percent unemployment rates in construction in Connecticut, with the number of hours worked by the state's union carpenters cut by half since 1988, is the biggest slump in more than two decades, says John Cunningham, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners Local 210, representing Fairfield and Litchfield counties. The situation cannot help but eventually improve, Mr. Cunningham says.
 
Seizing the Chance For a Fresh Start
 In the lower Merrimack Valley of Massachusetts, the industrial northeast corner of the state, local government officials are not waiting for the recession to end. They are engaged in an aggressive effort, aided by Federal money under the Job Training Partnership Act, to retrain and find jobs for laid-off workers. Under the local program, the trainees receive unemployment benefits for an extended period of 10 months while they take courses to prepare for a new career.
The lower Merrimack region includes high-tech industries and traditional manufacturing plants clustered around the cities of Lowell, Lawrence and Haverhill, which have unemployment rates of 12 to 15 percent. The well-known companies in the area include American Telephone and Telegraph, Wang, Digital Equipment and Raytheon, all of which have cut their payrolls.
Ellen Reingold worked for 24 years as a electronics production worker for various companies in the region. Her most recent job was a yearlong stint at $10.50 an hour for Raytheon, debugging the electronic circuitry on the Patriot missiles of gulf war fame. But she was laid off last May. Mrs. Reingold, who is divorced with two grown children, was forced to sell her house in Haverhill, unable to make the $1,068-a-month mortgage payment. "It was either sell it or lose it after I lost my job," she said.
In the good years, Mrs. Reingold made $30,000 as an electronics assembler. But in each of the last three years, she has been laid off for months at a time. Seeking a field that offers more steady work, she is studying for a career in medical transcribing, the task of typing up doctors' tape-recorded notes into a computer. Besides word-processing skills, she is studying medical terminology.
Hospitals and clinics have stables of medical transcribers, she has heard. "They say there's a lot of work out there," said Mrs. Reingold, who is 41 years old.
 
From Dying Job to a Healing One
 Some of the retraining students have embarked on striking career changes. Rene Martineau, a burly 48-year-old former printing superviser, is training to be a licensed practical nurse. A nursing job, he says, will pay only about half of the $50,000 a year he used to make. "But printing is a dying industry," he said. "It will all be done by computers soon. And there is a real shortage of nurses."
Others see the recession as an opportunity. Michelle Dryver of Amesbury, Mass., has moved through a succession of mainly factory jobs since she graduated from high school eight years ago. She and her husband, Andrew, an assembler at a circuit-board plant, are scrimping to get by and have put off plans to start a family.
But Ms. Dryver is now studying office management, accounting and word processing at Northern Essex Community College in Haverhill, as well as medical terminology and transcribing. "I should be able to get something more than dead-end jobs when I graduate," said Ms. Dryver, who is 26 years old. "This is a perfect opportunity for someone like me."
Northern Essex Community College has about 1,000 of what the college president, John Dimitry, likes to call "our new breed of student," in the worker assistance program, a three-year-old endeavor. The students' grades, he said, have been about a full grade point higher than those of the younger students.
"What this has taught me is that there is enormous flexibility on the part of the work force," Mr. Dimitry said. "They want to be retrained and educated, given the chance. It can be done and it is being done right here."

HEADLINE: Women Who Lose Breasts Define Their Own Femininity

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
Twenty to 30 years ago, women with breast cancer worried that even if they survived the disease, the loss of a breast would somehow diminish their femininity and sexual attractiveness. Many women hid their mastectomies, disguising their single-breasted figures with cumbersome prostheses even around family members.
Today, women are less likely to perceive breast cancer as an attack on their innate feminine nature. For one thing, more and more women are having surgery that removes the malignancy but spares the breast. When a mastectomy is necessary, more and more women are having reconstructive surgery using an implant or their own fatty tissue. 
 And while breasts are still viewed in many societies and cultures as a symbol of womanhood, nurturing and sexuality, many men no longer consider the loss of a woman's breast as having lessened her physical attributes or sexual desirability.
 
'We Are What We Are'

"When it comes to self-image, you can't let cancer dictate who and what you are," said Jean Ettesvold, a 60-year-old retired social worker from Grand Rapids, Mich. who had a mastectomy just over a year ago. "We are what we are, in spite of the trauma we have suffered."
In a recent study of the effects of breast cancer on sexuality, body image and intimate relationships, Dr. Leslie R. Schover, a staff psychologist at the Center for Sexual Function at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation in Ohio, concluded: "The majority of women cope well with the stress of cancer surgery and the loss of a breast. The options of breast conservation and reconstruction give women a new sense of control over their treatment and are quite successful in helping women feel comfortable with their bodies again."
Indeed, breast cancer patients are becoming militant, not only lobbying legislators and staging demonstrations urging more research on the disease, but talking about what it is like to have it.
In more than a dozen recent interviews, women who had lost a breast to cancer, ranging in age from their 30's to their 60's, said they did not feel less attractive then women with natural breasts. Most chose reconstructive surgery, though some used prostheses.
Some women have had their reconstructed breasts cosmetically tattoed instead of having additional surgery to reconstruct nipples or areolas.
"My cellulite bothers me more than my missing breast, because the cellulite's more visible," said Susan Brooks, a 39-year-old schoolteacher, wife and mother of two whose breast cancer was diagnosed in 1988. Two years later, Mrs. Brooks, who lives on Long Island, underwent a bone marrow transplant after the cancer spread to her left eye, back and right hip.
 
Some Reject Camouflage
 Indeed, breast cancer survivors like Audre Lorde, a poet who had a mastectomy in 1979, reject any kind of camouflage after mastectomy. They say cosmetic remedies undermine efforts to focus attention on thousands of women suffering and dying from the disease.
"When other one-breasted women hide behind the mask of prosthesis or reconstruction, I find little support in the broader female environment for my rejection for what feels like a cosmetic sham," said Ms. Lorde, a black lesbian feminist who has chosen not to wear a prosthesis for philosophical and political reasons. "The social and economic discrimination practiced against women who have breast cancer is not diminished by pretending that mastectomies do not exist."
In "The Cancer Journals," (Spinsters/Aunt Lute, 1981), a book that chronicles her battle with breast cancer, Ms. Lorde wrote: "I would lie if I did not also speak of loss. Any amputation is a physical and psychic reality that must be integrated into a new sense of self. The absence of my breast is a recurrent sadness, but certainly not one that dominates my life."
 
A Sense of Loss
 Other women agreed that loss of a breast can provoke feelings of loss, anger, pain or anxiety.
"When you walk through a lingerie department, you have a different feeling," said Mrs. Ettesvold. "Whether you have an implant or the mastectomy, you are reminded every time you look in the mirror."
"I didn't grieve the loss of my breast until eight years after I had my mastectomy," said Barbara Glenn, recalling that her double mastectomy at the age of 35 also came at a time, the 1980's, when women in New York outnumbered men. "I had a mental block. I didn't want to face it so I made believe nothing was happening. My denial was a way of surviving."
Most of the married women said their mastectomies had not had not harmed their marriages or their sex lives. The single women said their surgery had not impaired their relationships with men or dating. Some said they found men to be even more supportive after their mastectomies than before. Others said men seemed emotionally moved by their stories,often calling them courageous or survivors.
Paradoxically, many married women said they felt that single women fared better in coping with relationships after losing a breast, while single women believed that married women fared better.
"Single women particularly may feel more vulnerable, although many married women have as many problems as single," said Linda Dackman, the author of "Up Front, Sex and the Post-Mastectomy Woman" (New York Viking, 1990). Ms. Dackman, who is single, had her right breast removed in 1985.
Many women said they needed the reassurance of the men in their lives to feel psychologically whole again.
"My husband's been wonderful," said Carol Samnick, a 43-year-old mother of two from Plainview, L.I., who had a mastectomy and breast reconstruction last February. "He says he doesn't really care about the breast.As a teen-ager, I was big-breasted, and that was one thing people liked about me. So when I lost my breast, I had trouble dealing with it. In fact, I had more trouble dealing with it than my husband."
 
Touching the Scar
 "My wife wouldn't get dressed in front of me and I wouldn't allow it," said Michael Brooks, who is married to Susan Brooks, the schoolteacher. "At first, she wouldn't let me touch her scar, but I insisted." Mr. Brooks belongs to a men's support group set up by the Cancer Care Foundation for cancer patients' "significant others." Another member of the Woodbury, L.I., support group, who asked to be identified only as Robert, said his wife was also self-conscious about her reconstruction.
"That was so secondary to me," he said. Most men, he said, live in a society where they see a lot of cute girls with firm breasts. "I still look," he said. "But when I get in bed with my wife, I'm not afraid to touch. I think she's more uncomfortable with it than me."
Although many women are so afraid of losing a breast that they refuse to examine their breasts or have mammograms, women who have actually faced the disease often say that surviving is foremost, saving the breast is secondary.
"Initially, all I thought about was this stupid breast," acknowledged Betty Rollin, whose book "First, You Cry" (Lippincott, 1975) tells of her struggle with cancer and coping with a mastectomy. She had a second mastectomy in 1984. "Then I came to realize, I don't walk on it or type with it," she continued. "So what's the big deal? The second diagnosis, I really could have cared less about the breast. What I totally cared about was that I had cancer again."
 
Other Traumas
 In many instances, the women said they found the range of possible effects of chemotherapy -- hair loss, premature menopause, infertility and weight gain -- as traumatic as the loss of a breast, if not more so.
"I've always had a problem with thin hair," said Mrs. Samnick of a 43-Long Island, who had her mastectomy in early 1990. "Then I was told that the chemotherapy might cause me to lose my hair. First my boobs, then my hair, the two things a woman cherishes the most." Now, she says, she is able to laugh about her feelings , adding, "Humor is a healthy antidote for cancer."
Ann Marcou, the founder of Y-Me, a national support network for women with cancer, said: "I think it doesn't have quite the stigma it did. It's more accepted to have it."
Ms. Marcou, 59, who had a mastectomy 15 years ago, said: "People used to hide in the closet. Individual women still tussle with their body because it's so valued in society. Every woman who goes through this will wonder about her femininity and sexuality. But it comes down to this: 'Your femininity is not determined by whether or not you have breasts.' "


GRAPHIC: After breast removal, some women are comfortable with external prostheses and some prefer not to camouflage a missing breast.
 
For women who decide on breast reconstruction, there are two major surgical approaches
 
Complex flap surgery, using tissue from elsewhere in the body, can cost $20,000 for two breasts. 1,300 women had such reconstruction in 1988.
 
Less complex silicon implants are less expensive, at about $5,000. Safety concerns have been raised, 33,000 mastectomy patients got them in 1988. (Source: American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons)

HEADLINE: END OF THE SOVIET UNION;
BUSH LAUDS VISION OF SOVIET LEADER

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
President Bush moved quickly tonight to recognize Russia and other former republics of the now-extinct Soviet Union.
After praising the former Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush went out of his way to express support for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, who has emerged as the first among equals in the new Commonwealth of Independent States and as the custodian of the old Soviet Union's nuclear arsenal. 
 In his brief televised speech, Mr. Bush said that the United States would now recognize the independence of the 11 former Soviet republics that have banded together, as well as a 12th, Georgia, which has shunned the alliance. [Transcript of Mr. Bush's remarks, page A16.]
But he indicated that the equally important step of establishing diplomatic ties between Washington and all 12 parts of the old Soviet empire would be more complicated.
The President said he was satisifed with the assurances on nuclear controls that he has received from Mr. Yeltsin and from the other former republics with nuclear arms on their soil. Mr. Bush also said that the United States would establish diplomatic relations with Russia, Armenia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, Kazakhstan and Kirghizia.
Diplomatic relations with the remaining republics would come when the six meet five informal guidelines that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d outlined in September.
Mr. Baker said then that relations would be governed by the Soviet republics' commitments to peaceful self-determination by their citizens; to respect for borders; to orderly and democratic means of change; to human rights, and to the debts and other international obligations, such as treaties, that Moscow had already agreed to honor.
The White House appeared to have delayed recognizing Ukraine and Russia and openly supporting the new Commonwealth until after Mr. Gorbachev's formal retirement as a personal courtesy to the man Mr. Bush has praised as a visionary and peacemaker.
Long before Mr. Gorbachev made his resignation official in a speech on Soviet television today, Mr. Bush had been accused of allowing sentimentality to cloud cold judgments about where in the collapsing Soviet Union the White House should throw its support.
Mr. Bush's speech and a written statement issued tonight were tinged with sadness at the forced retirement of a man whom he had once dismissed as a fraud, but came to regard as a partner in the creation of a post-cold war order.
 
Eulogy for af Leader
 In his written statement, the President eulogized Mr. Gorbachev's leadership as "responsible for one of the most important developments of this century -- the revolutionary transformation of a totalitarian dictatorship and the liberation of his people from its smothering embrace."
"His personal commitment to democratic and economic reform through perestroika and glasnost," Mr. Gorbachev's opening and restructuring of Soviet society, "permitted the peoples of Russia and other republics to cast aside decades of dark oppression and put in place the foundations of freedom."
That task demanded "the highest degree of political and personal ingenuity and courage," Mr. Bush said.
But the President's decision to delay diplomatic recognition for six of the former republics reflected the Administration's own conviction that Mr. Gorbachev has left a task unfinished.
This fall, shortly after a coup attempt laid bare Mr. Gorbachev's faltering power, Mr. Baker expressed hope that the Soviet states could bind into a confederation so that Washington could deal with a single authority on matters of nuclear weapons and foreign affairs. Mr. Gorbachev's departure makes that hope reality, for now, but even Mr. Baker was said this week to fear that the confederation is doomed to fragment.
Tonight, Mr. Bush said that concerns about "responsible security policies and democratic principles" had led him to delay diplomatic recognition for Georgia and five Commonwealth members: Turkmenia, Moldavia, Tadzhikistan, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan.
In extending diplomatic recognition to Russia and Ukraine and some other members of the new Commonwealth, Mr. Bush joined major nations in certifying the new status of Russia as the continuation of the U.S.S.R., entitled to its permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council.
Britain, the Netherlands, Israel and the European Community today said that they recognized the Russian Federation as the legal successor to the Soviet Union. The European Community said in a statement from the Netherlands that it will speed up the establishment of diplomatic ties with the other former Soviet states.
 
Europe Issues Guidelines
 The community last week issued guidelines that it said the republics must follow to win recognition.
The Netherlands said in a separate statement that it considers Russia "to exercise the international rights and obligations of the former U.S.S.R., including those under the U.N. Charter." Italy said it is beginning the process of recognizing Russia.
Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, told Mr. Yeltsin in a letter on Monday that Britain already views Russia as the successor to the old Soviet Union of 15 Republics because the Russian Republic was the original founder of the Soviet Union in 1922, the Associated Press reported today.
Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that Canada will establish diplomatic relations immediately with Russia. Canada, which has a large population of Ukrainian origin moved to recognize Ukraine on Dec. 2.
Israel recognized all the states in the Commonwealth. Foreign minister David Levy urged the new nations to protect the rights of Jewish minorities, including their freedom to emigrate.
China's Foreign Ministry today issued a report on the world situation in which it said that the Soviet Union's demise signals the end of the East-West conflict and the dawn of a new "multi-polar" age, Tass reported.
China said it expects to have friendly relations with the new Soviet states "guided by the principle of noninterference in the domestic affairs of other states," Tass quoted China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen, as telling a committee of the Chinese Congress of Peoples Deputies.
Libya announced it recognized the new Commonwealth nations as well as Georgia. Iran recognized all the new states with the exception of Moldavia.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev said their personal farewells in a telephone call on Wednesday morning Washington time, shortly before Mr. Gorbachev made his resignation speech.
Mr. Bush praised Mr. Gorbachev in the conversation "for his personal courage and leadership in reforming the country," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said. Mr. Fitzwater said that Mr. Gorbachev thanked Mr. Bush for his support.
Tass, the press service, reported that Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Bush that he would immediately surrender control of the Soviet Union's 27,000-plus nuclear weapons to Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Bush that the White House could "spend a peaceful Christmas evening," with Mr. Yeltsin in control, Tass reported.
 
No Hiding in the Woods
 In an interview today with Cable News Network, Mr. Gorbachev said that he told Mr. Bush that he has "no intention of hiding in the taiga, hiding in the woods" now that he is out of power.
Mr. Bush's remarks tonight largely echoed those of leaders around the world who praised Mr. Gorbachev's determination to change the course of history and his willingness to step aside without a bloody struggle for power.
The British Prime Minister said: "It is given to very few people to change the course of history, but that is what Gorbachev has done. Whatever happens today, his place in history is secure."
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who vigorously urged economic aid to help Mr. Gorbachev's Government through the transformation to a market economy, said today that the Soviet leader played a pivotal role in world history.
"Without Mikhail Gorbachev, the overcoming of the East-West conflict and the unprecedented success in the last years of disarmament and arms control would not have been possible," he said. "His place in the history of our century will not be challenged by anyone."
France's President, Francois Mitterrand, expressed "personal gratitude for the work accomplished in the defense of peace." The Japanese Government, which saw a 50-year-old dispute over boundaries begin to edge toward resolution under Mr. Gorbachev said in a statement that his accomplishments "will be highly appreciated and will remain in the history of this century."
The Secretary General of NATO, Manfred Worner, said that Europe, most of all, is grateful to Mr. Gorbachev for his "essential contribution . . . toward a Europe whole and free."
The Israeli Foreign Minister saluted Mr. Gorbachev's "historic part" in ending controls on the emigration of Jews.
 
Praise From Reagan
 Among those with the warmest praise were two pillars of Western anticommunism who quickly came to recognize, shortly after Mr. Gorbachev's rise to power in 1985, that he represented a break with the Soviet past.
Former President Ronald Reagan said today that Mr. Gorbachev "will live forever in history." He "has been willing to break down barriers that have divided our countries and enslaved his citizens," Mr. Reagan said in a written statement.
Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister, said today, "He did great things for the world, and we are very grateful."
"He restored liberty to all the East European countries," she said, and "he brought it for the first time to the peoples of the Soviet Union." By itself, she said, that was "a tremendous achievement." But more important, she said, "he did it all without a shot being fired."
It was Mrs. Thatcher who first ushered Mr. Gorbachev onto the Western world's stage in December 1984, when he was still a deputy to Soviet leader Konstantin Chernenko, but his apparent successor as well.
Mrs. Thatcher's comments about her Soviet colleague, made after a meeting in London between the two, resounded around the world. "I like Mr. Gorbachev," she said. "We can do business."
