SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: Strike at Small Steelmaker Poses a Big Test for a Union

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COATESVILLE, Pa.

 BODY:
In this quiet industrial and farming area about 30 miles west of Philadelphia, a contentious strike by steelworkers may well reveal how much power the union still has and at what cost to the nation's big steel producers.
The strike target is Lukens Inc., a relatively small but profitable steel producer. From Lukens's perspective, the big issue is whether to yield to a demand by the United Steelworkers to eliminate a common industry practice known as contracting out. Under the practice, nonunion workers are hired to perform duties not directly tied to making steel. 
 Union officials insist that their members are far more interested in gaining better wages and benefits that will bring their compensation more in line with their counterparts at larger steel companies. That is a worrisome prospect to most steel producers, whose losses have been mounting.
 
Industrywide Losses Expected
 The strike comes while the steel industry is suffering economically. Prices have been weak through most of this year, with only a modest improvement in the last two months. Industry analysts expect the nation's big steel companies to report losses of more than $1 billion this year.
At the same time, larger steel companies are seeing their market shares erode because of aggressive inroads by smaller, nonunion companies known as mini-mills. Also, demand for steel has diminished with the recession as auto companies cut back production.
The financial health of Lukens has been notably stronger than that of most steel producers. Indeed, it has been one of the shining lights in a battered industry. The company has made its niche in high-quality steel plate, the thick steel sheets that go into everything from tanks and bridges to ships and highway products. But the strike by more than 1,200 members of the steelworkers' union has already crippled production at the one plant that is unionized, and it threatens to cut profits to break-even levels.
 
A Wider Significance
 The Lukens strike also has ramifications beyond the company. It has dragged on stubbornly for more than two months and has sent buyers scurrying to rivals.
Moreover, it will help determine whether the United Steelworkers -- the union that was once so powerful that its strikes virtually brought American industry to its knees in earlier decades -- still has enough influence to force changes in such matters as work rules, let alone pay.
The USX Corporation, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the LTV Corporation, among the bigger steel producers, are closely watching the union's strength at Lukens. Those companies are hoping to hold the line on increases in pay and benefits when a new round of labor negotiations starts next year.
"For the union, the central issue is whether they can control their destiny," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "This is an important test case that everyone in the industry is watching because it will determine the extent the union will continue to have influence over labor practices at steel mills."
The strike is also an important test for Lukens. The company is as much a rival of the big steelmakers as it is a competitor against the mini-mills, which have lower-paid, nonunion workers and far lower operating costs over all. Lukens executives argue that if the company's labor costs rise to that of the big companies, it would wipe out profits and make Lukens a far weaker competitor against smaller rivals like Citi Steel USA, Gulf States Steel Inc. and Oregon Steel Mills Inc.
But the executives here argue most vehemently against the union's proposal to prevent the contracting of outside workers to perform nonmanufacturing duties, like painting or lawn care. The union has sought to preserve those jobs for steelworkers or to set up a procedure that gives it a voice if such outside workers are to be hired.
At the moment, the company can contract out such jobs as painting and lawn care. The company said that since those services are contracted to outside vendors, it does not know how many jobs are involved. Union officials, however, estimate that several hundred jobs are contracted out.
Lukens executives object strongly to the union demands. "Steelworkers would like for us to pay steelworker wages for anything done in the plant, from mowing lawns to painting buildings," said Robert Schaal, Lukens's senior vice president for administration. "A steelworker's wages in total cost the company about $53,000 a year," he said. "Now you just don't go out and pay that kind of money to a painter. We don't want to see the company destroyed in the long haul by work practices that don't make sense."
Union officials say they are flexible on that issue and that they seek more than anything to have their wages increased to the level paid by the big steel companies. In contract talks two years ago, the big steel companies agreed to increase wages and benefits by 15 percent over the three-year contracts. Workers in those companies viewed those contracts as merely reinstating part of the pay they had lost through concessions in the industry's downturns. But company managements increasingly talk of those pacts as among the foremost reasons for their current financial problems.
Union leaders here say the contract negotiations with Lukens are a continuation of the talks with other steelmakers in 1989 and 1990. The contracts reached during those talks, on average, increased pay and benefits to $28.20 an hour from $24.50 an hour. Lukens said its employees earn $18.50 an hour in wages and profit sharing, but does not disclose how much more its benefits add to the package.
"Lukens, for whatever reason, is saying that the people who work at one of the most profitable steel companies in the country don't deserve the same benefits that everyone else in the industry receives," said Harry Haines, president of Local 1165 of the Steelworkers Union, which represents workers at Lukens.
Furthermore, union officials suggest that higher pay will not affect the profitability of Lukens, which earned $30.9 million in the first nine months of this year, a period in which the six largest domestic steelmakers posted combined losses of $844 million.
"There is no objective reason that's been presented to us that would suggest why they shouldn't step up to the table with the rest of the industry," said Lynn Williams, international president of the steelworkers' organization.
"The solutions to Lukens's problems don't lie with low wages," Mr. Williams added. "There should be a level playing field, and Lukens has simply not been willing to meet the pattern." So strongly does Mr. Williams embrace this issue that he took the unusual step of meeting with Wall Street analysts to discuss the union's position.
It is that image, of a level playing field of wages, that is so troubling to Lukens and some analysts. "If we're going to have a strong steel industry, the union has to recognize that each company has different markets and each should have a contract that is suited to the particulars of that company," said Barbara Crehan, a steel analyst with Merrill Lynch.
Ms. Crehan argues that since Lukens makes only plate steel, the union should negotiate with the idea that the company has vastly different competitive dynamics than companies like USX or Bethlehem.
"Steel plate is being shipped into the United States for $30 to $40 a ton below the commodity price," she said. "Lukens can't be viewed as another Bethlehem Steel, because it isn't."
In the meantime, Lukens's nonunion steel finishing plant 35 miles from here is operating at full steam while the company is struggling to keep production going at the plant here and is sending 85 percent of its prestrike shipments to customers.
Some union leaders and analysts saw the resignation early this month of the chairman, William R. Wilson, and his replacement by the president and chief operating officer, R. William Van Sant, as signs that the company might be a little more flexible.. But the two sides remain far apart on most issues, and the strike threatens to drag on for some time.
Talks had been suspended for several weeks, but were resumed in mid-December.
Whatever the outcome, the strike will be closely watched by all in the industry. "We in the integrated steel companies are looking to see what happens with Lukens," said the chief executive of a larger steel company, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The result, whatever that might be, will have an impact on all of us."

HEADLINE: Congress Is Impatient for South Asia Bureau

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Coping with daily changes in the map of Eastern Europe, the State Department is also faced with the task of rearranging Asia -- though only in an organizational sense.
After six years of trying, Congress in August attached to a State Department financial authorization bill the requirement that a new bureau for South Asia be created so that the Indian subcontinent, from Afghanistan to Bangladesh, would get more attention. Now Congress wants the department to stop stalling and act on the legislation. 
 The World Bank has already made a similar change, reflecting the importance of a region where development problems are huge and populations are growing rapidly. More than a billion people live in the region where two nations that are old enemies, Pakistan and India, are thought to have the ability to produce nuclear arms.
At the State Department, South Asia is now part of a larger division, the Bureau of Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs. Members of Congress say that this relegates South Asia to what time remains after the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and North Africa are dealt with.
The State Department asked for a Presidential veto of the legislation, according to Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who had led the drive to create the new bureau. President Bush declined to block it, however, leaving the State Department with no alternative to comply.
"They seem to be stalling," Mr. Solarz, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said in an interview before leaving on a trip to the Koreas. "Among other things, this will put them in violation of the law. Inattention to the region is now going to be compounded by illegality. They are setting themselves up for a major confrontation with the Congress."
At the State Department, an official who spoke on condition of anonymity said there is no question of defying or evading the Congressional mandate. It is just that no one knows where the money will come from to create a bureau that would cover India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, Maldives and Afghanistan.
Bureaus require more than just desk officers. Another assistant secretary of state would have to be named to head the division. There would also have to be a new press office and administrative support staff.
State Department officials also challenge the assumption that South Asian nations are neglected in the present bureau, saying that since the Middle East gets so much attention, Assistant Secretary of State Edward P. Djerejian sees Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d often, and can bring his attention to issues affecting South Asia.
Mr. Solarz is not impressed.
"With an incipient nuclear arms race in the region," he said, "with more than quarter of billion people, with another war possible between India and Pakistan, and Afghanistan still unsettled, and with the emergence of a series of new fledgling democracies that need to be supported and sustained, South Asia requires attention."
The new World Bank president, Lewis T. Preston, also thinks South Asia needs more attention. On Dec. 1, the Bank's Asia division was split in two, with vice presidencies created for East Asia and South Asia. An American, Joseph Wood, became vice president for South Asia. An Indian, Gautam Kaji, took over in East Asia.

HEADLINE: Recession-Ravaged Town Grieves for 6 Children

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 24

 BODY:
Fire Chief James Staffo has been thinking about life and probability lately. Two years ago today, his men failed to rescue three children and their mother from a trailer park fire in nearby Manheim. Then last Sunday morning -- again, just before Christmas -- another fire claimed the lives of all six children of Sheila McLeod on East Monroe Street.
Chief Staffo wonders whether an engine company or a fire chief can be cursed. He tries to comfort the firemen, many of them fathers, who see the dead children when they shut their eyes. His own eyes are puffy from insomnia; their spidery red lines seem a map of grief's back roads. 
 "I'm responsible for these guys here. You stand there and say, 'Why me?' " he asks.
The fire would have been wrenching anywhere. But for this manufacturing town, drained of its young families and much of its vitality by the death of major industries over the last few decades and a severe economic recession, the loss of six children has been devastating.
 
Industry Disappears
 "There's just nothing here," agreed Mary Petkovsek, 66 years old, who attended a memorial service for the children at St. Joseph's Church.
A Mohawk Valley city that once proudly straddled the only East-West waterway through New York State, boasting knitting mills, paper mills, shoe factories, a bicycle factory and the New York's first cheese manufacturer, Little Falls has been displaced by other regions, foreign competition and most of all, technology.
As in countless towns up and down the New York Central railroad lines, indeed all along an East Coast littered with the rusting carcasses of fallen industries, the mid- to late 20th century has in a sense meant the end of Little Falls.
The more graceful homes, in styles ranging from colonial to neo-classical, hint at livelier times.
But now, many of the houses have been divided into apartments, while others, large enough for a family with children, sit strangely silent.
"When World War II came, it knocked everything out," said Terese Kelly, a 65-year-old volunteer at St. Joseph's Church. "All the boys came back and wanted something better."
The population of today is but a third of that at the turn of the century. With 6,000 people, 80 percent of them elderly, one life has a resonance lost in the blare of a city like Manhattan. The community was still stunned by the murder of Greg Jouban, a jeweler killed in his shop two months ago. It was the first murder in Little Falls since 1920.
The McLeods, who came here from New London, Conn., two years ago, were cherished newcomers at a time most people cut a fast path out of Central New York for lack of jobs.
 
500 Jobs Gone
 "If you're from here, you're not going to stay here," said Mary-Carol Aiello, Mayor of the neighboring community of Herkimer. Miss Aiello noted that one of the few large employers in the area, the Remington Arms Company, had lost about 500 jobs over the last few years. Small businesses, like the butcher shop her family ran for generations, have had to close down in recent years.
Despite, or perhaps because of, the hard times, people here help one another. Miss Aiello's office was one of two that had been gathering Christmas presents and food for the McLeod children. The local social-service agency had suggested the family as the area's neediest, giving the office a list of the children's ages, likes and dislikes, without identifying them. The donors only learned the children's names after the fire, when they compared the McLeod children's ages to those on the presents they had wrapped.
"Each child had 10 to 12 packages of gifts," toys, jackets and sweatsuits, she said. "It was to have been an overwhelming Christmas for them."
The three elder children -- Douglas, 10, Jonathon, 9 and Christopher, 8 -- were to play the three wise men in the Christmas pageant at St. Joseph's Church. Instead, their costumes were draped over their chairs during tonight's performance. The younger children were Shannon, 5, Kelly, 2, and Daniel, 1.
 
'They Just Loved Life'
 The Rev. Charles Celeste, who officiated at a memorial service for the children Monday night, said they were chosen to play the wise men "because of who they were: friendly, outgoing. They just loved life."
"These six children have given the greatest gift of all: their lives," Father Celeste said, waving his hand over the six small coffins beside him on the altar. In the pews, the family's friends, teachers, neighbors and acquaintances sobbed, many of them embracing Miss McLeod and stroking her face. Chief Staffo and his men crossed themselves and prayed for absolution.
Even people who have never met the McLeod children seemed near tears in discussing the fire. Three local agencies set up telephone hot lines offering emotional support to people mourning the children.
In coming here, Miss McLeod, who is 30, had hoped to give her children precisely the kind of affordable community life they could never know in a big city. Friends said she had been struggling without child support from the father of her first four children, who lives in Michigan and was not known to visit them.
 
Starting Anew
 The family thrived in this depressed and yet humane community. Here, the McLeods could afford a one-family house that Miss McLeod was slowly restoring under an agreement with the landlord. She painted the walls, got the furnace replaced and planted a vegetable garden.
"I remember seeing her digging up the garden and planting, I think it was squash," said Kimberly Matthews, a Jehovah's Witness with whom Miss McLeod had begun studying last September. "She looked so happy."
And the McLeod family seemed to share the same generous nature as the people of Little Falls. The eldest child, Douglas, learned to swim at the public pool, and saved up his pennies to offer the lifeguard a pizza at the end of the season. Miss McLeod, upon learning her children were dead, offered to donate their eyes, which were too damaged in the fire to be used. She donated the Christmas gifts she had bought them to other needy children.
The area has "a decency to it that you never find in New York City," said Joe Dowd, the fast-talking city editor of The Utica Observer-Dispatch, himself a transplanted Brooklynite. "And that's despite the fact that they're watching their world as they knew it fall apart around them. I don't ever remember a traffic jam here, or shouting a curse word out of my car window," he said."
Mr. Dowd is convinced, however, that Little Falls's future depends on drawing back industry and young lives.
"This is a place without a lot of prospects," he said. "It's been through a lot. Time has passed it by." Now, it has few resources of its own. "Some outside force will save it. Or it won't be saved."
The morning after the memorial service, Miss McLeod flew home to Buffalo from the Rome-Utica Airport with her children's six small coffins. Mrs. Matthews, her friend from the Jehovah's Witnesses, said the mother felt she had nothing to keep her in Little Falls anymore.
Tonight at 6 P.M., the Little Falls Volunteer Fire Department rang its bells, and the city and its residents shut all the lights, in memory of the children it lost.

HEADLINE: RETAILERS REPORT SALES FELL SHORT OF DIM FORECASTS

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Retailers would probably like to forget Christmas 1991. While most merchants had been prepared for a sluggish season, many said sales turned out to be even worse than expected. Even the last-minute shopping frenzy was not enough to give merchants anything to cheer about.
As recently as a month ago, many retailers had hoped to exceed last year's sales by 5 percent. But results through the close of business on Monday indicate that spending will be flat or up slightly in December. The major retail chains are scheduled to release their final monthly sales results next week. 
 "We are disappointed with the season," Stephen E. Watson, president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday.
 
'Too Little Too Late'
 Business surged in the final days, and a number of retailers said that Monday was the busiest day of the year. But Mr. Watson said, "In our view, it's really been too little too late." Dayton Hudson, which relies on California for one-third of its business, was hit hard by the slowdown in that state's economy.
This is the third consecutive sluggish Christmas shopping season -- the make or break season for retailers -- and many analysts say this year's dismal results are likely to force thousands of companies into bankruptcy.
The economy received most of the blame for the weak sales, but retailers also said they had no hot product this year. The wave of layoff announcements in the last two months did not help either.
 
Bad News From G.M.
 The General Motors Corporation said last week that it would close 21 plants and lay off more than 70,000 workers, striking directly at consumer's already flagging confidence.
"That was not helpful," said Mr. Watson of Dayton Hudson, which has department stores and Target discount stores in Michigan. Going into the Christmas selling season, Dayton Hudson had planned for sales to increase by as much as 7 percent over last year. But Mr. Watson said sales at the nation's fourth-largest retailer, would be flat or show a small gain for December.
Lasker M. Meyer, vice chairman of Specialty Retailers Inc. in Houston, which operates 165 Palais Royale and Bealls department stores, also felt the announcement by General Motors put a damper on sales in the final week. "It could be totally coincidental, but news like that really makes a strong impression on people," Mr. Meyer said. "It makes them start worrying about their own jobs."
 
Predictions Fall Short
 The chain started the holiday sales season predicting a 5 percent sales increase over last year, but Mr. Meyer said its sales for the period would only equal those of 1990.
In addition to grappling with a drop in consumer confidence, merchants said they lacked a "must have" new product to draw people into stores. One telling sign of the lack of fresh merchandise could be found in the notoriously fickle toy aisles where Ninja Turtles remained a hot product for yet another year.
"It was probably the least exciting merchandising Christmas in recent history," said Julian M. Seeherman, chairman and chief executive of Venture Stores Inc., a Midwestern discount chain with about $1.5 billion in sales. "This year in particular you needed something new to try and break the consumer apathy." Venture's sales are likely to be better than last year, but not up to expectations.
Sales at Sears, Roebuck are also expected to be flat or down slightly for the month, analysts said.
 
Long Lull in December
 Sears, like other retailers said business was strong at Thanksgiving and in the last few days, but quiet for much of December. "For the first two and a half weeks in December, we were soft and somewhat below our expectations," said Matt Howard, senior vice president of marketing for Sears. The stores had a strong finish. "Monday was exceptionally strong," he said.
Mr. Howard said consumers were out in force, but they were simply buying less. "The size of the ticket over all for most retailers is probably smaller this year," he said.
Nonetheless, the number of customers shopping at Sears, and the number of transactions the company processed were up for the fourth quarter.
 
Some Bright Spots
 There were bright spots. With consumers searching for bargains, discount retailers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the K Mart Corporation are expected to post solid gains. "K Mart had a very good month," said Robert Roth, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch. The company did booming business on Monday and said it expected sales to be up by 8 or 9 percent compared with December last year.
"Everybody is talking recession and depression; in this store that's not been the case," said Curtis Williams, general manager of a K Mart store in the Altanta area, near Marietta. Business jumped 25 percent on Monday, compared with Dec. 23 last year, he said.
A Wal-Mart spokeswoman said, "We are pleased with sales for the holiday season this year."
The Gap, with its tables full of $36 jeans, $20 turtlenecks and $35 cotton sweaters, is also expected to do well this Christmas.
Merchants like the Gap and Wal-Mart benefited from the twin themes of value and the desire for basic merchandise, both emerged early and dominated consumers quest for gifts this year.
Mr. Howard of Sears said sheets, towels, portable electric tools, exercise bikes, jeans, turtlenecks and terry cloth robes had sold well.
J. C. Penney scaled back its hopes for the month after "business fell apart the beginning of December," said Harvey McCormick, a company spokesman. He said the company expected sales for the month to be flat or slightly better than a year earlier, although analysts felt that Penney's might be down for the month.
 
Last-Minute Rush Is Slow
 Cheryl Engstrom, a spokeswoman for Nordstrom Inc. in Seattle, said sales had not picked up as sharply as the company had anticipated. Although there has been an uptick in sales over the last couple of days, the results are not likely to meet the company's projections for the holiday selling season. "Shoppers have been slower than ever getting off the dime this year, and it looks like some of them may never take off," Ms. Engstrom said.
She said Nordstrom's specialty apparel stores had not done as well as its outlet divisions, Nordstrom Rack and Place Two. "Those have been doing great, which just reinforces the trend that our customers are shopping for price," Ms. Engstrom said.
In a season marked by many sales, retailers continued to cut prices aggressively up until stores closed on Christmas Eve.
 
Sales Before Christmas
 At a Bombay Company home furnishing store at the Oakland Mall near Detroit, the after-Christmas sales tags were being hung on items earlier than planned. "We're pulling out all the stops," said the store manager, Kathy Gurtek.
Such last-minute price-cutting was widespread. "If a competitor's price goes down, we'll tag our price down," said Wayne Inouye, vice president of merchandising for the Good Guys Inc. He said that a competitor, had recently dropped the price of a popular Sony camcorder to $600, which is $100 less than the advertised price a month ago. Good Guys matched that cut and others, a policy that has caused the company's stock price to drop recently.
Even though retailers ordered merchandise carefully this year, they are gearing up for huge after-Christmas sales. Sears will run extensive advertising for its post-Christmas "Best Week to Buy" sale.
Still, some chose to give the most practical gift of all this year, cash. Barry Levine, a 44-year old talent manager in Los Angeles, gave money to his brother, an unemployed engineer. "You can't eat a sweater," Mr. Levine said.

HEADLINE: Numbers Tell Story of Gifts To Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Most donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are in round figures -- $10, $50, $100 -- but many checks are for peculiar sums and there's a story behind each of them.
"We are pleased to enclose a contribution of $135 in honor of our daughter's birthday," wrote Sally and Alan Epstein of Rye, N.Y. "Peggy Epstein Tanner will be 34 years old so here is: 
 "$34 for the 34 years
"$1 to grow on
"$100 to attempt to make the support of your appeal a bit more meaningful."
Alfred I. Jaffe of Somers, N.Y,. wrote that "a few years back I hit upon the idea of honoring my wife on our anniversary, Dec. 24, by contributing $2 to the fund for each year of our marriage. So it is with pleasure that I'm enclosing a check for $104 in honor of Mimi Jaffe, who doesn't need a trinket or a doodad for a present."
 
The Sum of History
 Many contributors have decided on a sum by taking into account the long history of the Neediest Cases Fund. "I am pleased to to be able to make the enclosed contribution of $160 toward this year's appeal," wrote Theodore S. Smith Jr. of Geneva, N.Y. "I chose this figure because it is the 80th anniversary of the Neediest Cases fund and because it is the 40th year I have given. My gift the first few years was in the memory of an older man, a friend of our family who had died before his time because of an unfortunate life. On this, the 40th anniversary of my first gift, I again honor the memory of W.L.S."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor, and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases" has expanded to meet needs of thousands of individuals.
As in the past, The Times is covering all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed directly to seven charities, which provide food, clothing and housing. The seven charities also use the money to provide job training for the disabled, counseling for substance abusers, child abusers, and services that address the innumerable problems confronted by the victims of AIDS.
 
A Dollar a Day, or a Year
 In determing the size of their contribution, Dennis Appleton and Leslie Eisenberg of Lynbrook, L.I., settled upon one of the most traditional, and generous manners of calculation. "Although we are experiencing the effects of the current economic slump, as are so many people, we feel fortunate and privileged that we can still afford our annual $365 contribution," they wrote. "This 'dollar a day' donation is insignificant to our lives when compared to the good use to which it can be put for those who are truly in need."
Eric Zielenziger of Great Neck, L.I., sent in $45, representing one dollar "for every year I have been in the United States after having survived the Holocaust in Europe."
Finally, Lion and Mae Koppman of Jackson Heights, Queens, used two celebrations to help determine the amount of their contribution. "We recently celebrated or 43d wedding anniversary," Mr. Koppman wrote. "A few days before we marked my 71st birthday. Together they make 114. Here is a check for $114 with a wish that everyone mark events with a check to your worthy cause."

HEADLINE: Uncertainty Haunts Former Pan Am Workers

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
This was the Christmas that Herman Kobetitsch and 10,000 other Pan Am workers hoped they would never have.
Out of a job at the airline, which shut down three weeks ago, Mr. Kobetitsch has little except memories to show for his 35 years as a mechanic. 
 He has lost most of his medical insurance, is unsure whether there will be any money left from the airline's liquidation to pay any severance and is worried about his pension because the Pan Am fund was short about $900 million.
Mr. Kobetitsch will soon get unemployment insurance of $280 a week, but that is far short of the almost $700 a week he earned at Pan Am.
As for finding another job, Mr. Kobetitsch, who is 53 years old, is not optimistic. "To get a job at my age; it's almost nonexistent," he said. "With Eastern folding, the Midway layoffs and us, there must be at least 20,000 mechanics looking for jobs."
 
A Shared Predicament
 Mr. Kobetitsch's predicament is shared not only by many of the 10,000 workers who went down with Pan Am, most of them in or from the New York area, but also by those of Eastern Airlines, whose demise threw 18,000 people out of work last January, including 1,350 workers at La Guardia, and of Midway Airlines, which closed down Nov. 14.
Mr. Kobetitsch has asked the owner of a local auto-parts store, someone he knows, for any kind of job. "The guy laughed," he recalled. The man said he could not even hire his own cousin, who had also lost a job at Pan Am, because of slow sales caused by the recession.
So Mr. Kobetitsch now spends much of his time at home in Ozone Park, Queens. He and his wife, Rose, like to look at photos of themselves in Hong Kong, Bangkok and Hawaii, and of a trip around the world the family made in 1982 on free passes from the airline. He also looks fondly at his several citations for outstanding work.
 
Waiting for 'the Crunch'
 Despite his troubles, Mr. Kobetitsch has it better than many other Pan Am workers. At least "the children are all grown," he said, with jobs of their own.
And his wife has found work four hours a day as a school aide at $8 an hour. "For the next six months, we're O.K.," he predicted, referring to his savings and expected unemployment benefits. "After that, the crunch comes."
After Pan Am filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last January, its unions were able to get some protection for their workers in case of a shutdown. Most Pan Am employees will still get medical coverage for catastrophic injuries under a plan worked out last spring.
But at this point, it is uncertain whether workers will get any severance or other pay owed for vacations and the like. As a group, the employees represent one of many administrative claimants in bankruptcy court.
 
Unions Do What They Can
 Meanwhile, union locals such as the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 732, which represents 5,000 of the 6,000 Teamsters who lost their jobs at Pan Am, are doing what they can to ease the blow.
George Miranda, president of the local, and some of his staff are trying to set up a job bank, but so far the pickings have been slim.
He said some travel agencies had called looking for laid-off sales reservation people, offering to pay $6 to $7 an hour -- about half what workers were earning at Pan Am.
Some Pan Am employees, like Doris Sheehan, a ramp-service worker for 23 years, are still reeling from the shock of the shutdown. "We put everything on hold," she said. "We're still in a state of shock on what we want to do."
Others, like Hal Thomas, a senior technician for 19 years, are eager to go back to school and retrain. "Maybe I'll become a real estate broker," he said. "Now that it's over, we have to get on with our lives."
 
Few Openings Elsewhere
 Many workers did not wait to start looking for jobs. One man, insisting that he not be identified, said he had been circulating his resume for two years and in that time not one job he was offered would have paid anywhere near the income he was making at Pan Am.
Kathleen Thorp, an administratrive specialist for 23 years, said she had tried to submit her resume at American Airlines' office at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y.
"They wouldn't even take it," she said. "There are no jobs."

HEADLINE: Where the Boom Is in Health Care

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
A decade of rapid growth in home health care has forged a $15 billion industry with more than 12,500 companies and not-for-profit services. Many experts expect even faster growth in years to come as home treatment proves effective for a growing range of acutely ill or disabled patients whom doctors would once have insisted on hospitalizing at great cost.
The services range from traditional visiting-nurse associations to a host of entrepreneurial start-ups like Calldoctor Inc., a San Diego-based mobile emergency-room service. "We think it is going to be the fastest-growing business segment from the mid-1990's until well into the next century," said Gerald Celente, director of the Socio-Economic Research Institute of America in Rhinebeck, N.Y. "Most products and services for the home-health-care market haven't been invented yet."
 
New and Complex Services
 Most home care continues to involve chronic problems that are not life-threatening and are expected to affect more and more Americans as the population ages. But physicians at the frontiers of home health care are also expanding their work to include some stunningly acute and complex cases. 
 In Chicago, a 6-month-old infant with spinal cord injuries so severe that she cannot suck, cry, eat, breathe or move on her own was discharged from a hospital intensive-care unit and sent home. There, machinery run by nurses and her family has aided her growth. Her doctor hopes new technology will one day restore some of her lost abilities.
Some of the home patients are being pushed out of hospitals that need their beds for other people with more severe or immediate problems. In other cases, patients whom hospitals would gladly keep are going home to save money, recuperate faster and avoid exposure to hospital-based diseases. Still others are relying on home care to avoid going to hospitals for even initial treatment.
The home-care trend should be stimulated by recently proposed changes in Medicare compensation that would more than double Government payments for doctors to visit Medicare patients at home. But even without such incentives, health industry analysts say, the double-digit growth of the last few years is likely to accelerate as those born after World War II grow older.
The experts prefer to discuss trends rather than numbers because dependable financial data are hard to come by. Only a handful of companies publicly report earnings and revenue.
The $15 billion estimate for total spending on home medical-care services and equipment last year is a projection based on statistics from Government-financed programs, like Medicare and Medicaid, that serve patients who are elderly, disabled or extremely poor. About one person in 10 who saw a doctor last year needed some form of home care, according to the American Medical Association.
 
Abuses and Frauds
 The industry's growing pains have recently attracted more attention than its prospects. Last month, the Health and Human Services Department moved to clamp down on abuses of the Medicare system by medical equipment suppliers who sell their products for home use. More than 70 individuals and equipment companies have been convicted of fraud and other crimes involving inflated equipment costs, which total about $1.2 billion or roughly 2 percent of Medicare's annual budget.
The Government is also challenging a practice among some home-care companies of paying doctors to monitor therapy for the companies' patients. Caremark Inc., a Chicago-based subsidiary of Baxter International Inc., is the subject of a criminal investigation involving the practice. The Government says the practice may have operated as system to funnel kickbacks to Caremark.
Caremark has stopped such payments but defends them as legal within the vague guidelines Washington and the states have given the largely unregulated industry. More to the point, according to many doctors and home-care advocates, such payments represent necessary compensation to encourage doctors to oversee the increasingly complicated problems pateints are dealing with in their homes.
Home-care advocates complain that even with the new Medicare guidelines, the Government does not pay doctors for telephone consultations with home patients -- the most efficient way to handle most situations. Private insurers may authorize such payments case-by-case, but such compensation is not yet common.
Given the policy makers' wariness about supporting new home-care services, entrepreneurs like Dr. D. Gresham Bayne, founder of Calldoctor, face difficulty in proving the value of their ventures.
 
Emergency Service
 Calldoctor's vans, each staffed by a doctor and a technician trained to handle a variety of functions otherwise performed by a battery of hospital workers, contain most of the same equipment found in an emergency room, including X-ray machines.
When a Calldoctor physician decides a patient requires hospitalization, the company telephones in information that allows the patient to avoid waiting in an emergency room or admissions area. In other cases, a Calldoctor visit replaces a trip to the hospital.
Recently, Dr. A. Chris de Laurier, the company's medical director, answered a call at a small hotel room that is home to a woman whose legs were amputated. The woman, who usually goes to the emergency room of the local hospital when she is ill, was treated for severe bronchitis and a sinus infection in her room.
Calldoctor says its average charge of $200 is nearly 70 percent less than the basic charge at emergency rooms in the San Diego area. Patients also avoid the cost of the trip to the hospital, which can be as much as $350 in an ambulance.
The company, just five years old, spent three years designing the layout of its Ford vans. Dr. Bayne hopes to take it nationwide next year.
 
Rehabilitation Specialist
 Another new home-care company, Wellmark Healthcare Services Inc., based in the Boston suburb of Westwood, focuses on the rehabilitation of patients who have been severely disabled by illness or injury. "People are being discharged quicker and sicker from hospitals," said Jessica Robins Miller, a Wellmark social worker who had worked in hospitals for 13 years.
The company's teams include physicians, rehabilitation nurses, physical and occupational therapists and social workers. As in many other home-care programs, Wellmark puts more emphasis than most hospitals and clinics on recruiting patients' relatives, friends and employers as participants in the recovery. "You are more involved in all aspects of their lives," Mrs. Miller said.
The company points to case histories to suggest that patients often recover faster and more thoroughly than they would in a hospital. Mrs. Miller described the case of a 13-year-old boy who lost part of his left leg and part of his hand in a train accident. She said he had recently returned to school after only two months of intensive therapy and counseling from Wellmark in his home.
 
Home-Infusion Services
 These new ventures hope to duplicate the record of home-infusion services. These dominated the industry's expansion during the 1980's and are still growing at an impressive, though slower, 15 to 20 percent rate.
Millions of patients who would have stayed in hospitals to receive infusions of pain killers, antibiotics, intravenous nutritional supplements and anti-cancer drugs instead receive them through increasingly compact pumps at home under the supervision of expert nurses.
Medicare still does not cover home infusion for many drugs, but a growing number of private insurers do. The home-infusion companies' biggest allure has been savings of 30 percent or more compared with similar therapy in hospitals.
Home infusion technology continues to improve. Executives at the Ross Laboratories subsidiary of Abbott Laboratories Inc. in Chicago cite new pumps with better electronic sensors and miniature bellows that allow more precise control over the flow of medicine. Thw I-Flow Corporation of Irvine, Calif., is selling a portable infusion system that can deliver up to four separate medicines at four different rates and be reprogramed by a doctor by telephone.
Baxter International remains the giant of the business. It has long dominated the market for portable dialysis equipment that is used to cleanse the blood of patients suffering from kidney failure. Most other home- infusion companies are known for their regional strength or their focus on particular illnesses, including AIDS, hemophilia and high-risk pregnancies.
"This business has such a tail wind, that it's currently accommodating the growth of a number of companies," said John F. Hindelong, an analyst who tracks more than a dozen home-infusion companies for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "There are pockets of intense competition but that's the exception. We don't expect aggressive price competition for a couple of years."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
On Buffing and Polishing Even the Stereotypes

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
In the long, healthy career of Claude Chabrol, from his New Wave classic "The Cousins" through his sumptuous "Madame Bovary," which opened yesterday, "Inspector Lavardin" is a trifle. But this lighthearted detective movie shows that trifling entertainments do not have to be hack work. This wily film has first-rate appeal and plays into some cherished stereotypes about the French: it is blase, stylish, filled with effortless charm.
Though the film appeared in France in 1986, it has its United States premiere today at the Eighth Street Playhouse. The delay may reflect the film's slightness and the economics of distributing foreign films, but not its popularity abroad. This is, in fact, a sequel. The first Chabrol film to feature the urbane detective Lavardin was "Poulet au Vinaigre," which was released in France in 1985 and has yet to appear in the United States. 
 The plot involves a devout and wealthy Roman Catholic writer who is found murdered on a beach with the word pig written on his back. When Inspector Lavardin arrives to investigate, he discovers that the widow, Helene, is an old flame he hasn't seen in 20 years, a well-preserved beauty of elegant style and almost catatonic personality.
She and her family seem a strange match for the religious writer. Her daughter by a previous husband is a sweet 13-year-old schoolgirl by day, a nymphet by night. Helene's brother announces that since his wife's death he has preferred Romeos to Juliets and says, in English, that he is "the gay widower." His hobby is collecting painted glass eyeballs. Here is a classic situation: put a detective in a house where everyone has something to hide. Whether the family secrets are related to the murder is another question entirely.
As Lavardin, Jean Poiret has some resemblance to the middle-aged Laurence Olivier, with playful icy blue eyes and distinguished gray hair. He also has, as the final credits tell us, a wardrobe by Lanvin. Don't ask questions about detectives' salaries; doesn't everyone dress well in France? He underplays his charm as he snoops around the house and the countryside with his sidekick, whom he fondly calls Watson.
Despite such touches, there is nothing self-conscious about this cleverly sophisticated but straightforward use of the detective genre. Perhaps that is why, when the murderer is revealed, the episode is too Hitchcockian for its own good. It would take a lot more irony or homage to pull this off.
But the cast never lets the film down. Bernadette Lafont, something of a New Wave icon, looks appropriately frozen as Helene, with her pearls and perfect blond hair and blank, lost-in-the-past expression. Jean-Claude Brialy is wonderfully ambiguous as the brother, whose increasingly obvious lies may be for good or sinister purposes. And Mr. Poiret's performance as Lavardin is wry but never mocking -- just what a charming trifle needs.
 
Inspector Lavardin
 
Directed by Claude Chabrol; written by Dominique Roulet, based on an original idea and adaption by Mr. Chabrol and Ms. Roulet, in French with English subtitles; director of photography, Jean Rabier; edited by Monique Fardoulis and Angela Braga-Mermet; music by Matthieu Chabrol; production designer, Francoise Benoit-Fresco; produced by Martin Karmitz; released by MK 2 Productions et Films A2. At the Eighth Street Playhouse, at Avenue of the Americas. Running time: 100 minutes. This film has no rating.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Tartabull Negotiations Centering on Angels

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Danny Tartabull, whose 1991 offensive statistics were better than Bobby Bonilla's, remains the most attractive player left in baseball's free-agent market, and his prolonged availability has created one of the more intriguing developments of the off season.
Despite an angry confrontation between his agent and the Angels' general manager, California remains the team most likely to sign Tartabull, but at a price perhaps $2 million to $3 million below prior expectations, a lawyer who has had vast experience with free-agent negotiations said yesterday. 
 "Someone else could come out of the woods and get him, but Whitey is still the primary guy in this," the lawyer said, referring to Whitey Herzog, the Angels' general manager. "Whitey is clearly talking to Tartabull's agent."
The agent, Dennis Gilbert, has declined to discuss his negotiations for Tartabull, but earlier this week he said three teams remained in contention for the outfielder, who last season batted .316, hit 31 home runs, drove in 100 runs and led the American League with a .593 slugging percentage.
 
Rangers and White Sox Interested
 The other two teams apparently are the Texas Rangers and the Chicago White Sox. Tom Grieve, the Rangers' general manager, said yesterday that he and two other club officials had a "serious discussion" with Tartabull and Gilbert in Los Angeles last Saturday. He said he expected that they would have additional "serious discussions."
Bonilla received $29 million for five years, or $5.8 million a year, from the Mets. Tartabull had been expected to lag about $1 million a year and one year behind Bonilla, meaning he would gain a four-year contract in the $18.5 million-$19 million neighborhood.
Gilbert represents both Bonilla and Tartabull, and Herzog verbally assaulted him in a hotel coffee shop at the winter meetings in Miami Beach early this month, accusing the agent of lying to him and using the Angels to get a better contract for Bonilla elsewhere.
Gilbert was stunned by Herzog's attack, especially because they have known each other since Gilbert played in the Mets' minor league system when Herzog operated it.
The lawyer, who spoke on condition he not be identified, echoed the thinking among some people in baseball that Herzog also acted as he did with the Tartabull negotiations in mind, feeling that he could wind up lowering the cost to the Angels of signing the free agent. The lawyer speculated that the savings could be $2 million to $3 million.
Although the lawyer had no specific information from any ongoing talks between Gilbert and any club, he said the prevailing speculation was that Tartabull would now emerge with the kind of offer the Angels made unsuccessfully to Wally Joyner: four years for about $16 million.
The Rangers' economic interest in Tartabull would most likely be tempered by their negotiations with their own outstanding hitter, Ruben Sierra, who can be a free agent after next season. The Rangers have not offered Sierra more than $4 million a year, and they have not offered more than three guaranteed years.
"We're trying to do everything we can to put the strongest team on the field," Grieve said by telephone from Texas. "Having Tartabull would make our lineup better. It makes a lot more sense to spend money on players rather than pitchers."
The Angels need additional hitting more desperately than the Rangers. Texas led American League in runs scored while California was 13th.
The Angels have replaced Joyner and Dave Winfield, their two most productive players, with Von Hayes and Hubie Brooks, both of whom will be returning from injury-plagued, poor-production seasons.
Of the 98 players who became free agents Nov. 12, 34 have signed new contracts (including two with Japanese teams) and 8 others accepted their clubs' offers of salary arbitration, meaning they will remain with those teams. Another free agent, Ron Hassey, joined the Yankees as a scout, leaving 54 free agents besides Tartabull looking for jobs.
Among those who remain unemployed are second baseman Mike Gallego, shortstop Kurt Stillwell, third baseman Mike Pagliarulo, outfielder Mookie Wilson, designated hitters Pete Incaviglia and Alvin Davis and pitchers Dennis Rasmussen, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, Kirk McCaskill and Bob Walk.
Baseball's winter season is also approaching another major phase. Beginning Jan. 4, the 159 eligible players may file for salary arbitration. Some of the more noted players eligible are Barry Bonds, Ruben Sierra, Cecil Fielder, Roberto Kelly, Roberto Alomar, Ron Gant, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Rob Dibble, Barry Larkin, David Cone, Gregg Jefferies, Doug Drabek and John Smiley.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

 BODY:
The Italians have replaced the Japanese as the No. 1 buyers of art in the world, according to an annual list of the top 200 collectors, appearing in the January issue of Art News Magazine.
In fact, the number of Japanese collectors on the list dropped to 10 from 15, the steepest decline from last year, while those from Germany increased to 18 from 10, the biggest increase. 
 But numbers of collectors do not necessarily reflect their worth. There are 106 American collectors on the list, down from 109. There are only six Italians -- the same number as last year -- but their purchases outranked everyone else, said Art News, which did not report the monetary value of any collection.
It seems the list is something of a barometer of the world's economy. "Germany has not been affected by the recession that hit the United States, or the downturn that some folks in Japan are experiencing," notes MILTON ESTEROW, editor and publisher of the magazine.
A big surprise, he says, was a nearly 20 percent turnover from last year's list -- 39 new names, including HENRY W. BLOCH, the tax man, who collects Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, and SUSIE TOMPKINS, co-founder of Esprit de Corp. clothing, who collects 20th-century photography.
The list indicates several trends, as Mr. Esterow sees it. He notices a wider spread of buyers in the world and predicts that "we will be hearing more from collectors in Korea and Taiwan." And he perceives an emerging generation of collectors who do their own homework and choose art "they personally respond to" instead of relying on experts or collecting for "status and all the silly reasons."

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Toward the Ideal

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Have civil rights laws dealt adequately with racial problems in America? Has all that had to be done now been done? Has the burden shifted to blacks and other minorities to prove that they can compete in the colorblind society that now should exist? At Christmas 1991, many Americans seem to think so.
Witness the white majority's rising opposition to "quotas" -- the national shorthand for affirmative-action programs. "Cultural diversity" -- a catchall phrase for education policies that seem to threaten the dominance of a Western-focused curriculum -- also causes widespread anxiety among whites. Crime has converted white concern for the urban, mostly black underclass into fear and anger. 
 Few if any would advocate a return to state-ordered segregation, the virtual elimination of which in the South has been the great triumph of the civil rights movement. Nor would many Americans favor a revival of voting patterns that effectively excluded blacks from real political power.
But a great many Americans apparently do believe that because of these and other gains, enough has been "given" to minorities. The civil rights crisis, in this view, is over; the nation finally did what the Constitution and decency required, so every American of whatever color now plays -- or should play -- on the same level field.
If anything, these Americans assert, it's now white people who suffer discrimination -- when "quotas" cause them to lose out on jobs or educational and advancement opportunities. And this is not only unfair but unnecessary in this colorblind society, from which legal and official discrimination against minorities already has been eliminated.
This attitude overlooks continued, documented discrimination in bank and auto loans, housing availability, education, employment, economic opportunities, the most vital areas of life -- and not just in the South. Now it's disclosed that thousands of minority businesses have gone under because of court rulings that state and local government preferences designed to benefit them are unconstitutional.
In Philadelphia alone, Michael deCourcy Hinds has reported in The New York Times, black businesses saw their share of the city's contracts drop from 25 percent to 3.5 percent in fiscal 1990, and decline in value from $65 million to $21.3 million. This followed a court decision outlawing a Philadelphia law that set aside a share of its contracts for minority enterprises.
The picture is much the same elsewhere, as the result of a Supreme Court decision in 1989 that invalidated a similar law in Richmond, Va. The Court held that the racial set-aside deprived white contractors of the equal protection of the laws.
Many minority businesses -- though some were ill managed and most were inexperienced -- could not survive without the preferences. Did these disadvantage white competitors and violate the ideal of colorblindness? Or were they, as claimed to Mr. Hinds by Jihad Ali, a Philadelphia contractor who started his minority business with $500 in 1986, "a program to make up for 400 years of injustice"?
The answer is "yes" to both questions. A preference is obviously disadvantageous to those who don't get it -- just as, for 400 years, the preference that went culturally and automatically, even if not legally, to white businesses was historically disadvantageous to black competitors. But if the answer is "yes" only to the first question, the conclusion seems irrefutable that this is not yet a colorblind society.
How can it be "colorblind," how can the playing field be level, if would-be black entrepreneurs have been prevented from gaining the experience and resources to compete equally against whites? If a minority business was awarded contracts when that was legally required, but not after the law was voided, might not discrimination have been involved, at least partially?
And if the ideal is a level, colorblind playing field, how can that be achieved without some assistance to those who need help in competing, while they need it? And who better to lend that assistance than state and local governments, which most crucially affect the lives and livelihoods of Americans?
Many of these jurisdictions are preparing new and improved laws to meet court requirements and base minority preferences on proven discrimination. In a society that's still blatantly color-conscious, that's a necessary step toward the ideal.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 715 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
Optimists Are the Realists

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For Americans, 1492, 1776, 1862, 1945 and 1991 were the five best years of the past five centuries.
That's making a fairly big claim for this current year, especially when the Gloomy Guses are wailing about hard times, nuclear instability and holes in the ozone layer. 
 But consider reality, as Mikhail Gorbachev had to do in making a Christmas present to the world of his departure. The yoke of Communism has been lifted from a quarter of a billion people in this year, and the threat of its pernicious reach has been lifted from a third of a billion Europeans.
And that's not all: the division of an unnatural empire into its national parts has not only reduced the danger of superpower clash, but has engendered a new rationality in the Middle East and South Africa.
Peace -- real peace -- has broken out; why is nobody celebrating? Democracy has prevailed in its worldwide struggle against tyranny; why are democrats not dancing in the streets?
One reason for the curious reluctance to embrace the reality of the good news is that it has taken months to unfold; one-day victories are easier to grasp for whooping-up purposes. Another reason is that it seems too good to be true, and we don't want to jinx our incipient no-hitter by talking about it.
The biggest reason is that we are in the grip of the Melancholia Industry. This high priesthood of deep pessimism has a vested interest in the status quo of unrelieved worry.
Diplomatic depressives must justify their mistaken past doomsaying about Soviet disunion; political melancholiacs must knock down any outbursts of joy lest incumbents benefit; economic sages feel they must follow the herd of malcontented cows into their double-dipsy-doodle.
This cacophony of serious wailing is amplified by the megaphone of the media. No conspiracy; only the realization that bad news means good ratings and good news means a vast, happy tuning-out.
Moreover, the mild recession has touched the coastal media centers as never before. With layoffs hitting home, the viewer and reader would never know that non-frictional unemployment is much lower than in the recession a decade ago, even allowing for slow growth in the labor force.
As a result, it is unfashionable to be feisty. To be gloomy is to be serious; to be joyful is seen as frivolous or deceptive. That's why leaders are unwilling to appear confident; they fear the appearance of lacking compassion or being out of touch with the upside-down perception of reality.
That's why we foolishly flip over the coin of peaceful transition in 14 freed republics to examine violence in one; why we ignore the exciting potential for private farm and oil development to deplore the possibility of food riots; why we focus at home on the homeless and crime but overlook the liberating breakthroughs in neuroscience, computer education and genetics. That's why, in the world of the winners, you never hear the word "victory."
Such stress on stress warps reality. Let us stipulate that small wars and the poor will be with us; that nuclear spread to terrorists will be cause for concerted action; that earthquakes and floods will happen, and the innocent will suffer.
Now deal with the reality that will change our lives in the run-up to the millennium. Demobilization is real. The troops are coming home all over the world, and all we hear is "Where will they live? Who will give them jobs?" The fact is that tens of millions of able-bodied young people will move out of the inflationary business of war and into the world of productive work.
Here at home, the next generation will be much better off than ours because it will not have to bear the superpower burden of defense. Free of the cost of protecting Japan and Europe, the U.S. can better compete with them.
This was also the year that we stopped a near-nuclear dictator before he could take over the world's oil supply and dictate our inflation and interest rates. The lowest interest rates in a generation will sell houses, attract equity investment and propel the economy.
Freedom shined so brightly in 1991 that too many of us were willing to observe it through a glass darkly. Throw away the filter that obscures reality; this is a glorious moment in history, harbinger of good times to come.

HEADLINE: Child Poverty in the U.S. Continues to Grow;
A Misogynist Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Dec. 9 Washington Memo on Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and welfare: If all that were wrong with society were welfare dependency, that problem could be solved by eliminating welfare, something almost every political demagogue since the Depression has proposed. Unfortunately, Mr. Moynihan's insistence that "we were right" and your description of his "worrying out loud about the rise in dependency and the collapse of the family since at least 1965" masks many of the problems in his "explosive paper subsequently dubbed 'The Moynihan Report.' " 
 That report, rather than a piece of balanced scholarship, argued that the black family had been rendered a "tangle of pathology" by its experience of slavery and the failure of its families to raise male children undamaged by family matriarchs. Mr. Moynihan and his staff used and misread a number of scholars, particularly E. Franklin Frazier and Stanley Elkins. Ironically, they cited statistics gathered by the Urban League, a group very concerned with the problems of the black poor.
The report drew scholarly criticism because it blamed all black families for the problems of some families by painting a distorted picture using a small subset of multiproblem families, something pointed out in great detail by Andrew Billingsley in "Black Families in White America." Mr. Moynihan further confused matters by linking welfare dependency and black male unemployment to the high rates of labor force participation of black women to prove the black community was "matriarchal."
In one particularly egregious footnote, he complained about the large number of black women employed as clerical workers in the Department of Labor to suggest that black women pushed black men out of the labor market. The so-called report never took into account the massive change in the demand for female labor that was changing the employment opportunities for all women and the structure of labor force participation for black women, making it possible for them to work as nurses and clerical workers, not just household domestics -- jobs neither available to men nor wanted by them.
The logic of blaming black women's employment for the problems of welfare dependency escaped many of us who found problems in the report. Mr. Moynihan never took up the problems of industrial structure and social change, and never attempted to describe and then explain the problems of all families or all black families in all their diversity.
His report simply implied from the statistic on the number of children in one-parent families that black women were in charge of the black community and out of step with the nation's presumption of male leadership in public and private affairs.
The paper was originally a confidential report intended to appeal to a group of conservative politicians, who would be easily swayed by its distortions. Yet it spawned a major industry of academic scholarship, which dissected and examined poor black families, the work ethic of black men, the gender relations of married black people, the black family in slavery and other possible explanations of the black family.
There is a huge academic literature on the black family for anyone who wishes to go to a library and search the right indexes. It is a standard topic routinely included in review articles on family research. Your statement that "for decades the condition of the black family was seldom discussed in political and academic circles" is inaccurate.
Had Mr. Moynihan's paper been submitted to an academic journal or a learned society, such as the American Sociological Association, many of the inaccuracies, misconnections and distortions would have been roundly criticized, and the author would probably have been asked to make extensive revisions connecting his data to his explanations of the problems of poor black families on welfare.
The problem was that the report carried the authority of the highest levels of government as a foundation for social policy. It also made political uses of poor black people that sound eerily like David Duke's election campaigns. The report created such an explosive mixture of poverty and race that the only public image of poverty is a black image.
The report remains today what it was in 1965 -- a misogynist piece of pseudo-social science that did little to advance our understanding of black families or white families in all of their diverse responses to social change and deindustrialization. Let us hope in his policy making that Senator Moynihan takes time to read some of the more accurate and sophisticated work on families and their problems in order to provide the programs necessary to bring the jobless poor back into the labor force, to provide the working poor with a truly livable income and to create these programs in a context that does not blame women for the problems of men.
 
CHERYL TOWNSEND GILKES
Waterville, Me., Dec. 16, 1991
 
The writer is MacArthur Associate Professor of Sociology and African-American Studies at Colby College.
