LENGTH: 2403 words

HEADLINE: Harkin Seeks to Recall Democrats' History, Though Some Fear It

SERIES: First of six articles on the Democratic Presidential candidates. Next:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
There is still a long line for the breakfast buffet grits and refried beans -- when Jim Hightower, the former Texas Agriculture Commissioner, is called on to introduce the featured speaker. He grabs the podium and starts in with the adjectives.
 "This is a guy who is an unabashed, unapologetic, ungentrified, un-Republicanized, old-time, little people's Democrat," Mr. Hightower says, and the crowd lays down its collective fork and starts cheering. "Not just a progressive, but a person who is a-ggressive. This is a guy who knows how to take on these effete elites in the White House: George Herbert Walker Bush of Kennebunkport, C. Boyden Gray of the R. J. Reynolds inheritance and J. Danforth Quayle 3d of Pluto and points beyond." 
The crowd whistles its approval, and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa smiles and acknowledges the applause.
 "I've always believed in that passage out of Corinthians," Mr. Harkin says to the crowd. " 'If the trumpeter blow an uncertain sound, who will follow in the path?' Well, I can tell you with me you won't get an uncertain sound. You may not agree with where I stand, but you'll know what I stand for and what I stand against. And that's exactly how I intend to take on George Herbert Walker Bush."
 He continued: "If you don't remember anything else, remember one thing. I can whip George Bush. If I get in that ring, I can flatten him."
 This mixture of pugilism and politics is typical of Senator Harkin, a man who often seems to be running for President the way other men might pick a fight, with scorn in his voice and the memory of past slights on his mind. But if the style expresses Mr. Harkin's naturally combative personality, it is also one that is tailored to appeal to the core of Democratic voters -- the kind who are disheartened by the party's losses and who tend to turn out for primaries.
 
Replaying the Past

 Appeal to Labor And Liberals
 Mr. Harkin's campaign is built around the assumption that despite the results of the last three elections, a Democrat's best hope in 1992 is to aggressively defend the party's traditions. His hope is that a candidate who can make Democrats feel proud of their party again can win their loyalty -- and their votes.
 "Harkin believes that in bad economic times it is possible to appeal to traditional Democratic constituencies," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "This means not running away from labor, but embracing it. It means not shying away from more liberal groups, but courting them."
 Playing to labor and to the liberal wing of the party is essentially the same strategy that helped Walter F. Mondale and Michael S. Dukakis win the Democratic nomination, and then lose the general election. Many Democrats worry that history will repeat itself, and Mr. Harkin's tough talk about "whipping" Mr. Bush seems aimed at deflecting such anxieties.
 Mr. Harkin makes a point of trying to distinguish himself from his hapless predecessors, Mr. Mondale and Mr. Dukakis. They were not genuine, old-style Democrats, he suggests, and more importantly, they crumpled under pressure.
 "I believe there is a real hunger in this country to turn away from the policies of the last few years," he told the audience in Austin. "I think that hunger was there in 1988. Then we had a Willie Horton ad, a Pledge of Allegiance ad, a Boston Harbor ad and we didn't fight back, and that was the end of that campaign. I just want you to know this is one candidate who believes in fighting back."
 Conventional political wisdom holds that Mr. Harkin's main rival for the support of the traditionalists of the Democratic Party was Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York; indeed, many politicians had speculated that Mr. Harkin's candidacy would not survive Mr. Cuomo's entry into the race. Mr. Harkin's supporters now hope that he will be the chief beneficiary of the Governor's decision last week not to run.
 Appealing to traditional Democratic constituencies, Mr. Harkin offers a traditional Democratic prescription for solving the country's problems, a back-to-the-future-type program that relies heavily on the ideals of the New Deal. He calls, for example, for the Federal Government to embark on huge public works projects, like the Works Progress Administration efforts of the 1930's, that he says will put millions of Americans back to work. And he advocates passage of a new version of the G.I. Bill, which sent thousands of World War II veterans to college. Under his version, students could attend college free in return for several years of national service in the military, in hospitals or environmental cleanups, for example.
 In Mr. Harkin's down-home, pull-no-punches Presidential campaign, it is clearly the pitch more than the particulars that matter, and the Senator often brushes aside questions about the details of his proposals as if they were beside the point.
 Mr. Harkin, for instance, is a strong advocate of a national health care plan, but asked recently how malpractice would be handled under his proposal, he confessed genially that he had not really considered this issue. Asked how he would finance his public works projects, Mr. Harkin offers generalities. "It is time to stop subsidizing Europe and Japan and bring the money back home," he says.
 This inattention to detail has prompted even some of Mr. Harkin's allies to question whether his program is substantive enough to be seen as credible. But aides to the Senator insist that this criticism is undeserved. Mr. Harkin, they maintain, has purposefully tried to avoid subordinate issues and to focus attention on his major themes.
 "He's been very disciplined in terms of keeping the focus on the message," said Mr. Harkin's campaign manager, Tim Raftis. "He's been criticized for that, but it's a message that communicates with working people and that cuts across geographical, cultural and political boundaries."
 In a primary campaign, candidates tend to talk to the party faithful, and among this crowd, Mr. Harkin's message does seem to touch a chord -- even when it seems slightly out of tune with the setting.
 At a recent luncheon the Senator spoke to the well-heeled members of the Dallas Democratic Forum over pasta with cream sauce in an elegant downtown hotel. It did not seem like a crowd that would be particularly impressed by the Senator's populist oratory, and yet Mr. Harkin gave the same speech he gives before college students and labor unions. "I don't intend to hold George Bush's feet to the fire," he said. "I intend to put him into the fire."
 After the lunch, Alan Kahn, a forum member, said that while he did not necessarily agree with everything Mr. Harkin had said he liked the candidate's spirit. "I think he believes in what he's saying," Mr. Kahn said. "I don't know how far he's going to get with it, but it's refreshing to hear someone that candid."
 
Financing 1992

 A Frontrunner In the Money Race
 One way in which Mr. Harkin's spirited, Bush-bashing campaign has already paid off is in fund raising. Earlier this month, when the Presidential candidates applied for Federal matching funds, he was the best-financed Democrat.
 All individual contributions of $250 or less qualify for matching money. Mr. Harkin, according to his application, has collected $1.1 million in such contributions, and that is more than any of his Democratic rivals had taken in. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was second, with $581,000, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska was third, with $579,000. President Bush has $2.6 million in matchable financing.
 "It was the Clinton campaign that said that money was the first primary," Mr. Raftis said. "Well, they got whipped."
 Whether Mr. Harkin has maintained his early fund-raising edge will not be known until the end of next month, when the candidates have to make a detailed filing to the Federal Election Commission. Both the Clinton and Kerrey campaigns say they have made significant progress in recent weeks.
 Part of Mr. Harkin's early success at fund raising can be attributed simply to the time he has devoted to it. "In the number of events, Tom has probably done twice as many as the others," said Nathan Landow, chairman of the Democratic party in Maryland, where Mr. Harkin's campaign is based.
 Part of it, though, is also a result of Mr. Harkin's direct-mail campaign, which has been surprisingly successful.
 Most of the Democratic candidates this year have shied from soliciting contributions through the mail, a process that requires a large initial investment and that can produce uncertain returns. But Mr. Harkin began a direct-mail campaign immediately upon announcing his candidacy in September.
 Although aides to the Senator decline to give details, they acknowledge that the campaign has produced more money than even they expected. It is being handled by Mal Warwick and Associates of Berkeley, Calif., the same company that handled the Rev. Jesse Jackson's effort in 1988.
 "Tom's message lends itself to mail," said Carter Eskew, a political consultant who has worked on Mr. Harkin's Senate campaigns. "And it is a tremendous advantage to have a good direct-mail program because it gives you a real boost in the beginning when you need matching funds." Contributions solicited through the mail tend to be under $250 and therefore are eligible for matching money.
 Well-known from his Senate campaigns as an aggressive fund raiser, Mr. Harkin does not shun contributions from political action committees, and he is expected to be the major recipient among Democrats of money from such sources. In the last detailed filing that the candidates made to the Federal Election Commission, Mr. Harkin listed $60,000 in such contributions, significantly more than was declared by any other Democratic candidate.
 Mr. Harkin's decision to woo political action money -- some of his opponents, including Governor Clinton and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, have said they would not accept it -- has made him a target for people who are pressing for changes in campaign-finance law. Political action money, which comes from widely diverse sources, including unions and large corporations, has been important in the financing of Congressional as well as past presidential campaigns and this has fostered the impression that elected officials are hostage to special interest groups.
 In keeping with his credo, "Never defend, always attack," Mr. Harkin expresses no doubts about his decision.
 "I take P.A.C money, you bet I do," he told the audience in Dallas. "I don't want to fight with one hand tied behind my back. In George Bush, we are up against the mother of all money machines."
 
Testing the Waters

 New Hampshire Becomes Crucial
 As a native of Iowa and presumably its favorite Presidential candidate, Mr. Harkin has turned the first major contest of the primary season, the Iowa caucus on Feb. 10, into a nonevent. He is expected to win handily -- if he does not, it will be a major setback -- and so far none of the other candidates have bothered to challenge him there.
 The assumption that Mr. Harkin will win comfortably in Iowa has heightened the importance of the New Hampshire primary, the nation's first, which will be held Feb. 18. All the major Democratic candidates, except perhaps Governor Clinton, who must make a strong showing in the early southern primaries, know they need to do well in New Hampshire to stay in the race.
 Mr. Harkin's aides acknowledge that a good showing in New Hampshire is crucial, but they are careful not to define a good showing as first place. "The story often has been the strong showing in second," said Kay Casstevens, the Senator's deputy campaign manager.
 Campaigning for President in New Hampshire, where 10,000 votes can mean the difference between a defeat in the primary and a landslide, often seems to have as much glamor as running for a city council seat; on a recent visit to the state, for example, Mr. Harkin put in an hour and a half at a health-care forum that attracted no more than a dozen potential voters. He is a frequent visitor to diners and hotel basement meetings.
 New Hampshire is a state where voters expect to be contacted personally, if not by the candidate himself, then at least by his staff. Organization is critical for such a ground assault and Mr. Harkin has by most accounts established a solid team. His state director is Kathi Rogers, chairwoman of the Merrimack County Democratic Party, and his co-chairmen in the state are Mary Chambers, minority leader of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, and John Durkin, a former United States Senator.
 The Harkin campaign's central staff, based in Bethesda, Md., is at this point comparatively small in keeping with a strategy aimed at husbanding resources for a television and radio advertising blitz in New Hampshire starting next month. As of now, the campaign is without an official media consultant, although it is planning to sign up Ken Swope, who produced some of the primary commercials for Mr. Dukakis four years ago.
 So much depends on the New Hampshire race that the road beyond, whether long or short, is hard to anticipate. Mr. Harkin hopes to win enough support in early primaries, including in South Dakota and Minnesota, to be able to survive a poor showing on Super Tuesday, March 10, when a half-dozen Southern states will hold primaries. He is also making forays into Texas and Florida, where he says he believes he could make inroads in Mr. Clinton's Southern base.
 Mr. Harkin is certainly working hard at his campaign, but he is not allowing himself to be swallowed up by it. He is, for example, taking this week and next to vacation with his wife and two daughters in the Bahamas where, despite the Senator's blue-collar populism, the family owns a house.
 Whether it takes him all the way to the convention in New York City, Mr. Harkin's give-'em-hell campaign style has already influenced a Democratic Party that has been cowed by 11 years of Republican rule.
 In a sense he has already won, he has made people feel less apologetic about being a Democrat. Even if his candidacy fades, the one thing that he will pass on to the other candidates is the style: Don't take any guff.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1991, Saturday

Even if his candidacy fades, the one thing that he will pass on to the other candidates is the style: 'Don't take any guff.' "

PUB-DATE: December 26, 1991

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1123 words

HEADLINE: Little Software Maker With a Loud Voice

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBORO, Mass.

 BODY:
Ever since its founding in 1983, the marketing effort of Banyan Systems Inc. was virtually inaudible. The software maker quietly provided large, sophisticated customers with the products to link vast networks of personal computers.
Now Banyan is turning up the volume to seize market share from Novell Inc., its much-better-known rival. 
 Twice as many vendors will now distribute Banyan's products, as the company lays plans for going public next year and increases its visibility with a full frontal attack on Novell. "Things They Don't Tell You at Novell Presentations," a brassy new Banyan brochure announces.
"They've established a strong marketing presence for the first time in their history," said Robert Gill of the Gartner Group, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. "They are now getting in the door to pitch their story."
Banyan, based in this suburb west of Boston, has only 7.5 percent of the $1.2 billion market for network software. That is dwarfed by Novell, based in Provo, Utah, which, by serving much smaller computer networks, has captured almost 60 percent of the market. Novell has annual sales of $700 million and the loyalty of the nation's largest computer companies.
Some industry consultants, like George Colony of Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., believe Novell is simply too strong a competitor for Banyan or any other seller of network software.
"Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Digital have all thrown their hats in with Novell's Netware," Mr. Colony said, explaining that these companies have agreed to sell Netware -- Novell's network software -- with their own products. "The game is over."
Others say that Banyan's technology has been too far ahead of its time, and now that the world is ready for its products, it faces in Novell a much more powerful marketer.
David C. Mahoney, Banyan's president, chief executive and one of its founders, remains undaunted. He delivers his sales pitch with the vigor of an evangelist. Rather than compete directly with Novell, he decided to concentrate on linking larger computer networks.
"We had a vision and didn't want to deviate from it," he said.
Stressing Banyan's 25 percent annual growth rate and 20 straight profitable quarters, he noted that Banyan had successfully left the computer hardware business, which just last year accounted for 50 percent of sales, to focus on the more profitable sale of software.
Mr. Mahoney expects Banyan to increase its sales from $100 million to $500 million in just five years. Banyan, he said, has staked out a critical niche, with the technical strengths to emerge as a major, long-term competitor.
One of Mr. Mahoney's most pressing tasks is gaining credibility with many more corporate customers. To do that, Banyan, which is privately held, will probably go public early in 1992. Mr. Mahoney said that the company did not need the cash, but that corporate customers tended to be wary of private companies, and financial analysts ignored Banyan while touting its competitors.
"The financial community provides critical information to our customers," he said. "And the more viable and long term you look, the more they buy."
 
Pushing and Shoving
 Mr. Mahoney, 46 years old, is the sort of businessman who is not afraid to push and shove. He still plays goalie on a team of former college and professional hockey players.
He founded Banyan with two associates in 1983 -- one now the technology chief, the other departed to start his own software company. They named the company for a tropical tree that drops vines that then grow their own roots.
Banyan's problem today is not Novell but Banyan itself, Mr. Mahoney said: it simply has not gotten its message out. His solution was to bring in a new marketing chief last year, James D'Arezzo, the former vice president of international marketing at the Compaq Computer Corporation.
Mr. Mahoney is confident that Banyan's stronger marketing campaign will persuade others to share his vision. He says that the large global computer networks Banyan specializes in organizing will become as common as global telephone links.
"When the telephone was first introduced, everything was loosely organized and it took 25 years before the infrastructure was put into place for the modern phone networks," he explained. "Today I can talk to anyone in the world from my car. Computers will be the same way."
 
Building Vast Networks
 Companies will depend increasingly on building vast networks of personal computers, printers, scanners and fax machines, with users able to communicate immediately, he said.
This year, the Marine Corps used Banyan's Vines software in the Persian Gulf war to link 350 personal computers throughout the region -- transmitting almost immediately the equivalent of 300 pages of orders that until recently took hours to deliver electronically.
Banyan's Vines system allows users to find and communicate with each other in seconds -- a technically sophisticated feature that Novell's Netware lacks.
"If you use Novell's Netware with 500 users, it is very difficult to find the user you are looking for," said Frank Michnoff, a consultant with the Meta Group in Westport, Conn. "Are you going to scroll through 500 names? Not likely."
 
Seeing Larger Groupings
 Mr. Mahoney said that Banyan had 26 percent of the market for networks of 300 to 600 personal computers, about the same share as Novell. He expects that high-end segment to grow dramatically, as the market for small networks, Novell's specialty, eventually dries up.
Industry consultants say that Banyan has 12 to 18 months before Novell comes out with its own improved features for locating other users on a network.
"That will take away the most impressive advantage Banyan has," Mr. Michnoff of the Meta Group said.
Producing such sophisticated software is no simple matter, Mr. Mahoney contends. "If you didn't make this decision eight years ago, it would be very difficult to get into it now," he said.
 
Coming Counterattack
 And Banyan boasts of its coming counterattack: software that will allow many key features of Vines to run on systems linked by Novell's Netware. Though the delivery date is uncertain, Mr. Mahoney counts on this innovation to win customers who would otherwise wait for Novell's new features.
But many of those in the industry who agree that Banyan's short-range prospects are bright continue to question Mr. Mahoney's insistence that Banyan can remain independent indefinitely.
"They'll go public first and then, once they've been under more scrutiny, they may get acquired," Charlie Robbins, a consultant with the Aberdeen Group in Boston, predicted. "They can't go it alone at $100 million."

HEADLINE: Dow Soars to Record 3,082.96 Despite Vulnerable Economy

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stock prices jumped to record levels yesterday, continuing a rally that has defied gloomy expectations about the nation's economy. The rise apparently reflects confidence that a recovery will finally appear in 1992.
In a market that showed surprising strength, with many investors still distracted by the holidays, several indexes reached highs. The rally began in earnest when the Federal Reserve cut interest rates last Friday; the clear belief is that low interest rates will encourage companies to invest, and with yields down on other investments, stocks have become a more attractive option. 
 The number that for many people defines the market, the Dow Jones industrial average, climbed 31.98 points, to close at 3,082.96, its highest ever. That edged past its previous best, 3,077.15, set on Oct. 18, and puts the Dow 17.1 percent ahead of its level on Jan. 1, when the prospect of war had scared investors off.
 
Acting as a Fortune Teller
 In the face of signs of persistent weakness in the economy, like the recent announcement by General Motors that it would lay off 20,000 workers, the rally, some analysts say, is the best indication that a turnaround is on the way.
"The stock market has always acted as a fortune teller," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston. "It's based on what people think is going to happen."
Mr. Freedman and others said the rally was started by the Federal Reserve's decision to make a sharp cut in the discount rate, the rate at which the central bank issues short-term loans to banks, from 4 1/2 to 3 1/2 percent. In the four trading days since that announcement, the Dow has gained 168 points, or 5.8 percent.
The advance has been fueled by confidence among investors that stocks would continue to rise, even as an economic recovery remains elusive.
"Psychologically, the worst always comes right before a turnaround," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist for Oppenheimer & Company. "The bad news is on the front page, while the good news is in the financial section."
The market ordinarily slows in the final week of the year, as investors cash in gains they have made over the year or make trades for tax purposes. Since early this month, analysts have been predicting a drift, or even a slight downturn, in the market, and many were encouraged and surprised by the recent strong showing.
The overall market has been strong in 1991. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, a broader indication of performance by large stocks than the Dow, is up 22.6 percent and the Nasdaq composite, a measure of the generally smaller stocks traded over the counter, is up 49.6 percent.
Both indexes hit highs yesterday. The S.& P. 500, which pierced the 400 level for the first time, climbed 5.51, to 404.84, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 9.74, to 559.30.
 
Enthusiasm for the War
 For the year, most of those gains came early in the year, amid enthusiasm over the war in the Persian Gulf. Predictions by President Bush that the country would emerge from the recession by midyear proved wrong, but investor concern over the economy eased in recent weeks.
But economists warn low interest rates alone will not do the trick.
"We have the Fed versus the economy," said Robert Warburg, an MMS International analyst. "And the Fed has been losing for the last six months. Without help from Washington, they're going to get swamped."
Asked to explain the strength of the stock market in face of still-shallow consumer confidence, Mr. Metz called yesterday's rally "a vote of confidence in the Fed's decision to make more money available."
 
Many Issues Are Up
 Trading on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 149.2 million shares, down from Tuesday's 162.4 million, but sharply higher than the 78.7 million that changed hands the day after Christmas last year. Gaining stocks far outnumbered losing ones, by 1,286 to 456.
But analysts warned that support in the market might not be as deep as it was broad.
"A surprising amount of pessimism exists in the market," Mr. Warburg said. "There are still people not convinced of this recovery."
If company earnings do not begin to grow and an economic recovery does not arrive by mid-1992, he said, the market may be susceptible to a steep drop. Mr. Metz said he expected the market to continue rising.
 
Leading the Rally
 Among the companies that paced yesterday's rise were Merck, climbing 5 1/4, to 164 1/8; Boeing, which rose 1 1/2, to 46 7/8; Philip Morris, which went up 2 1/8, to 76 1/4; and J. P. Morgan, which rose 2 3/4, to 69 1/2.
The most heavily traded stocks were American Express, up 1, to 20 3/4, with 2.77 million shares changing hands, and Citicorp, up 1, to 10 3/4, on 2.73 million shares.
Transportation stocks performed strongly yesterday, but even more striking is the gains they have marked in recent weeks and months. Since the Fed's announcement last Friday, the Dow Jones transportation average of 20 stocks has shot up 8 percent. For 1991 so far, the transportation stocks have risen 44 percent.
 
Cyclical Stocks Join In
 Mr. Warburg added that the strongest sector of the market, drug, medical and biochemical companies, have been joined in recent weeks by cyclical stocks, whose profits are tied to gains in the economy.
Elsewhere in the market, Roberts Pharmeceuticals rose 3 1/2, to 31 1/2, after announcing a preliminary agreement to buy four prescription pharmaceutical lines from Wyeth Laboratories, a British unit of American Home Products.
Apple Computer was up 2 5/8, to 54 7/8, despite an analyst's estimate that 1992 earnings would drop.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SOVIET UNION: Capitalism's New Frontier - A special report;
Hunting for Riches in Ex-Soviet Lands

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
American companies are treating the territories of the now-defunct Soviet Union as wild, unpredictable places, without reliable laws, but good for trying to strike it rich with ventures that skim the cream from an economy in disarray.
Even Fortune 500 companies are signing deals that have a frontier quality. In fact, the upheaval seems to be stimulating imaginative deal-making, not inhibiting it. The greater the turmoil and risk, the greater the concessions the authorities in the newly independent lands seem willing to grant, although concern is surfacing that deals born today may be canceled tomorrow by some future government that views them as one-sided and exploitative.
 
Promise of Big Profits
 The guiding principle appears to be this: Gamble as little as possible in a risky investment that might very well return a jackpot profit, if the money is not lost altogether in the chaos. Robert S. Strauss, a millionaire Texas lawyer and the United States Ambassador to Moscow, describes the potential and the risk by advising business people that if he were younger -- he is 73 -- he would invest $100,000 in the old Soviet Union and run it up into $10 million, but that if he had $10 million, he would gamble only $100,000 of it. 
 In that canny spirit, Western companies are beginning to ride off in search of profits. Lured by the suddenly easy access to one of the richest lands on earth, they are offering their know-how and a modest infusion of cash in exchange for a share of the most valuable assets of the former Soviet lands: oil, cotton, timber, metals and minerals.
The ventures are mostly small ones, about all that is possible in so disrupted an economy. Indeed, United States Commerce Department records of the more than 2,000 deals between Americans and the authorities in the former Soviet lands show that most involve investments of less than $10 million, and total less than $300 million actually paid out.
But they hold the promise of big profits. One American company, for example, is manufacturing and marketing tampons, a product that is new to most women in the former Soviet lands, and is collecting profits in cotton. Another is pumping oil in Siberia and managing to sell some of the crude abroad for dollars.
The Western entrepreneurs are operating in an environment that Robert D. Hormats, an international investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company, likens "to a Yukon-Wild West economy where investors don't know for sure if they have legal title to what they purchase or laws to back them."
So far, Americans and Germans are the most active at this, encouraged by many business managers in the republics who are openly soliciting Western help to salvage enterprises they cannot seem to operate successfully on their own. As Robert Lipsey, an economist and expert in foreign investment at City University of New York, put it: "There is a recognition of how far they have fallen behind in technology, even low-tech technology. They think industrial countries can show them how to design a shoe, where to put the shoelace, how to attach the top to the bottom."
But along with the solicitations for help have come scattered complaints recently in the press in the former Soviet republics, criticism that suggests that people might find that Western businessmen fit the derisive descriptions of "greedy capitalists" that were so often a feature of Communist polemics.
The critics charge that the business managers who are making deals with the West are contributing far too much in buildings, land, raw materials and promises of profit, while Westerners are risking next to nothing.
So far, only about 50 of the 2,000 American deals are functioning, and dollars have been invested in only a handful of these operations, according to the World Deal Review, which gathers such data. McDonald's claims the largest active project: nearly $65 million paid out so far to open its Moscow restaurant and a food processing center, and also to construct a 10-story office building now going up on city-owned land a block from Red Square.
However small the Western presence so far, American executives argue almost unanimously that to survive, enterprises in the former Soviet Union must acquire not only Western technology but Western know-how in management, marketing and distribution. Still, investing Western expertise is risky, given the chaos, and that requires the lure of a jackpot return.
"In a situation that is perilously close to anarchy, these guys are taking wild risks," said Robert Heilbroner, the economics historian. "They are saying to themselves, 'In the worst of cases, we lose $50 million, but there is a chance to grab the whole marketplace.' "
 
Hunting Someone To Make a Deal
 The Western companies are forming joint ventures by acquiring a stake in enterprises still officially government-owned. With the Soviet government dying for months and now gone, some of the negotiating has taken place with officials of the various republics. Most often, however, American executives are dealing with the managers of state-owned companies that have, in effect, been abandoned by the state.
Graham Allison, a Soviet expert at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, described their evolution.
"You are the manager of a state enterprise, say an aircraft company with 10,000 employees, and you begin to imagine there is no one above you," he said. "You don't get any orders, and the ministry you reported to disappears. You begin to imagine that the property is yours, and since you aren't getting any supplies you have to look out for yourself and your employees. Sometimes you get a foreigner to buy half of the operation in a joint venture. That is spontaneous privatization."
The Gillette Company recently engaged in spontaneous privatization, signing a contract to make razor blades with the managers of amanufacturing complex in St. Petersburg. In return, Gillette was given permission to send home about $33 million a year. The money is to cover the cost of importing special steels and also what Milton L. Glass, Gillette's vice president for finance, calls "a reasonable return on our investment."
Gillette's joint venture with the Russian company, Leninets, promises that the new enterprise will manufacture 900 million high-quality blades a year, enough to make the former Soviet republics self-sufficient in blades. "And the Russians are big shavers," Mr. Glass said.
With self-sufficiency, the 11 members of the new Commonwealth of Independent States can in theory save roughly $100 million a year that is now spent for imported blades. In the contract, the managers of Leninets gave Gillette the right to convert ruble revenue into enough dollars to send abroad one-third of this savings, or $33 million. Gillette, for its part, will invest $50 million over five years to obtain control of the operation. It will spend most of the money on state-of-the-art machinery to make blades.
But will the contract hold up? So far only the Leninets managers have signed it. Various Russian government ministers will also have to sign on.
But should they? Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist and adviser to Eastern European governments, doubts whether any joint venture gives full value to the sellers when control of a company is sold without competitive bidding.
"Without an auction process established in law, the decision is left to managers, which lends itself to corruption," Mr. Sachs said, suggesting that the managers making the deals with the West might pocket some of the proceeds.
 
Americans Looking For Raw Materials
 So far, corruption involving foreign investment has not become a public issue. But corporate America's obsession with collecting its return in hard currency or in valuable products like oil or cotton is causing some problems.
Tambrands, the American manufacturer of Tampax, is a pioneer: since 1988 the company has invested $10 million to operate a new Tampax factory near Kiev. Tambrands' partner, the Ukrainian Health Ministry's General Pharmaceutical Department, which runs the republic's pharmacies, provided the building and land.
"We provided the first commercially produced sanitary napkin," said Paul Konney, a senior vice president at Tambrands. "Women traditionally bought bricks of bleached cotton, using four times as much cotton as an equivalent supply of tampons. We said, 'You could save the raw material, and out of that savings in cotton, you could pay us our profits, in cotton.' "
And that is what has happened. Rubles earned from the sale of tampons are used to purchase local cotton -- the Soviet Union was the world's third largest cotton producer -- and Tambrands ships some of that cotton out of the country.
But Tambrands' arrangement ran headlong into a Soviet concept, embodied in law and emotion, that says foreign investors should not be allowed to export products they do not produce themselves. Tambrands has dealt with this objection by noting that it does not export raw cotton; the company processes and bleaches it first, to make 300 million tampons a year in the Kiev factory, and also to sell some cotton abroad.
Could the Ukrainians have set up their own tampon manufacturing network to serve the huge and potentially lucrative market of Commonwealth of Independent States, using dollars earned from cotton exports to purchase equipment and technology?
Mr. Konney does not think so. "We are bringing something to the party," he said, "upgrading technology and marketing skills, and managing the operation as good, enlightened capitalist managers, and we are providing employment." That amounts to 300 jobs.
 
McDonald's Trades Burgers for Exports
 McDonald's must also deal with local criticism, but of a different sort. The issue for McDonald's is whether, in lands short of meat and dairy products, the company diverts too much to its huge Moscow restaurant, which says it serves 50,000 people a day.
Like the others, McDonald's has found ways to earn a return on its investment in hard currency. Just as Tambrands has permission to purchase and export cotton, McDonald's received government authorization to purchase and export a raw material, one that George Cohon, vice president of Moscow McDonald's, declined to identify. For competitive reasons, he said he did not want to give too much detail to other foreign investors who might be trying to make similar export arrangements.
The 10-story office building going up on city land near Red Square -- the City of Moscow is McDonald's joint-venture partner -- will be leased to foreign companies, and the rent will be paid in dollars abroad. Once the cost of the $15 million building is covered, the rentals will help provide a return on McDonald's overall Soviet investment, now approaching $65 million, Mr. Cohon said.
Finally, McDonald's 100,000-square-foot processing plant in Moscow, which is used to store and prepare food purchased in the countryside, is also a hard-currency earner. "There is excess capacity at that plant, so we sell food in dollars to an embassy or some store that operates in hard currency," Mr. Cohon said.
Mr. Cohon acknowledged that some people might question whether McDonald's should be permitted to purchase large quantities of food that might otherwise be distributed through different outlets, especially given the shortages now being experienced in Moscow and elsewhere. But he responded that McDonald's has increased food production, in part by teaching better techniques to the farmers it deals with. He also suggested that McDonald's restaurants are an efficient way to feed the public.
 
Lots of Oil, But Hard to Get
 The debate over tampons and Big Macs pales alongside the conflict that could develop over oil. The Soviet Union was the world's largest oil producer, and the reserves of the newly independent republics are sufficient to greatly increase production -- a goal sought by the Bush Administration, which hopes rising production can reduce American dependence on Middle East oil.
Oilfields in eastern Russia and in Kazakhstan are separately as large as Alaska's North Slope fields. But they have yet to produce much oil, largely because of a lack of money to develop them.
Still, the people administering the fields appear to be of two minds: They are actively inviting American oil companies to bring their technology and invest millions of dollars to pump the oil. But they are balking at turning over too much ownership of the oil that comes out of the ground.
In the most celebrated case, Chevron has been trying to make a deal in Kazakhstan that has raised local concerns.
"The Soviets seem unable to sign off on a deal," said Thomas Burns, Chevron's chief economist. "As everyone knows, oil is considered national patrimony, and that has a lot of impact politically and emotionally."
Having begun negotiations with the Government of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Chevron is now dealing with tougher, more nationalistic Kazakh officials, trying to arrange a joint venture in which Chevron would invest $1 billion over two to three years and several billion more over a decade. The money would be used to recover hundreds of thousands of barrels a day from two known oil fields, Tengiz and Korolev. But there is a sticking point: Chevron wants to own half the oil that comes out of the ground.
"The Soviets do not have an idea of an acceptable rate of return," Mr. Burns complained. "They are taking the approach that if you put in $1 million and you get a 30 percent return, that is acceptable."
The Chevron argument is that a higher return is essential to compensate for the risk of a multi-billion dollar investment. After all, Chevron argues, the final payoff might turn out to be far less than 30 percent.
Whatever the pros and cons, the Kazakh Government seems inclined to drive a harder bargain than the old Gorbachev Government. In July, Kazakhstanskaya Pravda carried a report accusing the Soviet Oil and Gas Ministry of endorsing an arrangement in which the Soviets would contribute far more in cash and assets than Chevron.
 
Two Houston Men Show a Success
 In such an atmosphere, smaller and less noticeable projects are turning out to be more successful. A Texas lawyer and a Texas oilman, operating as business partners out of Houston, negotiated the American oil venture now furthest along in the former Soviet Union. They flew to Raduzhny, in north central Siberia, and arranged a joint venture with Anatoly Sivak, chairman of the state company that pumps oil in the area.
Once Mr. Sivak had obtained the necessary signatures from higher-ups in the Russian Republic and the Gorbachev Government, the three men named their joint venture White Knights. Mr. Sivak's state enterprise provided the underground oil and 1,000 workers, and the Texans agreed to invest millions of dollars in modern equipment, technology, new housing and more.
But having no money of their own, the two Americans -- Gil Labbe, an oil engineer, and Gordon Andrus, a specialist in international law -- sold half of their share in the joint venture to Phibro Energy Production, an oil and gas division of Salomon Inc., the Wall Street firm. Phibro says it has invested $50 million so far to drill two new wells and to extract more oil from 20 to 30 old ones.
The Americans own half of all the oil that is taken from the ground. White Knights is exporting about 4,000 barrels a day for sale on the world market, and Mr. Labbe said that the dollars earned are being plowed back into the business. Eventually, a $1.5 billion investment is supposed to yield more than 300,000 barrels a day in new Siberian production.
How did Mr. Labbe and Mr. Andrus do it without loud public complaint? They made informal contacts with Soviet Oil and Gas Ministry officials in Houston, Mr. Labbe said, "and we told them what we wanted in exchange for capital and know-how: an oilfield already being developed, an existing road network and pipeline, and an area with a pool of oil fairly near the surface."
The officials sent the two Houston men to Mr. Sivak, who negotiated a 25-year agreement, then got the approval of the republic and federal officials.
Clearly, there are lessons in the White Knights experience. One is to start the negotiations at the bottom, not the top. Another is to resist any temptation to sell Western oil technology and capital without an ownership stake in the oil that is produced.
"The companies are not interested in giving the technology away for a fee," said John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Clinton Delivers a Mainstream Message With a Southern Accent

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Bill Clinton moved easily through a meeting room at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here, chatting up the Democrats who had put on expensive suits and velvet holiday dresses to meet the Arkansas Governor and write $500 checks for his Presidential campaign.
After spending weeks on the campaign trail in chilly New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton was back in the region he knows best: the South. That night, he collected endorsements from two important Georgians, Gov. Zell Miller and Senator Sam Nunn, and raised $75,000 from well-heeled Atlantans. Today, he flew to Tennessee to woo Democrats with deep pockets in Memphis and Nashville. 
 The events are signs of Mr. Clinton's early success and his main problem. He raised more than $3 million in the last three months. But much of that money came from the South -- nearly a third of it in one Little Rock, Ark., fund-raising event -- and Mr. Clinton and his aides know they must overcome any notion that the Arkansas Governor will be solely a regional candidate.
"The geography is clearly against me," he said recently. "I'm a stranger in nearly every place."
Running on a message that is tailored for conservative times, Mr. Clinton has staked out his position on the Democratic right in much the way that Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has laid claim to the left.
Square-jawed and good-humored, but lacking the charisma quotient and war hero status that has enhanced the candidacy of Senator Bob Kerrey, Mr. Clinton has nevertheless scored well with party officials and strategists with a series of policy speeches and a victory in the Florida Democratic Party's nonbinding straw poll.
In each appearance, he has offered an assessment of the state of the American economy that borrows as much from Republicans like Jack Kemp as it does from liberals like Jesse Jackson. Like the middle-of-the-road Democratic Leadership Council he founded in 1985, Mr. Clinton is self-consciously centrist, urging what amounts to a marriage of traditional Democratic social concerns with economic policies borrowed from the Republicans. The future of the Democratic Party, Mr. Clinton contends, depends on its willingness to alter its focus.
"I'd like for you to remember that John Kennedy got elected President not by telling people what they wanted to hear, but by challenging the established Democratic orthodoxy and challenging the American people to do better," he said in an interview. "I think we need dramatic change in this country. We've got to go beyond the established partisan divisions.
"Four years ago, I was giving a speech saying the Democrats were going downhill," he said. "And now it's become part of the conventional wisdom of the Democratic Party, so I guess I should be grateful."
To get the opportunity to present his message to the general electorate in the fall, Mr. Clinton must first convince the more left-leaning traditional Democrats who vote in state primaries that there is more than an intellectual case to be made for moving to the center. But in the party that nominated liberals, Michael S. Dukakis and Walter F. Mondale, in the last two elections, this may prove to be a tall order.
During these first throes of the primary season, Mr. Clinton has been received warmly enough outside the South to force Northern and Western Democrats -- and some Republicans -- to listen seriously to his mainstream message of middle-class tax relief and individual responsibility.
 
Carving Out a Niche
 Southerner Seeks Moderate Voter
 Mr. Clinton's toughest battles lie ahead. With New York Gov. Mario M. Cuomo out of the race, he has been deprived of the definition he had been seeking as the clear alternative to a liberal from the Northeast.
Instead, he must now carve out a niche for himself in a Democratic field where both Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Harkin have a shot at early victories before the campaign heads south for the Super Tuesday primaries in March.
Now that the field is set, Mr. Clinton's supporters are trying to make a marketable virtue of his moderation.
"The junior Senator from Iowa may run wild," Senator Nunn said in introducing Mr. Clinton recently. "The junior Senator from Nebraska may run hot and cold, and the Governor of New York may not run at all. Bill Clinton will run straight and true."
But the Democrats remember all too well their previous brushes with Presidential candidacies from the South, and comparisons are as inevitable as they are frequent. Many Democrats remember President Jimmy Carter's loss to Ronald Reagan in 1980 as a rejection of both the candidate and the party's message. In 1988, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, who was also billed as a conservative Democrat who could win back Reagan Democrats, based his strategy in the South only to stumble badly in New York.
Mr. Clinton and his aides insist they will make neither Mr. Carter's nor Mr. Gore's mistakes. But they also realize that for a governor from a small, impoverished state that has improved but not flourished under his leadership, the road to nomination has an alarming number of potential pitfalls.
During the last month, the most pressing chore has been to raise the money needed to introduce Mr. Clinton to millions of voters on the unfamiliar terrain he must negotiate during the next few months. If he fares respectably in New Hampshire and South Dakota, his hand will be strengthened when he returns to the South for a slate of regional primaries that will include Georgia, Florida, Tennessee, Louisiana and Texas.
David Wilhelm, the Clinton campaign manager who has spent much time shoring up his candidate's base in the South, is eager to lower expectations about how well Mr. Clinton can perform in the Northeast.
"New Hampshire's not going to be easy for us," he said.
 
Talking Economics
 Prods for Business And Cuts in Taxes
 Mr. Clinton, 45 years old, his bushy gray hair recently sculpted into a ruthlessly restrained style and his speeches similarly reined in, has been using the campaign trail to test themes and to gauge the degree to which an unknown Southern governor can win broad support in a time of national economic distress.
"The psychology of New Hampshire is very difficult," he said. "It's even different from the South, where we were used to getting beat up in the 80's. Half of the people drawing welfare checks are middle-class or higher. It's a very painful thing to see."
But for Mr. Clinton and the other Democrats, the economy's continuing slide is good political news as they seek footholds to challenge Mr. Bush. In conservative Orange County, Calif., a group of top Republican fund-raisers met with Mr. Clinton and immediately wrote checks for his campaign after hearing his economic message.
With each new piece of bad news, Mr. Clinton has tried to seize the moment. When General Motors announced it would close plants and eliminate 74,000 jobs, he criticized President Bush and said highway construction included in the recently signed transportation bill should be expedited to create new jobs.
"I don't want to be happy about a recession," said Frank Greer, the campaign's media consultant. "But let me tell you, it helps big time."
The message Mr. Clinton has been honing on the stump has emerged as a nakedly insistent appeal for middle-class votes that includes a proposal to cut income taxes for the middle class by 10 percent and provide tax incentives for business investment. After Mr. Clinton delivered his economic policy speech at Georgetown University last month, a student asked him if he was planning to abandon the party's traditional role as champion of the poor.
"There is no hostility to the poor in my plan," Mr. Clinton responded. "If you're going to help the poor with tax money, somebody's got to earn the money to pay the taxes. The best way to help the poor is to expand the middle class."
Most of the other major Democrats in the race have taken up that call, and party leaders appear to have conceded that they must reorient themselves toward the center in order to elect their Presidential nominees.
 
Establishing an Image
 Obscure Outsider With Inside Help
 Mr. Clinton's virtual anonymity has been both a virtue and a curse in the campaign he and his aides have been plotting. Eschewing Washington as a base of operation, Mr. Clinton has made Little Rock his national campaign headquarters and tapped his longtime Arkansas aide, Bruce Lindsay, as his traveling campaign director.
Mr. Clinton lashes out frequently at Congressional Democrats as well as at Republicans in Washington, inviting his audiences to believe that as a state executive he, too, is a victim.
He depicts himself as a Governor who "spent 11 years on the receiving end of the Reagan revolution" and who "tried to be one of those points of light the President talked about." But he also knows all politicians have been tarred.
"The average voter thinks we're all a bunch of slugs," Mr. Clinton said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton has not hesitated to latch onto insiders' Washington expertise for his campaign, hiring political professionals from Capitol Hill like George Stephanopolous and campaign veterans like Mr. Greer, the poll-taker Stanley Greenberg and James Carville and Paul Begala, the two Washington-based political consultants who helped guide Harris Wofford to victory in November over Dick Thornburgh in the closely watched Pennsylvania Senate race.
Mr. Clinton's only previous brush with national prominence came in 1988, when he delivered a nominating speech for Michael Dukakis that was so tedious that he was dropped for a time from the handicappers' lists of likely Presidential candidates.
 
'30-Minute Candidate'
 Although he is less long-winded these days, Mr. Clinton's advisers still worry that he has not yet perfected the concise television statement. "We've clearly proven we're the best 30-minute candidate in the race," Mr. Carville said after listening to Mr. Clinton deliver a well-received speech in Atlanta. "I just hope we can be the best 30-second candidate."
As with the other members of the field wooing the party faithful, Mr. Clinton must also convince fund-raisers and local party officials that he will be tough enough to challenge President Bush effectively.
"Can he fight the way the Republicans can?" Jerry Herskovitz, a Democrat from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said after hearing Mr. Clinton speak in November. "Can he cut throats?"
Few doubt that Mr. Harkin, with his vociferous blasts from the left, can challenge Mr. Bush on rhetoric. For Mr. Clinton, however, the question of whether he could go toe to toe with Mr. Bush arises frequently.
"Every time somebody hits me, I do my best to take their heads off," Mr. Clinton said after a recent speech. "And it's worked pretty well."
 
Planning Strategy
 Personal Queries And Code Words
 Mr. Clinton is clearly a man who has spent much of his career grooming himself for this moment. Now that it has arrived, he is trying to work out the rough spots in timing and strategy.
"Every day you're in Florida, you're not in New Hampshire," he fretted as he flew across Florida recently. "Every minute you're in an airplane, you're not on the phone."
Along the way, Mr. Clinton has already gotten a taste of how diversions can threaten to knock a campaign off course. When Mr. Kerrey told him an offensive sexual joke within range of C-SPAN microphones at a New Hampshire roast last month, reporters immediately demanded if Mr. Clinton had laughed at the joke. His aides said he did not, but Mr. Clinton seemed wounded that reporters were dogging him about the exchange.
And in a breakfast meeting with Washington political reporters in September, he was asked about the rumors concerning his marital fidelity that surfaced in his last race for Governor.
"Like nearly anybody who's been together 20 years, our relationship has not been perfect or free of its difficulties, but we feel good about where we are, and we believe in our obligation to each other and we intend to be together 30 or 40 years from now," he said as his wife, Hillary, sat at his side.
Mr. Clinton has also made it clear that he intends to tap into what he sees as a growing public impatience with overemphasis on the personal lives of candidates by issuing a blanket refusal to answer what he describes as "have you ever" questions. Such questions, he has said, are demeaning and beside the point.
 
Challenge to Wilder
 Mr. Clinton has also decided to make a serious run at challenging L. Douglas Wilder, the Virginia Governor who is the only major black candidate in the race, for the support of black voters.
"It's probably been since Robert Kennedy was assassinated that a white politician tried to go everywhere in America and say the same thing everywhere, and make a conscious decision to try to reach across racial and economic lines to draw people together," he said in an interview.
In his speeches, Mr. Clinton takes pains to denounce David Duke, the defeated Louisiana gubernatorial candidate who has said he will challenge President Bush for the Republican nomination. The words take on an additional edge in the South, where he does not hesitate to evoke memories of the region's past racial problems to illustrate his point.
Lashing out at the Republicans for what he describes as race-baiting, he told the largely white Atlanta crowd the other night, "They pay consultants millions for what Southerners know how to do by instinct."
The difference, he said, is that Southerners have come to realize that using what he calls "these little code words" about race have hurt their region.
The Clinton campaign prides itself on what advisers boast of as the consistency in their candidate's message. Mr. Clinton, they say, is willing to make the same speech to every audience.
Essentially, they are correct. The businessmen in New Hampshire and the black woman in Florida heard the same message, but Mr. Clinton pitched it with differing emphasis and inflection.
"He plays well down here," said Robert Slagle, the chairman of the Texas Democratic Party. "But, shoot, he's got the same accent we got, and he could be the boy next door over in East Texas."
To do well in New Hampshire or California or New York, Mr. Clinton knows he is going to have to get his name into the nation's living rooms in a hurry.
"In a lot of respects, Bill Clinton's got a good, solid general election message," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic consultant who is not working for any of the candidates. "And he is clearly saying the kind of things a Democrat has to say to win a general election. It's less clear that there's enough of an edge there to win the nomination."

HEADLINE: Bush Picks Nominee For Commerce Post

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
President Bush announced today that he would nominate Barbara H. Franklin, a well-connected management consultant, corporate director and Republican fund-raiser, to become Commerce Secretary next year.
Ms. Franklin would become the third woman in the election-year Cabinet of Mr. Bush, who has usually drawn less support from women than men. She was one of the first women to receive an M.B.A. from Harvard, and her Government career began in 1971, when President Richard M. Nixon brought her into his Administration to recruit more women. 
 She would replace Robert A. Mosbacher, who is leaving in January to head the Bush re-election campaign.
Ms. Franklin, who earns up to $327,000 a year as a director of seven corporations, has a long resume in both politics and business.
Federal campaign records show that she has contributed $45,550 since 1989 to Republican campaigns, according to The Associated Press. She has been active in Republican politics in her native Pennsylvania and was a chairwoman for a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner last month that gathered nearly $1.2 million for Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.
And as a director of seven corporations, Ms. Franklin, 51 years old, already knows business leaders. Commerce Secretaries have traditionally represented their views in the councils of Government. If appointed to the Cabinet, she would have to resign from all corporate boards.
At a White House press briefing this afternoon, Ms. Franklin said, "As Secretary of Commerce, when confirmed by the Senate, of course, I look forward to and will be very proud to be an advocate for American business," calling it "the economic backbone of America."
President Bush said Ms. Franklin would become part of his economic policy team. "Her first priority is the same as mine -- jobs and economic growth -- and she has shown a deep commitment to public service, from serving on the Consumer Products Safety Commission to working as an alternate public delegate to the United Nations," he said.
The nomination is an important one as the nation heads into a Presidential election campaign in which job losses to foreign competition are likely to be big issues. If Ms. Franklin is confirmed, both the nation's top trade officials will be women. The other one, United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and Labor Secretary Lynn Martin are the only women in the Cabinet now.
 
Deeply Involved With Trade
 Ms. Franklin did not discuss her views on trade policy at today's briefing and did not agree to be interviewed. President Bush said Ms. Franklin "has been a determined advocate of free and fair trade, keenly aware that when the playing field is level, American workers can compete with anyone, anywhere."
More than most new Commerce Secretaries, Ms. Franklin has been deeply involved with international trade, having served six years on the President's Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations. James D. Robinson 3d, chairman and chief executive of the American Express Company, heads the group, which also includes top corporate executives from other multinational companies.
The two biggest trade issues next year are a proposed 108-nation accord to pull down trade barriers worldwide and a free-trade agreement with Mexico. The Commerce Department has supported Mrs. Hills's office on both issues.
As one of the original commissioners of the Consumer Product Safety Commission when it was formed by President Nixon, Ms. Franklin has credentials that are likely to help the Administration when the trade accords go before Congress. Some labor unions and consumer groups have opposed the trade agreements, contending that they may lower safety standards for imported goods. Mrs. Hills and her aides deny that contention.
 
Heavy Corporate Lobbying
 Administration officials have been counting on heavy corporate lobbying to support Congressional approval of both trade agreements.
Ms. Franklin is a director of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, Armstrong World Industries, Automatic Data Processing Inc., the Black & Decker Corporation, the Dow Chemical Company, Nordstrom Inc. and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
She earns nearly $180,300 a year in retainer fees for serving on these boards, plus up to $146,800 a year and expenses depending on how many board meetings she attends, according to figures compiled by Directorship, a Westport, Conn., newsletter that publishes statistics on corporate directors.
Ann D. McLaughlin, a Labor Secretary in the Reagan Administration, is the only American woman to have served on more boards of the 1,000 largest industrial companies, said Elsa S. Nad, the editor of Directorship.
Ms. Franklin was also on the audit committee of each board -- an important but often tough position since its members may have to challenge management. At Armstrong, she took part in the company's successful fight against a hostile takeover attempt that led Pennsylvania to pass a tough anti-takeover law.
Corporate executives described Ms. Franklin as an energetic woman with expertise in several areas, including personnel policy and relations with the Government. John N. Nordstrom, co-chairman of the Nordstrom department store chain, said Ms. Franklin had helped the company -- which imports large quantities of merchandise -- understand the nation's import quota system.
Josh S. Weston, chairman and chief executive of Automatic Data Processing, pointed to Ms. Franklin's "extreme conservatism" in accounting practices, which helped keep the computer company from relaxing its standards in an industry marked by aggressive accounting.
Mr. Weston said she had been introduced to Automatic Data Processing by Alan Greenspan, then a director and now Federal Reserve chairman.
The former Barbara Hackman grew up in Lancaster County, Pa., the daughter of a school superintendent and a teacher. She graduated with honors from Pennsylvania State University in 1962 and received her master's of business administration from Harvard Business School in 1964, in the school's second class that included women. But when she returned to Harvard in recent years, she once told a reporter, one professor was dismissive, taking her to be a spouse, rather than an alumna.
Ms. Franklin met her husband, Wallace Barnes, the chairman of an automobile parts company, in 1979 when she joined the board of Aetna, where he was already a director. They were married in 1986. Mr. Barnes often flies his plane from their home in Bristol, Conn., to Washington, where she has an apartment.
Ms. Franklin said in 1988 that Aetna's chairman and chief executive, James T. Lynn, "thought that Aetna was entitled to a finder's fee for this, or maybe two finder's fees."

Markets
Stock prices rose to record levels, continuing a rally that has defied gloomy expectations about the nation's economy and apparently reflecting confidence that a recovery will finally appear in 1992. The Dow climbed 31.98, to 3,082.96. That represents a 5.8 percent rise in the four days since the Fed rate cut and puts it 17.1 percent above its level on Jan. 1. [Page A1.] 
 Bond prices rose modestly on the strength of slight buying by mutual funds and other investors. [D12.]
Oil prices dropped 47 cents, to $18.50, in thin trading, seemingly resuming their recent trend downward after rising earlier this week. [D13.]
The dollar dropped sharply in light trading, weakened by expectations that the currency will lose more value as the American economy struggles to overcome the recession. [D13.]
 
The Economy
U.S. oil-drilling activity in 1991 is certain to rank as the slowest of any year since the Government restricted drilling for military reasons in 1942. [D1.]
Bush will nominate Barbara H. Franklin to be Commerce Secretary, he announced. She is a well-connected management consultant, corporate director and Republican fund-raiser. [D1.]

Mosbacher, who has played a limited role in interagency debates on issues like tax and health policy and international trade. News Analysis. [D1.]
The virtual monopolies that local telephone companies have long enjoyed are under attack by state regulators around the country, led by those in New York. [A1.]

U.S. companies are treating the former Soviet territories as wild, unpredictable places, without reliable laws, but good for trying to strike it rich with ventures that skim the cream from an economy in disarray. [A1.]

[D2.]

HEADLINE: Turning Over A Ship Adrift

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
President Bush's choice for Commerce Secretary, Barbara H. Franklin, will inherit an agency diminished by its loss of primacy over international trade and somewhat weakened by the management style of its current leader, Robert A. Mosbacher.
Mr. Mosbacher, who will leave next month to head the President's re-election campaign, has played a limited role in interagency debates on business-related issues like tax and health policy and international trade. Unlike his combative predecessor, Malcolm Baldrige, he has spent much of his tenure jetting around the world on trade missions with the nation's corporate elite, seeking to open new markets for American exports. 
 And even though he is a close friend of President Bush, Mr. Mosbacher has not always chosen to use the relationship to push his own views or his agency's cause.
 
Losing Policy Debates
 The result, say Mr. Mosbacher's critics -- who include Administration officials and Washington trade experts, some of whom consider themselves friends and allies of the Commerce Secretary -- has been an agency adrift.
A small crew of veteran administrators continues to work long hours on technical issues like weather forecasting, the census and economic indicators, while the department loses policy debates to other Government agencies and watches from the sidelines while others determine the nation's health and tax policies.
And with the recent departure of several senior officials and the possible departure of several others, even the department's technical competence has been questioned.
"The department needs to be much more broad-gauged and not just a Chamber of Commerce," said a top Administration official, who, like other critics, insisted on anonymity. "There's a lot more to the Commerce Department than export promotion."
 
Defending the Secretary
 But other Administration officials and some corporate executives strongly disagree. They point out that Mr. Mosbacher has worked well with businesses, and defend his emphasis on exports in light of the growing concern about the nation's economic competitiveness.
He has promoted American exports with some success, including forcing Japan to amend its regulations on large retail stores, which allowed Toys "R" Us to open its first discount outlet there last week.
"The biggest thing he did as I saw it was that he is someone American businessmen trust," said Donald B. Marron, the chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber Inc. "He understands the issues; he's a good listener; he doesn't give people a lot of baloney."
Roger B. Porter, the assistant to the President for economic and domestic policy and a former Harvard University professor who has studied the nation's trade policy, said the department had not lost influence during Mr. Mosbacher's tenure.
"Bob Mosbacher has as close a personal relationship with the President as any Commerce Secretary has had in the post-World War II period," he said.
Mr. Porter, who served in the Ford and Reagan Administrations, said the officials and industry lobbyists who played down Mr. Mosbacher's role were exaggerating the influence of his predecessors and missing the extent to which Congress had strengthened the Office of the United States Trade Representative at the expense of the Commerce Department.
Legislation in 1974 and 1988 clearly designated the trade representative as the top trade negotiator, while the end of the cold war has left the Commerce Department's export control division with less to do, he said.
Mr. Mosbacher dismisses criticisms of his aloofness from policy matters as the complaints of "low-level nerds" in the Federal Government. The collegial nature of decision-making in the Bush Administration has obscured the extent of his involvement, Mr. Mosbacher said in an interview on Monday in his walnut-paneled, two-story office with a view of the Washington Monument.
 
A Measure of Persuasion
 Commerce Secretaries have traditionally championed the interests of business within the Administration. Mr. Mosbacher pointed to his success in persuading the White House that corporate leaders should accompany President Bush to Japan next month. And Mr. Mosbacher was the first Cabinet secretary to warn that banks' increasingly cautious lending policies were making it hard for companies to borrow.
Mr. Mosbacher waged a personal and ultimately successful crusade earlier this year to persuade the Japanese to stop importing the shells of endangered sea turtles, a goal that had eluded American officials and environmentalists for a decade.
The Commerce Department is also playing the lead negotiating role on American trade in automobiles and auto parts with Japan, the biggest bilateral commercial issue.
 
Illustration of Limits
 Yet Mr. Mosbacher's sometimes limited influence as a Cabinet secretary was illustrated again last Friday, when he scheduled a news briefing at the White House to discuss his successful effort to send top corporate executives with the President on his trip to Asia next month.
Samuel K. Skinner, the new White House chief of staff, appeared at the briefing and took the podium first, praising the decision to take the executives on the trip and then listing the President's key economic policy advisers as the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady; the budget director, Richard Darman, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael Boskin.
Mr. Skinner conspicuously did not mention either Mr. Mosbacher, who was standing nearby, or the Commerce Department, which has traditionally played a role in economic policy-making.
The incident highlighted the erosion of the Commerce Department's vast bureaucratic turf. The trade representative, Carla A. Hills, now dominates trade policy. The Departments of State and Defense increasingly share the Commerce Department's role in deciding export control issues. And White House officials, especially the chiefs of staff, John H. Sununu and now Mr. Skinner, dominate domestic economic policy.
