HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Slow Year In Drilling For U.S. Oil

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 26

 BODY:
When the final weekly figures for the year are released on Friday, oil-drilling activity for the United States in 1991 is certain to rank as the slowest of any year since the Government restricted drilling for military reasons in 1942.
The energy industry clamped down on domestic drilling as it confronted low prices for crude and natural gas, the recession and environmental laws that forbid the industry to drill in prime areas of potentially big reserves in Alaska and near the California coastline. 
 Even in the months before the allied bombardment of Baghdad began last January, as prices for domestic crude surged to $40 a barrel, the nation's oil giants kept a steady hand on drilling budgets.
 
Controls to Tighten
 And now, with prices for domestic reserves at their lowest level in 10 months, $18.50 a barrel, and natural gas prices depressed anew, analysts and oil executives say the energy industry will keep an even tighter rein on domestic drilling budgets into next year. That is expected to put thousands more oilfield employees out of work and accelerate a new round of mergers and asset sales that recently began in drilling services.
The average number of rigs active weekly in 1991, as monitored by Baker Hughes Inc., the drilling services company, will be about 860, down by nearly 15 percent from 1,010 last year and below the postwar low of 869 set in 1989. The average for the week that ended last Friday was 797, down almost 31 percent from the 1,151 rigs in operation the comparable week a year ago.
 
More Imports Expected
 As the volume of oil pumped from domestic fields declines, the nation seems likely to import nearly half of its daily consumption of more than 16 million barrels, the oil executives and analysts said. Imports contributed an average of 45.7 percent of total supplies through November of this year, according to the American Petroleum Institute, the industry trade group based in Washington.
"The reality is that the economics for drilling in the United States are not attractive," said James L. Carroll, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in New York. "I certainly don't expect it to turn around anytime soon. Most companies are planning for a U.S. rig count between 700 and 750 rigs in 1992."
The nation's lowest level of drilling activity since records were begun in 1940 was an average of 761 active rigs in 1942, when the Government temporarily diverted steel output from drilling-pipe production just before the nation entered World War II.
Ike Kerridge, the chief economist at Baker Hughes, said drilling for natural gas could also decline further next year. The tax credits that stimulated some drilling for natural gas this year in unconventional areas like tight rock formations and underground coal seams probably would not be extended by Congress, he said.
James W. Kinnear, the president and chief executive of Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, said today that spending on exploration projects in the United States by his company had fallen to 55 percent of Texaco's global exploration budget, from 75 percent 10 years ago.
 
'Pretty Marked Change'
 "It's a pretty marked change," he said. "The promising areas in Alaska, offshore California and otherwise are simply not available to us. But areas outside the United States are really quite attractive."
Texaco expects, for instance, to recover three billion barrels in the coming years in Indonesia by flooding aging fields with steam to loosen the crude. And, among other projects, it has allocated $500 million in the British North Sea on a field that will yield the company more than 100 million barrels.
"We have to put our stockholders' money out there where we can make money on it," Mr. Kinnear said. "In the United States, environmental laws are soaking up a lot of capital," he added. "It is clearly the taxpayers and citizens who will pay the bill at the end of the day. Obviously, U.S. production is going to continue to drop."
 
Creating Jobs Abroad
 Allen E. Murray, the chairman and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation and outgoing head of the American Petroleum Institute, said in a speech last month that by discouraging drilling at home and importing higher amounts of oil, the nation was sending jobs to oil-exporting nations.
The number of oilfield workers in the United States declined to 382,000 in November, from 402,300 in the same month a year ago, and from the yearly peak of 708,300 in 1982, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Most large oil companies have accelerated spending on foreign projects in recent years. Since 1989, the oil industry has invested more money in the hunt for oil outside the United States than within the nation's borders, according to Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm.
The Chevron Corporation spent more money abroad than in the United States this year for the first time -- an estimated $486 million, or more than 50 percent for foreign drilling from a total exploration budget of $944 million. In 1987, Chevron's foreign spending totaled $187 million, or 27 percent, of a total exploration budget of $685 million.
Earlier this month, the Pennzoil Company said its future exploration efforts would mainly be abroad. The retreat from current projects, mostly in the United States, reflects "a major business opportunity" to broaden the company's limited activities abroad, said James L. Pate, the president and chief executive.
Slumping oil prices have also put a damper on global drilling activity since the Persian Gulf war ended in March, but the decline has been less severe outside the United States. The average weekly drilling rate for 1991 outside the nation was 1,040 rigs, a slight decline from the levels of 1989 and 1990, according to Baker Hughes, which is based in Houston.
Dozens of countries that once shunned American oil giants are now wooing them to help raise oil output. They include Albania, Bulgaria and Vietnam and several republics of the former Soviet Union, said Mr. Carroll, the Paine Webber analyst. "The United States is the only country that has not improved fiscal terms or concessions since the war ended," he said.
The decline in the nation's search for oil and natural gas has some bright spots. It partly reflects greater productivity based on improved seismic studies to locate reserves and on better drilling equipment that together have reduced the number of dry holes. And one effect of the reduced drilling is that the nation will better conserve what remains of its fossil-fuel resources for future generations.
Mr. Kinnear of Texaco, who is not an alarmist about falling domestic drilling rates, said the best policy for the nation would include a combination of imports from many foreign producers, as well as conservation and economically prudent oil production at home.
Yet the decline in drilling will inevitably weaken smaller oilfield service companies, whose customers drilled mainly in the United States.
"We are in the early stages of another round of consolidation in the oilfield services that will be similar to what we saw in 1986" after oil prices fell to $12, from $27 early in the year, Mr. Carroll said. "Earnings this year have been nothing short of disaster."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mild Optimism For Steelmakers

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
IN the last year, the steel industry has suffered some of its worst times since the early 1980's.
After years of closing plants, laying off workers, and improving productivity, steelmakers' fortunes began to improve markedly by the late 1980's. But the recession has eroded nearly all those gains. The question now: How long will the bad times linger? 
 To hear analysts tell it, things are about to improve, although not greatly. With losses among the big steelmakers expected to surpass $1 billion this year, some expect a return to a modest profitability next year. John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants, says he expects the nation's largest steel companies to earn a combined $1.2 billion in profits next year. That compares with $3 billion in 1989, the industry's most recent banner year.
His optimism is based on the expectation that the economy will grow about 3 percent next year. About 400,000 more cars will be sold, he predicts, and demand for industrial products and appliances -- the leading sources of steel consumption -- will increase.
"Steel usually experiences a lag coming out of the recession," Mr. Jacobson said. "But some of the negatives that affect steel, like a buildup in inventories during a recession, will not be the case."
The USX Corporation's steel division seems to hold the most promise for financial improvement, said Charles Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities. Mr. Bradford said the company had less debt than most competitors and had streamlined its overhead and production costs efficiently. And although he expects the steel company to have a loss of about $2.25 a share for this year, he predicts it will earn about $3.50 a share next year. The shares of USX's U.S. Steel Group closed yesterday at $26 each, up 50 cents.
Mr. Bradford further predicted that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer, would earn $1.35 a share next year, compared with an expected loss of $2.80 a share. The Inland Steel Company, he forecast, will break even next year, after an expected loss of $4.35 a share for this year. Bethlehem Steel's shares were up 37.5 cents each yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $12.875. Inland stock was up 37.5 cents a share, closing at $18.75.
And the smaller steel companies -- which have largely remained profitable during the recession -- will also show improvement, Mr. Bradford said. But their gains will be less dramatic than their larger rivals.
Mr. Bradford expects the Nucor Corporation, the steel mini-mill company that is moving aggressively to compete against larger rivals in flat-rolled steel, to show earnings of $4 a share next year, from an anticipated $2.75 this year. In Big Board trading yesterday, Nucor's shares closed at $79.50, off 25 cents.
Mr. Jacobson of AUS added that the steel industry was now in a better competitive position than at the end of the last recession in 1982, when there was a great deal of excess capacity, the dollar was strengthening and prices were not particularly strong. This time, he said, "there isn't as much excess capacity, the dollar is weak and there has been a great deal of retrenchment in the steel industry." He added that the number of worker hours needed to make a ton of steel exceeded 10 in 1982, compared with 3 to 4 now. That compares with an average 4.5 in Japan and is far lower than in Korea and Brazil.
Pricing is another area that has shown some promise in recent months. After leveling off toward the end of last year following a downward decline, steel prices have been picking up slightly in the last two months. Led by an effort by the LTV Corporation's steel unit, prices have risen 2 to 3 percent since the summer. And USX announced another round of price increases for April.
The pricing, more than anything, will account for steelmakers' profitability, analysts maintain. Mr. Jacobson estimates that a 2 percent rise in prices translates into an added $800 million in sales and could be as much as $80 million in profits. Still, "steel prices are about $57 a ton less than what they were in 1989 and $45 a ton less than a year ago," Mr. Jacobson said. "So price improvement would mean all the difference."
But that has always been particularly difficult for the steelmakers, which typically compete on pricing to hold on to market share, often taking losses in the process. "There is still a lot of uncertainty about the economy, the auto industry and its layoffs, which work against pricing," Mr. Jacobson said. "But there is a shot that the increases in April might hold."
Mr. Bradford, the UBS analyst, pointed out that much of the losses reported by the major steel companies resulted from special items. "Each of the steel companies had programs to rebuild and modernize," Mr. Bradford said. "With those programs nearly complete, it will help the industry's competitive position."
Still, there are some sobering forces. Mr. Bradford and several other analysts say that it is highly unlikely that the price increases announced by USX for next April will stick.
Moreover, orders have been down slightly in recent months, and many in the industry fear they may erode further before picking up in the spring. "We think things have bottomed out," said the chairman of a major steel company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But you can never be sure. We're watching things closer than ever, hoping that orders will pick up in the next month or two."
Nonetheless, most analysts are optimistic, although cautiously so. "It seems that the economy will turn around and the hard work since the last recession will pay off," Mr. Jacobson said. "It is an election year, and things are bound to get better."

HEADLINE: Wachtler, in Letter, Vows To Seek Raises for Judges

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Despite budget cuts and hundreds of layoffs that have devastated the New York State court system, the state's Chief Judge has pledged to fight for pay increases for more than 1,100 state judges, saying they "deserve and must have" raises denied to them for more than four years.
"While judges must share the pain of the fiscal crisis, it is grossly unfair to single them out among the personnel of the co-equal branches of government to bear financial sacrifices far greater than those being imposed on others," Chief Judge Sol Wachtler of the Court of Appeals said in a letter to the judges. "Please rest assured that I will continue to use all of my energies to achieve a salary increase for judges." 
 The holiday message, dated Dec. 13 and addressed to "Dear Colleague," was reported in The Daily News yesterday and quickly stirred denunciations from unions representing court officers and other nonjudicial personnel, and from a spokeswoman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has exchanged lawsuits with Judge Wachtler in a running feud over financing for the courts.
 
Timing Is Criticized
 "The timing of the judge's letter is inappropriate, and it suggests he is unfeeling," said John McKillop, president of the New York State Supreme Court Officers Association, representing 1,180 uniformed court officers, whose morale, he said, had sunk to new lows amid layoffs and budget cuts.
Anne Crowley, speaking for the Governor, said of Judge Wachtler: "His startling request for raises for judges at this time of hardship for the hardworking people of the middle class, and those in poverty, does more to impair his credibility than we could."
Judge Wachtler, who did not ask for judicial pay increases in his budget request on Dec. 1 or in his lawsuit, said in an interview yesterday that he did not mean in his letter to imply that he wanted immediate raises for judges, or even raises during the current fiscal crisis.
 
'When Funds Are Available'
 "Ultimately, when the state economy improves and when funds are available -- when the fiscal crisis eases -- we will seek to have judges brought up to the equivalent of personnel in the executive branch of government who are earning more than judges," Judge Wachtler said. "I just did not want to them think that another eon would pass until they are considered."
Judge Wachtler said his recent budget message had asked for more money only for the union workers. "The unions should know that every penny in the budget message this year is for the nonjudicial personnel," he said.
The judges paid by the state -- in contrast to justices of the peace and others paid by counties and municipalities -- sit in criminal, civil and family courts and are paid an average of $84,000 a year, though the 300 State Supreme Court Justices are paid $95,000. Uniformed court officers are paid an average of $35,000 a year.
The court system, which has 13,000 employees, began its fiscal year in April with a $901 million budget. That amount was cut by $34 million in September, requiring 495 layoffs and sharp cuts in court functions, and the system faces another $26 million cut early next year that could lead to hundreds of additional layoffs.

HEADLINE: Thieving Lawyers Draining Client Security Funds

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Frederick Miller runs the New York State fund that reimburses people who have been robbed by their lawyers, and he has been sending out a lot of checks lately. There is no end in sight, so he's getting pretty worried.
"We have pending losses in excess of $35 million," Mr. Miller said. "We have assets of approximately $2 million." 
 The run on New York's fund, the Lawyers Fund for Client Protection, is the most dramatic example of the pressure such funds are facing around the country. More and more claims are being filed, officials say, leading them to be concerned not only about the state of the funds, but also about the state of the legal profession.
Although the rise in claims probably has other causes as well, a combination of hard times and abuse of alcohol and drugs is apparently driving more lawyers to dip into clients' estate and trust funds or pilfer their settlement checks or down payments on homes.
 
Funds Vary Widely
 Client security funds, which exist in every state except Kansas, Maine, New Mexico and North Dakota, cover only bare theft, not losses resulting from malpractice or excessive fees. Though they differ widely from state to state, the funds generally draw their revenue from fees levied on lawyers.
In New York, claims climbed from 311 in 1987 to 497 this year. No overall national data are available.
Gilbert Webb, assistant client protection counsel for the American Bar Association's Center for Professional Responsibility, is surveying the funds, but he says the numbers are not all in. "It's really hard to report a general trend," he said.
But fund managers were less tentative. "This is generally the story all over the country," said Mr. Miller, who is also chairman of the A.B.A.'s Advisory Commission on Client Protection Funds.
 
Florida Repayments Are Cut
 Because of a sudden rise in claims last year, the Florida Client Security Fund has had to reduce repayments to reach all its claimants with at least some money. "Our fund was tooling along, paying out $200,000, $300,000, and last year we got hit with this $1.3 million," said William Ricker, chairman of the fund.
"Times have changed, and I think with the recession there's going to be even more theft," he added.
Claims against Connecticut's client security fund have continued to increase steadily since the crimes of one lawyer yielded a record 23 approved claims in 1987, said George A. Buckley Jr., assistant executive director for the Connecticut Bar Association. The fund is seeking new sources of revenue.
In California, "applications increased tremendously in the late 80's," said Kiyoko Tatsui, director of the Client Security Fund for the California bar. This year she may have to pay out a record $3 million. Many lawyers who steal because of hard economic times today, she said, will not show up in the form of increased claims for a year or two.
 
A Public Service Venture
 To cover increases in claims, the funds can increase the revenue they receive from fees, as California's fund did in 1990, or cut the amount they will pay out per claim, as New York's did in July and may have to do again. Or the funds simply go out of business, as North Dakota's did this fall. The funds are not obligated to repay bilked clients; they are simply out to perform a public, and public relations, service on behalf of the legal profession.
As a result, unlike the fund that insured deposits in the nation's savings and loans, the client security funds will never be bailed out by the taxpayers. But lawyers and fund managers suggested that, as with the savings and loans, the funds' beggared condition provides a rough index of growing moral poverty among professionals whom people trust, not only with their savings but also with their secrets and even their dying requests.
Lawyers' victims tend to be society's most vulnerable members: the elderly, the illiterate, the very young. "We're not dealing with Lee Iacocca or Jackie Kennedy Onassis," Mr. Miller said. "It's the widows and orphans that are the saddest cases."
Besides pointing to drug and alcohol abuse and hard times, many lawyers trying to explain the rise in claims cited growing public awareness of the funds and the fact that there are more lawyers now.
 
'L.A. Law' Is Blamed
 "In the past 10 years there's more lawyers, there's more young lawyers, there's more lawyers building up a rich life style," said Geoffrey Hazard, Sterling Professor at the Yale Law School and a member of the A.B.A.'s Committee on Lawyers' Responsibility for Client Protection. "They made some investments, and some have been caught short."
Because it raised expectations of the kind of way of life lawyers should enjoy, the television show "L.A. Law" may also be to blame.
"There may be this sense from 'L.A. Law' that you graduate law school and you walk into a posh office and someone hands you the keys to a Porche, but there are a lot of lawyers out there who are struggling," said Ken Bossong, director and counsel of the New Jersey Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection, where claims and payouts are also on the rise.
Mr. Miller, the New York fund manager, said of lawyers who steal, "It's no excuse, but they have to eat."
The odds that any given lawyer will steal are still quite small. "One half of 1 percent of attorneys ever get into something like this," Mr. Bossong said. "And even among that group it's only a handful that really do the damage." Of the 45,000 lawyers in New Jersey, he said, 36 were responsible for the 126 claims approved by New Jersey's fund this year.
But the damage done by those few lawyers can be severe. Just as no one can rob a bank as smoothly or completely as a banker, no one can break the law quite like a lawyer.
"You become a victim once, that's why you go to an attorney, and then you get victimized again," said Cathy Proscia, whose lawyer absconded a year and a half ago with thousands of dollars due her from a settlement after her daughter's arm was ripped open by a chain swing. "You know, dealing with a man in a three-piece suit, an attorney from the Upper East Side, I'm not prepared to get robbed."
Mrs. Proscia, an executive secretary with Home Box Office, began to cry as she described hearing two weeks ago from Mr. Miller that the Lawyers' Fund would make up her entire loss.
 
Payoff After Conviction
 Vermont established the first client security fund in 1956. New York's Lawyers' Fund was created in 1981 and is financed mostly by portions of the $300 registration fee that the state's lawyers pay every two years.
New York's fund is typical in paying off clients only after their lawyers have been found guilty of misusing client funds by the court system. The lawyers are generally disbarred, if not convicted and imprisoned.
New York's fund pays as much as $50,000 to cover a client's losses. The cap was $100,000 per person until last summer, when the rising number of claims forced the trustees who supervise the fund to halve it. They may have to cut it further, Mr. Miller said. So far, the fund has disbursed $22 million to 1,943 victims.
In New York, the crooked lawyers have ranged from Robert B. Anderson, a former United States Secretary of the Treasury who stole a widow's retirement money, to Jack B. Solerwitz, 86 of whose victims cost the Lawyer's Fund almost $3 million, and to a lawyer in Otsego County who tacked an invented heiress onto an illiterate client's will and then, to create a paper trail, dressed as a woman and checked into a motel in Little Falls under her name. Mr. Miller said that at a probate hearing the judge caught on after a clerk from the motel described the mystery woman as 6 feet tall, 200 pounds and "a Bea Arthur look-alike."
 
Profile of Lawbreakers
 More recently, a New York lawyer stole the inheritance of a young man institutionalized with Down syndrome. Then there is the case of Sergio Taub, a lawyer from Queens who was shot and killed while driving home on the Meadowbrook Parkway in September, apparently by gunmen hired by his wife's lover. Lawyers picking through his estate found that close to $200,000 was missing from his clients' trust accounts, most of it down payments of about $3,000 apiece on homes in Queens.
"Every time I think I've seen it all, bam! In comes another," Mr. Miller said.
Lawyers who break the law are generally middle-aged men and tend to have some sort of addiction. "It's always drugs or alcohol, women, gambling -- craziness," said Eleanor Breitel Alter, a Manhattan lawyer who is chairman of the New York Lawyers' Fund.
In North Dakota, whose poorly financed client security fund recently went bankrupt, all six outstanding claims are against lawyers who stole to feed their cocaine habits, said Sherry King, acting executive director of the State Bar Association of North Dakota.
 
Ex-Addict Repays Fund
 Steven Winston, a lawyer in Manhattan, said: "I can tell you as an addict, all that matters is your drugs. You don't think about your wife or kids, so the last thing you think about is your career or clients."
The New York Lawyers' Fund paid $12,500 to a client of Mr. Winston, who later repaid the fund and now works as general counsel for Daytop Village Inc., where he underwent drug treatment.
The trustees of some client security funds have pushed for changes in the law that would allow them to spot dishonest lawyers quickly.
In New York, the remarkable career of Jerome Louis Spiegelman, who fleeced dozens of clients by secretly settling their personal injury cases and pocketing the proceeds, prompted the fund's trustees to push the State Insurance Department for a regulation, in force since 1988, that requires insurance companies to notify clients when they send settlement checks to their lawyers. The state's lawyers and bankers are now negotiating over a regulation that would force banks to report to the fund when checks bounce against attorney trust or escrow accounts.
State bar associations can generally inform clients if their lawyers are in good standing.

HEADLINE: No Budget Deal, No Break: Cuomo Orders Senate Back

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 26

 BODY:
The struggle over the state budget continued today with no progress, but, as he said he would last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo ordered all members of the Republican-led State Senate back to work on Friday.
The Governor's executive order applied only to the Senate, not to the Democratic-controlled Assembly. It appeared to be an attempt to force the Senators to act on an $875 million deficit-reduction package that the Assembly has already approved. The Senate Finance Committee rejected that package on Monday. 
 "This is nothing more than a costly p.r. stunt," said Edward Martin, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino.
 
Growing Irritated
 The Governor has increasingly expressed irritation with the Senate over its refusal to agree on an approach to closing the $875 million gap in the state's $30 billion budget. The Senate has been holding out for more cuts in Medicaid and welfare spending as well as for a plan that it says would attack the $4 billion potential gap in next year's budget.
Emerging from an afternoon meeting with Mr. Marino and the new Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, Mr. Cuomo said his staff was working on new legislation that he hoped would appeal to the Senate. Senate officials said they would study the proposal overnight.
The state Constitution gives the governor the authority to summon lawmakers back to Albany, but once they get here he cannot make them actually do anything.
 
Christmas Called Ruined
 Mr. Martin said the Governor's strategy would not work. "Going out of your way to ruin someone's Christmas holiday does not lend itself to making friends and influencing people," he said.
Mr. Cuomo, who is not up for reelection next year, and Mr. Weprin have both been openly skeptical in recent days that the 15-month budget proposal can be agreed to.
The crux of the dispute remains how to apportion hundreds of millions of dollars of spending cuts. The Senate continues to insist that most of the cuts be made in social-service programs. Their costs have risen in some cases by almost 20 percent in the last year, in part because of the recession.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Off Sharply, But Trading Remains Light

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply yesterday in light trading, weakened by expectations that it will lose more value as the American economy struggles to overcome the recession.
Gold prices also fell sharply, but traders said the decline was exaggerated by Japanese selling in an extremely thin market. There was no significant economic news to influence precious-metals trading. 
 "Because you have a lot less activity, there hasn't been anybody on the other side to buy," said Nina Lipton, head of research at the Platinum Guild, a New York precious metals concern.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery fell to $354.50 an ounce, down $4.60 from Tuesday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold fetched $354.95 an ounce, off $4.30 from Tuesday. Almost all markets were closed on Christmas Day, and most markets in Europe and in Hong Kong were closed yesterday as well.
Currency dealers said sentiment in the foreign-exchange markets had increasingly been turning against the dollar.
Last week, the Federal Reserve sharply lowered interest rates in the United States to stimulate lending and reinvigorate the anemic economy. Meanwhile, the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, raised its key domestic interest rates to battle inflation.
As a result of these conflicting moves, traders moved to sell dollars as the rate of return on dollar-denominated investments became less competitive. Moreover, traders said, there is no indication that the Bush Administration is overly concerned about the dollar's worth.
Expectations are also growing that President Bush will put pressure on the Japanese to raise the value of the yen to help ease the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan when he visits Tokyo next month. A stronger yen would make Japanese exports more expensive in the United States.
"The dollar is very weak," said Shigeru Tokunaga, vice president and foreign exchange manager at the New York branch of the Fuji Bank of Japan. "The sentiment is very bad for the dollar."
Hillel Waxman, chief dealer for foreign exchange at the New York branch of the Bank Leumi Trust Company, said he foresaw no events in coming days that could help the dollar. Indeed, he said, "whatever news there is won't be positive news."
In Tokyo, the dollar fell for the fourth straight trading day, closing at 126.65 yen, down 0.35 yen from Wednesday. In New York, the dollar closed even lower at 126.40 yen, down from 127.55 yen on Tuesday. These are the lowest levels for the dollar since the fall of 1990.
The British pound fetched $1.8840 in New York, up from $1.8735 late Tuesday.
Other dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5075 German marks, down from 1.5205; 1.3435 Swiss francs, down from 1.3490; 1.1605 Canadian dollars, unchanged; 5.1580 French francs, down from 5.1995, and 1,143.50 Italian lire, down from 1,152.00.
In silver trading, silver for current delivery slipped to $3.90 an ounce, down from $3.903 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Are Up; Taxables Continue to Drop

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money market funds showed a significant rise over the last week, according to IBC/ Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report. At the same time the taxable funds continued their steady downward progress, dropping quite sharply.
Referring to the tax-exempts, Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/ Donoghue's, said that yields had probably risen "because of the large supply of municipal securities that has come to market before the year end." 
 But he said total assets of the tax- exempts were $91.5 billion, down $1.2 billion for the week. The decline probably indicated that a substantial number of investors had withdrawn money to seek better yields elsewhere.
 
Shorter Maturity
 The average days to maturity of the holdings of the tax-free funds dropped by one day, to 58 from 59 days.
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempts was 4.01 percent, up 22 basis point from last week, which he called a sharp rise. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempt funds also showed an increase, rising by 20 basis points, to 3.93 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The 30-day compound yield was 3.83, up 6 basis points from the previous week, and the 30-day simple yield was 3.76 percent, also up 6 basis points.
Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York fund was once again Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 4.52 percent versus 4.48 percent a week earlier.
 
Top New York Fund
 In Connecticut the top-yielding fund this week again was Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.35 percent, compared with a yield of 4.14 percent.
New Jersey's leading fund for yields was again Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey with a seven-day compound yield of 4.42 percent, compared with 4.30 percent a week earlier.
Nationwide, among those funds with $100 million or more in assets, the highest-yield performance for the week was once again turned in by Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.97 percent, compared with 4.80 percent a week earlier.
 
Outflow of Assets
 With regard to the taxable funds, Martha Wittbrodt, editor of the IBC/ Donoghue Money Fund Report, said that their total assets showed a sizable drop, declining $6.4 billion to a total of $468.8 billion. She said, "Most of the asset outflow can be attributed to seasonal factors, which would include window dressing by institutional holders who like to show more cash on their books at year-end and withdrawals for holiday spending by individuals."
She said that "taxable money fund yields will continue to decline, especially in view of the Federal Reserve's aggressive move to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point about a week ago."
The average days to maturity of the portfolio holdings held steady at 61 days, indicating that money managers were trying to lock in rates ahead of the further expected declines in yields, according to Miss Wittbrodt.
 
Taxable Yields Drop
 The seven-day compound yield on the taxable funds was 4.64 percent, compared with 4.70 last week, and the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds was was 4.53 percent, compared with 4.59 percent. In each instance the decline was 6 basis points.
Meanwhile, the average compound 30-day yield dropped to 4.72 percent, down 5 basis points from 4.77 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was 4.61 percent, also down 5 basis points from 4.66 percent.
Among the taxables the top-yielding fund for the week was Riverside Capital Money Market Fund of Columbus, Ohio, with a yield of 16.87 percent, which includes capital gains.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, yielded 4.34 percent and certificates of deposit yielded an average of 4.37 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly national index issued on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Japan Posted Trade Surplus Of $7.26 Billion Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Only days before President Bush visits Japan to tackle a number of thorny trade issues, Tokyo announced today a more than threefold increase in its current-account balance of payments surplus.
The nation's current-account balance, the broadest measure of trade in good and services, widened to a $7.26 billion surplus in November without being adjusted for seasonal factors, from a surplus of $1.69 billion in the same month last year, the Finance Ministry said. 
 Criticism of Japanese trade practices is mounting quickly in Congress, fueled by such developments as the General Motors Corporation's decision last week to close 21 plants and slash its work force by 74,000.
 
Preparing for Worst
 Japanese officials are bracing for stinging attacks from Washington, and economists say that when Mr. Bush arrives in Japan on Jan. 7 for a four-day visit, much of the lobbying will likely be aimed at opening Japanese domestic markets.
The primary component of the current account, the trade balance, ballooned to $8.65 billion last month, from $4.43 billion a year earlier.
In a pattern that has been evident much of the year, the surplus was pushed higher by a decline in Japanese imports. Imports fell to $17.64 billion, from $20.62 billion.
Although Japan's slowing domestic economy has undercut purchases of foreign goods much of the year, recent months have seen especially weak figures because of high oil prices a year ago.
Crude oil prices have plunged from highs during the Persian Gulf crisis, from around $34 a barrel in November 1990 to around $20 in November of this year.
But Japan's exports grew an unimpressive 5 percent, to $26.29 billion, from $25.05 billion a year ago.
Export growth has slowed sharply much of this year, as slower economic growth among Japan's main trading partners has curtailed what Japan sends abroad.
 
Car Makers Still Expanding
 But Kenneth Courtis, the senior economist at Deutsche Bank Capital Markets (Asia) Ltd., said Japanese car makers were still expanding their market share abroad as manufacturers in other nations were retrenching.
"The message is that in this key market, Japanese companies are still expanding," he said.
The most recent Finance Ministry figures showed that Japan's November trade surplus with the United States was $3.59 billion, up from $3.56 billion in the same month last year.
The other major component of Japan's current account, the category that includes trade in services, tourism and some unilateral transfers, had a $1.15 billion deficit, compared with a $2.48 billion shortfall a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Beyond Just Complaining;
Self-Fullfilling Pessimism Is Said to Infect New York

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
New Yorkers are good complainers. They love to moan about taxi drivers who don't know their way around the city, stalled subway trains, insufferable co-op boards -- anything to get across the constant indignities they have to put up with.
But lately, this pessimism has grown to the point where many people say they no longer see it as a reflection of other problems, but as a problem in and of itself. It is leading business executives to curtail investments in local operations and expand elsewhere. Longtime residents are making plans to move far away. Some even think this new pessimism is causing consumers to spend less. 
 "There's nothing worse for an economy than when people begin to lose hope," said Philip K. Howard, a Manhattan lawyer, recalling the widespread dissatisfaction with the city he encountered during his unsuccessful campaign, earlier this year, for a seat on the City Council. "It affects their decision-making and energy. It's like an infection."
 
Calling for Leadership
 Some city residents are calling for political leaders to make symbolic gestures that lift morale until the economy recovers and the fiscal situation improves. Others say confidence will not be restored until there is a comprehensive plan that promises a brighter future for the city and explains in detail how it can be realized.
A poll of the region taken last month by The New York Times captured the sense of unease that seems to be permeating the city. It found that 58 percent of city residents who were interviewed said the city would be a worse place to live 10 to 15 years from now, the highest level of disaffection registered since the question was first asked in a poll in 1973. Only 36 percent said they expected the city to stay the same or improve.
A full 60 percent said that if they had any choice, they would like to be living somewhere else four years from now; 37 percent said they would want to continue living in the city. Fifty-one percent said they had plans to eventually leave the city; 47 percent said they did not have such plans. The telephone poll of 824 adults throughout the city was conducted Nov. 2 to Nov. 12 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
"I think that may be the biggest problem we have, this pervasive loss of confidence in the city's future," said Felix G. Rohatyn, an investment banker who is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up in 1975 to help stabilize the city's finances. "It's a terribly dangerous psychology, because people who are in a position to make decisions to move will move. If they're not at that decision-making point already, they're talking themselves into it." Mr. Rohatyn believes this loss of confidence is worse than it was during the city's last fiscal crisis, even though the problems then were in many ways more severe.
The lack of enthusiasm about the city's future reflected in The Times's poll spanned income, racial and age groups. While blacks were more optimistic about the city's future immediately after David N. Dinkins was elected mayor, their pessimism had returned to the same level as whites in this latest poll.
 
Planning to Move
 In follow-up interviews with over two dozen of those who participated in the poll and with business executives and civic leaders, New Yorkers spoke frequently of a feeling of hopelessness engulfing the city, eroding their desire to remain.
"I just can't see any light at the end of the tunnel," said Larry Bergin, a 45-year-old retired New York City police detective. "The school system has gone downhill, we're taxed like crazy, the services stink" He added, "I just don't see anything getting better."
Come January, Mr. Bergin plans to put his Staten Island house on the market, with the intention of moving his family to an area outside Scranton, Pa., that he and his wife came across in an intensive search for a new home last summer.
"It's a shame because I love the city," said Mr. Bergin, who was born in Brooklyn and has lived in the city all of his life. "But it's not just me -- people are leaving in droves."
The more people who become depressed about the future and leave, the smaller the tax base left to support public services. The danger is that this becomes a vicious cycle: as services decline, more people leave, forcing greater cuts in services, triggering still more departures.
Many who complain most are young and educated, with middle-class incomes gained from professions like nursing, administration and finance. They are the social and economic bedrock that would theoretically provide the city's next generation of growth.
 
New York's Not Alone
 New York is not the only city suffering from a rising chorus of complaints by its citizens. The combination of the national recession and the decline in Federal aid for cities has left many without the resources to cope with the growing problems of homelessness, AIDS and drug abuse while trying to provide a decent level of public services.
And the national mood of pessimism is surely not helping the city's morale. Add to that the tendency of New Yorkers to view themselves as the center of the universe, and one has the ingredients for a full-blown citywide crisis. "It's like personal depression, only on a mass scale," said Rudolph W. Giuliani, who lost to Mr. Dinkins in the last mayoral election and is likely to be a candidate in the next. "Everything looks bad, even when some things are good."
The causes of this collective depression vary. Many cited the debilitating effect that crime has had on their neighborhoods, making them feel unsafe walking home from the subway after work, forcing them to accompany their grown children to and from public school and leading them to fear for the security of their cars and their homes.
For some, particularly blacks, there was a growing fear of racial tension and police harassment of their children. "The different ethnic groups are not getting along," said Yvonne Grimsley, a 40-year-old black from Queens who makes more than $50,000 a year selling computers. "I worry about my son, wondering if he'll be stopped by the police because he's a boy of color." Many whites, meanwhile, complained that the recent wave of immigrants is dragging down the city. Young people said they did not want to raise families in the city, while older people were afraid of retirement in the city.
Contributing to this unease was a sense that the city government is no longer in command of the situation. The police do not respond when called. Public spaces have become the preserve of the homeless. Children are shot in school corridors. Traveling to work has become a question of dodging broken water mains, closed bridges and subway tunnels and seemingly endless street construction. And car alarms wail endlessly through the night, reminding their sleepless victims of just how helpless they are in controlling their environment.
 
Cuts Spending Plans
 "We don't expect the city to do anything except provide basic services," said Ira Nerenberg, who has lived in New York all his life and runs a woodworking company in Brooklyn. "But if you call the police, let them come." Mr. Nerenberg said he considers the city's future so bleak that he has decided to spend only a quarter of what he had originally intended to improve a building he took a 15-year lease on just last year. Future investment dollars, he said, will go toward setting up a factory outside the city.
"I think it's going to get worse," said Mr. Nerenberg, whose company employs about 100 people. "There's no sense of any hope. There's a total lack of leadership."
The absence of leadership was a common lament among those who spoke in follow-up interviews after the poll. Many blamed Mr. Dinkins, with whites in particular saying that he was elected only because he is black, and that he was not up to the job. Others said their disappointment extended to the business community and labor leaders.
 
Mayor Criticized
 "Maybe a coalition can do something about it, but everybody seems to be going their own way, looking after their own interests," said Emilio Rosario, a retired supervisor for a Stanley Works operation in New Jersey who plans to move to Florida with his family next year, after living in New York for 45 years.
Mayor Dinkins's spokesman, Leland T. Jones, contended that any pessimism about the city's future was similar to that felt in many other large cities across the country that are suffering from a cutoff of Federal aid. He admitted that some New York services have deteriorated, but insisted that many, like the subway system, have also improved. "I don't know why people say what they say," he said, of the pessimism expressed in The Times's poll.
Some of those people have concluded that the Mayor has either become so distant or so defensive that he does not recognize what many feel is now a key problem ailing the city. If he did, they say, he would at least be trying to engage in some cheerleading or symbolic exercises, instead of blaming the problem on external forces or trying to minimize its importance.
"People are hungry for leadership," said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Arts Society. "Today many have the feeling, 'I don't know who's in charge here.' "
Mr. Barwick noted the warm reception given to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's presentation several months ago of his plans to invest $7 billion in public works projects in and around the city. "Even though most of those projects already existed, everyone was so thrilled to see someone pretending to lead and to have vision," Mr. Barwick said.
What can be done to restore confidence? An economic recovery would certainly help, but previous Times polls suggest that it is not the weak economy that is behind much of the pessimism. Lack of confidence in the city's future has been increasing steadily since 1985, even though the economy did not begin its present tailspin until 1988.
What most people seemed to yearn for was someone who could spell out how New York can get through its immediate financial crunch and how the city can then remake itself to get onto a more stable, longterm footing. Many who were interviewed after the poll said they feared that when better times returned, the city would simply resume its profligate ways, planting the seeds of the next crisis.
Where might new leadership come from to revamp the city? Many people, including Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, theorize that only when conditions are perceived to be bad enough will people with new and forceful ideas be pushed to the fore. Most admit, however, that they see little sign of that as yet.
Gerald L. Golub, a partner in the accounting firm of Goldstein Golub and Kessler, is one New Yorker whose faith has not been shaken. "There is an opportunity for someone to fire up the crowd and clean up this city," he said. "Whatever it takes, New Yorkers will do it."
Spoken like a true, but increasingly rare, New Yorker.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fell by 20,000 in Midmonth

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reuters)

 BODY:
New applications for jobless benefits fell 20,000 in mid-December, the Government said today, but the number of claims remained at recession levels.
The Labor Department said first-time unemployment claims for the week that ended on Dec. 14 fell to 473,000, from 493,000 the previous week, which was inflated by a surge of applications after the Thanksgiving holiday. 
 "This is still at a very bad level," said Russ Sheldon, a senior economist at the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh.
The four-week average, considered a more reliable indicator of the job market's health, has risen steadily since November, reversing the summer's downward trend.
For the last four weeks, claims averaged 464,000, up from 449,000 in the prior four-week period, and compared with about 415,000 in August.
Mr. Sheldon said the new claims reflected efforts by businesses to slash payrolls at the end of the year to get tax write-offs "and clear their slates for a better year ahead."
The rise in mid-December claims for state unemployment aid could point to a surge in the national jobless rate for the month to 7 percent, from 6.8 percent, economists said.
The number of jobs in the overall economy could shrink by about 50,000 when December's employment report is released on Jan. 7, they said. The survey for that report, a separate Labor Department tally of employers, was conducted the same week as the latest weekly jobless claims data.
 
End Is Said to Be Near
 Fred Sturm, a senior economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said he expected no further dramatic surges in the average weekly jobless claims.
"We don't see the economy nodding off to the second leg of a double-dip recession," he said. "For that reason, we would not see this uptrend in claims for much longer."
Mr. Sturm said the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cuts last week should assure a vigorous rebound next summer. Already the number of people continuing to claim unemployment benefits is stabilizing, he said.
The department also reported that the number of people actually on the jobless rolls fell the week that ended Dec. 7 by 138,000, to 3.3 million, the latest period for which data were available.
There was little reaction in financial markets to the latest jobless claims figures, which matched economists' projections.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Post Modest Rise in Light Day

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bond prices rose modestly yesterday on the strength of slight buying by mutual funds and other investors who had cash but were not willing to keep it invested in low-yielding short-term securities.
By late in the day, the 8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2021 were offered at 105 7/8, up by an eighth of a point on the day, to yield 7.50 percent, compared with 7.51 percent late on Tuesday. Shorter-term issues were little changed, with two-year notes closing with a yield of 4.83 percent and five-year notes at 6 percent. 
 Trading was light, as securities dealers and other speculators, their ranks thinned by the holidays, stayed on the sidelines.
 
Stocks Still Gaining
 But while the bond market was little changed, the stock market continued to rise sharply. To some analysts, the recent behavior of the two markets suggested sharply different views of the future. The bond market has rallied, with 30-year Treasury bond yields falling from 8 percent in early November, amid predictions that inflation will remain subdued while the economy and credit demands stay weak.
Stock prices, meanwhile, are moving to new highs, in anticipation of a stronger economy because of recent cuts in interest rates and some package of increased spending or tax cuts to be enacted by Congress next year.
"The stock market is strong, looking ahead to developments of next year, while the bond market right now is not too cerebral, and isn't looking much beyond next week," said Len Santow, an economist and co-author of the Griggs & Santow Report, one of the oldest newsletters on Wall Street covering the bond markets and the economy.
Mr. Santow said that fiscal and monetary policy "are going to get mroe stimulative," and that by the second half of next year, "the economy will be considerably stronger." By 1993 or 1994, he said, rising inflation may cause bond investors, with the benefit of 20-20 hindsight, to decide that economic policy makers provided more stimulus than was needed.
Alan C. Lerner, managing director at the Bankers Trust Company, noted in a recent issue of Prospects for Credit Markets, a bank publication, that recent Fed moves to reduce short-term interest rates reflected a desire "to get the economy rolling before the politicians act."
But he added that the Fed's moves would take time to bear fruit and that "it seems almost inevitable that Congress and the Administration will be competing in 1992 to stimulate the economy."
In addition to the danger of a revived economy, Mr. Santow said bond investors and traders might be overlooking the potential for a heavier supply of new Treasury securities if Congress and the President agreed on tax cuts or new spending programs.
While there were no new corporate bond offerings yesterday, investment bankers expect a flurry of new issues in early January, as corporate treasurers try to take advantage of low rates. Based on past episodes of herd behavior by large corporations, new bond sales could exceed $10 billion in a week, or more than four times the monthly average of new investment-grade corporate issues this year.
According to Salomon Brothers Inc., the average monthly volume this year was about $9.09 billion for new investment-grade issues and $1.37 billion of below investment-grade issues, including those that could be converted into common stock.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Colony Hotels President Has Started Settling In

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
When she was appointed president of Colony Hotels and Resorts last month, Joan Sills became probably the only woman to head a leading hotel company with worldwide operations. The 42 properties that Colony manages and markets consist of more than 8,700 rooms in hotels, resorts, condominiums and time-share units from Hawaii to Phuket, Thailand (where a luxury Colony hotel will open in April).
Started in Hawaii almost 25 years ago, Colony "just came along for the ride," Ms. Sills said, when the Carlson Companies of Minneapolis bought it in 1979, along with the much bigger Ask Mr. Foster travel agencies. Both are now part of the Carlson Hospitality Group, which includes all the hotel and restaurant operations of the $8.1 billion Carlson Companies, one of the largest privately owned corporations in the United States. 
 Although Colony appears nicely positioned for a turnaround in the economy, with properties in the Caribbean as well as in New England ski resorts, 1991 has been a bumpy ride for the resort industry. Leisure travel plummeted, hotel rates fell and corporations cut back sharply on meetings at resort hotels -- meetings that had accounted for $6 billion in 1990.
"It was definitely a tough year, especially the first quarter, which is the biggest quarter in Hawaii," said Ms. Sills, who is 38. "We predominantly focus on the leisure vacationer, so we weren't hit as hard by the fall-off in meetings. But people shortened their vacations and stayed closer to home, although we have begun to see some pickup."
A bachelor of arts graduate of Michigan State University who also holds an M.B.A. from Loyola College in Baltimore, Ms. Sills is a 16-year-veteran of the hospitality industry, the first 14 of them with the Marriott Corporation. Before her recent promotion she was executive vice president of Colony, responsible for most of its operations. As president she will oversee not only operations, but Colony's entire management and marketing functions as well.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
What's Different About This Slump

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHAT was at first regarded by the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve as a mild and brief recession has become a long and painful one, possibly even what some economists are calling a "quiet depression."
David M. Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, says this slump is distinguished from its postwar predecessors by a clash between a dangerously overleveraged economy and unusually severe bank loan stringency. "The threat posed is an all-out private-sector credit contraction and asset price deflation, accompanied by mounting corporate bankruptcies and bank failures," he said. "The resulting decline in consumer wealth could curtail spending for a prolonged period." 
 Is 1992 shaping up as the analogue of 1932, the year when the recession of 1930-31 collapsed into depression? Or do we know enough economics to stop that from ever happening again?
Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, says in his introduction to "The Risk of Economic Crisis," a book based on a conference of leading American economists: "Although the United States has been fortunate enough not to experience the kind of massive economic collapse that occurred from time to time until the worldwide depression of the 1930's, there is no doubt that the possibility of another such financial and economic crisis cannot be dismissed."
In that book, Hyman P. Minsky, professor of economics at Washington University, concludes that the reason a vicious downward spiral has not yet led to depression in postwar America is that apt intervention by the Government and the central bank can abort the process leading to depression at two points. One comes when endangered financial institutions are at the point of selling off assets; the institutions can be refinanced to prevent a wave of sales and a sharp and general fall of asset prices. Refinancing banks and crucial financial players, he says, is the basic central bank lender-of-last-resort operation.
The other intervention point comes when profits start falling, and the Government can act to avert collapse. In the model Mr. Minsky uses, total profits equal investment plus the Government deficit. To sustain profits during a period of falling investment, the Government can run a larger deficit.
Why did the United States Government not do that after the crash of 1929? Mr. Minsky's answer is that the Federal Government then made up only 3 percent of gross national product -- too small to offset the impact that falling investment between 1929 and 1933 had upon corporate profits.
Today's Government, constituting some 25 percent of G.N.P., is large enough to sustain profits by increasing the deficit through automatic stabilizers or fiscal policy. The combination of lender-of-last-resort interventions and increasing Federal deficits, he says, "explains why a serious, long-lasting and deep depression has not taken place up until now."
But could it happen now? Like Mr. Feldstein, Mr. Minsky says it could. Through nearly all of the postwar period, the United States had "fiscal autonomy" -- the power to take policy actions without much concern about adverse foreign reactions to the widening deficits that sustained domestic profits. "The situation may be different now," he warns. "The United States no longer is as autonomous or as powerful as in the past. Scenarios in which cooperation in maintaining global asset values and profit flows is necessary but not forthcoming can be sketched."
Foreigners now have enormous holdings of American financial assets. The big deficits the United States ran in relatively prosperous times would mean the deficit it would have to run to abort a financial crisis might be enormous. The interventions next time, Mr. Minsky says, "may well be beyond the combined efforts of the Federal Reserve and the Treasury." Containing a future financial and economic crisis, he says, "may depend more on what Japan and Europe do than upon the Fed and the U.S. Treasury."
But, just when cooperation among the United States, Japan and Europe is more critical than ever, tensions among them are rising. The Uruguay Round of trade talks is in jeopardy. Germany and the United States are moving in opposite directions on monetary policy, with Germany following a tight-money, anti-inflation policy.
The Fed, with the year nearly over, moved to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point. And the Administration, at last publicly acknowledging that the recession was continuing, intensified its search for fiscal stimuli.
Both the Fed and the White House were driven by news of plant closings by General Motors and others, layoffs, the troubles of financial institutions, weak Christmas sales and the approaching cold dawn of the 1992 election year.
Thus, the United States is moving to head off a not-so-quiet depression, despite the big deficit and foreign constraints, and 1992 will prove whether the anti-depression economic medicine can work in an economy that has gone global. With its year-end surge, the stock market was betting that it would.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Examining the Scandals at a U.S. Relief Agency

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Sunday's edition of "Special Assignment," on CNN at 9 P.M., takes apart the record of the Agency for International Development. If Mark Feldstein's report is reasonably accurate, the agency, which distributes food, medicine and other help to the needy around the world, has been bilked by its own officials and employees. Gene Richardson, its assistant inspector general for investigations, says: "Our crime rate is essentially higher than virtually every other agency in the Government."
Contractors have squeezed kickbacks out of programs to help feed Pakistan's poor. A deputy director went to prison for accepting nearly $100,000 in payoffs for awarding contracts to Honduras. Three scientists who were supposed to use aid money to find a cure for malaria, that world-class killer, instead made killings of their own. And there's more. 
 Ronald W. Roskens, administrator of the agency, insists that it is "unbefitting" to apply the word "crooks," used by Mr. Feldstein, to even "a very few people, comparatively, at high levels."
Viewers of "A.I.D.: Under Investigation" may not be much reassured by that vocabulary lesson amid the hour's array of scandals. Instead of sending dry-cleaning fluid to Zimbabwe, a contractor sent toxic waste. Starving Sudanese, who were supposed to receive tons of powdered milk, got animal feed instead. Peruvian children were killed by tainted medicine supplied by the agency. After 13 years of construction and $75 million in aid, a low-income housing project near Cairo is still far from developed.
The successes of the Agency for International Development (there must be some) are not mentioned in this unsparing report, which will do nothing to improve the prospects for foreign aid in these hard times.
 
'The Great Nobel Debate'
Channel 13
Tonight at 9
The main revelation of "The Great Nobel Debate" is that Nobel Prize winners have nothing particularly original to say about puffy questions like "Is mankind on balance harnessing its intelligence to build a better world?" That was the balloon floated before a sizable group of laureates by David Frost a few weeks ago as part of the 90th-anniversary celebration of the Nobel Prizes in Stockholm. You can see how they handled it tonight on Channel 13.
It is an hour of familiar lamentations, bromides and inspirational tags. Archbishop Desmond Tutu, taking the affirmative position, says he puts his faith in freedom and science. Prof. Henry Kendall, a physicist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, accentuates the negative with references to global warming, the destruction of rain forests, water problems and overpopulation.
Everyone sounds intelligent, but the high-mindedness of the occasion evidently kept minds at the idle. Prof. Milton Friedman, the Stanford University economist, sees hope in the collapse of Communism; Octavio Paz puts in a plug for poetry, and Nadine Gordimer, the most recent winner for literature, proposes a marriage of the gods of science and spirituality.
All these worthies are on their best behavior. The closest attempt at a joke comes late, from Dr. Howard Temin, who won the prize for physiology and medicine in 1975. Drawing attention to the AIDS epidemic, he says, "We must return to love but remind everyone that if you love, use a condom." At the end, Mr. Frost asks for a show of hands on mankind's prospects. If you stay with the program that long, you'll learn the result.
 
'Made in New York'
Channel 2
Tonight at 9
"Made in New York" is an hourlong promotion for New York City's movie industry. Agreeable as it is to watch an upbeat program about a beaten-down town, the constant plugs delivered by Ron Silver, playing the host, make for a nonstop commercial. The liveliest scenes are of the movie director Sidney Lumet organizing the crash of a taxicab into a 47th Street jewelry store. (It actually takes place in a Queens studio.) Spike Lee, Paul Mazursky and other movie and television makers contribute to the New York boosterism. There's even a segment on Gary David Goldberg, who created the television series "Brooklyn Bridge," which of course is all about New York and is produced in Hollywood.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
Defying all odds -- and, some might say, common sense in this recession -- the Essex House has unveiled not one but two lavish restaurants: Les Celebrites, an art-festooned, $65-a-person dining room, and Cafe Botanica, a breezier yet ambitious spot in the splendid renovated lobby.
Two years in the making as part of a hotel renovation, Les Celebrites is surprisingly small, with only 14 tables, yet unabashedly opulent: giant gilded columns and ceiling moldings, thickly upholstered rugs and crescent-shaped banquettes, dark mahogany walls, thick red carpets, softly strategic lighting. The tables for 54 guests are set with Bernardaud Limoges plates, Christofle silver and glittering crystal. Nice touches, but unnecessary really, for the food of Christian Delouvrier, the chef, would be heavenly on paper plates. 
 The restaurant's leitmotif is paintings by celebrities; thus you are treated to the brushworks of Phyllis Diller, Gene Hackman, Van Johnson, Billy Dee Williams, Peggy Lee, Tennessee Williams, James Dean and more. These amateur landscapes and still lifes, dramatically illuminated against dark walls, are startling in such a formal setting. Yet with time -- say, between the cocktail and the appetizer -- they withdraw and become benign splashes of color.
Mr. Delouvrier, who garnered three stars in late 1986 at Maurice in the Hotel Parker Meridien in Manhattan, prepared for his current post by traveling extensively in Asia courtesy of his Japanese employers, Nikko Hotels International. His menu displays a Zenlike harmony of East and West that is a joy to experience. An example is the pristine tart of raw tuna and chives with a hint of sesame oil, surrounded by tomato emulsion holding nickel-sized rounds of red, yellow and green peppers. Something as simple as giant sea scallops served on a shell with dill and minced gravlax is memorable, too. A colorful palette of baby vegetables is bathed in good olive oil and strewn with minced truffles. Great, yes? Not without a unifying touch of salt and other seasonings lamentably.
Not everything is so light and pure. You can also get seductive cabbage rolls filled with foie gras and truffles set in a pond of excellent chicken broth. Then there is the winsomely named burger of foie gras. It is essentially a hot foie gras in a bun of sweet green apples, a harmonious marriage that poses no immediate threat to McDonald's.
The dining room runs with the precision of the Rockettes. No sooner have you swallowed the last morsel of your roll than a new one appears. Glasses must be the purview of a short-distance sprinter, for as an empty glass hits the table a hand is on its stem to remove it. Les Celebrites' wine list is appropriately comprehensive for a restaurant of this caliber, especially among California and French labels. Prices are lower than average.
Chef Delouvrier's Eastern influence is best seen in main courses like the crisp-skinned salmon set over a delicious leek compote, with vinegar-sharpened sauce seasoned with a blend of Oriental spices. Red snapper is infused with flavor by braising it in a strong vegetable bouillon. Its supporting cast includes a ripe tomato confit, sauteed zucchini and grilled eggplant fragrant with anise. Black bass wears a French cap, served mariniere style (a light butter and mussel juice sauce) with boulangere potatoes that are sliced, layered with onions and baked. Lobster is lustrous, simply roasted and served with pan juices and well-seasoned couscous.
Game aficionados should head straight for the squab. It has a characteristic woodsy flavor -- the reason you order game in the first place -- and is served with splendid mashed potatoes and cabbage drizzled with white truffle oil. It is perhaps the most dynamic item on the menu. Honey-lacquered duck did not prompt such excitement, for the meat was on the dry side. Two classic dishes are done with great finesse: rack of lamb with white beans and mashed potatoes, and rotisserie-cooked chicken with its natural juices, a hillock of wild mushrooms and tasty potato skin fries.
A cleansing and tangy culmination of a meal here is the superb grapefruit sorbet. More indulgent is the apple dessert featuring a Lincoln Tunnel of sliced apples with bumper-to-bumper cubed caramelized apples underneath, all in a Calvados sauce. My other favorite was the tart of orange cream and candied orange rinds served with chocolate sorbet. Light, moist mango cake with a mango coulis is a close runner-up.
In an era when almost all new restaurants are scrambling to capture the $10.95 roast chicken market, it is heartening to see one restaurant go all out to achieve both excellence and unbridled luxury. Les Celebrites has already reached that plateau, and it has the potential to rise even further.
 
 Les Celebrites

Wine: Wide-ranging list. Strong in California and French labels. Fair prices.

HEADLINE: The Republican Obligation in Albany

 BODY:
Once again Albany is paralyzed, unable to close New York State's budget gap or even agree on a strategy for closing it. And once again the Republican Senate, led by Ralph Marino of Long Island, is the stumbling block. After nearly two months of fruitless negotiations, the Senate majority leader has an obligation to help forge a compromise.
The legislators will have to approve hundreds of millions of dollars in spending cuts -- the last thing they want as they approach re-election. Mr. Marino wants Medicaid and social services to take the bulk of the cuts, imposing disproportionate pain on the poor and unemployed. If Mr. Marino produced a humane plan for spending cuts, it would be worth considering. But he has not. 
 Gov. Mario Cuomo and the new Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin of Queens, agree that escalating social programs must be scaled back, which would spread the pain more fairly and realistically.
The Governor and the Democratic Assembly have agreed on an approach to closing the $875 million gap in the fiscal year ending March 31. Although their plan includes some non-recurring revenues and unrealistically exempts school aid, it is a reasonable start. But Mr. Marino is holding out for a 15-month budget that closes this year's gap and next year's too -- a projected combined deficit approaching $5 billion.
The idea of a multi-year budget made sense when Mr. Cuomo first suggested it in November. But the Republican-controlled Senate balked, no doubt because a long-term solution would have let Mr. Cuomo run for President free of budget woes back home. Now the Senate wants the long-range budget, presumably because it would soften the impact of spending cuts in an election year.
But so late in the game, it seems impossible for all sides to agree on a 15-month strategy in time to prevent damage. Bond rating agencies warn that delay could lead them to lower the state's credit rating, hurting local governments and school districts as well as the state.
Dawdling in Albany has already disrupted negotiations over New York City's transit fare, which will have to go from $1.15 to a punishing $1.40 to close the Transit Authority's own budget gap unless the Legislature acts. Since lawmakers have yet to agree on how to help the T.A., the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board may again put off its vote on a fare increase. A protracted delay will cost the T.A. money and could hurt its credit rating.
Mr. Marino and the State Senate are meeting today, at Mr. Cuomo's request. They have a responsibility to agree to a fair gap-closing plan that minimizes the damage to New Yorkers, particularly those least able to tolerate a plunging economy.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Don't Send Aid

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
Don't send aid, Russians in Moscow kept saying -- bring it. Bring it, manage it, guard it.
 That message was repeated to me over and over as the days of the Soviet Union came to an end. It was the plainest testimony to the destruction by Communism not just of the economy but of trust in almost everything connected with government and bureaucracy. 
 The suspicion blankets most of those now supposed to introduce and run this thing they tell the people will make life better -- business, free market, capitalism, whatever -- without ever explaining how it works. It covers most of the presidents of the republics, understandable enough since they were among the high priests of the god that failed.
The Communists who ruled for 74 years left behind a society where work just stops much of the day as citizens hunt to find sausage in the stores. Then they stand in the streets to barter a hunk of the sausage for stockings for their children.
Russians are not fool enough suddenly to trust bureaucratic survivors of that system when they announce they have a better one in mind and intend to run it.
The politicians of the republics will have to earn trust and it will take time. As for business, it seems to Russians that many of the people making money are former government and party hacks using their old contacts still in office and splitting the take. They are right.
But the republics are the hope of the future. With the death of the Soviet Union there is no political or ethical reason to withhold as much as the West can afford without stripping other poor nations of help.
Experienced Russian journalists told me they thought that the food threat had been deliberately exaggerated by the Gorbachev Government. On foreign food credits, Vitaly Korotich, the famous former editor of the magazine Ogonyok, said that since 1964 the U.S. had supplied $74 billion of food credit and that the net result had been to cover up the failure of the "planners" to get food from the soil to the table.
True, but my own eyes told me that as a result Muscovites and other urban victims of Communism live on the brink. The decision by the Bush Administration to move quickly with food and particularly medicine was wise and decent -- as long as it all is kept out of the hands of the Red Army and the bureaucrats.
But it's worth remembering that in the past year or so alone the U.S. has set aside more than $3.5 billion for food aid and credits that will probably turn out to be grants. Kremlin officials themselves acknowledge that scores of billions of dollars have been misspent or "disappeared." Other billions were hidden in foreign banks by the Soviet Government and Communist Party, including espionage funds. Accountability is necessary, for credibility's sake.
With all Western good will, foreign help will not do a great deal of good until the republics eliminate the planning ministries, the heart of Communist corruption and criminal mismanagement. They still make it economic serfdom for farmers to send food to the cities. They still keep factories busy producing parts for tanks that have no mission.
And as long as foreign business has to deal with ministries deciding every time what licenses will be given and how much profit can be sent home and the precise amount of bribes to be paid, the commonwealth will get only a small amount of the foreign investment it needs.
So the real decisions on how much foreign assistance the commonwealth will get depends on the commonwealth. But in addition to emergency aid and perhaps anti-disaster backing for the ruble, the West can provide something as important: people the republics need to learn how to live in the real world.
Auditors, bankers, business computer specialists, private farmers, money managers, business teachers are rare and exotic in the commonwealth. Setting up a "Business Peace Corps" would be useful aid from the U.S., as long as it is directly related to commonwealth private enterprise, not channeled through official bureaucracies.
Russians I met also argued for continuing American hands-on management, supervision and accountability. That's not servility to the U.S. or simply a compliment to it. It is a growing clarity of vision about the past, perhaps the greatest asset for any new nation, or a whole commonwealth of them.
