HEADLINE: Recognize the Power of the New Germany

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is executive editor of The National Interest.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With its decision to recognize Croatia and Slovenia on Jan. 15, Germany proved it is no longer an economic giant and a political dwarf. It succeeded in pressing the European Community to recognize the Yugoslav republics against the objections of the United States and the United Nations. This act symbolized the collision between the post-World War II global order and the emerging post-cold war European order. If the gap between European and world institutions is not to grow, Europe's greatest power should be made a permanent member of the directorate of the world's great powers: the U.N. Security Council.
The new Germany, like its predecessors, has proved that it is a revisionist power, intent on reshaping Europe. Germany's initiatives -- often opposed at first by France, Britain and the United States -- have helped bring about the reunification of Germany within NATO, the Soviet evacuation from Eastern Europe and the extinction of the Warsaw Pact. 
 German pressure also influenced European leaders at the summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, this month to agree to move toward the adoption of a single European currency as early as 1996 and to increase cooperation in foreign, security, immigration and crime policy. This strengthening of the community will almost certainly be followed by its enlargement in an effort to reduce the poverty and political turmoil Germany fears to its south and east.
The weight of the new Germany has also been felt in European defense. After the gulf war, when France called for a European defense entity independent of the U.S.-led NATO alliance, the U.S. sent an Under Secretary of State to Europe to chide the allies. But when Germany joined France in endorsing such a force in October, President Bush himself responded with an emotional outburst at the NATO summit meeting in Rome in November. He testily challenged the European allies to make it clear whether they wanted a continued American commitment or not.
Germany has recognized the independence of its World War II satellites, Croatia and Slovenia, knowing well that Serbians and perhaps others will claim this as proof of an emerging "fourth Reich." Although Germany was not quick to recognize former Soviet republics, it evidently has perceived that its interests in the Balkans go beyond revising European institutions, to revising European borders.
Can global revisionism be far behind? As the influence of Germany grows, its exclusion from the Security Council (along with the exclusion of Japan) appears even more anomalous. What is more, Germany should take a place, not as one of a number of European nations that would occupy the proposed rotating European Community seat, but as an equal of the U.S., Britain, France and, soon, Russia, the Soviet Union's successor.
During the gulf war, Germany claimed (on dubious grounds) that its Constitution prevented military participation in the multinational force. The Government of Helmut Kohl, with the opposition's support, promised constitutional revision to permit participation in U.N. efforts -- a pledge recently renewed by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. This promise could lead to a historic deal, since council members argue that Germany, like Japan, cannot be a member so long as it cannot send troops to enforce council decisions.
President Bush has wisely, if sometimes reluctantly, allowed Germany to take the lead in reshaping Europe. Now America should take the lead in reshaping the United Nations by proposing permanent German membership on the Security Council. Britain and France, declining powers that fear being eclipsed by the new Germany, will not be enthusiastic. Russia may prefer the status quo. Only America has the confidence to support German membership.
American interest grows out of its commitment to the U.N. When the organization was designed, the Security Council was idealism's concession to realism: it reflected the actual distribution of power in the world and did not reward vanished glory. The council is not the House of Lords.
By sponsoring Germany as the sixth permanent member, the Americans can do more than give it an enlarged role in world affairs. This move can strengthen the rationale for America's commitment to the U.N. by making the council, already enhanced by the gulf war, even more influential. And it can show that the U.S., too, is a revisionist power, seeking friends among today's victors and not merely yesterday's.

HEADLINE: Indians' New Foe: Environmentalists

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOWAOC, Colo.

 BODY:
For centuries, Indian rights have routinely been superseded by more powerful interests: ranchers, miners, Federal and state governments have all claimed to know what is best for the Indian people.
Now the tribes here face a new foe: environmentalists. 
 The Ute Indians here in southwest Colorado recently won the right to desperately needed water and $60 million in Federal development money in a long-planned water diversion project from the Animas and La Plata rivers. The water, along with hundreds of new construction jobs, would be channeled to parched ranches, towns and reservations in Colorado and New Mexico.
But environmentalists have vowed to wage a court battle to stop the project, citing a peril to the endangered Colorado squawfish, a long, slender species that began dying when dams slowed the Colorado River's flow and caused water temperatures to fluctuate.
 
Escape From Poverty
 It is a battle that underscores the growing clashes between environmentalists, seeking to protect Western wilderness, and Indians, who also say they love the land, but who are struggling to improve their impoverished life.
"Environmentalists like to wrap themselves in Indian blankets when they can," said Charles Wilkinson, a law professor at the University of Colorado, who works with both groups. "And there is some natural alliance. But that alliance comes into collision in the face of such terrible poverty in Indian country."
Two Ute tribes live in this arid mountain region: the Mountain Utes and the Southern Utes. About 35 percent of the 3,000 Utes are unemployed, according to Federal statistics. But tribal leaders say unemployment is closer to 60 percent.
The Indians, who have scant job opportunities here, believe the project would breathe economic life into the region. They say many Indians would be hired for construction jobs on the project. And the water could be used to irrigate farm fields for crops, like alfalfa, that they could then market.
On the Mountain Ute reservation here, flimsy, weather-beaten houses, rickety trailers and dirt roads attest to the searing poverty of a tribe that once used their skills as horsemen to capture livestock and slaves, whom they sold to Spanish traders. In the 1860's the Utes -- for whom Utah is named -- signed treaties with the Federal Government relegating the tribe to reservations, which in many cases were taken back or diminished by the Government.
Judy Knight Frank, the Mountain Utes' leader, gazed across the vast, barren reservation, bereft of any hint of commerce save a cattle-crossing sign, and spoke of Indians' being forced to leave home for lack of work.
 
Squawfish vs. Indians
 "The environmentalists," she said, "tell us: 'Wait, this isn't the right project. There is something better for your people.' But they have yet to tell us what that better thing is."
She shrugged and shook her head. "For 100 years, we did not have running water on this reservation," she said. "Where were the environmentalists then? They weren't hollering about the terrible conditions for our children. But now, suddenly, the squawfish is so important. More important than the Indian people, apparently."
In large part, the resentment among many Indians toward environmentalists simply mirrors a sentiment across much of rural America. Indians who log timber in Montana, drive cattle in Nevada or mine for coal in Arizona do not greet environmental constraints, which translate to fewer jobs, any more warmly than their white counterparts who work the land.
"When you stop development, a lot of real people get hurt," said Daniel Israel, a lawyer for the Mountain Utes. "In the West, a lot of those people are going to be Indians."
In the Pacific Northwest, environmentalists and Indians have divided over the building of hatcheries for salmon. The Indians who fish for salmon support the hatcheries; the environmentalists oppose them, saying that artificial breeding saps the vitality of the species. On Utah land owned by the Mountain Utes, environmentalists have gone to court to reduce the number of cattle that Indians graze. In the Navajo Nation, centered in Arizona, where coal mines are the largest employers, Indians fear that environmental restrictions could affect jobs.
"Of course, we're concerned about Mother Earth," said DeWayne Beyal, a spokesman for the Navajo Nation. "But we're also concerned about Navajo families who need a paycheck."
Seeking to resolve differences and reach common ground, representatives of Indian tribes and environmentalists recently met in Washington. John Lear, head of the Center for Resource Management, a Salt Lake City group that acted as an intermediary at the conference, said possible conflicts would probably increase as the environmental movement grew and Indian tribes asserted their rights to promote business. "It's very important that these issues be addressed," he said.
Some environmentalists acknowledge that they had sometimes, rather arrogantly, presumed that Indian interests coincided with their own. Indians often look with suspicion upon environmentalists, who tend to be white, urban and relatively affluent.
"First, they stuck us out on these remote reservations, where it's almost impossible to make a living," said Ray Yowell, chief of the Western Shoshone tribe in Nevada, where some tribal members have been ordered to reduce cattle grazing for environmental reasons. "And then they restrict the land use. These environmentalists come out here from the cities and tell us how to care for the land."
In a political sense, the shifting views about protecting the wilderness reflect the changing demographics of the nation, particularly of the West. While rural areas are struggling, growth has been centered in urban areas, where people look upon the mountains and rivers for their beauty rather than the paychecks their resources produce.
Tourism has become perhaps the most important economic force in the West. Among the leaders in the fight against the water diversion project here in southwest Colorado, in fact, have been the kayak and raft operators. They fear that water diversion will lower river levels and shorten the rafting season. Ecologists cite an array of biological and environmental problems whenever water paths are diverted, and in this case they have pointed to troubles for at least two fish species.
 
Halting of Project
 The $600 million project has been halted before. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service stopped the project a year ago, citing possible danger to the squawfish and razorback suckers, another type of fish. The project was revised to the satisfaction of the Federal Government, and ground was broken last month.
But the Sierra Club has said it will fight the project on the grounds that the environmental impact statement, made several years ago, was out of date. "The history of water in the West is a history of changing the natural landscape for human and agricultural development," said Drew Caputo, a Denver lawyer for the Sierra Club. "The consequence has been harm for the environment."
Another lawyer for the Sierra Club, Lori Potter, contended that the project would bring "no economic benefit" to the Indians. She said the tribes lacked the conveyance machines necessary to draw the water to the reservations.
"And most of the construction work would be imported," she said.
Mr. Israel, the lawyer for the Mountain Utes, said the environmental battle carried overtones of class conflict. He said many of the most vocal environmentalists were prosperous newcomers drawn to the beauty of the region, but who did not depend on local jobs.
"Don't my clients have a right to live on the Western slope?" he asked, referring to the scenic western edge of the Continental Divide. "Or is it going to be only people in $1 million houses in Telluride?"

HEADLINE: Study Finds Enrollment Is Up At Colleges Despite Recession

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
College enrollment in public and private institutions increased this fall despite the recession, a new survey shows.
The survey, which covers both four-year and two-year institutions, found that total enrollment outstripped the totals for 1990 in 12 of 15 states it monitored and that two-year colleges grew faster. 
 The survey was taken by the American Council on Education, a Washington association of 1,700 colleges and universities in most states and the District of Columbia that account for about 40 percent of the nation's college students.
The survey identifies two opposing forces a recession can exert on college enrollment: one tending to increase enrollment as students stay in school longer because jobs are scarce, and another tending to decrease it as financially strained institutions reduce aid to students.
 
Emphasis on Job Training
 Contributing to the quicker growth in enrollment for two-year community institutions was the return of people in the work force who want to bolster their job skills.
"When times are tough, and people are unemployed, they want to go back to school and change careers," said Jim Brady, chief of the New York Department of Education's Bureau of Postsecondary Statistical Service. "Two-year schools typically offer occupational education."
The survey did find that total enrollment declined in three states that were particularly hard hit by the recession: New York, which experienced a decline of less than 1 percent to 995,628 students, from 1,000,185 students; Connecticut, which saw a 2 percent decline to 160,425 students from 163,744 students, and Minnesota, where enrollment dipped nearly 1 percent to 221,480 from 223,454.
Enrollment in four-year institutions in five states also declined: New York dropped 1.77 percent to 724,418 from 737,482; Connecticut declined 1.69 percent to 119,980 from 122,045; Illinois was off 2.01 percent to 372,295 students from 379,932 students; Virginia declined 1.64 percent to 212,107 students from 215,648 students, and Minnesota declined 3.72 percent to 158,805 percent from 164,946. The enrollment in two-year colleges grew in all states but Connecticut, where it declined 3 percent to 39,965 students from 41,216.
 
Growth Expected to Continue
 The overall growth in college enrollment, which the survey said was expected to continue, came despite the recession, which some college administrators said had depressed enrollment. Demographic trends also worked against college enrollment in some places.
"For a couple of years," said Connie Zak of the Connecticut Board of Governors of Higher Education, "we filled the decreases of college-age kids with adults going into retraining programs or back to school. Now we have exhausted that pool."
Tuition, too, has increased in the past year in several places to offset the effects of the recession, and some institutions have adopted enrollment limits to accommodate faculties that have been reduced by recession-induced layoffs.
Although demographic factors and recession have hurt overall enrollment figures, they are not expected to have long-term effects on enrollment growth at least at public institutions in the forseeable future, the survey said.
The increase in the next two years is expected to come from a slight increase in the number of college age students, said other higher education officials. "All indications are that we will have a substantial growth in the school age population by 1996," said Rich Novak, director of the Center for Higher Education Policy and Finance at the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. "However, an increasing number of institutions are placing caps on enrollment, which will be tough for some of the fastest growing states, such as California, Arizona and Florida."
The survey also found that several states expected increases of high school graduates in the next few years but had made few plans to expand colleges or build new ones to accommodate the increase. Those states, the survey indicated, include Texas, Florida and California.

HEADLINE: Brown Hopes One-Note Campaign Strikes a Responsive Chord

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H.

 BODY:
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California is a man of sometimes bewildering personal and political dimensions, but his current campaign for the Presidency is as one-dimensional as a straight line.
"Money," he says, "is the root of all political evil." 
 Mr. Brown, a Democrat who in 20 years in public life has raised and spent a full measure of political money, much of it on two earlier, unsuccessful Presidential races, is running this time as an insurgent candidate who will take no campaign gift larger than $100, one tenth the legal limit for donations from individuals. He promises that if he reaches the White House he will impose sharp limits on political spending, political advertising and the number of terms officials can serve.
"The aim of my campaign," he said in an interview recently, "is to take back America from the manipulative big-money interests and the beholden, self-preservationist politicians who those interests elect and keep in office."
To hear the applause that Mr. Brown gets at rallies, his message has considerable appeal with an electorate increasingly soured on the way politics is played in the United States, particularly the way huge campaign contributions flow to candidates from political action committees. But hardly anyone thinks Mr. Brown will succeed with his crusade -- even he has his doubts -- and there is some grousing within the Democratic hierarchy that his campaign is an ego trip that may tarnish the party's image in 1992 and hurt its chances of capturing the Presidency.
"This candidacy, this cause, will only work," Mr. Brown said, "if it sparks a grass-roots revolution and the people rise up, one by one, then by the thousands, then by the millions. A revolution is not an easy thing to pull off."
 
Prickly Reputation
A 'Moonbeam' On a Mission
 Thus far, Mr. Brown's revolution is mostly a one-man uprising. Some money is coming in and some volunteers are stepping forward. But "Jerry" Brown's cause, though it receives applause, is not yet considered a consuming Presidential campaign issue and so there is not yet any great rush to be at Mr. Brown's side as he storms the ramparts.
Beyond California, there is no state at this point where Mr. Brown can realistically expect to make a significant showing. And not even California is a sure thing since the former Governor recently pulled out of the United States Senate race there rather than risk defeat.
"I admit I have some problems to overcome," he said in an interview here as he pushed through another chilly day in the pre-primary snows of New Hampshire. "But I've got to try to turn this system around. Somebody's got to try. Our democracy has been the object of a hostile takeover. Government has become a Stop & Shop for every conceivable greedy and narrow interest. There are no new ideas and no real debate. We're down to a single political party: the incumbent party."
In speaking of "problems to overcome," Mr. Brown was referring not just to the difficulty of usurping an entrenched campaign financing system but also to his reputation as a prickly, unfocused and sometimes dreamy politician who acquired the sobriquet "Governor Moonbeam" during his tenure as Governor from 1975 to 1983. If he and his insurgency are to be taken seriously in the 1992 campaign, he concedes, he must put the "Moonbeam" reputation behind him.
Can he do it?
In mid-December, Mr. Brown shook up the first televised candidate debate with his blunt, finger-pointing attack on big-money interests and political action committees, overriding protestations from several candidates that they, too, were against PAC's. He startled and annoyed the other debaters, as well as the debate moderator and many of the millions of viewers, by brashly giving his "800" number for telephone contributions -- provided none exceeded $100.
Ronald H. Brown, the usually neutral national chairman of the Democratic Party, called the outburst "inappropriate."
Still, a picture of Brown and a sign with the "800" number has become the unofficial symbol of the Brown campaign and the 53-year-old former Governor's anti-establishment determination to mobilize the grass roots to overthrow what he believes to be an entrenched elite. The incident has also added to the controversy that seems to permanently surround Mr. Brown, his causes and the hard-edged way he presses them.
At times in his career, Mr. Brown has been a classically conventional politician, raising and spending money in the usual way and pushing the usual economic and social agenda of industrial development, new highways and schools and improved health and welfare programs.
But at other points, he has broken from the pack, getting well out in front -- too far out front, his critics say -- on such issues as using wind power to cut energy consumption on "Spaceship Earth," or making California a "place of dreams" by reducing air pollution, or conserving water supplies by modifying toilets to use three and a half gallons on each flush instead of the usual seven gallons.
Above all, he has always had the knack -- some say a weakness -- for jumping from one issue to another and for the unpredictable and the unconventional move or symbolic gesture: the barefoot choir at his first inauguration as Governor, the beat-up compact car that served as his executive limousine, the sabbatical in Japan to study Zen, the sackcloth trip to India to help Mother Teresa nurse the sick.
 
Political Epiphany
From PAC Fan To PAC Foe
 Most recently, he has undergone a political epiphany when it comes to campaign finance. As he explains it, as a willing, even eager, participant in the old political financing system in races for governor in 1974 and 1978, in Presidential campaigns in 1976 and 1980 and in a United States Senate campaign in California in 1982, he knows political money's corruptive force first hand.
"Just before I got into this Presidential race," he said, "I ran the California Democratic Party and helped raise more than $30 million for our candidates, and we still got beat. I asked, 'What's wrong?' And the answer came back, 'We didn't have enough money.' That's when I knew things had to change. Money is the problem, not the answer."
As Mr. Brown sees things, the political action committees of well-heeled special interests like banks, hospitals, arms manufacturers and labor unions have taken control of politics in the United States through huge contributions to candidates, first helping them get elected, then keeping them in office through further contributions. In return, Mr. Brown says, the recipients of the money do the governmental and legislative bidding of the special interests, ignoring the needs and desires of average voters.
"The truth is, the voters don't control anything," Mr. Brown tells his audiences. "They are manipulated. Candidates get this money and they use it to poll and then they produce political ads that fool people and speeches that are designed just to make the evening news. But there isn't any substance, no reality to what counts and is really needed. Political action committees now run America."
As he speaks, he rises on the balls of his feet and leans his long frame over the lectern, pointing hither and yon into the audience as if aiming his message at specific people. Sometimes the words and ideas tumble forth in such confused profusion that the "Moonbeam" label seems fully justified, as when he spoke at a rally recently of a "self-contained, quasi-autonomous reality."
Mr. Brown promises that if elected he will not only seek tighter limits on campaign contributions but will also push for limits on the number of terms elected officials can serve as well as limits on political advertising. He offers no details -- "they're evolving," he says -- but expects no problem achieving the limits once he reaches the White House because he assumes the revolution that puts him in office will also install a compliant Congress.
As for his governing agenda otherwise, Mr. Brown says he is working out its details, too, with special emphasis on economic, health and energy plans. He contends that the "greed" of special interest groups has bankrupted the country's economy, made its health care system one of the most inefficient and expensive in the world and left the nation too dependent on foreign energy supplies.
"We spend twice as much on energy as other advanced nations because the energy interests want it that way," he says in his speeches. "If we cut that, we'd have money to rebuild the nation's infastructure and that would mean more jobs for people. We don't have an efficient, reasonably priced health system because rich doctors and others pour money into Congressional races to keep things as they are. There's the corruption in the system."
 
Presidential Strategy
Small Staff On a Shoestring
 Mr. Brown ranks near the top in most early opinion polls. But the poll-takers say most voters have not yet begun to focus intently on the campaign and they credit his high standing mainly to high name recognition.
He was among the last candidates to jump into the race and thus far has only about a dozen paid staff members, most of them casually dressed men and women in their 20's who work out of an austere campaign headquarters in an office building in a slightly seedy part of Santa Monica, Calif. He says he is signing up scores of volunteers to work in the primary here, as well as in primaries and caucuses in other states, but few are in place thus far.
The campaign manager is Jodie Evans, an aide to Mr. Brown when he was Governor. A primary campaign adviser is Patrick H. Caddell, the political strategist who helped conceive the "outsider" insurgency that Jimmy Carter used to capture the Presidency in 1976.
"Jerry Brown's campaign is about a different kind of politics, not a different political style," Mr. Caddell said in an interview. "People say he's got a great message but that he's the wrong messenger, that he's tainted because he's been a part of the system he's now trying to get rid of. Well, Jerry is a man who believes in personal growth. He's always growing."
Paradoxically, but not unexpectedly, a main hurdle for the Brown campaign is money.
Through appeals on radio talk shows and in television interviews -- the candidate often holds up his "800" number sign, describing it as "an inelegant but honest appeal" -- the Brown campaign has managed to raise about $250,000 and has qualified for Federal matching money. But Mr. Brown will need much more than $500,000 to conduct a serious campaign.
John Deutsch is one of those willing to give.
Mr. Deutsch, an opera singer from Washington, ran into Mr. Brown the other day in the airport at Boston. The night before, he had seen the former Governor on television.
Reaching into his wallet, Mr. Deutsch pulled out a $20 bill and handed it to Mr. Brown.
"You're the only candidate in the whole field who has an original idea," he said. "I'm with you."

HEADLINE: A Visionary Of Disunion

BYLINE: By John McClaughry; John McClaughry, a Vermont state senator, is co-author with Frank Bryan of "The Vermont Papers."

DATELINE: KIRBY, Vt.

 BODY:
Secession and political disintegration have redrawn the map of Europe over the last few months. The Baltic states declared independence, Croatia and Slovenia have struggled to withdraw from Yugoslavia and a loose commonwealth has replaced the Soviet Union. There have even been independence movements within independence movements in areas like Abkhazia and South Ossetia in the ex-Soviet republic of Georgia.
Unnoticed amid this turmoil was the 50th anniversary of a remarkable essay that bravely declared the world would be better off if large states splintered into small pieces. 
 Disunion was an unpopular idea among internationalist Americans in 1941. Far more appealing was "union now" on a supranational scale. The threat of Adolf Hitler called for the power of unity, not fragmentation and weakness.
In this atmosphere, Commonweal magazine of Sept. 26, 1941, published an essay titled "Disunion Now: A Plea for a Society Based Upon Small Autonomous Units," by a Hans Kohr.
Its author was actually Leopold Kohr, a 31-year-old Austrian-born economist who used a pseudonym because he hoped readers would mistake the name for that of Dr. Hans Kohn, a well-known historian at City College of New York, and be more likely to read the article.
The essay began by rebutting the idea, as summarized by Mr. Kohr, that "The evils of our globe would be eliminated by simply doing away with the varieties of states through uniting -- the democracies now, the continents later, the world in the end."
Mr. Kohr argued that Switzerland, often cited as exemplifying the merits of unification, had thrived not because of national unity, but because of the smallness of its cells. "The great number of proud, democratic and almost sovereign cantons, and the small number of cantonal populations, eliminates all possible imperialist ambitions on the part of any one canton, because it would always be outnumbered by even a very small combination of others," he wrote.
In place of France, Germany, Russia and Italy, Mr. Kohr recommended 40 or 50 Venezias, Lombardies, Burgundies, Savoys and Estonias. "Then the Great Powers, which are the womb of all modern wars, because they alone are strong enough to give war its modern frightfulness, shall have disappeared," he wrote. "Once Europe is divided into small enough parcels, we shall have the Swiss foundation of a Pan European Union, based not on the collaboration of powerful nations but on the smallness of all the states."
Mr. Kohr argued that a new spirit among people who regain national independence would lead to peace, economic revival, a flowering of the arts and true participation all citizens in democratic government.
Alas, he was ignored. But today his theory of unity and peace through division looks more attractive.
It will be fascinating to see if the European Community hears appeals for political self-determination from its subnational regions (from Scotland, for example, to Brittany, Provence, Bavaria, Sicily and the Basque homeland, Euskadi) within the framework of its new economic institutions.
Mr. Kohr's vision was not utopian, and he anticipated micro-wars like those now happening in Croatia and Georgia. But these conflicts are minor compared with the those of 1941. And despite the uncertain future of the former Soviet Union, hostility among the republics is less dangerous to the world than the threat posed by their former empire.
Leopold Kohr, now 82 years old, remains largely unknown. His message never sat well with leading statesmen, most of whom were intoxicated with the grand and mighty.
But it has been instinctively rediscovered by people who have had enough of great empires ruled by faceless forces beyond their control. Fame has eluded him, yet few people have had his good fortune: to see the world at long last begin to unfold as he had hoped.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 18.56 to End Above 3,100

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks climbed to record levels yesterday for the second consecutive day, again propelled by lower interest rates and hopes for the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average vaulted past another barrier, closing above 3,100 for the first time. It ended at 3,101.52, up 18.56 points for the day and 167.04 for the four-day week, its biggest weekly point gain ever. 
 Records were also set again for the Nasdaq composite index, up 6.41, to 565.71, and for the Standard & Poors' 500 index, up 1.62, to 406.46. The Big Board composite index rose 1.14 points, to 223.75, another record. The American Stock Exchange index went up 5.42 points, to 382.94.
 
 
The Interest-Rate Factor
 Optimism for an economic recovery may have fed the rally, but brokers and analysts put more emphasis on the way bottom-of-the-barrel interest rates are making stocks a more attractive alternative to investors both big and small.
"New accounts are coming in from sticker shock at the bank," said Thomas Johnson, a retail broker with Dean Witter who has been gathering fresh customers in Indianapolis. "With interest rates the way they are, there's simply not a better place to put your money."
As fixed-income yields continue to decline, other brokers added, investors are increasingly moving into equity mutual funds, causing fund managers to go out and buy stocks.
"This is like a fast freight train," said Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments at Marion Bass Securities in Charlotte, N.C. "You just can't get in its way."
 
 
Expecting a January Spurt
 Although institutional investors were already in the market, they put extra funds into stocks this week partly in anticipation of a January spurt, said Elaine Garzarelli, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, citing big January advances in 3 of the last 10 years.
"People can get fired for missing that rally," Ms. Garzarelli said. She added that last week's slashing of short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve had the effect of spurring investors who had hesitated.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate yesterday, at 158.3 million shares, but heavier than usual for Christmas week. Issues that rose outnumbered those that lost by 1,085 to 609.
The week's gain for the Dow Jones industrial average surpassed the previous record of 145.29 for the trading week that ended on Jan. 18, when war broke out with Iraq. But that week's advance, to 2,646.78, amounted to 5.8 percent, making it larger than the 5.7 percent for this week.
 Ms. Garzarelli's calculations, based on four ingredients -- the economy, monetary policy, market valuation and sentiment -- has led her to predict further gains for at least two months. She estimates that 70 to 80 percent of analysts have to be bullish before a market peaks; she puts the current figure at about 50 percent.
For Jon Fossel, chief executive of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation, there are still plenty of reasons to be upbeat about the market over the coming year, including a combination of low inflation and low interest rates.
"Semi-intelligent people always make the same mistake," Mr. Fossel said. "They're extremely bullish at the top of the market and extremely bearish at the bottom." He quickly added that despite record highs, he did not think the Dow had peaked, predicting that it would reach 3,600 by the end of 1992.
 
 
'Can't Argue With It'
 Mr. Harrington, in Charlotte, is not so optimistic about the long-term strength of the market's move upward.
"Buying simply because the market is going up is not a good idea," Mr. Harrington said. "But this short-term rally is extremely explosive. You can't argue with it."
Another part of the rally, in Mr. Harrington's view, is institutional end-of-the-year window dressing. "They want to show that they have the winning stocks in their portfolio," he said.
I.B.M. and Merck, both market bellwethers, were up yesterday. I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 89 3/8, while Merck climbed 1 1/4, to 165 3/8. Morgan Stanley jumped 3 3/4, to 61, reflecting growth in the investment banking sector.
 Among losers, First Financial Management dropped 4 3/8, to 39, after the information-services firm restated its earnings for the first nine months of the year, cutting earnings for that period by 19 cents a share.
Tiffany & Company fell 1 1/2, to 43. The company reported late Thursday that its United States retail sales for the period of Nov. 1 to Dec. 25 were down 3 percent from last year's.
In over-the-counter trading, Mitsui rose 9 7/8, to 117 5/8. The Xoma Corporation , the medical and biotechnology concern, rose 2 5/8, to 22 7/8.

HEADLINE: For Workers, a Winter Lull

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Everything about work the last couple of days has been all wrong. Noah Rosenblum, an engineer at J. P. Morgan & Co. on Wall Street, noticed it. The phones rang less. He found a seat during his coffee break.
His co-worker Patrick McAleer said he felt it, too. A lot of people had brought their kids to work. "The funny thing," he said, sitting with Mr. Rosenblum yesterday in the atrium of the J. P. Morgan Building, lushly decorated for the holidays, "is that they're off for a day and they bring their family into the office." 
 With Christmas and New Year's Day falling in the middle of the last two weeks of the year, offices throughout the New York metropolitan region have drifted through the last two days in a sort of a holiday Twilight Zone.
 
An Outer-Office Experience
 "After Christmas, it's an interregnum," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner in New York City for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The old king is gone and the new one has not yet come. It's close-out time. The pace of activity begins to wind down, and it stays wound down until after the New Year."
While few offices have actually closed, few have had more than skeletal staffs. All but the most essential employees sawthis week and next as the perfect opportunity to stretch the two midweek holidays into a vacation -- what Irwin Kellner, the chief economist for Manufacturers Hanover Trust, called "white-collar holidays."
And yet those who did work found the office vacuum a vacation in itself. The commute has been a breeze, the office mood casual, almost festive. And while it has been nearly impossible to get anyone on the phone, some said it was the best time of the year to actually get some work done.
"You can accomplish more now, because there's not so many people harassing you," said Mr. Rosenblum, who said his office was in a "California state of mind."
Delos R. Smith, the senior business analyst for the Conference Board, a economic research organization in Manhattan, said "very little gets done" during these half-holidays, half-workdays.
"I'm not even bothering to make phone calls," he said. "Nobody's returning them."
Making the best of it, Mr. Smith took half the day off so he could take his wife and daughter to the movies. "At 1:30, goodbye," he said.
In Somers, N.Y., at the world headquarters of Pepsico Inc., a spokesman, Gary Gedermann, said a few workers had to be on hand "just in case Coke changes their formula again or something."
Mr. Gedermann said he believed the semiholidays gain momentum in a sort of ripple effect.
"Everyone figures, 'No one else is in, so I'm not going to go in,' " he said. "The assumption cascades and becomes a reality."
Jeanette Sivak went to work yesterday at the St. Andrews Textile Company at 135 West 50th Street in Manhattan, but wearing a "Guess University" sweatshirt and towing a 6-year-old "helper," her son Matthew.
 
Not Much Work
 The import company had virtually no business, so Ms. Sivak, a computer operator, spent the day with 8 of the company's 27 employees doing such things as sorting out "the things I've thrown in the drawer for the last year."
The office's casual mood aside, she said, "Every time I wake up at 7:30, it feels like a workday."
In some cases, the boss's absence alone was enough to make the week feel like a holiday.
"Both of my bosses are out -- one officially, one sick," said Jonathan Feinberg, a computer programming analyst at Columbia House in midtown Manhattan. "This is when I get all my computer-game-playing in."
Larry Cooperman, a case administrator at the American Arbitration Association, also in midtown, found another benefit. His commute on Long Island Rail Road this week has been something it very rarely is: a pleasure. "I wish I had a camcorder," he said. "All the seats were empty."
 
Professionals' Holiday
 Many of those who took off were professionals -- lawyers, accountants and advertisers. They could stay home anticipating a year-end slowdown, but others could not. Retail stores, restaurants, hotels, theaters and other businesses that cater to those on vacation were as busy as ever.
"I'm just grateful I'm working," said Michel Silva, a lobby receptionist in the Worldwide Plaza office tower on Eighth Avenue at 49th Street.
Raju Sewani waited all day in his gift store and newsstand in the same building for a mere trickle of customers. The tower is usually bustling with workers from Microsoft, the Polygram record company, and the advertising agencies N .W. Ayer Inc. and Olgilvy & Mather.
 
'Bad for Business'
 "The building told me 75 percent of the people who work here are off," said Mr. Sewani, who opened the shop just four months ago. "This whole week it's like this. It's bad for business."
Glenn Weiner, an actor, was working, too. Painted silver and wearing only a Speedo swimsuit and Nike sneakers, he walked along 49th Street in the Theater District, filming scenes for a multimedia production called "Power of Dreams."
Mr. Weiner, who was obviously cold, disrupted traffic as he posed with a large wooden heart smudged with dirt. "It's a man carrying his heart, with crud on it," explained David Niles, the director.
With opening night planned for January, Mr. Niles said, "We're working straight through."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Stocks reached record levels for a second straight day, again propelled by lower interest rates and hopes for the economy. The Dow industrials vaulted past another barrier, closing above 3,100 for the first time. It ended at 3,101.52, up 18.56 for the day and 167.04 for the week, its biggest weekly point gain ever. [Page 33.] 
 Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in extremely slow trading. [36.]
The dollar weakened further against the yen but gained against leading European currencies, helped somewhat by political tensions in the former Soviet republics. [42.]
Oil futures prices rose in thin trading after an industry report showed an unexpected drop in U.S. crude oil stocks. [42.]
 
Companies
Crop Genetics and Du Pont formed an alliance to develop naturally occurring insect viruses into pesticides. Du Pont will provide Crop Genetics with up to $3.7 million over two years to develop virus products and mass-produce them at low cost. [33.]
Bombardier of Canada has a knack for getting innovative technology cheaply and turning it into gold. That strategy has worked particularly well in aeronautics and military products, and now it is returning to its earlier business, ground transport. [33.]
British Petroleum agreed to pay $185 million to settle a 14-year-old lawsuit accusing it of cheating Alaska out of North Slope oil royalties. [35.]
 
The Economy
To make sure some lower-priced homes seized in the S.&L. debacle are sold to low-income families, Congress has written new laws. But so far many of the properties have gone instead to buyers with higher incomes, large corporations like G.E., or rich real estate developers. But it is not at all clear that the program will work under the new laws any better than under the old. [33.]
In a fast-growing scam involving advance fees for loans from unregulated companies, hundreds of thousands of consumers and small businesses are being swindled. Senator Lieberman of Connecticut has proposed that Congress outlaw advance fees for consumer and small-business loans offered by unregulated companies. [34.]
 
International
The Bush Administration plans to impose duties on Canadian beer to retaliate against Canada's restrictions on sales of American beer, it said. And it said it would extend some restrictions on imports of tools used to make machinery, including military equipment. [33.]

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
All of New York's Tumult Jammed Into a Terminal

BYLINE: By Joseph Berger

 BODY:
PEOPLE have been born and people have died at Grand Central Terminal and about two years ago someone's remains even wound up there.
An urn of ashes was turned in to the Lost and Found/Parcel room and deposited among the umbrellas, wallets and other commodities forsaken by some of the 100,000 commuters on the 550 trains that stream daily into the 50 platforms of the nation's largest railroad terminal. 
 "To find out you're going to end up at the Lost and Found at Grand Central among the unclaimed raincoats and pocketbooks full of condoms," laments Jimmy Scullin, who seems to have seen everything life has to dish up during his 10 years staffing the room. "God is mad at that person."
Grand Central is often called a city within the city, but it is more an emblem of New York itself, of its bustle and throb, of its yearnings and sorrows. The commanding image in its cathedral-like void is the flicker of bodies rushing -- to catch trains, to get to work, to take a crosstown shortcut. Scattered among these sober intentions are people with more modest ambitions, who have wound up in Grand Central only because it is warm and dry.
Yet, both the prosperous and the hapless seem equally dwarfed by the immensity of Grand Central's dusky sheltering vault.
As in the larger city, you can buy stamps at Grand Central's post office, make a call at one of 253 pay telephones, get your shoes heeled and soled in 12 minutes at Minas Polychronakis's shop, play tennis for $75 an hour on two courts nestled above the zodiac ceiling, or eat a gourmet meal at the Oyster Bar. Grand Central, built in 1913, was perhaps the nation's first shopping mall.
"Convenience," explains Gregg Randell of Grand Central Optical. "In the suburbs, you leave for work before the stores are open and come home after they've closed."
Grand Central has its own 140-strong police force and its own jail cell, a miniature hospital staffed by a full-time doctor, a volunteer fire brigade of 37, and two social agencies that minister to the homeless.
"We get the same crimes as in the street," said Capt. Anthony Ashby, the police commander. "The difference is you don't get as many domestic disputes."
Last week, there was an art exhibit -- photos of decaying Lower East Side synagogues -- and a concert -- by the Metro-North Employee Choir. The choir's "Silent Night," resounding through a nave that can enclose Paris's Notre Dame, was evoked with such solemn tenderness that commuters actually paused in mid-canter.
Several years ago, a couple were married on a terminal balcony, right there overlooking the whirring of the arrival-and-departure board and the concourse's four-sided brass clock (one of 350 terminal timepieces).
"Maybe that's where they met," said Fred Palmer, the terminal's superintendent.
Mr. Palmer, a cheery accountant who descends from two generations of railroad men, calls Grand Central "the greatest space enclosed by the 20th century." If that sounds a bit grand, it is perfectly in keeping with a place called Grand Central. Indeed, a terminal holding up the weight of several skyscrapers inspires all sorts of cosmic conclusions.
Jim Morrisey will tell you how a thinning in the hordes passing his locksmith stand presaged the current recession. Dennis Macklin, a homeless California cartoonist who has done comparison panhandling at Grand Central and Port Authority Bus Terminal, has determined that "the East Side is more compassionate than the West Side."
But no one seems to have a better handle on the foibles of human existence than Mr. Scullin, impresario of the lost and found room. He is still astonished by the things people will leave behind.
With more than 600 items found monthly by train workers, there are separate cardboard boxes for books, keycases, cameras, scarves, pairs of gloves, single gloves, eyeglasses in a case, eyeglasses out of a case. There are shelves of attache cases, suitcases, and, during the Christmas season, shopping bags filled with gaily wrapped presents. The office has latched onto an artificial leg, a stereo amplifier and $2,500 worth of wedding pictures.
The job has taught Mr. Scullin to keep his glasses perched on his skull when he does not wear them. But the work also has its frustrations. Too many customers contemptuously bark at him to produce their Burberrys, blaming "railroad employees" for their own sometimes Freudian slips.
"Successful people can't deal with the fact they've screwed up," he says. To identify owners, Mr. Scullin must examine contents. And sifting through attache cases holding onerous mortgage payments, pictures of children and hospital bills, he glimpses the struggles and Cheeveresque desperation of many commuter lives. He understands why so many people in the terminal are always rushing.
A search of one case, belonging to what Mr. Scullin says was a "six-figure guy from Scarsdale" revealed a compartment containing the paraphernalia of a lush sexual imagination, including a whip and a garter belt. To retrieve the case, the owner sent a messenger with a letter of authorization.
"He didn't want to show his face," Mr. Scullin says.
But that would be fitting. Grand Central should be just as vigilant in safeguarding anonymity as the city it mirrors.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jimmy Scullin seems to have seen everything life has to offer during his 10 years staffing the Lost and Found room at Grand Central Terminal. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Weak Russian Economy May Use Less Oil

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Experts once feared that the Soviet Union would stop exporting oil because of declining production, but now many think that economic collapse will cut internal demand as fast or faster, leaving a margin for Russian exports, a crucial factor in the world's balance between supply and demand.
For two years experts have feared that the strife in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, would turn that country from an exporter to an importer, increasing the power of Middle East suppliers and forcing up prices around the globe. But now some experts argue that an unprecedented economic decline may push down demand in the new Commonwealth of Independent States even more than supply falls. 
 In addition, they say, the post-Communist economy, no matter what its size, seems likely to use less energy for each unit of economic output.
 
Output Going Down
 Soviet oil production slipped slightly in the last few years, and gross national product, which declined 4 percent in 1990, has fallen 12 percent or more this year, experts say. But more drastic changes are ahead, especially in the parts of the economy that use large amounts of energy.
Thane Gustafson, who is currently on leave from Georgetown University, where he is director of the Soviet studies program, says the former Soviet Union "is on a track that could see its G.N.P. fall on the order of 50 percent over the period 1989 to 1995." That would reduce energy demand about 30 percent, or 10 million barrels a day, he said, although some of the lost demand would be for natural gas and coal.
Dr. Gustafson, who returned earlier this week from visiting the oilfields of western Siberia, wrote a recent book on Soviet energy policy, and is now with Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an influential consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. He wrote in a report sent to clients this week that "the economic consequences of such a slump could be a major export onslaught of Soviet commodities, including energy."
Oil producers have a special incentive to export, he said in a telephone interview, because the internal price is only about 65 cents a ton. A ton, the traditional Soviet measure of oil, is about 7.3 barrels, so at the current world price of about $18 a barrel, one barrel exported brings as much revenue as 200 barrels sold internally.
Product exports might also increase, he said, as the internal economy declines. For example, he said, Aeroflot, the airline, "had been run as a kind of Greyhound of the people." But if it had to raise fares to market levels, he said, its flights would be cut 90 percent, and the unused jet fuel would be sold.
Over all, Dr. Gustafson predicts, exports will decline but not disappear, partly because oil is one of the few commodities that could provide the capital the country so desperately needs. Several refineries have found new markets in the West and new transportation routes for their products, he said, and have shown great creativity in arranging exports to earn hard currency.
 
No Quick Turnaround Seen
 Another consulting firm, the Petroleum Industry Research Associates, predicts the G.N.P. will decline 35 percent from 1990 to 1995, before the economy begins to grow again. Oil exports will be steady or may even increase, Gary N. Ross, president of the firm, said. His group, which is based in New York and has clients in 15 countries, predicted that oil use would fall two million barrels a day -- an amount equivalent to production from Alaska's North Slope -- before bottoming out in the middle of this decade.
Exports will be roughly flat for the next few years, "with modest growth after 1995, but with probably more upside potential than downside," his group's report said, adding that it was "a frustrating profile for OPEC after the last two years' declines."
At the United States Department of Energy, Lee Schipper, an energy analyst at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and the author of several studies on Soviet energy consumption, said, "The drop in energy use will be fast enough to allow them to maintain their exports."
"I didn't think that even six months ago," Dr. Schipper said, adding that there is risk in any prediction about the area that used to comprise the Soviet Union. But economic activity is declining sharply, he said.
And the activity that replaces the old economy will use less energy, the experts say. Dr. Gustafson pointed to estimates that the Soviet military swallowed 60 percent of the "metal bashing industries," to make tanks and other heavy equipment; much of that, he said, will disappear.
Likewise, he said, ministries built huge buildings to house bloated bureaucracies, and in an economy where raw materials, when they were available, were essentially free, the buildings "were always built heavy, never economized on the use of materials, and were built in a way that leaked energy."
New buildings, to the extent that they are built, will be more efficient, he said. Likewise, "pioneering" Soviet developments, like the Baikal-Amur Mainline railroad, vast irrigation networks and "endless Siberian projects" are probably a thing of the past, he said.
Dr. Schipper pointed to other places where consumption would decline. "They won't drive as much, which will save on gasoline," he said. "They will probably waste a lot less fuel in trucking, because there just isn't that much to send around." Still, he said, some processes will become less efficient, with consumption falling less than overall economic production, because factories will be kept open and their boilers will continue consuming fuel, even if they nearly stop producing goods.
Significantly for Western Europe, both reports predict a huge surplus of natural gas in the former Soviet Union, as the domestic demand dries up. Petroleum Industry Research Associates put the figure at seven trillion cubic feet a year, which, it noted, is four times as much as is currently exported to Western Europe.

HEADLINE: Canada Beer and Asia Tools Target of U.S. Import Curbs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it planned to impose duties on Canadian beer to retaliate for Canada's restrictions on American beer. And it said it would extend some restrictions on imports of tools from Taiwan and Japan used to make machinery, including military equipment.
The move against Canadian beer could result in a doubling of the price of imported brands like Molson, Labatt and Moosehead next April, when the duties are scheduled to go into effect, although continuing negotiations could lead to smaller duties or no duties at all. 
 The tool restrictions would retain five-year-old caps on imports from Taiwan and Japan that were initially imposed because of the Reagan Administration's reluctance to have the United States become dependent on foreign equipment for the American military buildup.
Coming three days before President Bush's trip to Asia, on which he will press Japan to pull down its trade barriers, the two announcements this afternoon appeared to represent a shift in Administration policy, trade experts said.
"Taking machine tools and Canadian beer on the same day adds up to a get-tough stand on trade policy," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The two decisions are likely to mean that the Administration will extend similar import restrictions on steel and impose permanent duties on imports of Canadian softwoods next spring, he added.
But the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, who announced the machine-tool decision today, avoided presenting that action as a move toward protectionism.
"The main responsibility for achieving international competitiveness rests with the industry itself," he said.
The announcement today to prepare sanctions on Canadian beer imports, which was made by the deputy United States trade representative, Julius L. Katz, reflected American frustration with six years of efforts to open up Canada's beer market. Quebec province, for example, has 11,000 grocery stores licensed to sell domestically brewed beer but only 300 stores are licensed to sell American beer.
The Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets rules for international trade, issued rulings disapproving of the Canadian beer restrictions in 1988 and again this year, but has not required removal of the limits, which are set and maintained by each province. The GATT ruling this year only requires Canada to file reports next March and July on any changes in its policies.
The Canadian Embassy here objected to the American announcement, adding that it planned to comply with the GATT ruling.
"Canada has told the U.S. that retaliation is premature and inappropriate," said Pam K. Chappell, an embassy official.
 
Suit by U.S. Companies
 Two American brewers, The G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company, filed a legal case against their Canadian rivals in 1990 that forced the Office of the United States Trade Representative to announce by Sunday whether it was prepared to impose duties.
The exact amount of the duties on the $150 million a year of Canadian beer imported into the United States will depend on a planned Government study to determine the value of sales now lost unfairly by American brewers.
If the Government study finds that American losses exceed $150 million, the Administration will seek to eliminate Canadian beers from the American market by charging a prohibitive tariff that could exceed 100 percent of the wholesale price, said an American trade official who insisted on anonymity. People would presumably stop buying Canadian beer if it rose to $10 or more a six-pack.
 
Partial Duty Possible
 If the study found that losses were less than $150 million, the Administration could either impose prohibitive duties for part of each year or a moderate duty all year, the trade official added. The United States currently charges a duty of 1.2 cents a liter, or about 2 1/2 cents a six-pack, for Canadian beer, and this is scheduled to fall by 25 percent next year because of the free trade agreement with Canada.
Today's decision on machine tools was particularly hard fought within the Administration because it involves both trade and national security issues at a time when American officials are groping toward new policies after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
The Office of the Trade Representative and some White House officials had argued that continued restrictions could not be justified on purely economic grounds because of the industry's success in competing against some imports. The Defense Department, however, successfully argued that national security required President Bush to extend some of the restrictions, which are actually imposed by the exporting countries under American pressure as so-called voluntary restraint agreements.
 
From Cars to Submarines
 Machine tools are used to cut and grind the metal parts for everything from cars to bombs and nuclear submarines. Some members of Congress had joined the Defense Department in warning that the United States could not afford to depend on imported tools lest the supply be cut off.
Free-traders in the White House and elsewhere in the Administration had contended that the war in the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union's collapse had made it unlikely that the United States would again fight a war long enough to require the mobilization of the American economy.
President Bush ordered today that import restrictions on machining centers and computer-controlled machines that punch, shear, round and mill metal be extended for two years, although the caps are to be gradually lifted during that time. But import restrictions on similar machines without computer controls will be allowed to expire next Tuesday.
The Coordination Council for North American Affairs, which represents Taiwan in the United States, said the American decision unfairly penalized Taiwan. The decision keeps imports at 1986 levels, when Taiwan's industry was still small.

HEADLINE: Bailout Flop: Low-Income Housing

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Congress has written new laws to insure that some of the lower-priced homes seized in the savings and loan debacle are sold to low-income families.
Calling it the silver lining of the savings and loan foreclosures, Congress set up a program to accomplish this in 1989. But so far many of the properties have gone instead to buyers with higher incomes, large corporations like the General Electric Company, or rich real estate developers. In some cases, condos in resort towns, not college towns, have gone to college students whose parents put up the money. 
 But it is not at all clear that the program will work under the new laws any better than they did under the old.
The Resolution Trust Corporationremains torn between the same conflicting desires: to help the poor but also to earn as much money as possible for the Government.
Housing advocates say the agency still has enormous discretion to act as it sees fit and that its inclination has generally been to make it much more difficult for poorer buyers than for developers or private corporations to acquire the available houses or apartment complexes.
"A lot will depend on the R.T.C.'s willingness," said Barbara Thompson, director of government affairs of the Council of State Housing Agencies. "And their track record hasn't been strong."
Last month as Congress debated the changes, the housing advocates point out, property sold at a well-publicized Resolution Trust auction in Texas went to rich developers while nonprofit housing corporations walked away empty-handed.
For its part, Resolution Trust acknowledges that problems have existed in carrying out the affordable-housing program as Congress intended but pledges to do better. Stephen S. Allen, the program's director, insists, "We have a lot of new latitude and we will be aggressive."
If Resolution Trust does not act with greater concern for low-income families, Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who pushed the new affordable-housing provisions last month, says he will ask Congress to mandate what provisions to leave to the agency's discretion.
Among other things, the new provisions permit, but do not require, the agency to negotiate directly with nonprofit buyers rather than have them bid against private developers. To help prevent real estate speculation, buyers who sell their homes within a year will have to return 75 percent of any profits to Resolution Trust.
The changes require buyers of apartment complexes to set aside more units for the poor, bring into the program thousands of additional properties seized from failed banks as well, make financing easier for buyers, empower Resolution Trust to negotiate directly with nonprofit groups and permit it to donate houses and apartment complexes directly to state housing agencies.
This year, the agency has sold 6,300 of the 21,000 homes in its inventory and more are coming in every day, but critics are still skeptical that low-income families will get many of them.
 
Housing Subsidies
For the Middle Class
 "I don't believe a substantial number of homes are going to end up being occupied by lower-income families," said John J. Henneberger, head of the Texas Low Income Housing Information Service. "The R.T.C. is basically operating a middle-income housing subsidy program here."
For instance, housing advocates point to 8,000 properties for sale in Texas, where college students have been buying condos, sometimes for as little as $12,000 in resort towns. At a recent auction of 1,000 Texas properties, nearly half were bought by one-person households. Resolution Trust is debating whether to allow this situation to continue. But, Barry Wides, the agency's financing coordinator, said in a recent interview that the regulations "never state we can exclude students; they fall within our income limits."
Houses in the program are limited to those with an appraised value below $67,500 and are reserved for buyers whose household income falls below 115 percent of the area's median income. These houses are reserved for qualified households for a 90-day period -- 180 days under the new law -- and, if not sold, are offered on the open market.
 
Well-Heeled Buyers
Qualify Easily
 But determined buyers who hardly appear poor can slip through. For instance, in Rockport, Tex., a Gulf Coast town, L. E. Casterline, a director of the First National Bank of Rockport and a partner in a real estate firm that does business with Resolution Trust, was able to qualify as a low-income buyer and submit the winning bid for a condo adjacent to the country club of which he is a founding member.
Mr. Casterline, who lives with his wife in a house they own, reports an income of only $21,000. He said Resolution Trust never looked into his assets. Besides, he said his wife and sons, who have taken over his shrimping business, had assets, but he did not. "I went in, and the R.T.C. qualified me, so I bid," Mr. Casterline said. "I hadn't made any money and my tax returns show that."
Teresa McUsick, a spokeswoman for Resolution Trust, said the agency was investigating Mr. Casterline's eligibility and added that up to 5 percent of the bids in that auction might have been ineligible. She conceded, however, that the agency did not look at a person's net worth, only income, and that it had no enforcement powers, only the ability to stop a sale.
Few who can be considered truly low income appear to be getting homes, Mr. Henneberger said. The main problem for low-income families remains, as it has from the start, the difficulty in getting mortgages from banks to buy the homes.
Resolution Trust contends that its statistics show an increasing number of sales to poorer families. But housing advocates question the data and say precise information is extremely difficult to get.
The Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency, after analyzing data last fall, found that of 232 homes the agency said it had sold to low-income buyers, there were no income data on 129 of the bidders, or 56 percent.
 
Good Information
Is Hard to Find
 In Texas, Mr. Henneberger said he had filed a Freedom of Information Act request for detailed information on buyers and had been told it would cost $14,500 in computer time, more than his agency could afford.
Conrad Egan, executive vice president at the National Housing Partnership, said: "It's like pulling teeth. If you know the exact right questions and find the right person, you may find something out. Then again, you may not."
Mr. Henneberger said his agency had received a list of available houses, found six they wanted to buy for battered women and went to Resolution Trust with earnest money. The agency said it had never owned four of them, had sold one and had a contract pending on another. He then got a list showing 29 duplexes available in the program. When he put in a bid, he was told all had been sold. When he checked further, he was told that the duplexes had never been listed with the program, even though some sold for as low as $8,000.
"This process is nuts," Mr. Henneberger said.
Housing authorities said much of the impetus for the new legislation came after The New York Times published an account in June of a plan under which G.E. was about to obtain 6,000 apartments under the program. G.E. was to buy the apartments from Resolution Trust for an estimated 50 percent discount by agreeing to set aside 35 percent of them for low-income renters. G.E. would "aggregate" -- a real estate term meaning to segregate economically -- the low-income tenants into 11 of the 26 complexes and rent the rest at market rates. All of the properties would then be resold at a profit to new buyers: the rent-controlled complexes to nonprofit groups and the market-rate ones to private developers. "We want to sell them at something above what we paid for them." said John Deterding, a senior vice president at General Electric.
In a Congressional hearing following this account, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady acknowledged that the affordable program was off to a slow start, and the Secretary for Housing and Urban Development, Jack F. Kemp, pledged to make improvements. Both are members of the policy-making Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Since then, the $75 million General Electric deal, the largest in the program, has gone through. Though it spells profits for General Electric, housing advocates say it will create the slums of the future. "It's a recipe for disaster," said John J. Ervin, a consultant to Volunteers of America.
Mr. Deterding of G.E. disagrees. "We'll round up the cream of the crop of nonprofits to buy these properties," he said. In the meantime, General Electric plans to keep them "so well maintained they will not become a slum."
 
Some Foresee
Slums of the Future
 "G.E.'s strategy is a perversion of the program," said Sara Johnson, executive director at the National Housing Trust. "From a social point of view, bunching all the poor people in one property and letting General Electric make hay out of the others is just wrong."
Earlier this month, G.E. persuaded the Government, through the Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs, to issue $15 million in tax credits on the complexes. This arrangement will enable a nonprofit organization buying the property from G.E. to sell the credits to a third party as a tax shelter and use the proceeds to pay G.E. Nonprofit groups say this arrangment helps them raise money; they also point out that tax credits are a direct loss to the Treasury -- in effect, General Electric is tapping the Treasury to generate more money for itself.
Under the new law, still to be budgeted, buyers of apartment complexes must set aside 40 percent of the units for low-income renters, instead of 35 percent, and to limit aggregation, buyers of more than one complex must reserve at least 10 percent of the units in each complex for the poor.
Still, General Electric's ability to find profits in a program for the poor is being emulated by other developers. "I dropped into a conference for real estate moguls and the view was that the G.E. strategy was the way to go," said Ms. Johnson of the National Housing Trust.
So far, of the 514 apartment complexes listed for sale under the program, only 20 have been bought by nonprofit groups or public-housing agencies. In a recent Texas auction of 62 complexes, held while Congress debated the issue, only five went to nonprofit groups. "This is a sham," said Bart Harvey, chief executive of the Enterprise Foundation, a nonprofit organization that bid on five of these properties and got none. "We were fools to ever get involved." Mr. Ervin of Volunteers added: "There is little if any concern about the living conditions of the people. There's a lot of frustration."
Nonprofit groups, which often fashion bids from grants, tax credits and borrowings, cannot put together the all-cash deals that profit-minded buyers can.
To remedy this, Resolution Trust says it is arranging special financing with the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, for nonprofit groups that should level the playing field, said Mr. Wides of Resolution Trust. And the new law allows Resolution Trust to provide credit enhancements for nonprofit groups that issue tax-exempt bonds.
The new law also requires Resolution Trust to make detailed reports on the status of the program at six-month intervals to Congress.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in extremely slow trading yesterday.
"What little activity there has been is related to year-end book balancing," one Government securities trader said. 
 But unlike the seasonal activity in previous years, the squaring of positions has not included much outright selling.
"Customers have huge pent-up profits, but we are seeing very little selling," the trader added. "For more than a decade, December has been a time to take profits. But not this year. That's a clear sign that investors think the rally is going to continue."
The continued rise in the Dow Jones industrial average, which posted a high yesterday, had little effect in the fixed-income markets even though the performance of the equity market is widely seen as a harbinger of future economic trends.
 
Effect of Stocks on Bonds
 Earlier this year, for example, a rising stock market sent shivers through the bond market because credit market participants feared that the gain in equities signaled an improving economy that could push interest rates up.
Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that researches developments in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets, said there were good reasons that credit market participants were not focusing on the rise in stock prices.
"The Federal Reserve's dramatic one percentage point cut in the discount rate last week took the market by surprise," he said, "and the fact that economic data released this month have been weak has also helped to hold the market together. So, too, has continued talk that the Treasury might reduce the size of its bond offerings."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 105 25/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 7.51 percent, compared with 7.50 percent late Thursday and 7.57 percent on Dec. 20.
 
More Gains Are Expected
 Analysts said further declines in bond yields are possible once the holiday season has passed.
"We do not look for anything in the economic data to be released in early January to get in the way of a rally," analysts at Ramirez Capital Consultants wrote in their daily market commentary.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 7/8, up 6/32 , to yield 6.81 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were unchanged at 100 10/32 , to yield 4.83 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.83 percent late yesterday, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.87 percent. One-year bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.96 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 16.
The reported increases in M-2 and M-3, the two broadest money measurements, were larger than most Wall Street economists had anticipated. However, the report had no impact on prices in the fixed-income markets.
Trading in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was slow, according to participants. They said prices of most issues were essentially unchanged.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted securities were up by about an eighth of a point in quiet trading.

HEADLINE: Auto Export Cut Weighed By Japanese

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Japan said today that it might reduce auto exports to the United States as a way to answer President Bush's demands for more trade fairness, but such a move is expected to have little effect.
Government officials disclosed the possible cutback as part of what they called their best effort to defuse rising trade tensions. 
 Confronting a recession in an election year, Mr. Bush is expected to make tough requests on his Jan. 7-10 visit for the Japanese to open their markets wider to American goods and restrain their export-driven economy.
 
Traveling With Auto Officials
 Mr. Bush will be accompanied by the heads of the Detroit auto makers, a reflection of the importance the United States Government attaches to the trade problem. The Big Three have been among the most visible American manufacturers hurt by the recession and competition from Japan.
About 75 percent of Japan's $41 billion trade surplus with the United States last year was connected with the automobile industry. The Japanese now claim about one-third of the United States car market, while only a handful of American cars are sold in Japan.
Japan's International Trade Minister, Kozo Watanabe, said at a news conference today that the export-reduction plan could be ready before Mr. Bush arrives.
Still, it is highly questionable what such a measure would accomplish. Japanese car exports to the United States have actually declined since 1987, partly because Japan's leading auto makers have established assembly plants in the United States.
 
Drop in Car Exports
 Japan already restricts annual car exports to the United States to 2.3 million. Passenger car exports to the United States in the fiscal year ending March 31 are expected to be about 1.75 million, down from about 1.85 million a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association says.
American trade officials also want to increase the United States share of the Japanese car market, now less than four-tenths of 1 percent. Japanese often complain that American auto makers are not doing enough to sell here, while United States officials say informal barriers, like stringent inspections, keep imports out.
A senior Foreign Ministry official indicated today that trade issues would not be ignored in documents to be released at the end of the meeting with President Bush.
Initially, Japan had hoped the meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa would produce a declaration focusing on global cooperation. But Japan now supports issuing documents at the end of the meeting regarding "concrete action plans" on economic and other pressing issues, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
