HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filings Up 24%

 BODY:
The number of personal bankruptcy filings have soared by 24 percent in the 12 months ended Sept. 30, increasing in every region of the country, Government figures show.
The East was hit hardest. Personal bankruptcies rose by 50 percent in a region containing Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island, and 43 percent in New York, Connecticut and Vermont. 
 Over all, the number of personal bankruptcies nationwide rose to 848,812 in the period from Oct. 1, 1990, to Sept. 30, from 685,429 the previous year, according to the Office of Administrative Courts in Washington.
"We don't really see any end in sight in terms of setting new records every quarter," Judy Kent, a spokeswoman for the American Financial Services Association, a trade group for non-banking providers of consumer credit, said yesterday.
The New England region recorded 27,138 personal bankruptcies, with 47,206 in the New York-Connecticut-Vermont region.
The number of filings rose 42 percent in Delaware, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, to 40,711, and 37 percent in Maryland, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia and West Virginia, to 60,697.
In the South, personal bankruptcy filings rose 29 percent in Alabama, Florida and Georgia, to 119,403, and 16 percent in a region containing Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, to 68,020.
The smallest increase was 11 percent in Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Utah and Wyoming, to 53,416.
In the Midwest, personal bankruptcy filings rose 19 percent, to 120,475, in Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky and Tennessee, and 17 percent in Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin, to 76,972.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Disney Doubts Trade Report

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Recession and the Persian Gulf war slowed the turnstiles at Disneyland and kept attendance flat at Southern California's four other major amusement parks, an industry publication reported.
This week's Amusement Business magazine estimated that Disneyland attendance dropped about 10 percent, to 11.6 million this year. 
 A Disneyland spokesman, Greg Albrecht, disputed the report Thursday, but said it was the park's policy not to divulge attendance figures.
"I don't know where they got those figures," Mr. Albrecht said. "Our feeling is we've had a very healthy year. We've had an excellent first quarter and one of the best Christmases ever."
Tim O'Brien, editor of the Nashville-based magazine, said the estimate had been based on industry sources, an analysis of tourist patterns and data supplied by competitors.
The magazine said business was unchanged at Universal Studios Hollywood, Knott's Berry Farm in Buena Park, Sea World of California in San Diego and Six Flags Magic Mountain in Valencia.
A Unversal Studios spokesman, Steve Lew, said new attractions and a resurgence in foreign tourism kept business from slipping at the Universal City park.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Report of Lower Oil Stocks Pushes Energy Prices Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Most energy futures prices rose in thin trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after an industry report showed an unexpected drop in United States crude oil stocks.
Crude oil for delivery in February rose 26 cents, to $18.76 a barrel; January wholesale home heating oil rose 0.06 cent, to 50.38 cents a gallon, and 
 January wholesale unleaded gasoline climbed 0.43 cent, to 53.42 cents a gallon.
Natural gas futures ended narrowly mixed. The February contract fell 0.3 cent, to $1.378 for 1,000 cubic feet.
February crude reached its intraday high of $18.79 early in the session in reaction to a weekly American Petroleum Institute report released on Thursday that showed a 4.5-million-barrel drop in domestic crude stocks.
Crude seesawed for much of the rest of the session before closing higher in a rally led by the refined products.
The price of crude has fallen from $23 a barrel over the last two months as unseasonably warm weather and the recession softened demand and supplies proved abundant.
 
Buying by Short-Sellers
 Analysts pegged yesterday's gains mainly to buying of gasoline and heating oil contracts by traders who previously sold those products at higher prices. Most of the action occurred in the January contracts, which expire Tuesday.
Analysts discounted the petroleum institute's report of lower-than-expected gasoline and heating-oil stocks.
Despite a 1.5-million-barrel decline in domestic supplies of heating oil, which is also known as No. 2 oil, stocks remain burdensome, said James Ritterbusch, vice president of trading and research at the Carson Petroleum Company, a Chicago-area oil distributor.
"The bottom line is that there are still over 140 million barrels of 2 oil, and that's plenty," he said.
He noted that unseasonably warm weather is expected to continue in the Northeast at least through the second week of January, which indicates weak heating-oil demand.
Tom Bentz, director of trading with United Energy Inc. in New York, said, "The fundamentals really have not changed, and any rally should be viewed as a selling opportunity."
Grain and soybean futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Profit taking ended a rally in the wheat market that had lifted near-term deliveries by 19 cents a bushel in the four previous sessions.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher, But It Falls Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened further against the yen yesterday but gained against leading European currencies, helped somewhat by political tensions in the former Soviet republics.
Gold prices weakened. In New York, the Republic National Bank quoted bullion at $353.75 late yesterday, down $1.20 from Thursday. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fetched $353.60, down 90 cents. 
 Foreign-exchange dealers said they did not read too much into the dollar's behavior, since trading was extremely light. European and Hong Kong markets reopened yesterday after a two-day Christmas break.
 
 
Anticipating Bush Visit
 The main action was in dollar-yen trading, which over the last few days has kept the dollar at its weakest levels since the fall of 1990.
Investors have been buying yen before President Bush visits Tokyo next month, on the assumption that the Japanese will try to bolster the value of their currency to help ease Japan's enormous trade surplus with the United States and forestall American trade sanctions.
On Thursday, Japan reported that its overall trade surplus more than tripled in November, to $7.26 billion.
"When they're faced with that kind of high trade surplus, they're willing to do something that shows they're willing to help out," said Charles Cossentino, assistant vice president at the New York branch of Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank.
 The dollar has also weakened markedly against European currencies since last week, when the Federal Reserve cut lending rates.
European traders kept selling the dollar yesterday, but the currency's slide was reversed in late dealings in the United States. Traders reasoned that the Soviet crisis could have a profound effect on Germany and other neighboring economies, so they bought dollars instead.
This gave an undertone of strength to the dollar, which is historically considered the best safe-haven currency in times of political upheaval.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.75 yen, down 0.90 yen from Thursday. In London, it was quoted at 125.80 yen. In New York, the dollar traded for 125.93 yen, compared with 126.40 on Thursday.
The British pound fetched $1.8755 in London, weaker than its $1.8760 value late Tuesday, the last trading session before the market's Christmas break. In New York, the pound fetched $1.8740, weaker than its $1.8840 value on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Making It Easier To File Returns

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Internal Revenue Service, freed for the time being from carrying out major changes in the tax law, is pressing efforts to make it easier for taxpayers to file returns -- at least simple ones. More than 110 million packages of forms are to start reaching taxpayers on Jan. 2.
In Ohio, 1.2 million taxpayers eligible to use Form 1040EZ -- single people with income under $50,000 -- will be able to file by telephone. They must fill out a five-line Form 1040-TEL, entering wages, interest and tax withheld. They then call a toll-free number and punch in the information. The I.R.S. takes over from there, figuring the tax and refund or amount due while the taxpayer remains on the phone. 
 Finally, the taxpayer signs the form and mails it in along with W-2 statements from employers. Refunds are sent in about three weeks.
In another experiment, one in which the I.R.S. does practically all the work, the 1040EZ-1 program is being expanded to 340,000 residents of Rhode Island, Texas and Washington. The taxpayer merely supplies any interest income, answers three questions, attaches W-2's and signs the form.
Meanwhile, electronic filing by computer, first tested in 1986, is to reach another milestone. This year it can be used for balance-due as well as refund returns, and I.R.S. centers in Austin, Tex., and Memphis will join those in Andover, Mass.; Ogden, Utah, and Cincinnati in accepting them.
A new form also should make filing easier for business owners -- although not for employees who do some work at home -- by allowing them to list home-based expenses in one place. Form 8829 is for data that entrepreneurs now supply on Form 1040 Schedule C or on Form 4562.
This year's packages of forms cost about $13 million to print and $19 million to mail, a total of 29 cents apiece, the agency figures.
 
Sorting Out Tax Proposals
 With passage of some sort of vote-catching tax bill considered an almost sure bet for 1992, proposals are proliferating. Among the 15 or so entries so far are the Tax Fairness and Savings Incentives Act, the Family Tax Relief Act, the Enterprise Capital Formation Act, the Tax Fairness for Families Act, the Working-Family Tax Relief Act, the Economic Growth and Family Tax Freedom Act, the Middle-Income Tax Relief and Fairness Proposal, the Economic Growth and Jobs-Creation Act and -- no doubt a long shot -- the Family and Corporate Tax-Sense Act.
Since this clearly requries a scorecard, the Tax Foundation has provided one, offering summaries of each major proposal and a calculation of how much two hypothetical families would save.
A family with two dependent children now paying $4,654 on income of $30,000 would find its total Federal tax bite -- income and Social Security taxes -- decline anywhere from $236 in the first year for Senator Bob Packwood's plan to $1,300 under the one advanced by Senator Robert Kasten and Representative Vin Weber.
Mr. Packwood, an Oregon Republican, would cut taxes on middle-income people and expand individual retirement accounts. Mr. Kasten of Wisconsin and Mr. Weber of Minnesota, also Republicans, propose a cut in capital gains taxes and credit for each child in addition to expanding I.R.A.'s.
For the same-size family but with two full-time workers earning a combined $53,265, the results change. A Democratic plan sponsored by Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk County would trim a modest $396 from a current tax bill of $10,568. The proposal offers tax credits offset by increases for high earners. The most generous plan is that of Senator William Roth, a Delaware Republican. His "Jog America" plan, according to the nonpartisan research organization, would save that family $1,672 with three-percentage-point cuts in lower-bracket rates and a major expansion of I.R.A.'s.
 
Footnote:
 * An investigation by the General Accounting Office found no conflict-of-interest violations by top I.R.S. officials, including Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr., in the agency's March 1990 decision deeming that auction rate preferred stock is equity rather than debt. It also found that there was no violation of rules requiring officials to recuse themselves from, or avoid involvement in, matters that might pose a conflict. Mr. Goldberg's former law firm represented the American Express Company, the parent of Shearson Lehman Brothers, a pioneer underwriter of such securities. Still, the G.A.O. found it "troubling" that the agency's primary consultant on the issue was Shearson.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates At 18-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The average interest charged on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped to its lowest level in more than 18 years, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.
Economists believe rates may continue falling slightly after the new year begins, but they said rates will likely start to climb again in the spring as the economy emerges from its slump. 
 "This is probably a perfect time to start looking for a home and close on a mortgage in the next few weeks," said Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
"I think we're getting near the bottom in the rate decline. But I wouldn't be surprised if rates continued to decline in the next few weeks."
Fixed rates this week fell to an average of 8.35 percent, down from 8.49 percent the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, said. It was the lowest since rates averaged 8.26 percent during the week ending Aug. 3, 1973.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, the average initial rate was 6.02 percent, down from 6.21 percent last week. It was the lowest since Freddie Mac began tracking adjustable-rate mortgages in 1984.
The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.
The drop in mortgage rates this week followed the Federal Reserve's sharp, one percentage point reduction in its discount rate, which it charges on loans to member banks. The rate is now 3 1/2 percent, the lowest in 27 years.

HEADLINE: Seeking Real Gains In an Era of 4% Yields

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
As a new year sweeps in, Americans are confronted with an unhappy choice: Whether to accept skimpy interest of 4 percent or less on their savings or, in the quest for a decent yield, to put their money into investments that entail worrisome risk.
Two years ago, certificates of deposit, money-market funds and Treasury bills offered 8 percent interest. Even after inflation and income taxes, these investments -- known as cash equivalents because they pose little or no risk to principal -- provided a positive return on money. But those days are past. 
 Many people have a marginal tax bracket around 40 percent -- a 31 percent Federal rate, plus state and local taxes. That would reduce a 4 percent yield on a money-market fund, for example, to 2.4 percent after taxes. With inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, running at an annual rate of 3.6 percent, they have a negative real return.
To get a positive return today, people must take some risk. Securities that offer a potential for price appreciation may lose value instead. In longer-term bonds or notes, the principal is safe if held to maturity and the issuer is sound, but if inflation and interest rates heat up the bondholder could be locked into an underperforming asset.
The trick is to evaluate the risk-reward tradeoff and identify which investment will most closely fill your needs. That means the already overburdened consumer has to become more educated than two years ago.
"Individuals should start with themselves and what they need and when," said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of client services at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. "It's where we start with every single client."
For example, he said, if a client needs to pay a child's college tuition several years from now, he may suggest "time-matched maturities," that is, bonds or certificates of deposit that begin maturing when the child enters college and are "laddered over the course of the education."
The interest they pay will be higher than short-term savings. And it is important to lock in the amount of money that will be needed at that particular time, not worrying about where interest rates might be then.
If the client's needs are longer term -- say, a 45-year-old wants to build a nest egg to retire in 15 or 20 years -- a good portion might go into stocks because, despite short-term volatility, over longer periods stocks generally provide a greater total return, in price appreciation plus yield, than other investments. In the last decade, the return on equities as measured by Standard & Poor's 500 stock index averaged more than 17 percent a year, 10 percentage points above Treasury bills.
To get that sort of return, Mr. Barbee cautioned, investors need to stay the course. "Plenty of people try to out-time the timers," he said, meaning they seek to buy low and sell high or panic when the market tumbles. They "get whipsawed," he added.
"Some people can't afford to play in the game at all," he went on. "If they need the money for tuition or a major expenditure six months from now," the prudent choice is a short-term cash equivalent, despite the current low yields.
Once investors have decided which types of holdings are best, it is time to choose the particular investments.
 
Likes 7-Year Treasuries
 In bonds, Martin J. Mauro, senior economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, noted that the yield curve, as the spread between short-term and long-term rates is known, is "as wide as it has been for any sustained period," with 3-month Treasury bills around 3.9 percent and 30-year Treasury bonds about 7.5 percent, for a difference of 3.6 percentage points, or 360 basis points in market jargon.
"Take advantage of the steep yield curve, but only to a point," he said at the firm's annual outlook briefing in New York last month. "In Treasuries, 70 percent of that 360 basis points is in the three-month to seven-year portion."
Therefore, he recommends seven-year Treasury securities -- either notes or bonds purchased in the secondary market -- for "the optimal risk-reward combination." In the municipal market, he would extend maturities to 15 to 20 years. He also sees opportunities in high-quality corporate issues, rated double-A or triple-A. The spread between yields on these issues and lower rated bonds is not enough to offset the risk, he said.
 
Harder Choices in Stocks
 In stocks, the choices are more difficult. Robert J. Farrell, Merrill Lynch's chief market analyst, noted that blue-chip stocks like those measured by the Dow Jones industrial average had moved within a 5 percent range in the last year, but that certain segments like medical and financial services had performed strongly. Also, bullish sentiment in 1991 has already given the market a high valuation.
"It may be a time to take some profits and reduce some risks," he said, adding that a decline of 15 percent or more may lie ahead, although January should provide a clearer indication of the market's future direction. "At present, the market has less potential than a year ago. Avoid big-ticket consumer stocks." He said he favors buying high-yield stocks in industries like producer capital goods, oil services and utilities.
"There are three themes we like in the 90's," he said. "Stocks with strong growth or earnings momentum, small and medium capitalization stocks and capital goods." He recommends buying stocks in small companies with good growth potential when prices dip or in dollar-cost averaging, investing a set amount regularly over the long term.
The difficulties of picking stocks notwithstanding, Mr. Farrell said, in general"the individual is underinvested in equities compared with other assets: 16 percent, down from a peak of 35 percent in the 60's, and the alternatives to equities are not going to work in this decade. Real estate is not going to be the great wealth provider it was in the past."
If the task of picking stocks is too daunting, mutual funds may be the way to go. Professional portfolio managers make the selections.
For example, the Kaufmann Fund, a no-load mutual fund that invests in small growth companies, had a 52 percent rise in the first three quarters of 1991 and a 121.7 percent return over the years 1988 through 1990. It is heavily weighted in medical stocks like T2 Medical and Kinetic Concepts, consumer-oriented companies like Filene's Basement and Outback Steakhouse, and certain high-technology companies.
If you want it both ways -- more current dividend income and some potential for price appreciation -- equity income funds like Oppenheimer Equity Income and MetLife-State Street Equity Income are a possibility. Their yields are more than 4 percent, and combined with price appreciation, they have outperformed both bonds and inflation over the years.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Islamic Symbols
With Christmas trees and Hanukkah menorahs everywhere in shops, banks and some post offices in the past month, an Islamic group is hoping that the crescent and the five-pointed star will get equal time in the holy season of Ramadan. 
 Dr. Mohammad T. Mehdi, secretary general of the National Council on Islamic Affairs, wrote about that in a letter to David Rockefeller, the former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and John F. Kelly, the postmaster of New York. "The banks and post offices should honor Islam as they honor Christianity and Judaism," he said.
Dr. Mehdi said that Ramadan, a month of fasting and prayers that is determined by the sighting of a new moon, is expected to begin next year on March 5. The end of the period is celebrated with a festival, Eid al-Fitr.
"Celebrating Islam and recognizing it as an integral part of the American society is a tribute to the ever-expanding America," Dr. Mehdi wrote. "I trust that banks and the post office will not wish to discriminate against Islam."
Spokesmen for the bank and the United States Postal Service said they were not aware of Dr. Mehdi's letter. Dr. Mehdi said that he had not yet received a response. "Maybe after the holidays," he said.
 
Views of New Age
 A new survey finds that half of Americans who are aware of New Age religions scoff at them and a third say they are detrimental to traditional Judeo-Christian beliefs. Yet large numbers of Americans follow many New Age practices, the survey says.
The term New Age encompasses a wide range of beliefs that stress the paranormal or the harnessing of untapped mental powers through such means as rock crystals, clairvoyance and astrology. Some beliefs run counter to traditional religion, but others, like healing through touch, have been part of it.
The survey, by the Princeton Religion Research Center, an affiliate of the Gallup Organization, found that awareness was low (only one in four Americans knew of New Age religion) and suspicion high (49 percent of those aware of it had an unfavorable opinion). Yet among all Americans, roughly half said they believed in extrasensory perception, the ability to perceive thoughts and feelings by means other than the five senses.
In general, Roman Catholics are more open to the paranormal than Protestants, the survey found. For example, among all those surveyed 30 percent of Catholics and 22 percent of Protestants said they believed in clairvoyance, the ability to see in the mind or through some medium like a crystal ball events in the future or in another place. Forty-eight percent of Catholics and 44 percent of Protestants said they believed in psychic healing. And 25 percent of both groups said they believed that the affairs of their lives may be governed by the movement of the stars.
The New Age experience that scored lowest in the poll concerned rocks. Only 5 percent of Catholics and 3 percent of Protestants said they believed that healing could be obtained thorugh crystals.
The poll takers wrote: "The line separating established religious belief and practice from superstitions and cult practices can often be thin and indistinct. Many who consider themselves good Christians nonetheless have engaged in practices that seemingly are counter to the teachings of their church."
The findings were based on a nationwide sample of 2,045 adults reached by telephone from July to September 1990. The results have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Limits on Holy Days
 Are Roman Catholic Holy Days of Obligation "spiritual alarm clocks" or "hardships for priests and the faithful"?
Those were the two sides in the debate among Catholic bishops on the question of whether to reduce the six days aside from Sundays when Catholics are required to attend Mass. A proposal to do away with some holy days did not receive the required two-thirds majority at the November meeting of all bishops in Washington.
But in a recent mail ballot, the bishops voted to do away with the obligation when some of the days fall on Saturdays or Mondays, which leads to requiring attendance at Mass two days in a row. The three days affected are the Solemnity of Mary, the Mother of God, which is observed on Jan. 1; the Feast of the Assumption on Aug. 15, and the Feast of All Saints on Nov. 1.
The days not affected are Christmas; the Feast of the Assumption on Dec. 8, and Ascension Thursday, which comes 40 days after Easter.
The vote, which still requires confirmation by the Vatican, would be the first change in a century in the observance of Holy Days of Obligation in the United States.
 
High School Plan
 The Jewish Theological Seminary, which ordains rabbis for the Conservative movement, will open a coeducational high school on its main campus in Manhattan next fall. The high school, where both general and religious studies will be taught, will be part of the nationwide system of Solomon Schecter Day Schools. It will begin with a ninth grade in the fall and add a grade each year.
The high school will not be the first established by a Jewish seminary. In 1915, the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, an Orthodox seminary that later gave rise to Yeshiva University, opened a yeshiva high school for boys on its Manhattan campus. In 1948 it opened a separate high school for girls. The two continue as separate schools of Yeshiva University.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 4, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Religion Notes column last Saturday about Roman Catholic Holy Days of Obligation referred incorrectly to the observance on Dec. 8 for which attendance at Mass will remain obligatory, regardless of the day of the week on which it falls. It is the Feast of the Immaculate Conception. (As noted elsewhere in the report, the Feast of the Assumption is observed on Aug. 15; for that day, if it falls on a Saturday or a Monday, the nation's bishops are proposing that the obligation to attend Mass be lifted.)

HEADLINE: Philippines Orders U.S. to Leave Strategic Navy Base at Subic Bay

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The Philippines told the United States today that it must withdraw from the Subic Bay naval base by the end of 1992, ending a vast American military presence that began with the capture of the islands from Spain in 1898.
The decision, which resulted from an impasse in negotiations, follows a year of intense talks between the countries on the fate of American bases in the Philippines. The announcement also comes just three days before President Bush begins a 12-day Asian tour. 
 The shutdown of the sprawling Subic Bay base, together with the closing of Clark Air Base after a volcanic eruption this year, amounts to the biggest reduction to date in the United States military presence in the western Pacific. The 60,000-acre Subic base is the Navy's principal supply and ship-repair installation in the region.
 
U.S. to Look for New Sites
 Although it is theoretically possible that a new agreement could be hammered out, Administration officials in Washington said that they considered this unlikely, and that they would accelerate the pullout and the search for alternative sites in the Pacific.
American and Philippine officials reached tentative agreement last summer on a treaty that would have extended the lease on the naval base for at least another decade in exchange for $203 million in annual aid. But the Philippine Senate rejected the treaty in September after an impassioned debate in which the American military presence was assailed as a vestige of colonialism and an affront to Philippine sovereignty.
The United States never increased its offer, but opened negotiations on a three-year phased withdrawal in the hope that the lease could be extended after a new government is elected in the Philippines in May.
The negotiations stumbled, officials said, over the United States' reluctance to commit itself to a firm schedule for removing troops and equipment and to guarantee that no nuclear weapons would pass through the base. Though President Bush has said that tactical nuclear weapons will be removed from surface warships, it is assumed that many of the ships that pass through the port are armed with them now.
But over the past month it has become clear in any case that the American military was reconciled to losing the base, and saw little use in dragging out the process. By the middle of 1993, most of the American personnel and much of the movable equipment would have been moved elsewhere, at a cost of billions of dollars, and sending them back would have probably proved prohibitively expensive.
"Once it begins, it is an irreversible process," a senior American official said today. "The bottom line is that we are gone."
President Corazon C. Aquino had vowed to find a way to keep the United States in place, even proposing a referendum on the issue after the Senate rejected the bases treaty. But Mrs. Aquino, who has indicated that she does not plan to seek re-election next year, eventually backed down in the face of adamant political opposition.
Money was not an issue in the impasse. In recent years, Washington has pledged a certain amount in economic, military and housing assistance instead of paying yearly rent for American bases. In the fiscal year that ended in September, the Philippines received $408 million in connection with the bases, and the Subic Bay base has pumped more than $344 million a year into the country's economy.
As the prospects of remaining in the Philippines have faded in recent months, Defense Department officials have scrambled to find alternatives. None of the proposed sites, including Singapore and Japan, two scheduled stops on the President's trip, seem to match Subic's advantages, which include huge deep-water facilities and access to the strategic waters of the South China Sea.
Subic, 50 miles west of Manila, is the last of six American bases that until recently housed 40,000 troops, dependents and civilian employees. Four others were returned to the Philippine Government this year. Clark Air Base, the other major American installation in the Philippines, was abandoned in June and eventually closed after it was buried in volcanic ash from the eruption of nearby Mount Pinatubo.
 
Threat and Interest Wane
 Both American and Philippine officials said today that the United States' willingness to retain the Subic base had waned in recent months, especially after the disintegration of the Soviet Union. "Global events overtook Subic and undermined its value," said Alan Ortiz, assistant director of the Philippine Government's National Security Council.
Franklin Drilon, one of Mrs. Aquino's top aides, said at a news conference in Manila that "the friendly and cordial relations between the United States and the Philippines will continue."
The closing of the base will mean relocating 5,800 officers and enlisted men and women, 600 civilians working for the Department of Defense and 5,000 to 6,000 military dependents. It will also be a major economic loss for the impoverished Philippines, which will lose the aid it receives annually for use of the base and the hundreds of millions of dollars in business generated by its presence.
About 20,000 Filipino workers are employed there, and the honky-tonk bars of Olongapo and Subic, the two cities that border the installation, are legendary among generations of sailors whose ships have pulled in to Subic's docks. Many predict that the cities will become neon ghost towns.
 
Commitment to Asia Questioned
 The withdrawal may also raise questions about the Bush Administration's assertion that the United States remains fully committed to Asia, a theme the President is expected to voice throughout his trip.
"Without the bases in the Philippines, I don't think there is any question that U.S. influence in Asia will decline," Masashi Nishihara, a professor at Japan's top military institute and an analyst of security policy in the Pacific, said today in a telephone interview from Tokyo.
"If events occur in the South China Sea -- a conflict between China and Taiwan, for example, or Hong Kong -- the United States may have very little ability to change events," he said. "As we learned in the Persian Gulf war, effective diplomacy has the backup of an effective military."
Singapore has already offered the United States access to ship-repair sites and says the United States can base some forces there. But the tiny island nation is too small to be of more than token use. The commander of the Pacific fleet, Adm. Charles R. Larson, said recently that he was talking with Malaysia and other nations, but that no site could match the advantages of Subic Bay, which included a plentiful and inexpensive work force.
"A lot of functions will be dispersed, and a lot will be returned to the United States," a senior American official in the Philippines said today. "And some will just disappear."
 
Negotiators Exasperated
 American officials seemed somewhat relieved that the long and often angry negotiations with the Philippines were over, and that the United States could quickly withdraw from its former military empire there. Negotiators have expressed exasperation with what they view as Mrs. Aquino's confused signals and ultimately ineffective leadership on the issue.
In the Philippine Senate, the move to eject United States forces seemed less a debate over the bases' value than a demonstration of sovereignty and national pride. The Philippines was essentially an American colony from 1898, when George Dewey sailed into Manila Bay to defeat the Spanish fleet, until 1946, when it became an independent republic.
Subic Bay, which began as a Spanish military garrison in the late 1860's, has always been a critical part of America's military operations in the Pacific. It is the main repair site for ships operating everywhere from Japan to the Indian Ocean, and marines have long been trained in jungle warfare in the wooded mountains near the base. It was the site of fierce battles with the Japanese during World War II, a staging area for naval operations during the Korean and Vietnam wars and a strategic counterpoint to Soviet forces in Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam.
But the vast American military presence has long been an irritant in the Philippines' uneasy relations with the United States. Resentment flared this year when Mrs. Aquino's Government finally negotiated the 10-year extension of the Subic Bay lease. Opposition was fierce in the Senate, where lawmakers asserted that the deal would perpetuate the country's image as an American lackey, though polls suggested that the Philippine people largely supported the treaty.
It is unclear whether nuclear weapons are stored at Subic. The United States, following its usual policy, will not say.

HEADLINE: Taming Japan's Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By C. Fred Bergsten; C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, is a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Japanese trade surplus is soaring again. It will probably hit a record $100 billion for 1991 and rise even higher in 1992. Japan now has the only sizable surplus, with Europe as well as the United States running large deficits.
Two steps are urgently required. First, the value of the yen should be raised substantially. In addition, the Japanese must be encouraged to end the recent stagnation in their domestic spending, which has led to renewed reliance on exports. 
 The grossly undervalued yen is now weaker than at the end of 1987. But a lot has happened to improve Japan's competitive position. Its inflation has run 8 to 10 percentage points less than American inflation in this four-year period (about 2 percent a year versus America's 4.5 percent). At the same time, Japanese productivity has grown by 8 to 10 percentage points more -- about 5 percent annually from 1987 to 1991 compared with 3 percent for the U.S. This means the yen is now undervalued in trade terms by 15 to 20 percent. Correcting this should cut the Japanese surplus by $30 billion to $50 billion.
President Bush should therefore work out an agreement with Japan to strengthen the yen to about 100 to 1 against the dollar from its current level of about 125 to 1. Clear statements and joint intervention in currency markets by the Group of Seven industrial nations should be enough to start the bandwagon rolling. A similar strategy in 1985-87 succeeded, so we know that currency changes will promote a turnaround.
The second immediate cause of Japan's trade surge is an abrupt slowdown in domestic spending as an engine for expansion. After five years of rising domestic demand for imports -- a period in which its surplus declined by more than 5 percent of its real gross national product -- Japan's internal spending has stagnated for the past six months. As a result, import growth is flat and Japan is once again relying on exports.
President Bush must therefore seek a Japanese commitment to restore domestic expansion, each percentage point of which would cut Japan's surplus by about $3 billion. Japanese national and local government combined is running a sizable surplus. Hence it can stimulate the economy through new tax cuts and spending that will improve living standards. It is incomprehensible that the Japanese bureaucracy is now contemplating new tax increases instead, which must be firmly rejected.
America cannot blame Japan for its present recession or more fundamental economic woes. The U.S. will restore solid and sustained growth only when it deals decisively with its own basic internal problems.
But Japan's soaring trade surplus indicates that production and jobs are being created there at the expense of growth in the rest of the world, much of which is stagnating, rather than through domestic spending on better housing and other amenities desperately needed by the Japanese people.
These trade patterns are particularly critical for the U.S because its recovery depends heavily on trade gains: our huge deficit precludes higher Government spending to expand the economy and the financial system's fragility is stifling any stimulating impact of low interest rates. If the Japanese trade excess continues, new protectionist actions are likely.
Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa carried out a plan in 1986-87 like the one proposed here when he was Finance Minister working with then Treasury Secretary James Baker. Mr. Miyazawa could make a dramatic contribution to the world economy and U.S.-Japan relations by initiating such steps with President Bush. His doing so would show that Japan was finally ready to accept the global responsibilities that must accompany its economic success.

HEADLINE: Letter: On Poverty;
Growth of Mother-Centered Families

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New Census Bureau findings on the leap in percentages of single mothers among American teen-agers ("Larger Number of New Mothers Are Unmarried," news article, Dec. 4) brought to mind the Economist article (April 27) identifying as the least solvable of all family poverty problems "the increasing proportion of children born out of wedlock." 
 We can take this further. The traditional family is nearly nonexistent. There is a fast-moving global trend that shifts the economic responsibility for families from men to women. The result is variously called the mother-centered family and the matri-weighted household. By whatever name, one of every three households in the world has a woman as its sole breadwinner. In another third or more families women are co-breadwinners with a working husband. In rural-based economies, women often grow the food for the family (in Africa, 80 percent; Asia, 60 percent) and market the surplus to get needed cash. They are some 70 percent of the world's micro-entrepreneurs. And the evidence is overwhelming that the bulk of women's earnings is spent on the children.
The myth of the male breadwinner persists in societies despite such facts. The myth dictates that a man must have higher wages than a woman because he (supposedly) is the sole or major support of a family. The prevalence of this myth permits employers to pay women only 50 to 70 percent of men's earnings.
Women heading families are lucky to get above the poverty line. Their earnings are too low and their dependency ratio is too high. Worst of all, as noted in your editorial of March 4 last ("Schools Are Not Families"), a high-school dropout with one or two children who is a female household head has a cruel 89 percent chance of falling into poverty in the United States today.
How then do we stave off family poverty? We can lament the demise of the traditional family, but sentiment never fed a hungry child. More realistically, for a start we can: (1) banish the myth that the family breadwinner is always male, and pay women a family wage; (2) get "Iron Johns" to talk tough about supporting the children they co-create, and (3) get girls worldwide to finish secondary school.
 
MARGARET C. SNYDER
New York, Dec. 10, 1991
 
The writer is founding director of the United Nations Development Fund for Women.

HEADLINE: No Free Ride for Credit Services

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I disagree with the view that free credit reports will cost credit bureaus and creditors too much ("In Credit Reports, 'Free' Isn't The Issue," Forum, Dec. 8). Free credit reports are the touchstone of a credit reporting system that is fair to the three parties in the system's three-way transaction -- creditors, the bureaus and consumers. Free reports offer a shortcut -- what economists call a "second-best solution" -- to a clearly impossible task: building an error-free, but reasonably priced credit bureau computer. 
 That's why every major consumer and privacy group in the country supports free credit reports as a major part of a comprehensive credit bureau reform package offered by Representative Esteban Torres, Democrat of California, and to be considered by Congress in 1992.
 
EDMUND MIERZWINSKI
Washington, Dec. 11
 
The author is with the United States Public Interest Research Group.

HEADLINE: Wrong Way to Fight a Recession

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's first step toward an anti-recession policy is a serious misstep. Federal regulators, at the behest of the Treasury Department, are telling bank examiners to ease up on loan officers. The idea is to entice banks into extending more loans -- even ones hitherto deemed a shade too risky -- to pump life into a stagnant economy.
But manipulating loan decisions to fight recession is dangerously wrong. It invites loan officers to make the same mistakes that buried the economy in wasteful real estate boondoggles during the 1970's and 1980's, and buried taxpayers under a $500 billion bailout. 
 Indeed, Federal officials have yet to produce evidence that loan decisions are the least bit responsible for the recession. Sure, bank loans are off. But that's primarily because loan applications decline during recession; relatively few businesses want to expand when sales are plummeting. Banks are also turning down familiar corporate customers because in a poor business climate even trusted borrowers can become risky.
Federal officials can perform a useful role in fighting recession, but not by arm-twisting bank examiners. During the last few months the Federal Reserve Board has rightly put its foot firmly on the monetary pedal, driving up the money supply at double-digit rates. Unfortunately, the intended consequences of accelerated money growth -- lower long-term interest rates, higher investment and consumer spending -- won't be felt for several more months. That's agonizingly slow, but to try to hasten matters by interfering with bank lending procedures invites peril.
In recent testimony before Congress, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged examiners to substitute their own, presumably more favorable, appraisals of real estate for appraisals based on current market prices. He called for appraisals that reflect the long-term value of properties, not their "liquidation" values because, he argued, banks aren't forced to unload properties at a fire sale.
That's a bizarre analysis, coming as it does from a devotee of market efficiencies. To appreciate why, just ask yourself a simple question. Who would you trust to take a safe long-term view of property values? Investors betting their own money? Or Federal officials responding to White House pressure to play loose with other people's money?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
A More Desperate Struggle

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
The end of the Soviet Union and the resignation of Mikhail Gorbachev, though at least a momentary gain for freedom and democracy, are sad events. The fall of a giant state, owing largely to its own human flaws, has the quality of tragedy; and a great leader's peaceful surrender of power again demonstrated the vision that distinguished him, as few others of his time.
President Bush paid the proper tribute when he said that Mr. Gorbachev had been "responsible for one of the most important developments of this century -- the revolutionary transformation of a totalitarian dictatorship and the liberation of his people from its smothering embrace." 
 Boris Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev's other successors have yet to show themselves capable of achievement on such a scale. They, and we, might well keep in mind Benjamin Franklin's reply to a woman who asked what the Founding Fathers of the United States had created at Philadelphia in 1787:
"A republic, if you can keep it."
More immediately, the transformation of the Soviet Union into the Commonwealth of Independent States leaves Washington the necessity to exercise in a new world a more visionary leadership than it provided the West during the cold war. Military and political confrontation needs to be replaced by a more demanding diplomacy on numerous economic and environmental complexities. These may be less apocalyptic than a nuclear exchange, but are more threatening to peace and stability.
Even the survival of some or all peoples is at risk in the great environmental issues the world has only begun to face -- like global warming or deforestation -- and on which the U.S. has failed, so far, to display the kind of foresight and courage for which Mr. Bush rightly praised Mr. Gorbachev.
For the Soviet Union's political and economic systems, Mr. Gorbachev recognized the inevitable, and acted on it, not always wisely but with great goals constantly in mind. For the equally difficult problems of the world's debased and deteriorating environment, Mr. Bush disputes the predictable and acts as if he and his country need take no responsibility for the future:
* Though the world needs to restrain its use of fossil fuels and emission of carbon dioxide, Mr. Bush proposes oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, holds back from higher auto mileage requirements and shrinks from a petroleum tax that would reduce auto usage and greenhouse gases, and raise needed revenues.
* Though global population growth still strains natural resources and exceeds the world's ability to provide jobs and decent living standards -- in Latin America and the Caribbean, 44 percent of the labor force is unemployed or underemployed -- the Bush Administration, owing to its fear of anti-abortion forces, refuses to contribute to the U.N. Population Fund, or to support domestic or foreign family-planning programs.
* Many nations are substituting military expenditures for sustainable development; the U.S. gives high priority to anti-missile defenses against ill-defined future threats.
In these areas as vital to the global future as a strategic arms treaty, the Administration not only abdicates leadership; by its own policies or lack of them, it provides instead a bad example to a world that now must look first to Washington for vision, encouragement and help.
Mr. Bush has not even agreed to attend the so-called "Earth Summit" in Rio de Janeiro, a U.N. Conference on Environment and Development, to be held in June. In sharp contrast, both Japan and Europe are pushing to use the "Earth Summit" to set global targets -- to limit, for instance, emissions of warming gases like carbon dioxide, in which the U.S. leads the world.
Even with a 30 percent cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 2005, the U.S. still would exceed the average of most European nations. But at least until the departure of John Sununu as White House chief of staff, the Administration did not even approve the concept of global warming -- while many authorities fear the world already may be too late in trying to reverse it.
Such quiescence is unworthy of a great nation, the last superpower, the leader of the free world in its "long, twilight struggle" against despotism. As the U.S. did not hesitate to spend its resources to prevail in the cold war, it needs now to go forward as boldly to lead a longer, more desperate struggle to save the planet, and rescue the human race from itself.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Who Can Stop Civil Wars?

BYLINE: By Brian Urquhart; Brian Urquhart, scholar in residence at the Ford Foundation, was U.N. Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs.

 BODY:
Civil war with modern weapons is a brutal and destructive business that is often extraordinarily hard to stop. Until now such situations have generally been considered as beyond the jurisdiction of international or regional organizations. Even the provision of international emergency humanitarian assistance has often proved difficult and controversial.
In Yugoslavia the pattern of non-intervention has been cautiously put aside. Both the European Community and United Nations are involved in efforts to halt the fighting and foster the process of peaceful settlement. In Somalia, in a far less publicized but even more lethal civil war, there has been virtually no regional or international effort to stop the fighting, and it has become increasingly difficult to provide even minimum humanitarian relief. In other formerly proud states, sovereignty is also dissolving into anarchy, fueled by old feuds and grudges and an abundant supply of arms. 
 In Yugoslavia, part of the problem is that without a cease-fire there can be no peacekeeping force, but without a peacekeeping force a cease-fire is unlikely. A similar impasse is likely in other places where there are international efforts to end civil wars.
In this time of extraordinary change, would a new approach be justified, and could it be agreed on?
At the moment, the U.N. has basically two military options. The first is traditional peacekeeping -- that is, forces that can only be deployed after a cease-fire is in place, that are accepted by the parties to the conflict and that may only use force in self-defense. The second option is a large-scale collective enforcement action like that in Korea in 1950 or, under Chapter VII of the Charter, in Kuwait in 1991 -- both under the leadership of the United States.
A third category of international military operation is needed, somewhere between peacekeeping and large-scale enforcement. It would be intended to put an end to random violence and to provide a reasonable degree of peace and order so that humanitarian relief work could go forward and a conciliation process could commence. The forces involved would be relatively small, representatively international and would not have military objectives as such. But, unlike peacekeeping forces, such troops would be required to take, initially at least, certain combat risks in bringing the violence under control. They would essentially be armed police actions.
This idea raises both political and practical questions. International intervention in most forms is now extremely suspect in many parts of the world. New rules of engagement would have to be devised. Staff, training, planning and command structures would have to be developed. A wide range of governments would have to be willing to provide highly trained and well-led military contingents under U.N. command.
In 1945, after six years of war, Article 43 of the Charter was considered to be an important practical innovation. It provided that U.N. members would "make available to the Security Council . . . armed forces, assistance and facilities . . . necessary for the purpose of maintaining international peace and security." Thus the Council would have the means to enforce its decisions, and the U.N. members would participate in this process according to their capacity. Paralyzed by the cold war, the Council never activated Article 43.
Perhaps, Article 43's time has now come, although in a broader context than originally intended by the words "international peace and security." The aim would be to enable the Security Council to deploy an international force quickly in a situation where the cycle of violence could not be broken except by firm intervention. Such a situation now exists in Somalia and perhaps in Yugoslavia. It existed in Liberia until the military intervention earlier this year by the Economic Commission of West African States. Such situations exist or can be expected in a number of other places.
As with all innovations, there will be plenty of arguments against intervention by a new type of international force. There is one large argument in favor of it. The unraveling of national sovereignty seems to be a feature of the post-cold war period. In more and more situations, only firm and evenhanded intervention from the outside is likely to put an end to self-perpetuating bloodshed and the progressive ruin of once peaceful human societies.
Can the United Nations do something to meet this challenge? Or must the world continue to stand by and watch the carnage on television?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Cut Social Security Tax to Boost Spending

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recent economic columns disdain tax cutting as a counter to the recession. The Federal Government, according to this view, would poorly select and tardily deploy the tax-cut weapon. While the blundering of politicians during a Presidential election year is surely to be feared, one must nevertheless respect the ability of Congress to implement certain economic policy options. 
 One such option combines near-term economic stimulation with political sex appeal: A temporary 50 percent cut in the Federal Insurance Contribution Act withholding tax -- the Social Security tax -- could take effect immediately, providing a nearly universal 3.1 percent increase in take-home pay and a 3.1 decrease in employer payroll costs.
Virtually all of this money would flow into pocketbooks for spending on domestic goods and services. Employers might be tempted to reconsider plans for layoffs in light of improved business prospects and reduced labor costs.
In contrast, the benefits of income tax reductions would flow late and disproportionately to consumers of imported goods; and capital gains tax reductions, to the extent that they fostered savings and investment, could be self-defeating.
Some may decry this proposal's impact on the Federal deficit (though withheld tax revenues are only lent, not donated, to the Federal Government). I suggest Congress extend the Social Security tax to amounts over $53,400. Incomes up to $106,800 would still be less burdened than at present. For those with even higher incomes to complain about reduced means would be unbecoming.
A lower Social Security tax spread over a larger tax base might even work well enough to deserve permanence.
 
RON GREENBERG
Glen Rock, N.J., Dec. 12, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Given New York Today, Could Anyone Lead It?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IN 1989, when New Yorkers had grown tired of Edward I. Koch and were yearning for a new beginning -- or, at least, some peace and quiet -- David N. Dinkins was asked whether the city had gotten so out of control that not even a mayor could make a difference.
"If nothing else," Mr. Dinkins replied, "I can change the climate, the atmosphere. I can provide leadership.
"If a mayor can't make a difference," he said, "who can?" 
 To Mr. Dinkins, it was a characteristically rhetorical question. To many New Yorkers, that question has assumed a concrete dimension two years into his mayoralty: Is this Mayor making a difference? If he is doing the best he can, has it been good enough? Could anybody -- anybody endowed with the ambition or illusions to want the job, that is -- do any better?
If visitors from outer space landed today and demanded, "Take me to your leader," to whom would New Yorkers lead them? To Lowell Weicker? To Boris Yeltsin? To Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who abdicated an opportunity for national leadership ostensibly to fulfill his obligations at home? To anyone in New York City, unless all that was wanted was a ceremonial welcome?
To Mr. Cuomo, the void in political leadership is an enduring national phenomenon, one dramatized most recently by the intense speculation about his candidacy for the Presidency and one that he says was immortalized two decades ago by Simon and Garfunkel: "Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you."
It's not just Joe, though. Where have the likes of Franklin D. Roosevelt gone? Or of Fiorello LaGuardia? Or of any of the other legendary public figures who embodied leadership qualities without crossing the line between bold populism and ugly demagoguery?
In 1991, David Dinkins seemed to his critics to be a paradigm of unfulfilled wishful thinking. Entering office with only modest performance expectations in the opinion polls, he seemed even to some supporters to frequently perform below them and, at the same time, to sell himself short.
New Yorkers have an uncanny knack of choosing the right candidate for the right time. In 1989, Mr. Dinkins was elected Mayor as much to heal as to lead. If, as some supporters maintained, his greatest asset was that he had always been underestimated, his greatest mistake was to get elected during a recession. By midterm, even among those people who expressed their approval of Mr. Dinkins in a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll, more than twice as many predicted that the city would get worse over the long term than said it would get better.
The Mayor is hardly devoid of accomplishments -- from luring the 1992 Democratic national convention to New York, to redeeming his pledge to be the toughest Mayor on crime by expanding the police force, to personally intervening to quell racial disturbances in Brooklyn's Crown Heights last summer. Moreover, perhaps the Mayor was heeding Jefferson's dictum that "great innovations should not be forced on slender majorities."
 
Mixed Messages
 But Mr. Dinkins's two-year tenure has been hobbled by mixed messages: two days after repeating his toughness pledge, he delayed police hiring; his police hiring plan was immediately followed by the threat of thousands of layoffs, many of which never took place.
"While the Presidency can elevate even average people," Wallace S. Sayre and Herbert Kaufman wrote presciently decades ago, "the mayoralty is the highly vulnerable symbol of all defects in the city and its government."
A portion of today's power shortage is institutional. LaGuardia presided over New York City during the Depression, but was bolstered by a sympathetic President and a powerful Democratic machine and less hampered by the diffusion of government power. Mr. Dinkins, in contrast, is so confined by Federal, state and court mandates and by declining resources that his discretionary power over spending is limited to about one-half of one percent of the city's budget.
The context in which Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City proclaimed, "I am the law," has been debated for decades, although historians have largely concluded that his despotism surpassed his benevolence. LaGuardia generally left a better impression, even if his perception of power -- "In this administration," he informed one balky alderman, "I'm the majority" -- was often no less absolute. In "Fiorello H. LaGuardia and the Making of Modern New York" (Penguin), Thomas Kessner wrote that his "government represented a dangerous style of personal rule hitched to a transcendent purpose," adding, "Perhaps even in a democracy that sort of leadership is necessary to create the sweeping changes that LaGuardia fashioned." Professor Kessner said though, "People would be afraid of allowing anybody to take that kind of power today."
Even LaGuardia "used to say one person cannot make a difference," said Charles V. Hamilton, author of "Adam Clayton Powell Jr.: The Political Biography of an American Dilemma" (Atheneum). "When he was responding to the Harlem audiences in the 1930's riot and again in 1943, he said our problems are economic, and that means Washington." Leadership, Professor Hamilton said, "can establish to a certain extent a mood of either confidence or of pessimism."
Mr. Dinkins has often been accused of failing to meet that definition of leadership, too -- of lacking a vision or, at the very least, the skill to convey one on television. He may believe that he is handicapped, in part, because he is the city's first black mayor, but that defense cannot fully explain his unpopularity. Among blacks in the Times/ WCBS poll, fully a third said it was time to give someone else a chance to manage the city.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, who nearly defeated Mr. Dinkins two years ago and is preparing another challenge in 1993, once compared this Mayor with Winston Churchill during the Battle of Britain: "There was not much Churchill could do to stop the bombs from falling, but he talked about making sacrifices for the future. He didn't just say that things were worse in Czechoslovakia."
But Edward N. Costikyan, a lawyer and former Democratic leader in Manhattan, complained that the phenomenon is not unique to Mr. Dinkins. "A whole generation has been brought up believing that leadership is out of place and in bad taste, that you have to find out what your people think first and that you can't take a chance," Mr. Costikyan said. He recalled the persistence of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, hardly a charismatic figure either, in winning approval to fluoridate the city's water supply nearly four decades ago -- suggesting that, perhaps, history might be kinder to Mr. Dinkins.
"Wagner was a great leader," Mr. Costikyan said, "although none of us realized it at the time."

HEADLINE: In the New Era, a New Realism;
As Germany Flexes Its Muscles, The New Europe Goes Along

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THAT a shiver would go down the spine of Europe when a reunified Germany started exercising its new political and economic muscle was not surprising. What is surprising, perhaps, is how the other nations of Europe seem to have accepted German clout as a natural part of the new order of things.
That the Germans can pursue what they see as their own national interests just as vigorously as the French or the British, despite their frequent professions of loyal support for European unity, became clear when Bonn charged ahead with long-delayed plans to give diplomatic recognition to Croatia and Slovenia, leaving the rest of the Europeans scrambling to catch up. This came only a few days after French and German leaders had tried to persuade the rest of their European Community partners to make more foreign policy decisions together, by consensus. 
 By barging ahead, the Germans forced the rest to recognize reality and acknowledge that Yugoslavia ceased to exist when civil war broke out last summer. The decision by the Europeans to recognize the two former Yugoslav republics by Jan. 15 will, according to the man behind the German move, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, provide greater international leverage against Serbia, the republic that is widely perceived throughout Germany to be the aggressor in Yugoslavia's civil war.
Whether it is right or wrong, the step fills something of a policy vacuum. Until former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance undertook his peace-seeking mission for the United Nations, the influence of the United States had seemed altogether negligible in a disaster the Bush Administration had been quite happy to leave to the Europeans to try to solve. The European Community's peace negotiator, Lord Carrington, warned last week that recognition of two of the former Yugoslav republics wouldn't exactly help his efforts to bring about a cease-fire, but since Community Cease-Fire Number Umpty-Nine had just collapsed like all its predecessors, the warning was easy to shrug off.
International recognition of Slovenia and Croatia might not hurt either, most seemed to feel, though it certainly would if outside countries began supplying them with arms. This, however, is something the Germans say their constitution bars them from doing.
Even in Britain, few saw anything more sinister in the German argument, though some were reminded of the German-Croatian axis in World War II. Territorial ambitions have less to do with Bonn's interest this time than do feelings. Germans feel strongly about the right of national self-determination, since it brought them unification. And German politicians also feel the political pressures exerted by 700,000 Yugoslav "guest workers," many of them Croats, and their descendants who have lived in Germany since they were invited in the 1960's to come in and sustain the German "economic miracle."
"We have a large immigrant population of Indians, Pakistanis and Jamaicans," a British official close to Prime Minister John Major said understandingly of the German decision, "and if something happened in one of those places we'd come under great pressure to get involved, too."
 
A Missed Opportunity
 Mr. Major's predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, warned before unification that a united Germany would dominate Europe. She was right, but she also resisted moves toward closer European unity that were sought, in particular, by France, Belgium and the Netherlands as a way of countering the weight of the German colossus. Last week, even some British commentators were looking longingly at the prospect of European monetary union, perhaps as early as 1997, as a way of dealing with the problems caused by another unilateral German action -- raising interest rates to control the inflationary pressures of reunification.
If a common currency is established later in the decade, as European Community leaders agreed in the Dutch town of Maastricht earlier this month, it will require the Germans, too, to leave decisions about interest rates and other instruments of monetary policy to a European Central Bank in which they will have a strong but not determining voice. For now, Germany's Bundesbank seemed determined to show that it is still in control, and still dead set on keeping the mark steady, though the heavens fall, before it is replaced by the European ecu.
To keep their currencies stable against the mark in the European Monetary System, France, Italy and Spain all had to raise their domestic rates last week, despite the fact that all their economies have been hit hard by the recession. The German move was most painful for Britain, which is now unable to lower bank rates below 10.5 percent though unemployment has risen to 2.5 million, but it also hit President Francois Mitterrand hard in France, where unemployment reached a record high of 2.82 million last month and his popularity sank to a record low.
 
A Distasteful Choice
 Unlike him, Mr. Major has to face a general election some time in the next six months. The German monetary moves could soon put him in the uncomfortable position of being forced to choose between raising interest rates, thus killing off any remaining slim hope of an upturn before the election, or devaluing the pound sterling against the mark, and thereby losing face.
Germany's coming of age began when Charles de Gaulle demonstratively embraced Konrad Adenauer and bet on Franco-German entente as the best guarantee of continued French dominance of the European Community. With the United States now unsure at best how to preserve its strategic and economic interests here, the Germans have considerably more weight and room to throw it around in, a fact recognized by President Bush in mid-1989 when he disregarded former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's advice and let Chancellor Helmut Kohl refuse to station new NATO medium-range nuclear missiles on German territory.
That was clear American recognition of the new German clout, which seemed strangely absent last winter when the Chancellor failed to use it to fashion a concerted European response to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Now, with that war over and the Soviet threat a startlingly distant memory, the Germans are beginning to behave more like what they really are -- a mid-range Central European power whose interests are not global, or even Atlantic, but mainly in Mitteleuropa.
The rest of the Europeans seem to realize that they are just going to have to get used to it.

HEADLINE: A Meditation;
History's Being Written, But It's Lives That Matter

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
THE rides are closed, guarded by snappish dogs. The broad boardwalk is almost deserted, gulls scream their elemental hunger, the air smells of briny decay. This narrow, desolate sand bar at the foot of Brooklyn, five miles long and nine eternal miles from Manhattan, feels like the end of the world.
I have come to Coney Island to walk in the winter wind and try to make sense of this remarkable year. 
 Somebody, clearly, has pushed the fast-forward button on history. Communism, apartheid, crooked Teamsters all seem racing toward extinction. General Motors and I.B.M. are shrinking, the Soviet Union dissolving, European nations merging. Takes your breath away.
The lot of Americans meanwhile diminishes. You can read it in the unemployment numbers, sense it in a general reluctance of people to spend money. Uncertainty -- and, increasingly, real fear -- flicker in people's eyes. No one knows what will happen next, and that takes your spirit away.
We lack the perspective of geologic time, which might or might not be a good thing. Just for a minute, consider the earth's history as the old measure of the English yard, the distance from the King's nose to the tip of his outstretched hand. One stroke of a nail file on his middle finger erases human history.
If we had such perspective, daily aggravations like desperate, forgotten people begging us for sustenance might not be so grating. At the least, we might remember life's kindest lesson: time heals.
 
An Immense Hurt
 My rubber soles squeak on the cold wood. The wind whistles in many tones, all at once. Sand races along an inch above the beach's surface. A solitudinous dreamer of small dreams combs the beach with a metal detector.
Two men, one white and one black, talk loudly on the boardwalk about the economy. "Nothing's made in America," one declares. His companion answers, "Everybody's out of work."
They sound almost trite, but there is immense hurt, a hurt widely shared, in these words. There is a feeling in the land that things are worse than before, that the only direction is down. Things were once certainly better on Coney Island.
Before the fires, the disastrous housing projects, the breakdown in services and all the rest, this penin sula called an island shimmered like a mythic paradise.
There was once a hotel in the shape of an elephant, John Philip Sousa led the band, Irving Berlin and Eddie Cantor sang. Cary Grant walked on stilts, Mae West performed her first act, rides spun people to Mars and beyond. On busy days, more than a million sunburned visitors gorged themselves on cotton candy.
"Fabulous and beyond conceiving, ineffably beautiful, is this fiery scintillation," the Russian author Maxim Gorky wrote in 1906 -- and he hated the place.
In the winter, many years later, there is just the leaden gray sky, the endless waves, the black form of the eerie and disgracefully decrepit parachute jump, a National Landmark. My son Roy, who will be 4 years old in February, grips my hand harder. We are a man and a boy walking toward an uncertain future.
A jogger waves. On the pier, people bait hooks with painfully red hands. Two dogs cavort. I continue to try to sort things out, admittedly most disjointedly.
One thing that keeps coming to the forefront is the meaninglessness of politics, at least as we usually understand politics. Who cares if Cuomo runs for President? Who cares if the President goes to Japan? Should we now lie awake worrying that Kazakhstan or some other leftover of the Soviet Union will nuke us?
Maybe, but most people's minds are closer to home. What concerns them is balancing the checkbook, keeping a tiny step ahead of those infernal credit cards, last night's arthritis attack, the radiant smile or icy silence of someone you love.
I think of my uncle who spent a career working for I.B.M., selling typewriters and moving every couple of years to a new city. A constant in his family's life were the signs that decorated whatever house was next. They said "Think," I.B.M.'s motto, in different languages.
Now I.B.M. is imploding, and one way one family defined itself seems a curious vestige. It must be vaguely the same for the Soviet "Hero Mothers" who adorned their children with those cute little "Baby Lenin" pins.
Questions of group identity are meaningless to people on the economic edge, of course. Not too long ago, I bought an unemployed friend lunch. He made a little sandwich and put it in his pocket. When I called him a couple of days later, his phone was disconnected.
 
Those Whom Life Kicks
 And there are the people whom life kicks, then kicks again and again. My brother was brain-injured at birth. His head was enlarged and his judgment terrible. But his intelligence was high, and he went to public schools in a small town. Thus did I learn of the special cruelty of children, no softer for being unknowing. Almost every family learns something of cruelty.
So as much as I could tell you of the pains I have witnessed and felt -- my beloved, once articulate mother's terrible stroke, and all the rest -- you doubtless have plenty of your own.
The point is that these concerns are what come first, along with the true joys of life: a new baby's gurgle, a graduation, a tree-planting. It is the joys that memory holds dearest, a great and inexplicable gift of the human mind.
All this makes it difficult for many people to keep up with the news, though everybody was happy the hostages, those poor hostages, were finally free. People's own lives are what matter, even in fast-paced times like these. Dollars to doughnuts, there are more people this morning concocting the perfect number to play in the lottery or daydreaming about old lovers than are reading the newspaper. And they are not bad people.
My son is now tired and we are both cold. We retreat to the tiny dining room in the back of the huge food stand that is Nathan's Famous at the intersection of Surf and Stillwell Avenues. There are beautiful plastic Christmas decorations, cheap only in price. The windows are in the shape of portholes. We are alone as we share the wonderfully greasy fries with melted cheese. Alone in paradise.
Our last stop is somewhere almost indescribably special. It is the B & B Carousell, spelled in the manner of the master craftsman who built it, William Mangels. The horses are decidedly of what is called the Coney Island style -- leaping, snorting, tongues protruding exuberantly. The calliope plays "Sidewalks of New York."
More than a year ago, on a summer day, on his first visit to this magical merry-go-round, my son ran to the big green stallion.But as it spun faster and faster, he began to cry. He was shaking like a leaf by the time I could help him to the ground.
Though no one was around the other day, the operator said he would, of course, start up the whole darned machine for just one little boy. Roy immediately selected the same terrifying green horse. Great.
But this time he grinned like a young Roy Rogers mounting Trigger for the Rose Bowl Parade. The bell sounded. As happy music filled the chilly air, the brightly painted steeds began their endless gallop -- up and down, round and round, through all the seasons and all the years.
Just like the world.
