HEADLINE: BUSH'S ASIAN TRIP RECAST TO STRESS JOBS AND EXPORTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
As President Bush departs Monday for Australia and Asia, the trip he had originally scheduled as a good-will tour has changed under political pressures into a blunt sales pitch for American exports and jobs, bringing anger and dismay in Japan.
Mr. Bush's decision to take with him a group of American business executives to help insist on freer access to Asian markets is born in part of domestic concerns. Those concerns, his advisers say, include the fear that his decision to travel 26,000 miles overseas amid what some are calling the longest recession since the 1930's will only add fuel to Democrats' criticism that the President prefers tackling problems abroad rather than those in his back yard. 
 But the announcement that Mr. Bush would take the business executives with him has brought some strenuous negative reactions from business and political leaders in Japan, aggravating tensions between the two economic superpowers as the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, is seeing his domestic political problems grow.
 
Actions by Tokyo
 Japanese and American officials are likely to seek to avoid open confrontation during the Japan segment of the trip. And the Japanese, who enjoy a $41 billion trade surplus with the United States, appear to be reacting in small ways already to the Administration's pressure.
Officials in Tokyo said Friday that they might agree to reduce their auto exports to the United States next year, a move that seems to nod to the American concerns on Japan's auto imports but would probably have little effect because sales already are declining.
With the economy wounded and his political rivals scenting the blood, Mr. Bush is taking in tow 21 executives of major American corporations, including the heads of Detroit's Big Three automakers, for the 12-day lobbying tour of Australia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan.
 
Japanese Criticisms
 The stop in Tokyo from Jan. 7-10 is the last and by far the most important stop of the trip. There, Mr. Bush is scheduled to present his delegation to Mr. Miyazawa and local business leaders in what some Japanese newspapers already are calling an exercise in "Japan bashing" at the highest level of the American Government.
Mr. Bush's advisers insist that the display of American unhappiness is justified by Japan's steadfast refusal to open its markets to American goods, and that their aim is not to embarrass their hosts.
"I don't think it's going to be done in a high-handed manner," one of the President's political advisers, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in an interview this week. "We're not going to castigate Japan."
That adviser nonetheless said that the visit entails "some risk" of generating a diplomatic backlash in Japan, where opinion polls suggest that the United States increasingly is seen as a declining economic power demanding handouts from its more robust Japanese competitors.
In Tokyo, the mere anticipation of Mr. Bush's tough-talking mission and his corporate delegation has generated a backwash of angry editorials in major newspapers, and even experts who applaud the idea say it might provoke diplomatic and public-relations problems. In a typical comment, Asahi Shimbun, Japan's leading newspaper, said Mr. Bush appeared to be waging "gunboat diplomacy in economic areas."
On the American side, some public statements have been equally tough. Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told reporters outside the White House this month that Japanese trade policies are "basically unfair" and deny American manufacturers "a fair shake."
Joseph T. Gorman, chairman of TRW Inc. and one of the executives making the trip, said in an interview last week that business leaders plan to deliver an unvarnished message to Tokyo.
"They have to realize that the problem of trade barriers is inescapable, and it's one that's unsustainable, and something has to be done," he said. "That's the point."
Mr. Bush's Democratic critics have heightened the political stakes, with a group led by the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, threatening legislation that would limit Japanese automobile imports unless the President returned from Tokyo with real trade concession in hand.
Mr. Bush, in turn, has sought tolower expectations, waying this week only that he would make clear that "They had better do something" about unfair trade practices.
One senior official, citing White House polling data, said that the public believed the nation's economic problems required long-term solutions, and that Mr. Bush agreed.
When the journey was first scheduled for late November, it was depicted as a personal visit to two of Mr. Bush's favorite world leaders in Japan and Australia, leavened with a new diplomatic initiative on free trade. But Mr. Bush abruptly canceled the trip on Nov. 5, election night, after returns underscored voters' unhappiness with the economy and the Administration's handling of domestic matters in general.
 
'Jobs, Jobs, Jobs'
 Since then, Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan have been ousted from office, the last vestiges of Soviet military power in Asia have vanished, Mr. Bush's popularity has plummeted and a new team of political and policy advisers has taken command in the White House. And while the thrust of the Asia visit remains the same, its political complexion is considerably changed.
Mr. Bush has billed the trip as a crusade to create and save "jobs, jobs, jobs" at home by persuading allies to lower trade barriers and buy more American goods. In a news conference this week, he went as far as to suggest that his hopscotch through two continents and two archipelagos was entirely a domestic matter, devoted solely to promoting exports, "working out the final phases of a highly complex Federal budget," and "putting the final touches on a State of the Union" address that will offer new economic meassures.
In Japan, where he once planned to visit a model high school in Tokyo and play tennis with Emperor Akihito, Mr. Bush now is scheduled to visit an American Toys 'R' Us outlet and invite 18 executives from his business delegation to press Japan's top business and government leaders for trade concessions.
The shift in emphasis was endorsed by Mr. Bush's new chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, and his chief campaign advisers, Fred Malek and Robert Teeter, officials said.
 
Assertions of Pandering
 A second senior Administration official said that the Asian trip had been intended from its origin to underscore the desire for freer trade in the Pacific, but that the political pressures generated by a sagging economy have now cast it in a sharper and less forgiving light.
"Admittedly, it looks more politically expedient than I wanted," said that official, who insisted on not being identified.
Some outside experts are accusing Mr. Bush of pandering to domestic politic pressures.
"It's a hell of a way to pursue domestic policy, by sending the President 26,000 miles," said Seth Cropsey, a scholar at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington research institute, at a recent briefing on the Asia trip for reporters. "We suspect that both he and Barbara will qualify for a free trip to New Hampshire with these miles he's been getting on that."
But the President's aides insist that the four-nation tour is good politics and good diplomacy.
"This isn't just a trip to spread diplomatic niceties around to our allies," said one of his advisers. "It's a trip to deal with some of their unfair trade practices and to protect American jobs. If you consider political benefits to be job creation and a better trade balance, then this is a political trip."
 
Bush Government's Help
 The trip also will yield more subtle political benefits for Mr. Bush by allowing his principal campaign fund-raiser, the departing Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, to wield White House clout on behalf of American business interests.
"Mosbacher wants to signal everybody in the Administration and all the business leaders he's going to have to touch next year that we've got a new relationship -- that business is going to get tangible help from the Government in selling its goods," said a former senior trade official in the Bush Administration, who insisted on not being identified. "And the most tangible evidence of that is this business delegation."
In a telephone interview today, Mr. Mosbacher called Japanese criticism of Mr. Bush's trip "part of their normal posturing" and said that Tokyo seldom makes concessions in its trade practices until outside pressures force them to do so.
In taking business executives with him to Asia, he said, Mr. Bush is merely taking his cue from Asian political leaders, who routinely travel abroad with corporate officials. The coming trip allows business and the White House "to speak with one voice" to Tokyo, he said.
"The Japanese are much too smart and sophisticated to overreact" to that, he said. "We're their No. 1 customer," he continued. "And they know that the President has a very positive attitude toward Japan in general."
The delegation of corporate executives -- the first ever to accompany a President on a state visit -- is potentially the most productive and most risky facet of the entire tour, Mr. Bush's aides acknowledge. It includes officials of some firms that have penetrated the Asian market, some that are showcases of American manufacturing quality, and some that have failed to make a dent in Japan and the rest of Asia and are openly angry about it.

HEADLINE: Dollars Are Leaving Philippines, Too

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Dec. 28

 BODY:
The withdrawal of American forces from the Subic Bay naval base by the end of 1992 will close a chapter in the Philippines' turbulent relationship with its former colonial ruler, but it poses economic problems for this already poor country.
The decision to withdraw from Subic is expected to end a longstanding political debate. Since Filipinos won full independence from the United States in 1946, they have been divided over the issue of the American military presence. 
 "We can now get on with our national agenda," said Senator Rene Saguisag, who is opposed to any extension of base agreements.
But the American withdrawal also means economic dislocation, especially in the city of Olongapo, the rest-and-recreation center just south of Subic that thrives on the base's presence. The naval installation provides jobs for more than 40,000 Filipinos, directly employing about 20,000, and about 160,000 more depend on income generated by the base.
In 1990, revenue from all American-leased military installations contributed somewhere between 1.7 percent and 3 percent of the Philippine gross national product. Estimates of the amount vary.
Since then, Washington has closed minor installations as part of global military cutbacks. Then the United States Air Force shut down Clark Air Base after it was heavily damaged by the volcanic eruption in June of Mount Pinatubo. That left Subic.
The volcano-damaged area where Subic and Clark are situated is in the central region of Luzon, the Philippines' main island. The eruption of Mount Pinatubo displaced tens of thousands of people and destroyed farms and other property whose value was estimated at hundreds of millions of dollars.
 
Cutbacks Were Planned
 Analysts expect the economic impact of the American withdrawal to be limited to Olongapo and nearby towns.
What is more, reductions were on the way before Mount Pinatubo erupted and before Philippine Senators refused to renew the Subic lease in September.
Twelve of the 23 senators rejected a proposed treaty that would have extended the lease for 10 years. Senators who opposed extension, like Mr. Saguisag, saw the American military presence as a colonial relic that had to be discarded.
If the base lease had been extended, the radical change in global security needs brought on by the collapse of Communism would have led the Navy to drastically cut back its operations at Subic Bay.
The base has pumped about $220million a year in wages and purchases into the local economy. If Manila had agreed to a new treaty, the United States would have paid $200 million more in annual compensation.
While loss of this income will not significantly alter the national economy -- a weak one, with per capita income less than $700 -- it will cripple communities around Subic and the Philippine armed forces, which rely on American military aid that comes with the base compensation package.
"Our town is totally devastated," said Mayor Richard Gordon of Olangapo. "We will lose everything -- our money, our jobs -- and we are not ready."
A Philippine Government plan to convert the Subic base into a commercial ship-repair facility and an industrial zone has floundered. The Senate has delayed passage of a bill creating a Bases Conversion Authority, and the businessman who heads a conversion committee has resigned because the Government has not released funds to him.
Efforts over the last six months to convert the abandoned Clark base into a special economic zone that includes an international airport, have not progressed beyond rough drafts. Manila does not have the money.
President Corazon C. Aquino is among those who wanted to renew or extend the leases. She argued that the economic benefits from the stationing of American troops were too great to pass up.
But Mrs. Aquino is a lame-duck President, and the election campaign that will determine her successor has already gathered steam.
Mr. Saguisag remarked, "The national debate will continue to focus on the bases as long as the issue is alive."

HEADLINE: Plan for New Commodities Center Faces Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A year after it was announced as a victory in New York City's battle to retain big business, the plan for a new $450 million commodities trading center in TriBeCa appears likely to be scaled down because commodities firms can now find cheaper office space elsewhere in lower Manhattan.
The project would be the recipient of one of the largest real-estate subsidies from the city and state. Already the focus of fierce opposition from TriBeCa residents, the project is now being squeezed by a depressed market for office space in which landlords are desperate for corporate tenants. 
 "Given the current economic climate, the timing of this project is horrible," said Henry Jarecki, chairman of Brody White and Company, one of more than 1,000 members of the city's five commodities exchanges. "I don't think any of us will move in," he said. The project should be abandoned altogether, he said.
The city's Planning Commission is to make its recommendation on the project to the City Council by Jan. 13. City and state officials acknowledge that offices in the new center, if it is built by the end of 1994 as scheduled, will face tough competition in lower Manhattan. But they insist that the project is critical to New York's long-term economic health.
 
An Important Message
 "It is particularly important now, in this economy, that we send a message to the world that New York's future is bright," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, in testimony before the Planning Commission earlier this month.
The project is part of a deal struck late last year after the city's five exchanges, which trade on a cramped floor at the World Trade Center, said they needed more modern space and would move to Jersey City.
New York City and the state promised to pay $100 million of the cost of building the commodities center. At least $42 million more came later in tax breaks and rent subsidies.
Commodities executives say they do not know how many firms would move in. But even the ones who support the project see potential problems, if, for example, neighborhood opposition delays construction.
 
'Reassess Our Commitment'
 "If the time line on this project changes, it would be necessary to reassess our commitment to New York City," said R. Patrick Thompson, president of the New York Merchantile Exchange, the largest of the city's five commodities exchanges.
The other exchanges are the Commodities Exchange; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange. The exchanges say they employ 11,700 people in lower Manhattan, more than five times the number 10 years ago.
City officials say one reason so much public money is being pledged is that commodities trading has grown despite the poor economy.
If approved, the TriBeCa project, on a city-owned block bounded by West, Murray, Greenwich and Warren Streets, would be built in two parts. The most important part, city officials and the exchanges agree, would be a 20-story exchange building that would house two new trading floors, with four times the space it now uses in the World Trade Center. All the public money promised for construction subsidies would be dedicated to that part of the project.
The second part, which appears more likely to be revised, is an adjoining 47-story office tower for commodities brokers, data processors and others employed by the member firms. As much as $20 million in city and state money would be available to subsidize tenants' rents and energy costs.
 
Questions on 2d Tower
 In testimony before the Planning Commission and subsequent interviews, more than a dozen member firms said they supported the plan for the trading floor, but had not yet made up their minds about leasing office space. They say the most likely solution is to build the 20-story exchange building and reduce the size of the second tower for only those firms that commit themselves to office space.
"This was never intended as a speculative project, and is not now," said Amy Benenson, managing director of the New York Exchanges Project, a group formed by the five exchanges to coordinate their plans.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said, "We have simply got to reduce the height of that tower," and cited reasons including opposition from the neighborhood and the fear that the space would not be leased. She added that the change "would in no way derail this project."
But the project is drawing harsh criticism in the neighborhood. Groups in TriBeCa, including its Community Board, have opposed it from the start, saying it would overwhelm their streets with traffic and overburden their public services.
 
'There Is Already a Glut'
 "The question is whether the city should be underwriting more office space in lower Manhattan when there is already a glut," said Kent Barwick, executive director of the Municipal Art Society, the urban design and planning group.
"Given the huge financial stake the city and state want to take, we ought to see a lot more specifics about this project," he added.
Commodities executives say they, too, want more information.
Office space in the proposed center "is definitely under consideration, but it is far to early in the cycle for us to make up our minds," said Susan Quigly, a spokesman for Shearson Commodities Inc., one of the city's largest commodities traders.
Another of the city's large firms, Cargill Investor Services Inc., says it believes that the new commodities exchange center is needed, but has no plans to move to an office there.
"It would be very, very difficult for us to consider moving for several years to come," said William F. Berger, senior vice president at Cargill, which has a 10-year lease on an office for 125 workers in the World Financial Center, two blocks from the proposed site of the new complex. "We don't plan to break our lease," Mr. Berger said.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

 
No More Friendly Enemies
 For all the attention in Albany on the war between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Republican leaders of the State Senate, whom Mr. Cuomo has blamed for blocking a budget agreement and for keeping him out of the Presidential race, there has been something of a sideshow struggle between the Governor and another Republican: United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Although they come from different parties, the Governor and Senator D'Amato were on distinctly friendly terms for years, sometimes using words like "superb" (Mr. Cuomo did) and "super, just super" (Mr. D'Amato did) to describe each other's work.
But not now.
The first real signs of hostility surfaced two weeks ago, when Mr. D'Amato announced that he would go to snowy Albany to issue some thoughts about the state budget. "Oh, we'll make sure to shovel the Capitol steps for him," a sarcastic Mr. Cuomo told reporters at a news conference. ("Yes, before and after," piped in his chief of staff, Andrew J. Zambelli, as the room dissolved in laughter.)
The next day Mr. D'Amato, who had never before taken such a public interest in state budget matters, did show up, declaring that if Mr. Cuomo couldn't handle his own state's budget, "obviously people will wonder how you can handle that situation nationwide." Mr. Cuomo lashed back at the Senator as a lackey sent by Republicans in Washington, calling him "B.A.D. -- a Bush Attack Dog."
That provoked an expression of outrage from Mr. D'Amato. "Your decision to respond to my economic ideas with personal vitriol is wrong," he wrote in a letter to Mr. Cuomo. "I demand an apology."
None came from the Governor, who later predicted that Mr. D'Amato, who is expected to face a tough reelection battle next fall, would be a severe drag on the Republican State Senators who will also be campaigning. "It's going to be like running through the mud with a 900-pound sumo wrestler on your back," he said.
People close to both men say there is genuine irritation between the two that could well harden into permanent ill feelings. On the other hand, it is certainly not impossible that all the nasty words served other purposes than just an exchange of slurs.
For Mr. Cuomo, the D'Amato appearance did bolster his contention that there might be a national Republican plot against him. And for Mr. D'Amato, an attack on a Governor who has sagged in the polls, along with the publicity surrounding the theatrics of their falling out, may well have given a boost to his re-election bid.
 
You Wanted It
 Angry Democrats last week turned the table on New Jersey's largest teachers' union, the New Jersey Education Association, using an Assembly Appropriations Committee hearing on tax repeal to deliver a stern public lecture.
"The teachers' union unmistakably added their voice to the chorus of repeal, repeal, repeal," said Assemblyman Bernard F. Kenny, a Democrat from Hudson County. "Now that the Legislature is considering a sunset and review of the tax package and programs, the N.J.E.A. is doing an about-face. I'm perplexed."
The 137,000-member association put its money and votes behind Republican candidates in the Nov. 5 election. The teachers' union, one of the most powerful unions in the state, was angry with Democrats over a section of the Quality Education Act that tried to shift teacher pension costs from the state to local schools in richer districts.
Monday's hearing was the first face-to-face meeting between Democrats and N.J.E.A. representatives since the election, and the Democrats seized that opportunity to give the union a tongue-lashing.
"When the N.J.E.A. panicked because the Q.E.A. shifted teacher pension and social security costs to the local level, the Democrats stepped in and delayed the shift for a period of two years," said Assemblyman John A. Villapiano, another Democratic member of the Appropriations Committee. "But the union still balked, then worked to defeat the Democratic legislators who crafted the 1990 tax program.
"To suggest now that the program is fine and should be left alone is at best an about face and at worst, hypocrisy."
Wayne S. Dibofsky, the associate director of government relations for the union, bore the brunt of the Democrats' anger as he sat before the committee arguing against repeal of the entire $2.8 billion tax package the Democratic-controlled Legislature approved 18 months ago.
"We're concerned about the growing deficit, the quality of life in New Jersey and the quality of schools," Mr. Dibofsky said. "All could be drastically hurt by this suggestion that we start from ground zero."
And a spokeswoman for the teachers' union, Karen Joseph, accused the Democrats of "distorting our message."
"The N.J.E.A. has never opposed taxes," Ms. Joseph said. "Taxes are what pay for public education."
 
From Erie to Albany
 Jim Kelly, the Buffalo Bills quarterback, is arguably the best-known person in western New York right now. But a new survey of community leaders by Business First, a magazine that covers the area, cites somebody else as the "most influential" person in the region: Dennis T. Gorski, the Erie County Executive.
Mr. Gorski, a Democrat who soundly turned back a challenge in November from Mayor James D. Griffin of Buffalo, is about to start his second four-year term. He is the only Democrat ever elected to the post.
Although Buffalo and the New York metropolitan region are so far apart that some people have suggested they belong in different states, the 47-year-old Mr. Gorski is expected at some point to try to parlay his influence into a bid for statewide office. One of his predecessors as county executive, Edward V. Regan, a Republican, is the State Comptroller, and another western New Yorker, Stan Lundine, the former Mayor of Jamestown, is the Lieutenant Governor.
 
Directory Assistance
 What a difference a year makes.
"Crotty, Davis, Forsythe, Dullea, Fryer, Poklemba," reads the speed-dial listings on the telephone in Governor Cuomo's conference room in the State Capitol.
Apparently the budget chaos has kept Mr. Cuomo's staff so busy that no one has had a chance to change the names, which represent the people who held six of the highest positions in the Cuomo administration last year. All six men -- who were, respectively, the Governor's chief of staff, counsel, budget director, director of state operations, press officer and criminal-justice director -- left following Mr. Cuomo's November 1990 re-election, for jobs in either private business or higher education.
The changeover has been cast as a way to bring on a new team for Mr. Cuomo's third term, although some officials in the Capitol also took it as an early sign that some of those closest to Mr. Cuomo, who might not have left if they thought he were headed for the White House, did not believe he would wind up running for President.
Just for the record, when things calm down it's time to change the labels on those buttons to: (Andrew J.) Zambelli, (Elizabeth D.) Moore, (Patrick J.) Bulgaro, (Mary Ann) Crotty, (Anne W.) Crowley and (Richard H.) Girgenti.

HEADLINE: 1991: THE YEAR IN SPORTS;
Champions And Casualties Share the Stage

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
WHILE the Giants were winning a classic Super Bowl, scud missiles were whining through the skies of the Persian Gulf. When the Minnesota Twins were winning a classic World Series, the Soviet Union was crumbling, ruble by ruble, into a commonwealth without wealth.
In 1991, sports produced classic theater amid raw reality. 
 Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls dunked the National Basketball Association championship. Duke upset previously unbeaten Nevada-Las Vegas before winning the national collegiate title.
Mike Powell soared to a long-jump world record of 29 feet 4 1/2 inches in Tokyo, where Carl Lewis burned 100 meters in a record 9.86 seconds. Earlier, Sergei Bubka pole-vaulted a record 20 feet 1/4 inch.
With golf's Ryder Cup at stake on the final green of the final match, the United States recaptured it when Europe's Bernhard Langer missed a 5-foot putt.
Tennis' grand old man, 39-year-old Jimmy Connors, was center stage at the United States Open until the semifinals. In the biggest upset in Davis Cup history, France won the final for the first time in 59 years, dethroning the United States.
In women's soccer, the United States won the world championship, beating Norway in the final. And three American figure skaters (Kristi Yamaguchi, Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan) finished first, second and third in the world championships.
But more often than usual, harsh human elements intruded on the fun and games.
Magic Johnson was among 10 National Basketball Association players named to the 1992 Olympic basketball team before he suddenly retired from the Los Angeles Lakers. He had contracted human immunodeficiency virus, which leads to AIDS.
Bo Jackson's baseball career was interrupted and his pro football career presumably ended by a severely damaged hip.
Soon after Mike Tyson signed to challenge Evander Holyfield for the world heavyweight title, Tyson was indicted on charges of raping an 18-year-old Miss Black America contestant in Indianapolis; his trial begins Jan. 27.
Lyle Alzado disclosed that he believed his brain tumor had been caused by steroids taken to enhance his pro football career.
As the Pittsburgh Penguins began defending the Stanley Cup, their coach, Bob Johnson, died of brain cancer.
Howard Spira, the Bronx gambler whose link to George Steinbrenner had resulted in the Yankees principal owner being exiled from baseball, was convicted of extortion and sentenced to 30 months in Federal prison.
Dexter Manley of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Roy Tarpley of the Dallas Mavericks were banned from their sports for illegal-drug abuse; Steve Howe's baseball career was again in jeopardy after a cocaine arrest.
Robert Helmick resigned the presidency of the United States Olympic Committee amid accusations of unethical business conduct.
Mike Utley, a Detroit Lions lineman, was paralyzed in a freak fall during a game and Willie Shoemaker, again a trainer of race horses, was paralyzed in an auto accident.
Lightning killed spectators at the United States Open and the Professional Golfers Association championship.
And in the economic recession, Calumet Farm, once the grand dame of thoroughbred racing stables, filed for bankruptcy.
But the recession didn't affect salaries. After the Mets finished fifth, their new general manager, Al Harazin, signed the free agent Bobby Bonilla to a five-year $29 million contract. The Knicks negotiated a six-year extension with Patrick Ewing worth $33 million. And the Miami Dolphins quarterback, Dan Marino, received a five-year $25 million deal.
The value of the Super Bowl XXV champion Giants franchise was pegged at $140 million after Robert Tisch, a billionaire businessman, purchased 50 percent for a reported $70 million.
 
Quarterback Controversy
 For the Giants, the glory of their 20-19 Super Bowl victory over the Buffalo Bills at the start of the year dissolved into embarrassment following Coach Bill Parcells's decision that "it was time" to stop coaching. In the 1991 season, the Giants sagged to an 8-8 record with Ray Handley, who chose Jeff Hostetler over Phil Simms at quarterback.
As the dismal season ended, Simms's future with the Giants was uncertain. Lawrence Taylor, who missed most of the last four games with a damaged knee, was not chosen as a Pro Bowl linebacker for the first time in his 11 seasons.
In the Jets' second year under Bruce Coslet, they finished the regular season 8-8 and earned their wild-card playoff game with the Houston Oilers today with a theatrical 23-20 overtime victory in Miami.
The Washington Redskins, with a 14-2 record, and the Bills, at 13-3, were favored to produce a Super Bowl XXVI showdown in Minneapolis after a season played without two of the National Football League's best quarterbacks: San Francisco's Joe Montana (elbow) and Philadelphia's Randall Cunningham (knee) sat out the year with injuries.
In college football, the University of Miami hoped to assure itself the national championship with an Orange Bowl victory over Nebraska on Wednesday, but that wouldn't break the three-way share of the 1990 title the bowl games didn't settle. Miami was the choice of The New York Times's computer while Colorado and Georgia Tech were first in the Associated Press and United Press International polls.
Desmond Howard, a Michigan wide receiver, was voted the Heisman Trophy in a landslide while Auburn coped with charges of illegal payments to Eric Ramsey, once a cornerback there.
In its first season, the World League of American Football cost N.F.L. owners a reported $28 million. The London Monarchs, one of three European franchises, won the championship.
 
Baseball and Money
 At the age of 36, Jack Morris symbolized baseball, artistically and financially. In the seventh game of the World Series, he shut out the Atlanta Braves for 10 innings before the Minnesota Twins finally won, 1-0, on Gene Larkin's pinch-single. Two months later, Morris departed his hometown area to join the Toronto Blue Jays for $10.85 million over two years.
But the memory of what was generally considered the best World Series ever will endure. Among other footnotes, it was the first to have the seventh game go scoreless through nine innings, the first with four games decided on the last pitch, the first with five games decided on a team's last turn at bat, the first with three extra-inning games.
Both the Twins and the Braves had ascended from last place finishes in 1990. The Twins won the American League pennant in four games with the Blue Jays. The Braves, with 21-year-old Steve Avery earning two 1-0 victories and their fans doing the controversial tomahawk chop, needed seven to eliminate the Pittsburgh Pirates for the National League title.
Even though Howard Johnson led the National League with 38 homers and 117 runs batted in, the Mets sagged to fifth with a 77-84 record, prompting the dismissal of Manager Buddy Harrelson and the transfer of the general manager's torch to Harazin from Frank Cashen, who retired from day-to-day duties. Harazin hired Jeff Torborg as manager, signed Bonilla for $29 million over five years and first baseman Eddie Murray for $7.5 million over two years, then acquired ace righthander Bret Saberhagen and infielder Bill Pecota in a blockbuster trade that shipped Kevin McReynolds, Gregg Jefferies and Keith Miller to the Kansas City Royals. But a three-year, $15.45 million deal with Dwight Gooden was clouded by rotator-cuff surgery.
With a 71-91 record, the Yankees not only finished fifth but, worse, showed little interest in improving. Buck Showalter received a one-year contract to succeed Stump Merrill, the manager in the middle when Don Mattingly was benched for one game for not having a proper haircut. Robert Nederlander announced his resignation, effective Wednesday, as managing partner. That prompted speculation that George Steinbrenner will try to return from his permanent suspension meted out in 1990 by Commissioner Fay Vincent.
The directors of the Baseball Hall of Fame ruled that anybody on baseball's ineligible list, meaning Pete Rose, would not be listed on the annual ballot for election.
At age 44, Nolan Ryan fired his fastball for a record seventh no-hitter only a few hours after Rickey Henderson stole his 939th base, surpassing Lou Brock's total. Dennis Martinez of the Montreal Expos pitched the major leagues' 15th perfect game. And the National League awarded franchises to Denver and Miami, to begin play with the 1993 season.
 
Bulls Get Bullish
 In the N.B.A., the Bulls lost the opening game of the championship series to the Lakers, then swept four straight as Jordan averaged 31.2 points and 11.4 assists. He earned most valuable player awards for both the playoffs and the season; he won his fifth consecutive scoring title with a 31.5 average. The Bulls roared through the playoffs with a 15-2 record, dethroning Detroit in the Eastern Conference final in four games after having eliminated Philadelphia in five and the Knicks in three straight.
Even before completing a third-place 39-43 record in the Atlantic Division under John MacLeod, the Knicks hired a new general manager, Dave Checketts, to succeed the dismissed Al Bianchi. Checketts lured Pat Riley away from television for $5 million over five years. The players responded to Riley by challenging Boston for first place.
The Nets continued to flounder. With the second choice in the college draft, they took Kenny Anderson, the Georgia Tech playmaker. But a contract dispute prevented him from joining the team until after the season opener. Typical of the franchise's confusion, Jim Valvano, once the North Carolina State coach, was recently reported about to succeed Bill Fitch as coach, but the Nets' chairman, Alan Aufzien, denied there was an official offer to Valvano.
In college basketball, defending champion U.N.L.V., its program and Coach Jerry Tarkanian hounded by the National Collegiate Athletic Association rules enforcers, appeared on a 30-game roll to another title. But in the tournament semifinals, Duke surprised the top-ranked Runnin' Rebels, 79-77, then dominated Kansas, 72-65. In the Blue Devils' fourth consecutive trip to the Final Four and second straight appearance in the title game, Coach Mike Krzyzewski finally received the trophy.
In a surprise Stanley Cup final, the Penguins prevailed over the Minnesota North Stars, who with only 27 regular-season victories had reached the finals after upsets over the two teams with the most triumphs, Chicago and St. Louis. In the playoffs, Mario Lemieux, the Penguins center who had missed more than half the season while recovering from spinal surgery, produced 44 points, including 16 goals. During the season, Brett Hull of the St. Louis Blues scored 86 goals.
Both the Rangers and the Devils were eliminated in the opening round of the playoffs, but later fortified their rosters. The Rangers obtained center Mark Messier, then rewarded him with a five-year $13 million contract. The Devils acquired defenseman Scott Stephens and forward Stephane Richer. The Islanders, who traded Pat Lafontaine to Buffalo, were scheduled to be sold to a group of Long Island businessmen.
 
New Hero Emerges
 John Daly emerged as an instant folk hero by winning the Professional Golfers Association championship with booming tee shots of more than 300 yards at Crooked Stick. Payne Stewart won the United States Open at Hazeltine National in an 18-hole playoff with Scott Simpson. Ian Woosnam of Wales put on the Masters green jacket and Ian Baker-Finch of Australia took the British Open at Royal Birkdale. Chip Beck's 59 on 13 birdies in Las Vegas equaled Al Geiberger's PGA Tour record.
Jack Nicklaus won the Senior Open but a Long Island club pro, Jim Albus, stunned Lee Trevino in a Senior Players Championship duel. Among the women, Meg Mallon had a rare double: the Women's Open and the L.P.G.A. title.
In tennis, Connors's march at the United States Open ended in the semifinals against Jim Courier, the French Open champion, who lost to Stefan Edberg in the final. Monica Seles won the women's title. After having won both the Australian Open and the French Open, the 17-year-old Yugoslav strangely snubbed Wimbledon, provoking fines of $26,000. She then refused to play in the Federation Cup and was banned from the 1992 Olympics. Michael Stich and Steffi Graf produced a German sweep of singles at Wimbledon.
The unbeaten heavyweight boxing champion, Holyfield, twice retained the title. He earned a 12-round decision over 42-year-old George Foreman and stopped Bert Cooper in the seventh round after arising from a third-round knockdown, the first of his pro career. Mike Tyson twice conquered Donovan (Razor) Ruddock. Sugar Ray Leonard retired, finally, after being clearly outpointed by the superwelterweight champion, Terry Norris.
In thoroughbred racing, Hansel won both the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes after Strike the Gold took the Kentucky Derby. In the Breeders' Cup, the Classic went to Black Tie Affair after Arazi, a two-year-old who had raced in France, streaked in the Juvenile. Angel Cordero rode his 7,000th winner. In harness racing, Giant Victory took the Hambletonian.
With his fourth triumph in the Indianpolis 500, Rick Mears shared the record with Al Unser and A. J. Foyt, who at age 56 drove there for the record 34th and perhaps last time following leg injuries in a 1990 crash. Michael Andretti, winning eight races, took the Indy-car title. Dale Earnhardt earned his fifth stock-car championship, but was briefly upstaged when 51-year-old Harry Gant won four consecutive races.
In the world gymnastics championships, Kim Zmeskal, a 15-year-old Texan, was the first American to win the women's all-around title. After two consecutive Tour de France triumphs, Greg LeMond finished seventh to Spain's Miguel Indurain. Salvador Garcia of Mexico and Liz McColgan of Scotland won the New York Marathon.
For the first time in Pan American Games history, the United States didn't win the most gold medals. Cuba, the host nation, did, 140 to 130. But the Americans won the most medals, 322. The American basketball team, stocked with collegiate talent, was stunned by Puerto Rico, 73-68, and the U.S. baseball team lost to Cuba, 7-1.
As the Winter Olympics approached, A. J. Kitt was the first American in eight years to win a men's downhill on the World Cup ski tour, and 18-year-old Eric Lindros, who refused to sign with the Quebec Nordiques, loomed as Canada's hope in hockey. South Africa, reinstated by the International Olympic Committee following the end of apartheid there, intended to return in the Summer Olympics in Barcelona.
With the upheaval in the Soviet Union, the Soviet republics are not likely to be quite so dominant in the Olympics. The three seceding Baltic states (Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia) were quickly recognized by the International Olympic Committe as separate competing nations. And the structure of the new team or teams that might represent the new commonwealth of former Soviet republics is in turmoil. Another harsh reminder of the impact on sports, in 1991, of the world's raw reality.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Pan Am Demise Hits Caribbean

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
THE demise of Pan American World Airways on Dec. 4, on the brink of the big season in the Caribbean, has created a pinch for flights there and back.
The airline had held onto its South and Central American business despite declaring bankruptcy Jan. 8, 1991, and also its routes to the Caribbean, Mexico and Bermuda, three vacation areas where it had a longstanding reputation and where it focused its hopes for rebuilding. But Pan Am never made it into the season of bigger cash flow. And the timing of its expiration has affected both northern tourists and Caribbean nationals returning home for the holidays. In the jargon of the industry, lack of lift is affecting some islands and cruise vessels that sail from island ports. 
 Travel agents say it is now hard to find discounted seats on weekends to some places in the eastern Caribbean, and, beyond that, impossible to find any seats at all for close-in January weekends. These are the visible waves in the storm, but there is also a building undertow that may have a longer-term impact for travelers, as well as for the islands that depend upon them.
"The loss of the competition may drive prices of air fares up," said Marcella Martinez, a spokeswoman for the Caribbean Tourism Organization. "Our advantage is our lovely, inexpensive hotels and resorts. But if it costs $800 a person to get there, the advantage is eaten up."
Another travel official in the Caribbean said American Airlines was now an almost exclusive carrier in many areas, as Delta was in the South, and that discounts were tougher to negotiate. "No one has taken Pan Am's place," this official, Gene Conry of Regency Cruises, said, "just as no one took Eastern's place, so we have a compounded impact."
 
Barbados Traffic Hit
 A weekend ticket to Barbados, which is now served on a direct-flight basis from New York only by American Airlines and B.W.I.A., is a difficult item at the moment. The Caribbean Tourism Organization estimates that Pan Am brought in 30 percent of the island's United States visitors. In terms of all passengers, including visiting Barbadians, Pan Am carried 14 percent between January and July this year, compared with American Airlines' 13 percent and B.W.I.A.'s 21 percent.
According to Tom Fredo, a spokesman for the Barbados Board of Tourism, the United States is the biggest source of tourists for Barbados, and New York ranks first among the states. That means that the loss of Pan Am's daily nonstop early-morning Flight 219 from Kennedy International Airport, which got the visitor on the beach by midafternoon, represents a loss of convenience for New Yorkers as well as a loss of 150-odd seats a day. American Airlines has a daily flight leaving at 7:50 A.M. but it stops in San Juan, P.R. There is nonstop service on B.W.I.A., leaving at 9 A.M., and arriving about the same time as American, about 2:45 P.M., and these are the flights that are sold out on weekends. Anyone who is willing to connect in San Juan can get to Barbados.
Ann Oberhaus Mackin, president of Sterling Travel in Bedford Hills, N.Y., said "all of the popular destinations" -- Barbados, St. Martin and St. Thomas -- were sold out at lower fares. "I can get weekend tickets at $700," Ms. Mackin said, "but people are not going for that." Access to St. Martin, she said, is important as a gateway to places that her Westchester and Manhattan clients want to visit -- Anguilla, St. Barts and St. Thomas.
"But when I suggest midweek," Ms. Mackin said, "I am surprised at how many people can split their weeks, and then we can manage."
Other sorts of adjustments are being made by cruise companies that had put their passengers on Pan Am flights to get to departure ports. Mr. Conry of Regency Cruises said that the crush over the holidays was terrible, persisting into January. In some cases, passengers who would have flown from Newark are being bused to Kennedy to be flown to their embarkation point. "They aren't happy," said Mr. Conry, assistant manager of air-sea. "But they do understand."
United, which bought the rights to Pan Am's routes, subject to Government approval, has not yet said which services it will operate. Rumors say that Barbados is a good possibility, but Lynn Martenstein, a United spokeswoman, said on Dec. 23 that nothing had been decided.
However, before the Pan Am purchase, United announced it was starting a service from New York to Caracas, Venezuela, and then to Trinidad. This will compensate for the loss of Pan Am's daily service to Trinidad, the southernmost island in the Caribbean. United is also adding some business service to South America in February and March.
Delta began a new service into St. Thomas in mid-December from Atlanta, which may relieve some pressure there, although Pan Am ran two Virgin Island flights daily from Miami and one from New York.
 
Continental Adds Seats
 Continental and American are adjusting by shifting planes around and changing itineraries. . Continental put a wide-body plane on its Saturday service to St. Thomas and St. Croix, leaving a smaller plane on the run on the six other days. The line formerly served Montego Bay, Jamaica, and then Kingston, but dropped Kingston because of lack of demand. Ned Walker, a Continental spokesman, said this created more seats for Montego Bay. Through such steps, Mr. Walker said, Continental has increased by 13 percent its seat allocations from Newark to "key leisure destinations."
In March, American will start using widebody planes for both of its flights into Barbados through San Juan, increasing capacity by 150 seats a day. But Marty Hires, an American spokesman, said the line had not experienced great demand for Barbados. In January and February, he said, the planes were 40 percent full. In the same two months of 1990 they were only 43 percent full, he said.
A couple of travel agents said they found American unhelpful and some spokesmen for the Caribbean tourist industry said Pan Am's passing seemed to have created "an attitude problem" at American. Continental, an agent said, was more helpful and had more seats, but not all customers wanted to buy a ticket on another bankrupt airline.
Ms. Martinez of Caribbean Tourism pointed to a reality that is now a year old, or more. New Yorkers planning to go to the Caribbean in the dead of winter once made their bookings about Dec. 1. But with the bad economy and volatile ticket prices, people now wait to book until two weeks ahead, or less, so the pinch created by Pan Am means many hopeful travelers cannot get to their Caribbean destinations.
What's the best maneuver? Leave on a Tuesday or Wednesday. Or stay a day or two into the next week, which is what some Pan Am passengers did when they were stranded.
Or, you may have to allocate an extra day, but take a look at places you can reach by flying into San Juan.
And an old technique is being revived, with help from the islands: public charters on a regular schedule, weekly or more often. Key Airlines is flying tour operators' public charters from several American cities to Savannah, Ga., where flights will fan out to Caribbean points. The schedules are given in three computer services used by travel agents , but tickets must be ordered by phone.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: ART & PHOTOGRAPHY/1991;
Should They Sell? Should They Censor? Talk About Your Hard Choices

BYLINE: By Michael Kimmelman

 BODY:
The Mario Cuomo Award -- To the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., for deciding that it cannot decide if a Greek kouros it bought for around $9 million in 1985 is a fake.
Closest Call -- Blaming what it called "adverse publicity," the Barnes Foundation withdrew its petition to a Pennsylvania court for the right to go against the wishes of its founder and sell paintings from its remarkable collection. 
 Biggest Miscalculation -- The hitherto diffident National Museum of American Art in Washington provoked charges of censorship when it threatened to exclude from an exhibition a work by Sol LeWitt. The museum's director deemed it "degrading and offensive" to women.
Second Biggest Miscalculation -- The hitherto diffident National Museum of American Art in Washington provoked charges of political correctness with its haranguing presentation of the exhibition "West as America."
Best One-Two Combination by a Painter -- A tie between Brice Marden and Chuck Close, each of whom organized provocative exhibitions drawn from the collections of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, respectively, and followed those up with outstanding solo shows.
Best One-Two Combination by a Sculptor -- Vito Acconci for his gigantic bras at the Gladstone Gallery and his gigantic clamshell in the Whitney Biennial.
Art vs. Architecture, Round 1 -- A knockdown of art at the new Frankfurt Museum of Modern Art.
Art vs. Architecture, Round 2 -- A draw at the National Gallery of London's new Sainsbury Wing, whose exterior was derided as "mediocre slime" in one architecture magazine but whose interior proved hospitable to the sublime collection of Italian Renaissance paintings.
Alarming Signs That the Recession Has Hit the Museum World -- The closed galleries and curtailed visiting hours at the Brooklyn Museum and Detroit Institute of Arts because of cutbacks in public support, and the decision by the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston to raise cash by renting works from its collection to a museum in Japan.
Signs That the Museum World Is Flourishing Nonetheless -- The retrospectives of Andre Breton and Gericault in Paris, of Seurat in Paris and New York, of Constable in London, and of Liubov Popova, Stuart Davis and Ad Reinhardt in New York and Los Angeles.
Most Inspired Idea for a Show -- The partial re-creation by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art of "Degenerate Art," the exhibition organized by the Nazis in Munich in 1937.

LENGTH: 2599 words

HEADLINE: Experiencing the Spirit of Zen

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD; JAMES STERNGOLD is a correspondent in the Tokyo bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
PASS through the weathered wooden gate of Kyoto's huge Daitokuji temple complex, walk along the mud and stone walls of hidden gardens, past the schoolchildren taking a short cut through the old cedars, and at the north end of this neatly manicured realm, turn up a narrow walled path and, to the left, enter the nondescript little gate marked with a faded wooden sign that reads "Zazen."
Inside lies a Japan that few foreigners -- or Japanese, for that matter -- come in contact with these days. It is not just an entry to an exquisite Zen Buddhist temple and handsome garden, of which there are many in Kyoto, but to a place where zazen -- sitting meditation -- is a way of life and not a cultural curiosity. 
 In this case, it is also a way open to foreigners. For those who have read Alan Watts or D. T. Suzuki, two famous Zen Buddhist scholars, and wondered about the world they describe, for those who like to travel and also to meditate, or for those who wish to encounter a different, if increasingly isolated Japan, there are still many urban and rural zazen centers to explore.
It is a rigorous discipline certainly not accessible to everyone, although not the remote, esoteric practice that some made zazen out to be in the 1960's. Zazen can be extremely relaxing as well as a way to see Japan with a more appreciative eye.
Much of the country's greatest art, be it haiku poetry, calligraphy, ink-drawn scrolls, the tea ceremony, flower arranging or even traditional garden design have been inspired by the austere and elusive Zen spirit. To practice Zen meditation surrounded by the culture is a way of touching the esthetic more deeply than through a casual visit.
That is an especially important alternative approach to Japan at a time when it is viewed increasingly by the West, and even many Japanese, as an aggressive economic machine devoted to the computer chip and the Walkman. The country is not the spiritual, antimaterialist haven some 1960's enthusiasts mistakenly made it out to be, but neither is it just a predatory industrial juggernaut without a soul. It is a complicated society, and zazen helps bring that out.
The zazen centers range from mountain redoubts where the adepts live ascetic lives, to open centers in some big cities where visitors are welcomed at regular meditation sessions under the guidance of experienced priests. Foreigners can take part by stopping by for an hour or two at designated times or, in some instances, by staying for several days of meditation, work and typical vegetarian cuisine.
Don't expect a Magical Mystery Tour with levitating swamis and out of body experiences, however. While some forms of transcendental meditation popular in the United States promise such experiences, zazen is a quieter and more personal discipline. It is about finding a higher reality through concentration, not escaping reality. In simpler terms, zazen is an attempt to put the normal cares and concerns of the day behind for a short while, and even distance oneself from the rigors of common logic; thoughts are not erased, they just flow in and out with great freedom. Zazen can also be physically grueling for those unused to spending long periods of time in the lotus or half-lotus positions, but not a terrible challenge for those who are reasonably limber.
Zen Buddhism came to Japan from China, where it flowered in the sixth century. In the 12th century it began to spread through Japan. In the process it took on unique traits and began to influence the arts, under the guidance of several famous Zen priests.
It differs from other schools of Buddhism in many ways, but two key points are its emphasis on making meditation its central tenet rather than adherence to a particular scripture or doctrine and a lack of the elements usually associated with a religion. D. T. Suzuki preferred to describe Zen as "a cloud floating in the sky," rather than as an organized religion. Indeed, Zen is most often defined by describing what it is not.
This may be difficult for Westerners to grasp, but religion in general plays a very different role in Japan. People rarely worship, in the Western sense, and freely mix rituals from Shinto, Buddhism and Christianity to mark events like marriages or funerals. Few, in fact, practice zazen, not many Zen temples have zazen sessions, and even those who do meditate do not always consider themselves Zen Buddhists. It is not considered a form of worship, but a discipline, a way to self-knowledge, or simply a way to unwind. It is not, for instance, comparable to taking Holy Communion in a Catholic church. Thus, people of many religions feel comfortable trying zazen without a sense that it calls into question their religious devotion.
Zen's influence over the culture has spread in part because Japan's rulers began to patronize Zen hundreds of years ago. Zen was thus adopted by the highest classes, and through them its principles began to shape a range of Japanese arts, stripping away the seemingly frivolous and creating meaning with impressively austere metaphors or flicks of the brush.
It is one of the many contradictions -- and attractions -- of Zen that it has so few serious followers in Japan yet has come to seem the very essence of Japanese culture.
There is no orthodox zazen routine, and even within the various Zen sects different priests follow slightly different paths. They all include some form of sitting, usually on pillows set on mats, for periods of an hour or more. It is a good idea, although not essential, to have had some experience before meditating at the Japanese centers. Many of the centers also perform walking meditation, known as kinhin, which is less demanding.
Staying overnight or for several days at some of the zazen centers generally follows an even more rigorous routine. The food is all vegetarian, the days usually begin early, sometimes at 3:30 A.M., and one's time is divided between meditation, instruction, chores and eating, with only a little free time. Most activities are communal.
Take, for instance, a session at Ryosen-an, the temple that lies behind the zazen sign at Daitokuji in Kyoto. The sessions usually begin at 7 A.M. (Those who need English instruction should show up a half hour earlier. The abbot, Taiun Matsunami, speaks excellent English.) At that hour, Kyoto is whisper quiet, with dew on the leaves and little sense of the modern city it has become.
Ryosen-an was rebuilt after the war by an American, Ruth Fuller Sasaki, who was not only a devoted Zen Buddhist but did some important translations of Buddhist works into English. She died in 1968. As a result of her work the center tries to have an American woman in residence, said Taiun-san. He insists on "appropriate dress," which means loose-fitting clothing that covers the arms and the legs.
The first impression on entering the open meditation hall, in a traditional wood building facing a garden, is a faint scent of incense. You remove shoes and socks, bow to the altar and then choose a spot on the woven straw tatami mats, where you settle on two firm pillows. The room is generally the same temperature as outside, so one should have somewhat warmer clothes in winter.
Taiun-san describes the proper way to sit -- he prefers a half-lotus, a cross-legged position with the right leg under the left and the knees pressing forward on the pillow. The three important points are posture, a straight back and relaxed shoulders, breathing, which you count to make it even and deep, and the eyes remaining open enough to let light in, but not enough to see anything clearly.
The aim is to "still the waters of the mind," as Taiun-san puts it, to escape normal rational thought and to observe oneself from a removed perspective. Some forms of zazen use a technique of focusing on a koan, or a kind of riddle built around a contradictory statement -- "When you clap your hands together a sound arises. Listen to the sound of one hand." -- to paralyze, in a sense, routine ways of thinking and achieve a different state. Taiun-san, however, teaches students to focus on their breathing, so that one's thoughts flow in and flow out with the air.
The meditation begins with the resonant peal of a bell, which Taiun-san rings four times. He then leads the group in a walking meditation, in which you pace slowly, eyes barely open, around the perimeter of the room. After about four turns, the pace picks up, the only sound a slight shuffling and breathing.
Participants then resume the half-lotus position on the pillows. There is no sound. What many beginners find most difficult is keeping their eyes open just the right amount. When the eyes close totally, there is a tendencyto fall asleep, which is when the famous wooden stick or paddle comes in. Its use can differ slightly in each temple, but in general it is wielded by a priest and applied lightly to heads and shoulders to make sure participants stay awake and to ease the strain of weary muscles. The bell is rung once to mark the end of the hour.
For those who want to plunge into an extended experience with zazen in a wonderful location, Eiheiji, one of the main temples of the Soto Zen sect, offers stays of up to three days. English-speaking visitors can arrange to have an interpreter on hand. The temple is situated in lush mountains near the Japan Sea, not far from Fukui City. The schedule is rigorous. The grounds, which are kept spick-and-span by the zazen practitioners, are quite handsome, with huge and lovely old cedars.
One must be familiar with sitting in the half-lotus position to take on a longer visit. Visitors are expected to act like trainees. The routine begins in late afternoon, when visitors arrive, bathe privately, and then have supper as a group at 5 P.M. Shortly afterwards a video offering instruction is shown, and there is a zazen session. Everyone is in bed at 9 P.M. Private rooms are available for small mixed groups, but generally men and women sleep separately, in Japanese-style beds, futon on tatami mats.
The next day gets off to a very early start -- at 3:30 A.M. The first zazen begins 20 minutes later for about an hour. That is followed by a morning service of chanting sutras, or Buddhist texts, and reading and a tour of the temple's beautiful grounds. Visitors will be taught the few words they need to know for chanting. A light vegetarian breakfast of tofu, vegetables and tea is served at 7 A.M. Participants then do chores, mostly cleaning stairs and other areas of the temple, until the late-morning zazen starts at 10 A.M. Lunch is served to all at noon, followed by another work period and then more zazen, from 2 to 4 P.M. Dinner is at 5 P.M., followed by a late meditation session, then back to bed before rising early again for the last day's meditation and departure.
There is only a little free time for participants. They can chat and mix, but not during the meditation sessions. For the most part, one's time is tightly controlled.
To adepts, zazen can be a means to everything from self-knowledge to contentment. It is also a form of deep relaxation in a serene place for those whose expectations run to something less than enlightenment.
Tom Wright, an American who has lived in Kyoto for 24 years and is a priest in the Soto sect, prefers the word sitting to meditation. His sect uses no koan or other verbal focus, but attempts in zazen to reduce the influence of the ego and just let thoughts flow by in uninterrupted form. "My advice to newcomers to zazen is not to suppress, not to reject, and not to chase after," Mr. Wright said.
 
 
 
TEMPLES WHERE THE VISITOR IS WELCOME TO SIT AND CONTEMPLATE
 Following are a handful of the many zazen centers that can be visited in Japan. These temples can recommend others, and the Japan National Tourist Office in Kyoto can also help; telephone (075) 371-5649.
 
Fukui City
 Kokusaibu Eiheiji, Eiheiji-cho, Yoshida-gun, Fukui-ken, 910-12; telephone (0776) 63-3640.
The center, near Fukui City, about 200 miles west of Tokyo, was founded in the 13th century and is a training ground for priests. Its lovely tree-shaded grounds also attract scores of tourists, mostly Japanese. Five hours from Tokyo by bullet train and then regular train to Fukui City; then by bus.
Sanzensha, or lay practice, is set up as a three-night, two-day stay. Guests are expected to bring loose-fitting clothes in subdued colors and white socks. The Japanese priests wear tabi, the cotton socks with an articulation between the big and second toes (so they can be worn with sandals). The temples will lend guests the loose robes worn for meditation, meals and other functions. An interpreter can be provided.
The sanzensha schedule costs $23.50 a night (calculated at 127 yen to the dollar), including meals, a bargain for a stay at such a lovely spot, with extra charges for laundry and some of the implements needed. A more intensive program, called sanrosha, lasts two days and one night and costs $55..
Reservations should be made more than a month ahead, by mail, with international reply coupons included. Applicants should provide name, address, phone number, age, sex, reason for wanting to experience zazen at Eiheiji, general health and preferred dates for the visit. Alternative dates should be provided.
 
 
Kamakura
 Engakuji, 409 Yamanouchi, Kamakura-shi, Kanagawa-ken; (0467) 22-0478.
On the tree-shaded north side of Kamakura, Engakuji is one of the lovelier spots to practice zazen, but it is for those already adept at meditation. Kamakura, about an hour south of Tokyo, was an ancient capital and is filled with temples and shrines. Engakuji, a two-minute walk from the Kita-Kamakura train station, on the Yokosuka line, was founded in 1282. Engakuji does not provide instruction in English. Zazen is held every day from 5:30 to 6:30 A.M. from March to October, and from 6 to 7:00 A.M. from November to February. There is no charge; call to double check time.
 
Kyoto
 Sosenji, Takakura Gojo Kudaru, Shimokyo-ku, Kyoto-shi; (075) 351-4270. Tom Wright can be reached at (075) 752-0421.
Sesenji is not far from the main Kyoto train station. It is also a Soto Zen temple, and is open to visitors for zazen on the first and third Mondays of every month (except January and August). The sessions run from 6 to 9 P.M. It is free of charge, and Mr. Wright offers instruction in English.
Ryosen-an, 107 Daitokuji-cho, Murasakino, Kita-ku, Kyoto-shi; (075) 491-0543.
Ryosen-an, a Rinzai Zen temple, can be reached by taking the number 205 bus from the Kyoto station. It takes about 35 minutes. Reservations must be made. The sessions are held on Wednesday and Sunday from 7 to 8:30 A.M. Taiun Matsunami, the abbot, provides English instruction, if necessary, starting at 6:30 A.M.
 
Yokohama
 Sojiji, 2-1-1 Tsurumi, Tsurumi-ku, Yokohama City 230; (045) 581-6021.
An hour's train ride south of Tokyo, Sojiji goes out of its way to welcome guests, foreign as well as Japanese, and has put together seven different programs, running from a few hours to eight days, depending on one's appetite for the discipline. The temple is a campus-like cluster of buildings in a commercial neighborhood. Sojiji is the other principal temple in the Soto Zen sect. Ikuo Azuma, a pleasant, elderly priest with a warm and welcoming air, offers instruction in English. The cost is $39 a night, including meals, and $8 for the shorter sessions. Reservations are required. Sojiji is about a five-minute walk from the Tsurumi station, on the Keihin Tohoku line.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: DANCE/1991;
Mocking American Mores, And Shaking Off a Royal Slump

BYLINE: By Jack Anderson

 BODY:
Oddest Successful Classical Revival -- Peter Martins's New York City Ballet production of "The Sleeping Beauty" sparkled with brilliant dancing, yet its breakneck pace robbed the fairy tale of magic and humanity.
Rugged Individualists, Still -- Pina Bausch, Meredith Monk and Phoebe Neville continued to go their own choreographic ways, and it remains exciting to follow them. 
 Heartening Comeback -- The overall high standards of the Royal Ballet of London during its New York season suggested that this troupe has pulled itself out of a creative slump.
Rewarding Pilgrimage -- It was worth a journey to England to see the Birmingham Royal Ballet's revival of "Choreartium," Leonide Massine's monumentally scaled masterpiece.
Rhythmic Wonders -- Slapping their bodies while swaying and twisting, the participants in the "Music and Dance of Sumatra" program at the Joyce Theater made astonishing music out of their dancing.
Serious Jesters -- Donald Byrd in "The Minstrel Show" and Stephanie Skura in "The Bad Play" provoked thought as well as laughter by spoofing theatrical conventions and satirizing American society.
Soulful Soloist -- Alarmel Valli's recital of Indian Bharata Natyam dancing invested technically intricate movements with spiritual radiance.
Perpetual Question -- Does the proliferation of abstract ballets in the style of George Balanchine represent a development of the Balanchine tradition or a reduction of that tradition to dry compositional formulas?
Storm Clouds -- Attempts to place content restrictions on works eligible for National Endowment for the Arts grants, as well as the slashing of arts budgets due to nationwide economic troubles, still darken the dance scene.
In Memoriam -- Although Martha Graham, Margot Fonteyn, Richard Englund, Robert Irving, Roman Jasinski, Eleanor King, Irina Nijinska, Ruth Page, Olga Spessivtzeva, Edward Stierle and Muriel Stuart died this year, they continue to enrich our lives with their talents.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: VIDEO & AUDIO/1991;
It's a Great Movie. Now, if They Can Just Get It Into the Cassette.

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:
Biggest -- It earned $185 million at the box office and won seven Academy Awards, but "Dances With Wolves" was never bigger than in its first week in video stores, when the nearly 1,200 feet of tape required for the three-hour movie frequently caused it to spill off its spools and jam inside the cassette.
You Heard the Man -- "There will be no colorized 'Citizen Kane,' " said Martin Weinstein, vice president of Turner Home Entertainment, on the occasion of the classic's 50th-anniversary release in August. 
 Wait, It Gets Worse -- Carrying on the tradition of extremely bad major motion pictures that do well in video stores were "Bonfire of the Vanities" in April and, pushed out there last month, "Hudson Hawk," both of them top renters.
Best How-To -- In the catalogue for its Library of African Cinema video series, California Newsreel had these suggestions for those watching movies by African film makers: "Scenes unfold at a measured pace, with the deliberation of story-telling or folk tales. . . don't fight these differences; try to appreciate the timeless rhythms and ordered life of a less industrialized society. . . imagine what these same stories would look like if they had been directed by Spike Lee or David Lynch, starring Eddie Murphy. . . ."
Best Beginner -- "Fantasia," out for the first time last month, is O.K., but even better is "Les Enfants du Paradis" ("Children of Paradise"), the Marcel Carne masterpiece released in September.
Here, Try Mine -- Promoting his own documentary about Jim Morrison and the Doors, the rock group's keyboardist, Ray Manzarek, said this about Oliver Stone's film "The Doors," released on tape about the same time: "He made us look like jerks. . . . Everything Oliver Stone didn't portray, that's what I portray."
What Next? -- In a scheme to get video stores to buy more copies of hot releases, Rank Video Services, a tape duplicator in California, came up with a cassette that erases the movie after 25 plays.
All Together Now -- "Three Tenors in Concert," starring Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras, climbed to No. 3 on the Billboard video best-seller list, the highest spot ever for a classical performance title.
Best Offer of the Recession -- A seven-cassette "Godfather" Collectors Edition with the three Coppola films and a how-they-made-it documentary, for $150.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: ANTIQUES/1991;
Baseball Cards, Blobs and Bauble It Was That Kind of a Year In the Art Market

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
Score One for Reunification -- The manuscript of most of Gustav Mahler's unfinished Symphony No. 10 escaped the auction block when the Austrian National Library bought it just one day before it was to be sold by Sotheby's. The library has long owned the rest of the manuscript.
Recession-Proof Silver -- A sterling rococo dish by the 18th-century silversmith Paul de Lamerie was sold for $2.6 million at Christie's, defying the downward trend in prices for most antiques. 
 Pioneering Performance -- Space-age masks proved as terrifying and magical as those from ancient and tribal cultures at the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition "Modern Masks and Helmets," a first on the subject.
A Bounty for a Bauble Box -- Marie Antoinette's jewelry-cabinet-on-a-stand brought $4.9 million at a court-ordered sale in Paris of the collection of Roberto Polo, the Cuban-born financier who became a fugitive. The buyer, the French banker and sugar king Jean Marc Vernes, said that upon his death the piece would return to Versailles.
Two Out of Three -- Determined to repatriate all three of the American Indian ceremonial masks she bought for $39,050 at Sotheby's, Elizabeth Sackler returned two to the Hopi nation. The third is being studied by two other tribes.
Kwakiutl Treasures From the Attic -- Stored for 90 years at the American Museum of Natural History, 120 masks, bowls and figures from its stunning collection of art from the Northwest Coast tribe were displayed at an acclaimed exhibition.
A Fortune for Ephemera -- A 1910 baseball card showing Honus Wagner, the Pittsburg Pirates shortstop, became the costliest single collectible ever auctioned when it was sold for $451,000 at Sotheby's to Wayne Gretzky, the Los Angeles Kings hockey superstar, and Bruce McNall, the club's owner.
Ancient Mystery -- Despite a three-year restoration, little new information was revealed about the witty Paracas tapestry of masked figures at the Brooklyn Museum, although the 2,000-year-old pre-Columbian work, depicting a glorious feast, remains one of the museum's most satisfying objects.
Banner Year for Blobs -- The biomorphic style of the mid-20th century -- as seen in the amoeba-shaped tables of Isamu Noguchi, the curvy chairs of Charles and Ray Eames, and the chubby salt-and-pepper shakers of Eva Zeisel -- took place of pride at three New York exhibitions: at the I.B.M. Gallery, the Museum of Modern Art and the Brooklyn Museum.
Intimacy in Cosmic Scenes -- In the most important Japanese screen exhibition ever held in this country, "The Triumph of Japanese Style" at the Cleveland Museum of Art, bold strokes captured sweeping landscapes, epic legends and the entire city of Kyoto, yet always with delicate, humanizing details.
