HEADLINE: Hope Dims for Saving a Millbrook Mansion

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: MILLBROOK, N.Y.

 BODY:
DECAY chips relentlessly at Halcyon Hall, a vast and vacant 200-room mansion built in the Tudor style that for nearly a century has towered over the rustic village homes of Millbrook, N.Y, like a lord over his serfs. But the market is weak and government agencies are feuding, and a result is that the building may be beyond repair -- assuming there is anyone ready to undertake that task.
Halcyon Hall may become one of the more dramatic examples in the Northeast of the architectural losses in prospect as agencies like the Resolution Trust Corporation, charged with disposing of thousands of foreclosed properties as efficently and economically as possible, overwhelm other agencies seeking to preserve these symbols of the nation's history. 
 For the last year, Halycon Hall has been snared in a controversy pitting the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation against the goals of the National Register of Historic Places. The F.D.I.C., through its marketing agency, has been trying to block the Hall's nomination as a landmark to keep marketing options wide open. The New York State Office of Historic Preservation has continued to champion the nomination, arguing that it could help keep Halycon Hall standing.
Friends of Halcyon Hall, a group organized to save the Hall, maintains that such feuding has not only held up the nomination but also has resulted in fewer attempts to stabilize the structure. "It's already open to the elements and anyone can just walk in," said David Sloan, the group's executive director.
Similar clashes are occurring over historic buildings in such places as Colorado, New Hampshire and the District of Columbia. And lawyers say it may be a long time before a definitive conclusion can be reached on whose objectives take precedent.
In the meantime, said Andrea Ferster, an assistant general counsel to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a private, nonprofit organization, "agencies like the R.T.C. and F.D.I.C. are not even making minimal efforts to maintain the historic properties they have in inventory."
Instead, she maintained, they are selling to the highest bidder. "They're certainly not insisting on the kind of protective convenants other Federal agencies put in place before they sell off the historic buildings they might own," she added.
Properties she is monitoring that she insists are facing such problems include an opera house in Telluride, Colo., and an old Spanish mission in San Augustine, Tex.
But Andrew Porterfield, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C., said that, in general, his agency did not "just let these properties rot while we're preparing them for sale." He also said the agency gives preservation groups a 60-day exclusive marketing period for all historic properties and provides 100 percent financing.
KATE SPEARS, a spokeswoman for the R.T.C., said it also routinely alerts local preservation groups before placing such properties on the market. In fact, she noted, a building in in a Biloxi, Miss., historic district was recently given free to a community group after a determination that the building would have "no redeeming recovery value."
Preservationists, however, are seeking legislation to force the agencies to take more substantial steps to preserve historic structures in their inventory. One of the first proposals, sponsored by Representative Bruce F. Vento of Minnesota and Peter Hoagland of Nebraska, both Democrats, would require the R.T.C. to maintain historic properties at the same standard as when they were first received into inventory.
The amendment was dropped but a spokesman for Mr. Vento said the Represented intended to reintroduce it in March.
It is little wonder, then, that future of Halcyon Hall, caught in the middle of the agency wars, appears far from halcyon. It historic signifcance, however, is in little doubt. "Its an absolute landmark," insisted Gary Ciferri, Mayor of Millbrook, a well-to-do town noted for its horse breeders.
Utilizing expensive cobblestone foundations, half timbering, leaded-glass windows, patterned wood shingles, towers and broad terraces, the main strucuture was built in the 1890's as a luxury hotel combined with a country retreat for Henry J. Davison Jr, a publisher. But it was soon turned into a girls' finishing school and eventually became Bennett College.
IT has been empty since Bennett College went bankrupt in 1978. It was then repossessed by the New York Bank for Savings and has been mired in financial problems since.
The subsequent owner also defaulted before doing anything with the property. Once again it was repossessed by the New York Bank for Savings. In 1983, James J. O'Dea, a Millbrook developer and civil engineer, bought the 34-acre campus and its 250,000 square feet of buildings from the bank for about $10 a square foot and a willingness to pay off $700,000 in unpaid property taxes.
HE turned the newer dormitories into Halcyon Village, a 38-unit condominum complex completed in the mid-80's. He took the president's house and 7 acres for his own use. And he planned to turn the original buildings into a conference center at an estimated cost of $9 million.
Although the town was behind the idea ("we would have even entertained tax incentives," said Mr. Ciferri), Mr. O'Dea's ambitious plans never materalized. He sold the Hall in 1989 together with some of the remaining "smaller pieces" for $2 million to a development affiliate of Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank of Bridgeport, Conn. New talk of redevelopment began, "but no formal proposals were received," said Mr. Ceferrai. In October 1991 the Bridgeport bank failed and certain assets it owned, including Halcyon Hall, fell to the F.D.I.C.
In December the New York State Office of Historic Preservation approved the hall's nomination to the National Register -- put forward by the local preservation group in the spring of 1991. The agency eventually went ahead, said Lloyd Adams, its counsel, since the objections did not come from a private owner. Only a private owner can legitimately object to a nomination, he asserted.
Mr. O'Dea considers the move suicidal, arguing that nomination will deter a buyer since it could add "at least $3 million" to any redevelopment program and thus may further depress the appeal of the hall. And George T. Whalen, Jr., president of the Bank of Millbrook, thinks that after a decade of decay, chances of redeeming the hall are dim even though its probable market value is now nominal, given the tight commercial lending climate.
But Friends of Halcyon Hall haven't given up. They are trying to interest developers even though they do not have ownership. They are working with local officials to create more specific tax incentives. And they are trying to force the F.D.I.C. to better maintain it.
"We're going to give it our best shot," said Mr. Sloan.

HEADLINE: Talking: Mortgages;
Whether To Retain A Broker

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IT'S increasingly likely that anyone seeking to finance or refinance a home may be planning to do so through a mortgage broker. The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest investor in home mortgages, estimates that by the end of 1991 about 37 percent of all mortgages it is financing originated through brokers, compared with 27 percent in 1989.
A mortgage broker acts as an intermediary between borrower and lender, seeking the best rates and terms for the borrower by shopping among many lenders and helping compile the documentation needed to qualify the borrower. 
 The use of mortgage brokers for residential transactions dates to the recession of the early 80's, when mortgage lending ground to a halt. Some institutional lending officers thrown out of work began offering to bring in to their former employers and other bankers home-buying customers and handle all the loan-originationpaperwork in exchange for a percentage of the origination charges. Some estate brokers followed suit, viewing it as a way to earn an extra commission.
However, so many people with questionable credentials began rushing into the business and controls remained so limited that regulatory agencies began receiving an avalanche of complaints about shoddy dealings -- the most common being over upfront fees retained for loans that never materialized.
As a result, some 34 states now license mortgage brokers to regulate conduct and set a minimum level of proficiency. Further, the 15-year-old National Association of Mortgage Brokers has been working to raise industry standards and instill a stricter code of ethics.
Even so, sentiment remains mixed over using a mortgage broker. Consider, for example, the contrasting experiences of William and Victoria Masters of Manhattan and Beth Carpenter of Stamford, Conn.
Mr. and Mrs. Masters, who work long hours in television production, initially turned to a broker because they did not have time to shop for a loan. But they maintain that their application for a $225,00 loan was delayed so long by the broker that it nearly cost them the triplex apartment they were buying in lower Manhattan.
With no approval in sight and no apparent reason for the holdup, Mr. Masters said, they decided to withdraw their application and seek a lender directly. They got a commitment in a few days, he said, but it took months to get the broker to return their $500 in application fees.
Beth Carpenter, on the other hand, says she might never have got a low-cost, fixed- rate $90,000 loan had she not used a mortgage broker. A single mother on a tight budget, she had been turned down for a fixed-rate loan by the bank where she normally does business.
The bank had been willing to provide only a variable-rate loan. Unwilling to accept this because she feared future fluctuations in payments, Ms. Carpenter contacted a mortgage broker, who persuaded another lender that Ms. Carpenter was indeed qualified for the loan she sought.
All this suggests caution but also potential. Bankers confirm that a reputable broker can indeed be most valuable when borrowers are too busy to complete forms themselves. "We will even go to your house," said Joanne Satmary, executive vice president of the Source Mortgage Group in Fairfield, Conn.
Mortgage brokers are also useful when a borrower needs guidance in selecting the most suitable mortgage and help in filling out forms. And they can be crucial when a borrower's personal financial circumstances or the property are problematic.
"Only last month we were able to show a banker that if he had included the borrower's dividend income in his calculations the man would have qualified," said Ms. Satmary. "We're the borrower's advocate."
Even so, a mortgage broker should still be chosen with care. "We still get" complaints, said David Tedeschi, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Banking, echoing the views of officials in other states.
ONE safeguard is to make sure the intended broker is licensed, where applicable, and a member of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers or, even better, if that broker has ever been an officer of a local chapter. For a referral, call the association at (602) 992-6181 or write: NAMB, 706 East Bell Road, Suite 101, Phoenix, Ariz. 85022.
The association can also provide information about its standards. Jill Hoogendyk, the associate director, said borrowers should also ask for a detailed accounting of estimated fees in advance. The only initial fees the broker should request, she said, are the $300 to $500 needed to process an application and do an appraisal and credit check.
The subsequent charge -- normally 1 to 1 1/2 percent of the loan amount -- is due when the loan has been granted by a lender, known as "the "commitment." But even this charge, she said, is normally payable only on closing.
"We always allow our customers to wait," said Margaret S. Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services of Manhattan and of the Mortgage Brokers Association of New York City.
Before making a decision Ms. Scott said, a borrower should also ask the mortgage broker for the number of lenders it represents. Some brokers, she asserted, have affiliations with only a handful of lenders and a borrower should be aware of this limitation in advance. It can range from a half dozen to 30 or more.
Borrowers might also wish to check with the state licensing authority -- normally the Department of Banking -- to see if any complaints have been received lately about a broker they plan to use.
Experts say it's important to keep in mind that a mortgage broker should never cost a borrower more than going directly to a lender since the broker makes money by sharing the origination fees with the lender -- not by charging extra. Nor should it take longer. Whether a broker can indeed provide the borrower with the lowest possible rates and terms, as many claim to do, still seems to be a matter of speculation and may be impossible to verify.
To be sure they aren't overpaying, said Nicholas Lore, senior vice president of Manhattan Savings Bank, borrowers should also shop around to get a handle on prevailing rates and terms -- if only by making a few phone calls and checking newspapers. They might also wish to double-check with the lender, when told by the broker who it will be, to make sure they aren't being charged more by that lender than if they had walked through the door themselves.

HEADLINE: Cars Trickle Back To Pedestrian Malls

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
DOWNTOWN pedestrian malls, which spread across the country in the 1960's and '70's, have been plagued in recent years with slumping sales and a severe image problem.
It is estimated that there are 200 of them, and many were unable to compete successfully in the 80's with the more modern malls and shopping centers on the cities' outskirts. Shoppers tended to dismiss many of the pedestrian malls -- sometimes little more than repaved older streets closed to traffic -- as inconvenient and inaccessible. 
 But the cities have not stopped trying to find ways to attract shoppers to their pedestrian malls -- often part of the main street in a smaller community or, in a big city, a major commercial street functioning as the downtown of a large neighborhood. Now many of the smaller cities that have created downtown malls, among them Poughkeepsie, N. Y., Oak Park, Ill., and Santa Monica, Calif., think they have the solution: reopening all or part of them to traffic.
In Poughkeepsie, in Dutchess County, it was a case of returning a section of the mall to the way it was before 1974. At that time, the city connected shops and department stores, some dating to the mid-1800's, with a concrete walkway. This linear shopping corridor, with benches and landscaping, and gazebos at each end, starts at Market Street, the city's main artery, and stretches east for three blocks.
For a while it thrived, with large department stores, like Wallace Company and Luckey Platt, which had a loyal following in the city since 1867. But the mall soon felt a sharp business decline as anchors and other stores left, some moving to shopping centers and enclosed malls being built on Route 9. The easternmost block of the mall was hit hardest and never really recovered.
Then, in July, the city decided to open the block up to traffic. The street now accommodates one lane of traffic and has free one-hour parking for more than 50 cars.
"Even though it's only been opened a short time, we've already seen very positive results," said Kathryn LaVanche, executive director of the Poughkeepsie Partnership, a group dedicated to revitalizing the city's downtown.
On an average weekday, merchants have clocked 160 cars on the street every hour. "The fact that the parking is free seems to be really important," said Ms. LaVanche. She explained that the mall now has several parking lots and garages, and all charge around 40 cents an hour to park. "It's laughable," she said, "but even that small a price seems to make a difference to people."
The street's opening has also attracted new businesses, resulting in its vacancy rate's declining from 31 percent to 10.7 percent. And seven formerly vacant properties now have new owners or tenants.
One of those new tenants is the Dutchess County Health Department, which now occupies a 35,000-square-foot building. The department, with 125 employees, signed a five-year lease on the building in November 1990 when the street's reopening was still in the planning stages.
"THE building has a parking lot in the back, but the idea that people would also be able to drive up to the front of the building and park was a real positive for us," said Richard C. Sewell, acting commissioner of health for Dutchess County. "Especially for our night clinics when people might feel safer parking in front of the building."
Mr. Sewell said that the department has been so happy with the location that it has just extended its lease to 10 years.
Merchants on the street think the reopening helped bolster Christmas sales this year.
"I think we did better than some of the malls, from what I've been hearing," said Stephen Browne, store manager for Woolworth's, the largest retailer on the street. "We've always attracted customers who live in the city and who walk over. But now we're also getting ones who would rather drive over here than head out to the highway to an outside mall."
Shopkeepers also believe the street's novelty worked in their favor.
"People came down just to see the change," said Paul S. Mancarella, co-owner of De's Jewelers. "I think there's a curiosity factor that's drawing customers."
"Once they're here," he said, "we have the chance to hold them by offering the kind of individualized service not available at large chain stores in modern malls."
When Poughkeepsie was considering reopening its mall, it wanted to find out what other cities with similar malls were doing. It hired Hyett Palmer, a commerical business consulting firm based in Washington, to survey cities across the country. The study, completed in 1989, took in Santa Monica, Calif.; Eugene, Ore.; Oak Park, Ill.; Sioux Falls, S. Dak.; Vicksburg, Miss.; Baltimore; Ithaca, N.Y.; Memphis, Miami Beach and St. Joseph, Mo.
Most of the malls were built in the late 60's and early 70's. The only exception is the one in Miami Beach, which was built in 1959.
In seven of the cities, the malls were successful for a few years after they built. Then business declined, due in large part to the growth of shopping centers outside the city's downtown areas. Of the 10 cities surveyed, five had either totally or partially opened their pedestrian malls to traffic in the last three or four years, and two others were considering doing so.
Only Baltimore and Ithaca believed their downtown malls were fine just the way they were. And instead of opening its mall to traffic, Memphis was considering developing a trolley system to take shoppers around.
Of the cities that reopened their malls, all reported business gains. In Oak Park, three of four blocks of the mall were opened to traffic in November 1988. This resulted in an increase in sales of 6.3 percent from 1988 to 1989. In the same period, retail occupancy went from 75 percent to 80 percent.
"We now have a lease pending that would increase retail occupancy to almost 90 percent," said Christine Burdick, executive director of Downtown Oak Park, a group that manages the mall's retail businesses. "That lease would not even have been a possibility if we hadn't opened up the streets."
IN Santa Monica, opening the mall to traffic attracted many new businesses, including restaurants, movie houses and comedy clubs. So many people now use the mall that the city has temporarily banned cars.
"There are just too many pedestrians," said Tom Carroll, executive director of the Bayside District Corporation, which manages the city's downtown. "It's not practical to have traffic passing through."
Since the road is what first drew the new businesses to the mall, "it's ironic that we're not even using it," Mr. Carroll said. "But we might again if business slows down."
Opening a mall to traffic is a major job, usually involving building a road and new sidewalks and installing new lighting and other amenities. In Poughkeepsie, it took three months to complete and cost almost $1 million. The city financed 60 percent of the project with Federal Community Development funds; the rest came from a bond issue to be repaid by the merchants on the street with tax assessments over 12 years.
A major thrust behind the project was provided by Karl Ehmer, a meat retailer known for his television commercials. In keeping with his high profile, he promised publicly to reopen his meat market, which closed in 1986, if the block was opened to traffic and to donate $250,000 to charity if the city agreed to the project.
"He's not the first merchant to suggest it," Ms. LaVance said. "But he was the first one to bring the issue before the public and that helped move things along."
When Bruce McIlravy, owner of Haber House of Wheels, a bicycle shop, was looking to move his business from another part of the city, the opening of the east block was attractive for several reasons. He wanted to be in the center of the city, but not stuck in the middle of the mall.
"I need to be in a free-standing structure," he said. "People don't want to shlep a broken bike through a mall."
MR. McIlravy's business has been in Poughkeepsie since 1919. "It keeps moving as the city grows and changes," he said, "and I think this location is the city's current hot spot." All his regular customers have managed to find him at his new location, he said, and "I'm also getting people who haven't been downtown in 10 or 15 years."
Mr. McIlravy bought two buildings on the street. He plans to use the ground floors for the bicycle business and renovate the rest for offices or apartments. "That would require a zoning use change," he said. "But I think there's a market for housing in the mall."
In most of the cities surveyed, opening the malls to traffic is only the latest attempt to revitalize their downtown shopping areas. In Poughkeepsie, $30 million has been spent on such things as rehabilitating storefronts and in new construction since 1989. In that period, 45 new businesses started up or moved downtown, and 17 closed or left. "That's a net gain of 28, which in the present economy isn't bad," said Ms. La Vanche of the Poughkeepsie Partnership.
Started four years ago, the partnership comprises an amalgam of public and private interests. On its board of directors are John E. Mack 3d, C.E.O. and chairman of Central Hudson Gas & Electric Company, and Robert A. Bleakley. the mayor of Poughkeepsie. Membership includes representatives of 160 local businesses. All will be watching closely for the success or failure of east block to determine if the process should continue throughout the rest of the mall.
"Some of the other blocks on the mall are doing better than east block did," said Ms. LaVanche. "But if the success is compelling enough, we probably will open up the rest."
The Mayor seems ready and eager for that to happen. "If the merchants on the street want it and they are willing to pay for 40 percent of it," he said, "we'll do it."

(Steve Kagan for The New York Times)(pg. 7)

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Taking Note of the Year's Events

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
EVEN as we make ready to greet the New Year, it might be well to look back at some of the cultural events that brightened (or dampened) the Connecticut music scene in 1991. Among other happenings, for instance, we greeted the arrival of the first ever:
State Troubadour: The poet, composer and balladeer Tom Callinan was appointed to that exalted post in June, after 14 years and 6 solo albums (the most recent, aptly enough called "The Connecticut Troubadour") devoted largely to writing and singing about life in New England. "The state is a vibrant patchwork of people and places," said the 44-year old Clinton resident, who added that he hoped to compile a book of local stories and songs. 
 Chief Performing Executive: "Molto bene," said Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in March, when he agreed to make his operatic debut as an American Naval officer in the Connecticut Opera production of "Madama Butterfly." His next stage outing came in October, the Governor narrating Aaron Copland's "Lincoln Portrait" at the season opener of the Eastern Connecticut Symphony.
Chamber Music Brunch: The cellist Warren Lash came up with the idea for a series of recitals in the banquet room of Zenny's Restaurant in Storrs. So starting in January, it was Mozart and muffins.
Opera Awareness Month: September was thus designated in Stamford and Bridgeport, both to honor Connecticut Grand Opera, which splits its performing allegiance between the two cities, and to encourage the enjoyment of opera by listeners of all ages. In their respective proclamations, Stamford Mayor Thom Serrani called opera "the grand collective of the performing arts," while Bridgeport Mayor Mary Moran dubbed it "a cultural resource that enhances the quality of life as well as the economic vitality of this community."
Frog Fest: As an adjunct to the summer festival at the Charles Ives Center for the Arts, Western Connecticut State University opened its campus for a series of "Sundays in the Park" with family entertainment like folk singalongs, story-telling sessions and concerts by the Danbury Brass Band. Oh, yes, the Frog Fest -- those were programs held by the pond to introduce children to the instruments of the orchestra, as well as the relationship of music and nature.
Ferry Festival: You had to take a motor launch to reach the inaugural recitals of the First Outer Island Chamber Music Festival last July, so the sponsoring Southern Connecticut State University Foundation made a social event out of it, throwing in a tour through the Thimble Islands and encouraging concertgoers to enjoy a leisurely supper on Outer Island itself.
And now the bad news. The cultural disaster of the year, of course, was the Hartford Symphony strike, forcing the cancellation of the first three sets of subscription concerts, along with events like the pops program with Henry Mancini, the annual "Messiah" performance and many others. The State Labor Board voted last month to call the impasse a lockout, so the musicians are entitled to receive unemployment compensation, but at press time the impasse had not yet been resolved.
A shimmering of light amidst the Hartford Symphony darkness: the orchestra's volunteer association is accepting applications for the 18th annual young artists competition. Open to music students in Connecticut public, private and parochial school in grades 9 through 12, the auditions this year are for piano or any of the orchestral instruments. More than $2,500 in cash prizes will be distributed, with the top winner earning an appearance with the Hartford Symphony at its Discovery Concert in May. The applications deadline is March 25; for more details call 246-8742.
Finally, congratulations to some of the organizations and artists who celebrated anniversaries in 1991. By the round numbers, they are:
10: The Emerson Quartet, celebrating its residence at the Hartt School with a recital series that continues into the spring; Litchfield Performing Arts, rounding off a gala season that featured music notables like Richard Goode, Gary Karr, Ruth Laredo and the Shanghai String Quartet, and the Fairfield Orchestra, giving 22 concerts under its founding music director, Thomas Crawford.
15: The Greater Bridgeport Symphony's William and Francis Carlson and Ruth Carlson Horn Competition for Young Instrumentalists, a blessing through the years for so many emerging performers, and Frank Brieff, who has showcased so many deserving young artists during his 15 years as music director of the Waterbury Symphony.
20: Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, co-founders of Chamber Music Plus, marked two decades of performing and personal togetherness, as did the Chamber Players of the Greenwich Symphony, and Gustav Meier, who last month began his 20th year as music director of the Greater Bridgeport Symphony. The Symphony's Youth Orchestras, by the way, completed their own 30th anniversary season in 1991.
25: The Yale Symphony, which lowered the ticket price of its silver anniversary concert in March concert to 25 cents.
40: The New Haven Chorale, celebrating a proud history of performances from the New Haven Green to Manhattan.
45: Three cheers (and one cheer more) for the Troupers Light Opera Company, whose Gilbert and Sullivan productions through the years have given a high new meaning to the phrase "community theater."
50: Modestly billing its October production as "a breathtaking extravaganza of mammoth proportions," Connecticut Opera began its golden anniversary season in September with 20 horses, 4 camels, 2 elephants, 1 zebra and "Aida."
75: The Connecticut Federation of Music and Dance Clubs, continuing to provide performing opportunities to gifted young artists.
95: "The Bible says Moses lived till the age of 120," said Moshe Paranov, the grand old man of Connecticut music. "Well, I believe in the Bible, so I think I'll try to do just that."
Mr. Paranov continues to travel to schools all around the state, leading children to the promised land of music. And in May he conducted a piece and received a multitude of honors at a birthday concert simultaneously celebrating the 70th anniversary of the institution he co-founded and still serves as president emeritus, the Hartt School of Music.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Transferring Rent Rights
 
Question: My rent-stabilized studio apartment has seven months left on the lease. There is a vacant one-bedroom apartment in the building with a rent lower than mine. Can my landlord refuse to rent me the larger apartment? . . . Dale La Shomb, Manhattan 

Answer: Yes. Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said no rent regulations oblige a landlord to transfer leasing rights for existing tenants when apartment vacancies come up.
 
Tenant Rights
 
Question: I live in a three-unit building (one commercial and two residential). My landlord did not give me a new lease until a week before the previous lease expired. Was this legal? . . . Thomas F. Roche, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Probably, but it would depend on the terms of your lease. Since your apartment is not covered by the laws that govern rent-regulated housing, there are no statutory requirement that your landlord offer you a new lease within a certain time. Bruce Friedberg, an attorney specializing in real estate matters, said most standard leases are silent on lease renewal notice. But that does not mean your landlord would have been able to put you out at the end of the lease. "Even if the lease has expired," he said, "a landlord cannot evict a tenant without an order from housing court."
Moreover, Section 232 c. of the state's Real Property law says that when a tenant remains beyond the lease term and the landlord accepts rent after that, the tenant is governed by the rules that pertain to month-to-month tenancies. Among them is the requirement that landlords provide a tenant with 30 days' notice to vacate. In New York City, all tenants must be given 30 days' notice, in writing, before eviction proceedings.
 
Change of Use
 
Question: I own a four-family brownstone in a residential zone where a doctor's office is a permitted use for one of the units. Can this space be rented to another commercial use, such as for an accountant, or be used by the professional as a residence as well as an office? . . . Elliot Schuman, Brooklyn
 
Answer: No. Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the Department of Buildings, said the doctor's office cannot be rented to a commercial tenant.
"The zoning resolution permits certain non-residential uses in residential areas," said Mr. Tiryakian, "In general they are for recreational, religious, educational or medical facilities. The law does allow doctor's offices but commercial uses like accounting businesses."
Mr. Tiryakian said it would be possible to convert the space designated for community use into a residence where certain "home occupations" would be permitted and accounting is not a business that is banned as a home occupation. One requirement of the home occupation law is that the business take up no more than 500 square feet or 25 percent of the total floor area.
If you convert the doctor's office to a residence, you would need permits from the Buildings Department for any alterations and you probably would have to meet the requirements of Local Laws 58 and 87, which pertain to space modifications for use by the handicapped.
For more information contact the Buildings Department's Brooklyn borough office at 718-802-3681.
 
SCRIE Income Limits
 
Question: Under the Senior Citizens Rent Increase Exemption program (SCRIE), is money withdrawn from an IRA or any other tax-deferred income annuity included in the $15,000 limit on disposable income? . . . A.M. Goldschmidt, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. According to Roz Post, a spokesman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which administers the SCRIE program, such income is used in calculating the income eligibility for those who apply for the program.
For more information call the SCRIE office at 240-7000.

HEADLINE: Making a Differnce;
Pennzoil's Siberian Gambit

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
CAN Russian oil help rescue the Pennzoil Company?
The Houston-based company, disparaged by Wall Street and weakened by falling oil and gas profits, said last week that it had struck a deal to develop and produce oil and gas in a western Siberian field within the vast Russian Federated Republic. 
 The oil output, estimated by industry analysts at 25,000 barrels a day, could come as early as next year from the West Mogotlorsk field, which Pennzoil said might contain 45 million barrels of recoverable reserves. The gas reserves, thought to be about 35 billion cubic feet, are to be developed later.
These amounts pale beside the larger production deals envisioned in various parts of the former Soviet Union. Still, Pennzoil's rights to 25 percent of the oil output of the joint venture could increase its overall oil production by 21 percent. The Russian partner is the Agansk Geological Enterprise of Novoagansk.
Some analysts say that James L. Pate, president and chief executive, has to bolster Pennzoil's prospects soon. He and other directors maintained earlier this month that the yearly dividend of $3 a share was safe, but Bernard J. Picchi, senior oil analyst at Salomon Brothers, sees it differently. "They'll be paying out their seed corn" if the dividend stays at that level for long, he said.
Weak natural gas prices, a drop in the value of Pennzoil's 9.4 percent stake in the shares of the Chevron Corporation and a poor record of finding new reserves have damaged the company's assets and earning power, Mr. Picchi said.
And the sale by J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman, of one-fifth of his Pennzoil shares this year raised some investor concerns. Mr. Liedtke sold at an average price of $73 a share. The stock closed Friday at $53.625.
The top economist at the Commerce Department during the Ford Administration, Mr. Pate, 56, climbed the financial executive ladder after joining Pennzoil in 1976 and has been chief executive since March 1990. The third heir-apparent named by Mr. Liedtke in four years, Mr. Pate early this month hired four outside oilmen to lead a new campaign, bankrolled by $100 million in each of the next three years, to find foreign reserves.
A much-discussed restructuring that many analysts had encouraged, including sales of some large business units, apparently is on hold.
Mr. Pate, who declined a request for an interview, said earlier this month that the opening of vast oil regions in many parts of the world to exploration by American oil companies is "a major business opportunity."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Clouded Vision and Purple Hearts

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
IT is a Wall Street tradition for outstanding analysts to be honored each year by inclusion in the "All-American" team named each year by Institutional Investor magazine. But prestigious as they are, those awards do not seem to do justice to the marvelous three-ring circus that is the world of Wall Street research.
There is no category, for example, for "the best solo performance by a battered bear in a bull market" -- a prize that should go, hands down, to Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service newsletter in Half Moon Bay, Calif. Mr. Murphy was wrong about the market's overall direction -- in August, his newsletter advised: "Short Everything!" He was dead right, though, about Cascade International, the little Florida-based retailing chain whose chief, Victor Incendy, vanished before a public meeting on Nov. 20 at which he was to answer Mr. Murphy's complaints that the company's financial reports were inaccurate. (Cascade filed for bankruptcy court protection on Dec. 16, still unable to determine its assets and liabilities, and still unable to locate Mr. Incendy.) 
 Nor do Institutional Investor's awards recognize the delicate hair-splitting, the double-jointed contortions of logic and language, and the blindfolded leaps of faith that added spice to the year's reports. And where are the Purple Hearts for those fearless analysts who stated their views without hedging or equivocation -- and turned out to be wrong? Herewith, then, are the awards the magazine missed, honoring some of the great moments in Wall Street research in 1991.
The Blindfolded Bear-Baiting Trophy goes this year to Keith Mullins, an analyst at Smith, Barney Harris Upham & Company, and Ray Dirks, the irrepressible research chief at Baird, Patrick & Company. Both did yeoman work defending Healthcare Services Group, which provides cleaning and laundry services to nursing homes, against a series of skeptical attacks by Charles Biderman, the editor of Market Trim Tabs, a newsletter in Santa Rosa, Calif.
Beginning last June, with the company's split-adjusted stock price in the high teens, Mr. Biderman began to question the company's accounting and sales practices and argued that its pricing structure inflated nursing home expenses and could be open to challenge by Medicaid auditors.
Mr. Mullins countered with a strong defense of the company's revenue and profit growth and predicted its stock could double by next spring. And Mr. Dirks added the company to his "Shortbuster Club," companies he believes have been unfairly portrayed by bearish investors.
What neither analyst apparently detected -- but what was disclosed by Healthcare two weeks ago -- is that the Securities and Exchange Commission has been investigating the company's "business, financial statements, client relations and accounting" since the fall of 1990 -- and the company has "cooperated voluntarily" with all the commission's requests "since that time." Its stock closed at $13.75 a share on Friday.
The Fine Distinctions Award goes to Nomi Ghez, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, for her reports on Hershey Foods. In an Oct. 23 report, with Hershey trading at $43 a share, she examined its vital signs, including its slight market slippage and its stable but lackluster profit growth, and recommended its shares for conservative long-term investors. After the market closed on Nov. 19, she sent out a new report in which she again cited Hershey's slippage in market share and lackluster profit growth -- this time as reasons for removing it from Goldman's recommended list. It is too soon to say if the glass was indeed half-empty, but Hershey's shares tumbled to $36.50 on Goldman's action, and have crept back to just $42.88 since then.
As the year opened, Michael Rosen at Smith, Barney was a strong contender for the Courageous Contrarian Award, having upgraded McDonnell Douglas to a "buy" on Jan. 4, in part because of its role in the Stealth bomber program. On Jan. 7, when the stock opened at $39.25 a share, the Stealth was scrapped by the Defense Department, and McDonnell's stock dove, closing at $28 a share on Jan. 9. Forbes magazine pilloried Mr. Rosen for failing to foresee the cancellation -- a lapse committed by millions -- and the analyst made a simple but classy admission of error. Then, sacrificing the contrarian's crown, he downgraded McDonnell's battered stock to a "hold" and did not restore it to "buy" status until Nov. 12 -- by which point the shares were priced at $77 apiece. Was Mr. Rosen's buy-signal timing any better this time around? Well, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 5.3 percent since its Nov. 15 tumble, McDonnell Douglas closed on Friday at $70.25 a share.
If miscalling the direction of the nation's economy were all it took to win the Fearless Forecasting Award for 1991, there would be enough winners to fill the soon-to-be-empty parking lot at your neighborhood General Motors plant. But among the honorable mentions in this crowded category were the forecasters at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, who greeted 1991 with the prediction that "consumer spending should come alive again in the second half of 1991 as economic expansion resumes," a development that would push up profits for retailers.
But that performance cannot hold a candle to the courage shown by the authors of the Purvin & Gertz monthly oil market research report. The date was Jan. 14, 1991. The topic was the tension in the Persian Gulf, where the United Nations had given Iraq until Jan. 15 to pull out of Kuwait. Purvin & Gertz was utterly fearless: "Despite the recent negative indicators," the authors said, "we continue to stand by our original base case, which calls for a resolution to the crisis without military engagement, though it is difficult to anticipate how this will occur in the time remaining." The 100-day war broke out on Jan. 16, making Purvin & Gertz the slam-dunk winner of this year's Thomas E. Dewey Headliners Award.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Stempel Walks the Tightrope

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
IN Robert C. Stempel, the General Motors Corporation has a chief executive with more respect among factory workers than any other commander of the auto giant in modern times.
"He's a people person, not one of those financial guys," said Annette Morrow, a 15-year veteran at G.M.'s Arlington, Tex., plant. 
 That signals a trust that Mr. Stempel and other G.M. executives only belatedly built, compared with other American and Japanese automakers. The basis for it is a bigger worker voice at the factory since the mid-1980's. But the trust is in danger of shredding.
The problem is not that G.M., as Mr. Stempel announced on Dec. 18, will close 21 plants and shed 74,000 workers by the end of 1995. Most agree that should have been done years ago. The problem is that Mr. Stempel did not say which plants would close, leaving most of G.M.'s work force of 400,000 to worry about where the ax will fall -- and when.
"Rather than lift the uncertainty for many, they've increased it and made it more immediate for hundreds of thousands of workers," said Harley Shaiken, a visiting scholar in industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley. "This will leave broader scars than the specific plants closed."
The situation also highlighted the dangers management faces in "whipsawing." Mr. Stempel had said G.M. was not pitting one plant against another to drive down costs -- but then announced that work at two plants, in Arlington, Tex., and at Willow Run in Ypsilanti, Mich., would be "consolidated" into one sometime next year.
Which one is the question and it has set off an emotional, 11th-hour scramble -- plus boxing Mr. Stempel into a corner with the unions. Local politicians and plant and union officials in Arlington are huddling to plead their cause before Mr. Stempel at G.M. headquarters in early January. An Ypsilanti contingent is expected in Detroit a week later.
This Darwinian competition is the essence of a market economy and, indeed, probably will produce lower costs and higher productivity at the surviving plant, said Peter Cappelli, a management professor at the Wharton School in Philadelphia.
But by hauling the contest into public view, Mr. Stempel put a spotlight on his own role. If he rejects the concessions expected from Arlington and Ypsilanti, G.M. could miss an opportunity to cut costs. Yet worker morale will plunge throughout G.M. if the decision is perceived as being tipped by last-minute bargaining, said William N. Cooke, an auto-industry consultant on factory work teams.
"If they jeopardize the joint decision-making and the close involvement of the employees by whipsawing, they will never recover in the long run," said Mr. Cooke, a professor at Wayne State University. He added that Mr. Stempel's clearest way out of the jam now is to restate his opposition to whipsawing and spell out the criteria G.M. will use to make the decision -- which should include rejecting any new concessions from either plant.
THE G.M. leader appeared to choose his words carefully on the whipsawing issue: "We have to first of all consider the work force, the community and the state where we operate, what the balance of employment will be in the state afterwards, what the impact is on the local community and so forth."
Doug Fraser, president of the U.A.W. between 1977 and 1983, agreed that Mr. Stempel is obliged by his Dec. 18 remarks not to consider any new offers from Arlington or Ypsilanti in deciding which will remain open and retain nearly 4,000 jobs.
"The C.E.O. of General Motors has to be a man of his word and that there won't be any whipsawing," said Mr. Fraser, also a professor at Wayne State. G.M. should have named all 21 plants to be closed, he added. "Not only does that eliminate whipsawing, but it's the right thing to do."
Ultimately, Mr. Stempel's success in restructuring may be measured not by plants closed or workers furloughed, but by shrinkage in G.M.'s bloated management ranks.
"If there are people making $300,000 or $400,000 a year who are blocking or resisting change, then he has to send them home quickly," said Noel M. Tichy, a professor of business at the University of Michigan. "The only thing Stempel can do now is make the fastest possible decision and reduce the uncertainty. Clearly , the clock is ticking."

HEADLINE: All About: Silicone Products;
A War Baby, Versatile Silicone Now Shows Up Everywhere

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH they only occasionally grab headlines, and then only when used in their most exotic applications, such as breast implants or the O-rings of the space shuttle, silicone compounds have become blue-collar mainstays of the chemical world. Silicone compounds are so widely used in construction, industrial applications, textile production and service sector support businesses like printing and labeling that the earnings growth of the Dow Corning Corporation (negative in 1982, slipping since 1987), the largest silicone producer, can be used as an indicator for the health of the economy.
Few worldwide markets the size of silicone's -- some estimates run as high as $6 billion -- are made up of so many niches. Dow Corning estimates that it sells more than 5,000 silicone products to 105 different segments of industry, none accounting for more than 3 percent of the company's total sales of silicone products. The General Electric Company, the No. 2 producer, figures it has more than 4,000 silicone products. 
 Silicones are polymers, or chains of repeating molecules, with spines made up of oxygen alternating with silicon, an element best known today as the most common building block for semiconductors. A variety of resins, gels, foams, liquids, pastes and rubber-like materials are made by attaching other chemicals to the polymer backbone or forming crosslinks between polymers.
Silicon is the main constituent of sand and quartz rock and one of the most common elements on earth. It has been used for thousands of years in ceramics and has long been known for the easy and stable bonds it forms with oxygen. But silicone chemistry did not develop until researchers began to systematically explore the effects of binding silicon to organic compounds early in this century. Although the basic components are inexpensive, the series of chemical reactions needed to synthesize useful quantities of silicones is anything but.
"There's still a lot of art and a lot of unexplored chemistry," said Donald Perkins, general manager of General Electric's silicone business.
 
The Players
 Dow Corning Leads And G.E. Is No. 2
 Dow Corning was created in 1943 and quickly introduced the first important silicone product, a superior insulating grease for electrical machinery used to help Allied aircraft fly at high altitudes and in low temperatures during World War II. The company was set up by the Corning Glass Works, which in 1938 developed the first silicone product, for insulating fiber glass, and the Dow Chemical Company.
Dow Corning, based in Midland, Mich., last year netted $171 million on sales of $1.72 billion. More than half of its sales of silicone products come from overseas operations. The company spends about 8 percent of revenues on research, an unusually high figure in the chemical business.
General Electric, which bases its silicone operations in Waterford, N.Y., entered the business shortly after Dow Corning with a more efficient manufacturing process that is still used today for many silicone products. The company is currently attempting to focus its product line more narrowly, Mr. Perkins said. G.E., like the other major companies other than Dow Corning, does not report any figures detailing the extent or profitability of its silicone business.
A third major American player is the Union Carbide Company. After plans to sell its silicone business to G.E. in 1988 were opposed by the Federal Trade Commission, Carbide moved further into the field by purchasing British Petroleum's silicone operations in Europe.
The United States is the leading market for the newest applications of silicones, but industry executives here say that Europe is catching up fast. Although no one collects or reports industry-wide figures, sales revenues in Europe and the Far East are thought to be similar to those in the United States. Major foreign producers include Huls, Wakker and Bayer of Germany; Rhone Poulenc in France, and Shenetsu in Japan.
 
Medical Uses
 From Implants To Burn Therapy

Silicone has long been recognized as a useful material for medical equipment, medicines and consumer products like deoderants, shampoos and cosmetics because it can be made in forms that are unusually chemically compatible with the human body.
In each application, other silicone characteristics also come into play. Silicones that act as a foam-control agent are an active ingredient in many antiacids. Others are used to lubricate needles. A rubbery silicone is used in balloons injected under the skin to stretch it, thus creating more skin for plastic surgeons to work with in reconstructive surgery for burn victims. Another has supplanted natural rubber in baby bottle nipples. One new use of silicones is to chemically encapsulate other compounds in drugs and cosmetics to regulate the release of active ingredients.
The highest-profile medical silicones recently have been those used in breast implants. More than 2 million American women have had silicone implants over the past 30 years, either to enlarge small breasts or restore breasts lost to cancer. The implants consist of a hard silicone around a silicone gel. In recent years, critics have said that there is evidence linking the operations to a number of diseases.
Last month, a Food and Drug Administration panel said more data was needed to support the manufacturers' claims that implants are safe but recommended they be left on the market pending completion of the research. The agency must act on that qualified vote of confidence by Jan. 6.
 
More Niches
 Beating Oil-Based Competition
 Silicones tend to be more expensive than organic polymers, such as all those derived from oil. As a result, silicones often come into their own in high-performance situations where there are no oil-based substitutes and price is not the first concern. Silicones replace organic lubricants where parts are exposed to extremely high or low temperatures or pressures.
A particularly prized trait is the ability of many silicones to be applied in a liquid or paste form and then cure into a solid at low heat or even through simple exposure to air.
One of silicone's broadest applications is to simultaneously attach and seal glass windows to buildings. Silicones are typically extremely water repellant, resistant to rust and slow to degrade when exposed to sunlight. These characteristics, along with flexibility and simple curing, account for their use in highway expansion joints and home caulking compounds.
Occasionally a new market is almost thrust on silicone manufacturers. That happened when concerns about the toxicity of PCB's forced utilities to search for another substance that had similar heat tolerance and electrical characteristics. More often, though, manufacturers find themselves tinkering with silicone chemistry to create a collection of characteristics fitting a customer's needs so well that it will pay a premium for silicone over a cheaper plastic or metal.
"We do a lot of molecular modeling on computers today before trying to synthesize new compounds," said Leon Crossman, director of science and technology at Dow Corning. "That lets us try a lot of weird combinations."
 
Silly Putty, Now a Classic
 PERHAPS the most famous silicone compound is a methyl borosiloxane with unusual cross-linking that was discovered by accident in a General Electric laboratory in 1943. The engineers were looking for a very hard silicone rubber. But the stockroom sent the wrong chemicals and what the engineers got was a putty-like material that flattened into a pancake when left alone, could be stretched like taffy, and bounced like crazy when rolled into a ball and tossed on the floor.
The substance was dismissed as a simple mistake with an unusually goofy result until 1949 when Peter C. Hodgson, an advertising copywriter, heard about it from a friend. He borrowed some money, named the stuff Silly Putty, packaged it in plastic eggs, and began marketing it as a novelty through Neiman-Marcus and Doubleday bookstores.
Some 3,000 tons later, Silly Putty no longer enjoys the fad status it had in the 1950's, but it's selling. It is made in Easton, Pa., by Binney & Smith Inc., better known for its Crayola crayons. Last year, it introduced a number of colored versions to go along with the classic pinkish-beige original and this year, added a glow-in-the-dark version.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Beware the Fickle Prediction

DATELINE: Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THE news from many stock markets has been bad lately. So predictions of rising earnings for companies around the world in 1992 may sound encouraging for investors eager to buy stocks.
But recent history shows that there is good reason to beware of these earnings estimates. Predictions have a distinct tendency to change, and if they drop, stocks become much less attractive because anticipated price-to-earnings ratios rise as earnings fall. 
 According to data compiled by the New York-based Institutional Brokers Estimate System, analysts predicted last May that the earnings per share for companies in the CAC index of 40 leading blue chip stocks in France would rise 4.6 percent in 1991. By the end of November, the latest data compiled, that prediction had turned to a 3 percent drop.
The same pattern is true for the other six countries in the Group of Seven, which consists of the United States and its main economic allies, homes of the major stock markets in the world.
For example, the forecast for the earnings of companies in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 American shares went from a 3.1 percent increase predicted last May to a 9.7 percent decline predicted at the end of last month. In Japan, forecasts for companies in the Nikkei 225-share index moved from an increase of 2 percent to 3.9 percent decline. In Britain, the change was more dramatic, with a swing from a 5.2 percent rise to a 7.1 percent drop.
Canada, which traditionally has had very volatile earnings, had an even wider swing, with earnings estimates moving from up 5.2 percent to down 17 percent. In Italy, the change was all negative, from down 1.8 percent to down 12.5 percent. Only in Germany, where the global slowdown has had the least impact this year, was there an upward revision, although a minor one, from down 1.1 percent to down just half a percentage point.
Clearly, 1991 has been a year for downward revisions. In the United States, the hoped-for recovery has disappeared, and in England, it has not begun. In Continental Europe, the slowdown came much faster than expected, and Germany's aggressive increase in interest rates a week ago could make it worse. In Japan, the economy has slowed and the financial atmosphere has been seared by scandal and a significant slump in the stock market.
But according to Rick Pucci, vice president of the Institutional Brokers Estimate System, downward revisions have been the rule, not the exception. In all but two of the last 12 years in which the firm has collected the data, the revisions in the United States have lowered the earnings estimates by the end of the year. The exceptions were in 1979, when Mr. Pucci said estimates were driven up by double-digit inflation, and 1988, when a recession that was predicted to have followed the 1987 stock market crash never materialized.
For foreign stock market earnings, for which the system began collecting complete data in 1988, the pattern of downward revision was true in 1990 and 1991.
"Analysts tend to be optimistic," Mr. Pucci said. Even if their estimates appear to be off early in the year, they tend to think the difference can be made up by year end, he said. As the end of the year approaches, they have no choice but to cut their estimates sharply. "Every analyst in the industrial world has been cutting estimates drastically over the last couple of months," he said.
Because of this evidence of persistent overoptimism among earnings analysts, Mr. Pucci is already predicting that the earnings estimates for 1992 will be coming down, too. In the United States, the current forecast for next year is a 31 percent jump in earnings per share. On average, analysts cut their earnings estimates by 1 percent a month. This would bring the United States forecast down to 18 percent by the beginning of 1993. But Mr. Pucci said the forecast could fall to around 15 percent because the recovery is being put off further into the future.
The revisions should knock down the other current 1992 estimates as well. They are: Canada, 51.3 percent; France, 16.5 percent; Germany, 7.9 percent; Italy 16.5 percent; Japan, 4.7 percent, and Britain, 26.1 percent.
The broad country stock market estimates do not mean, of course, that all companies' estimates are lowered. So far this year, of the 9,958 companies followed by analysts, 73.5 percent have been lowered since January and 26.5 percent have been raised.
Most of the companies whose earnings estimates were revised downward for 1991 also had their forecasts for 1992 cut. The same pattern, in reverse, was true for companies with profit increases forecast.
Among the companies with the largest downward revisions in 1991 are: Volkswagen in Germany, Peugeot in France, British Aerospace, Bridgestone of Japan, Fiat of Italy and Imperial Oil in Canada.
The pattern of revisions is clear enough that investors should take forecasts with a grain of salt. Some firms acknowledge this. In its new outlook for the beginning of 1992, the UBS Phillips & Drew global research group in London notes that there have been downward revisions in their initial earnings forecasts in the past two years and adds: "Our forecasts for 1992 could justifiably be treated with some skepticism."

HEADLINE: Hurtling Off the Precipice?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Will the Aura of Recession Always Be With Us?" (Nov. 24) presents two schools of opinion regarding the engineered "soft landing" of 1991. One contends that it is a deep, lingering recession; the other, that it is a shallow, short recession in the recovery mode. 
 Let me suggest a third: None of the above.
Ever since Adam Smith wrote the book on the dismal science of economics, depressions have afflicted capitalist economies. Yes, I know most respectable economists pooh-pooh any mention of the big "D," and the President says, "our economy is fundamentally sound," at every photo opportunity. But I'm certain he would change his tune if he realized that Herbert Hoover also sang that song -- in 1929.
Every panic, bust, slump and economic upheaval since Adam Smith's day was unbelievable -- before the fact. Witness the last depression. Experts kept on parroting "our economy is fundamentally sound" even while it hurtled headlong into the abyss of the 30's.
 
HENRY FOGEL
Lexington, Mass., Nov. 24

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
On Whom Will the Spotlight -- and the Ax -- Fall in 1992?

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
THE past year has been a tumultuous one for the computer industry, and there is no reason to suspect the new year will be any more tranquil. The most optimistic executives say the market may grow a little; others suggest that a shakeout will winnow many second- and third-tier companies and shake the foundations of the top tier.
John McCarthy, an analyst with Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., a market research firm, predicted "continued bloodletting as business and the economy go bad." 
 "There's going to be real pricing competition on the operating system side," Mr. McCarthy said, looking ahead to upgraded versions that are scheduled to be released. "I.B.M. is going to spark a pricing war with Windows in March as they attempt to resuscitate OS/2."
He continued: "The question is, can I.B.M. really lock marketing horns with Microsoft? Because that's what it is, a marketing battle, not a technology battle. I.B.M. has been great at freezing the market in the past with FUD -- fear, uncertainty and doubt. The question is whether they can use marketing to activate a market."
In networking, he predicted, "we'll see the advent of combination Token Ring and Ethernet chips built right into the motherboard of high-end business-class PC's." That, he said, would be "the beginning of the end for the network interface card business," predicting problems ahead for the 3COM Corporation, of Santa Clara, Calif., a leading manufacturer of those cards.
Tim Bajarin, vice president of Creative Strategies International Inc., a market research and consulting firm based in San Jose, Calif., predicted that the most significant event of 1992 would be the court ruling on Apple Computer Inc.'s suit against Microsoft, which it accuses of illegally copying aspects of the Macintosh operating system in its Windows operating system. The trial is scheduled for the summer. If Apple wins, "I am convinced that Apple will not license its Macintosh interface to Microsoft," Mr. Bajarin said. "I believe Apple will force Microsoft back to the drawing board."
Jim Seymour of Seymour & Associates, an Austin, Tex., firm that advises large companies on information technology, predicted that Borland International Inc. would be "the most noticed and most admired software company in 1992." He added: "There will be blood in the streets as it battles Microsoft with its new products, Paradox for Windows and Quattro Pro for Windows. Those products are so, so good."
Mr. Seymour also foresees a renewed interest in monitors, because of Windows, which works best on bigger, higher-quality displays. "People are catching on that the 13- and 14-inch monitors of yesterday are not enough," Mr. Seymour said. "Yet the 19-inch models are too big and too expensive."
He said he was impressed with a new crop of 16-inch monitors -- a "compromise between the big ones you can't afford and the little ones you can't stand" -- that will be brought to market by the NEC Corporation of Japan and Radius Inc., of San Jose, Calif.
Elsewhere, he predicted a shakeout among clone companies "in that layer just below Dell and AST Research," where he predicted a third of the competitors would be "gone in the next 12 to 18 months." He declined to speculate on which ones. He also predicted, "It will be a difficult year for Compaq, which is going to find its first year or 18 months of selling low-cost PC's to be profitless."
Cheryl Currid, the president of Currid & Company, a Houston-based consulting company, said she would be paying special attention to Compaq, which is also based in Houston. "Their challenge is to push in two directions, to the low end, to get back on the desktop, without forgetting the high end, where they stand to be one of the chosen few to benefit from downsizing," she said.
Downsizing, in this case, is the replacement of large mainframe systems with smaller computers linked on a network. "Anywhere from 1 to 4 percent of corporate revenues are spent on computing, and there is no rhyme or reason on why it's higher one place than another," she said, before backtracking: "Actually, there is a reason. It's a lot of little old men sitting in glass houses" -- mainframe centers -- "waiting to change. Outside the glass houses are lots of computing options that rationalize the cost of computers and increase flexibility."
While many companies took a beating in 1991, corporate and other buyers enjoyed round after round of price cuts, as well as steady increases in computer performance. "Consumers made out like bandits between price drops, changes in distribution and the fact that companies are paying more attention to service and support," said Peter Zandan, president of Intelliquest, a technology market research company in Austin, Tex.
That phrase -- service and support -- which is no more than working hard to keep customers happy, is now in vogue. "Service is easy to say and very, very hard to deliver," Mr. Zandan observed. "It requires an experience base. If you promise 24-hour turnaround, the customer will know right away if it gets repaired in 24 hours."
Companies to watch, Mr. Zandan said, start with Apple. "They've really positioned themselves well this year, in pricing, distribution, products, and their relationships with I.B.M., Motorola and Sony." On the software side, he said he liked "Borland, if they are able to keep on their path," adding, "They've been very aggressive with their applications and seem to have put together a good formula for success."
Nancy E. McSharry, a software analyst with the International Data Corporation in San Jose, Calif., is another Borland fan. "In five years they have come from the back of the pack in the software race to become the leader in terms of product quality, market growth and perception in marketplace," she said, adding this caution: "The dark side is that Borland's merger with Ashton-Tate has sapped a lot of resources."
She said she also expected strong products from the Symantex Corporation, Central Point Software Inc. "and maybe some companies we haven't heard about yet."
For all the popularity of Microsoft Windows, William F. Zachmann, the president of Canopus Research in Duxbury, Mass., struck a cautionary note: "Microsoft has a lot of underlying problems. There are a variety of wildcards, like the Federal Trace Commission investigation and the Apple lawsuit. But more important, the success of Windows is not nearly as sweeping as is commonly believed." Microsoft says it has sold seven million copies of Windows, but software companies are selling relatively few Windows applications, he said.
"Windows, if OS/2 2.0 does what it is supposed to do, might look a lot less invincible," he said. "Windows 3.1, or at least the final beta version I've seen, looks like nothing dramatic. It evokes more promises than it can deliver."
