HEADLINE: Human Tides: The Influx in Europe - A special report.;
Europeans Look for Ways To Bar Door to Immigrants

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
The "fortress Europe" that Americans, Japanese and other outsiders fear when the European Community finally becomes a tariff-free, continent-wide market at the end of next year is already being built. But its walls are intended to keep out people, not commodities.
A flood of people fleeing poverty and political unrest in parts of Eastern Europe, in Africa and in South Asia has combined with years of high unemployment in Europe to inflame social and political tensions not only in European Community countries but in Austria and Switzerland as well. 
 A total of 500,000 people applied for asylum in Western Europe as a whole last year, according to the British Home Secretary, Kenneth Baker. And as unemployment levels have risen in every major European economy this year, popular resentment at the influx has nurtured right-wing political movements in Belgium, Switzerland, France and Germany, among others.
 
Heaviest Influx in Germany
 Time-consuming asylum procedures, including an obligation to house and feed applicants while their cases are being decided, are also imposing a drain on governments already hard pressed to meet welfare demands, and raising questions about how European countries that have never thought of themselves as ethnic melting pots can preserve their national identities.
The influx has been heaviest in Germany, which because of its past is the European country most inhibited from just sending the refugees packing. As the richest European nation and with a population just over 79 million, it already has its hands full coping with the estimated 2.5 million ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe who have taken up citizenship over the last three years, a right the 1949 Constitution automatically guaranteed to Germans everywhere.
While 500,000 applications for asylum does not seem a lot in a continent of more than 300 million people, there are hundreds of thousands more illegal immigrants in most of the principal countries. Until 1985, the number of applications for asylum in Europe and North America combined had never exceeded 250,000.
Not since the collapse of colonialism after World War II have the countries of Europe faced influxes of people on such a scale. Then, the immigration of hundreds of thousands of Indians and Pakistanis helped change the face of Britain, as the flow of North and Central Africans changed the faces of France and Belgium.
Now the process is repeating itself in countries that had no overseas empires, challenging Germans, for instance, to re-examine their long-held aversion to immigration by other ethnic groups. While the Europeans are only groping for answers, they seem more intent this time on keeping as many of these people out as they can, if only they can find a way.
Last summer, Italy sent entire boatloads of would-be asylum-seekers from Albania back across the Adriatic Sea, much as the United States has been barring Haitians from coming across the Caribbean.
 
Spian
 Public Attitudes Largely Tolerant
 European approaches to the problem vary greatly from country to country. In Spain, which has tolerated large-scale illegal immigration from Morocco for years, public attitudes so far are relatively tolerant.
Abdalia Aziz Dukuly, a 27-year-old refugee from the civil war in Liberia, discovered that life in Spain would not be easy after he arrived in the Canary Islands on a freighter from Mauretania on Oct. 29. "I lost my family, so I had nothing to lose," he said one recent morning at the Spanish Red Cross headquarters in Madrid, waiting in a corridor with a score of other refugees, most of them new arrivals from Africa.
"My mother was killed in the fighting," he said, "and I made up my mind to come and hide in Europe. They told me in Las Palmas that Spain couldn't accept me unless I went to the capital, so here I am."
It is not easy to establish grounds to stay in any European country as a refugee. Under the terms of the 1951 United Nations Convention that all European Community countries, as well as the United States, are pledged to observe, asylum can be granted only to someone who can prove a "well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion."
Only seven percent of applications for refugee or asylum status in Spain are approved, a figure roughly typical for the whole of the European Community, and for a basic reason: Most "refugees" coming to Europe actually want to build a better life for themselves, either here or, eventually, back home, and perhaps therefore are better described as immigrants.
Since few European countries permit much immigration at all, the only way to get a foot in the door is to sneak into countries like Spain, which until recently did not even require visas of people coming over from Morocco, or to fly into an airport and ask for asylum, then taking advantage of the time it takes to determine qualification to settle down and take root anyway.
But gradually, the new arrivals are beginning to change the face of the country in unexpected ways, even in Spain, where the numbers -- about 5,000 a year -- are relatively small in a total population of more than 39 million. A surprising number of Spaniards had never laid eyes on a black person before Africans began arriving, for instance.
"King Balthazar was the only black most people here had ever been familiar with," said Felix Barrena, director of the Spanish Red Cross Center for Assistance to Foreigners, referring to one of the Three Magi.
Referring to the difficulties asylum-seekers have in being integrated in Spanish society, he said: "It's a social problem, not a racial problem, in my experience. People see refugees sleeping in the parks, and last summer some of them were caught selling drugs on the Plaza de Espana, and they make stereotypical judgments."
So far Spain has been spared the kind of organized campaigns against foreigners that have seen gangs of skinheads demonstrate against and attack Vietnamese and other refugees in some of the hardest-hit industrial towns in eastern Germany, where unemployment after the collapse of the Communist economy has soared to around 50 percent of the work force.
 
Germany
 Both Acceptance And Resistance
 The integration of foreigners, whether they are immigrants or refugees, has come a long way in Germany, which has had substantial populations of Yugoslavs, Turks and Italians since the 1960's, when they were invited in as "guest workers."
In Berlin, for example, 312,374 foreigners now make up 11 percent of the population, and 136,302 of them are Turks. In 1960, there were only 22,065 non-German people in the city.
The civil war in Yugoslavia has sent more Yugoslavs fleeing into Germany in recent months, and they have displaced Romanians as the largest single group seeking asylum there.
Many Germans have been as shocked as the rest of the world by the beatings and firebomb attacks on refugee centers. As Barbara John, the Berlin city official in charge of helping foreigners, sees it, the public image of Germany as a country where neo-Nazi thugs terrorize anybody who does not look German distorts the true picture.
"That has happened mainly in the East, and it's a sign of the collapse of the old system and of the order that held it up," she said.
Racism in a mostly homogeneous, white society like Germany can hide better than it does in a country like Britain or Belgium that had to accept a large number of immigrants from former colonies.
And Mrs. John was optimistic. "We know many Germans don't object to foreigners being here," she said. Hundreds of thousands of them took to the streets in November to protest the harassment of foreigners and to demand that the authorities do more to stop it.
The reason Germany attracts almost two-thirds of the total number of asylum-seekers in the European Community, according to many officials, is that the German Constitution gives them a better chance of getting one foot in the door. It allows anyone a chance to make a claim and obliges the state to look after them while officials painstakingly examine it.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl tried this year to get the Constitution changed to allow a speedup in the examination procedure, which might discourage some "refugees" from coming, but he was blocked by the opposition Social Democrats.
Failing that, he tried at the meeting of European leaders in Maastricht, the Netherlands, to get the others to agree to a common asylum and immigration policy to be decided by majority vote. Instead, they agreed to coordinate them as closely as possible by the end of 1993, in effect putting off an attempt to find a solution.
"Politicians show a helplessness that confuses and disturbs voters," Mrs. John said. One way out, she suggested, might be for countries like Germany to give up the pretense that they do not allow immigration -- since most of the asylum seekers who stay on are not expelled even if they are rejected -- and instead to set limits on numbers of immigrants.
With civil war in Yugoslavia and economic chaos in the territory of the old Soviet Union, German newspapers and magazines often speak of the threat of millions of refugees flooding in unless something is done to bar the door. But so far, the main group that has come are the descendants of ethnic Germans imported into Russia in the 18th century by Catherine the Great. And according to the weekly news magazine Der Spiegel, only 50,000 non-Germans have been granted German citizenship in the last 10 years.
 
France
 New Citizens And Illegal Aliens
 In France, by contrast, the census of 1990 showed that 1.77 million people who had acquired their French citizenship were living in the country at the end of the year, representing 3.13 percent of the total population of more than 56 million.
Estimates of the number of foreigners living illegally in France range to the hundreds of thousands. Many of them work in the construction industry in big cities like Paris, Lyon or Marseille, according to Michel Devacht, a caseworker with the French Democratic Confederation of Labor.
"Any economist will tell you these people are necessary for the economy," Mr. Devacht said, because they do dirty or disagreeable work that French workers no longer want to do. "But there are three million unemployed, so they are a scapegoat."
Last month, the ultra-right National Front party of Jean-Marie Le Pen proposed an anti-immigration platform that would ship out unwanted aliens by boat, and put those awaiting expulsion into guarded camps.
It is not competition for jobs, but skin color that often defines the true nature of the antagonism, according to many experts.
"What worries the French is not the number of people who are legally foreigners, but the number of non-European immigrants and their children," Robert Sole wrote last month in the daily Le Monde.
Mr. Devacht said, "Eastern Europeans are invisible." Black Africans and people from the formerly French territories of North Africa stood out and were resented, even though statistics show that the North Africans are 80 percent more likely to lose their jobs in hard times than "native" French workers are, according to Mr. Sole.
 
Britain
New Rules Due On Asylum-Seekers
 Nowhere is the racist aspect of the new European anxiety about immigrants more open than in Britain, where there were fewer than 20,000 nonwhite residents before the collapse of the empire.
Today the nonwhite population is about 2.6 million, 4.7 percent of the population of about 56 million and more than half of them of Indian, Pakistani or Bangladeshi origin, according to official statistics, and about one-fifth of West Indian origin. Yet it is still possible for a well-dressed black man to walk into a barbershop, as one did near Victoria Station the other day, and cause all three Italian barbers to stop snipping. Asked what he wanted, the man answered, "A haircut." Apologetically but firmly, the chief barber answered, "We don't know how to cut your kind of hair."
British immigration from former colonies has been largely stopped, and only about 50,000 people a year are accepted here for settlement every year, many of them from Canada or Australia. The thought that more are seeking entry, most of them from Asia or Africa, raises fears among some Britons that their country might soon become ethnically unrecognizable.
Applications for asylum in Britain have risen from 5,000 in 1988 to an estimated 50,000 this year, according to Home Secretary Baker.
The British are enacting new legislation so the authorities can determine whether asylum-seekers qualify within 90 days, instead of years as before. Refugees would have only two days to appeal refusals, in writing, to immigration officials who could decide, without a hearing, within five days whether an "arguable" case exists.
"I do not think the problem is a question of numbers, though numbers make it worse," wrote Charles Moore in The Spectator Magazine, known for its conservatism, earlier this fall.
"It is a question of race," he went on. "You can be British without speaking English or being Christian or being white, but nevertheless Britain is basically English-speaking, Christian and white, and if one starts to think that it might become basically Urdu-speaking and Muslim and brown, one gets frightened and angry."
So the reaction has led, as it has in other European countries, to pressure to crack down and keep more such people out. At the beginning of November, Britain doubled the fine on foreign airlines that fly in foreigners without proper entry documents, from 1,000 to 2,000, or $3,600, per person.
The problem, as Amnesty International and other organizations that look after the rights of asylum-seekers and refugees have pointed out, is that most people who do qualify for asylum are likely as not to arrive without passports or visas because asking for them in the countries from which they fled could have been dangerous.
Increasingly, the London-based human rights organization said in a report at the end of November, all governments in Europe, not just Britain's, are taking a restrictive approach toward asylum-seekers. And increasingly, they are playing with people's lives.
Last March, in an example Amnesty International cited in its report, 17 Tamils from Sri Lanka, which has been torn by civil strife for the last several years, arrived at Schwechat Airport in Vienna and claimed asylum. The Austrian authorities turned them back to Rome, through which they had passed in transit on their way to Vienna, saying that because they had first arrived on Italian soil, Italy should consider their claim first.
"In Vienna, they were held in the transit lounge and denied access to a U.N. representative," Amnesty International reported. Upon their return to Italy, they were sent back to Sri Lanka as "deportees in transit" from Austria.
United Nations officials said later that at least some of the Tamils had presented "clear grounds for asylum" to the Austrian airport authorities, according to Amnesty.
 
The Outlook
Restrictions Seem Most Likely
 Small wonder, perhaps, that at Maastricht, the European Community countries agreed to leave asylum policies in the hands of national governments, for the most part, instead of agreeing to common policies.
"That would have lost us our ability to control our own borders," said a British official close to Prime Minister John Major. "The long-term solution is to strengthen everybody's external frontiers."
The outlook, as Eastern Europe and the lands of the former Soviet Union continue to be wracked by upheavals, is for a restrictive policy that, in most countries, favors whites from Eastern Europe who can speak the language of the country they seek to settle in and have, in the eyes of the authorities, a reasonable chance of economic success.
"Either we continue with a very restrictive immigration policy," Mr. Moore wrote in The Spectator, "or we develop a more liberal one which is more 'racist.' "
With nationalist parties feeding off the discontent with the present trend in Belgium, Germany, Austria, and France, many outsiders fear that he may be right.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 29 about migration in Europe misstated an eligibility rule for German citizenship. The 1949 constitution offers citizenship to ethnic Germans from all former territories of the Third Reich, and to people who were deprived of German citizenship on political, racial or religious grounds by the Nazis.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Amid Recession, a Recovery for Shelton

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
TWO years ago, the vacancy rate for Shelton's six million square feet of office and industrial buildings was 37 percent, the highest in Fairfield County.
This was a result of a building spree that began in the late 70's, when the city courted developers in an effort to shed its smokestack image and create a more viable economy. Hundreds of thousands of square feet of new commercial space came onto the market in time for the 1987 crash. 
 For the next three years, half-finished and completed buildings went begging for buyers. With overbuilding rife everywhere and prices dropping, companies sought more fashionable southern Fairfield towns in preference to Shelton.
But this year, Shelton's office vacancy rate dropped substantially, to 20 percent. Less than 530,000 of a total of 2.5 million square feet of office space remain vacant, and only 10 percent of almost four million square feet of light industrial space is empty. Shelton has absorbed more than 200,000 square feet in 1991, bringing its vacancy rate below those of its chief competitors, Stamford, at 22 percent, and Norwalk, at 22.8.
A deepening recession has heightened interest in Shelton's lower costs and taxes, expandable tracts of land, and most importantly, accessibility to a geographically broad labor market. "It's a first choice now," said James Fagan, vice president at the CB Commercial Real Estate Group in Stamford.
The Prudential Relocation Corporation moved its northeast headquarters this year from Merritt 7, a prestigious complex in Norwalk, to Enterprise Tower II in Shelton, merging a small New Jersey office into its new 35,000-square-foot space. Retention of employees was a key element.
"We couldn't tap into a stable labor market in Norwalk," said Richard Schwartz, senior vice president for Prudential Relocation. The turnover among clerical and middle management employees earning $20,000 to $60,000 a year was around 25 percent because of the long travel time to reach affordable housing.
Enterprise Tower II, a 290,000-square-foot, 10-story building was completed last spring. Some 150,000 square feet is available at rents of $13.50 to $15.50 a square foot. Its twin, completed two years ago, is connected by an atrium, and completely leased.
"We saved 20 to 25 percent in rent and got more amenities," Mr. Schwartz said. For the convenience of its tenants, the complex has its own cafeteria, dry cleaner, florist, hair salon, carwash, copy center, bank teller machine, limo and car rental service, helicopter service to Manhattan and travel service.
Robert Scinto of Greenwich, its developer, is the largest taxpayer in town. He paid $1.6 million into Shelton's coffers in 1990. A former Bridgeport plumber, he owns 28 office buildings with a total of two million square feet, most of it in Shelton. "What brought me here was Route 8," he said, referring to the north-south expressway from Bridgeport to Waterbury. "You can attract executives from Stamford and entry-level employees from Naugatuck." Driving time to Waterbury, Stamford, Danbury, Norwalk, New Haven or Bridgeport ranges from 10 to 30 minutes.
"LABOR costs are significantly lower simply because of housing," he continued. "Condos in Naugatuck go for $49,900. You can pay people $300 a week and they are happy with it. When Cartier moved into Enterprise Towers they had 2,000 applicants for 60 jobs."
He will begin building a Finast Supermarket of 67,000 square feet on Bridgeport Avenue in March.
"We have our city approvals, and Finast advances construction funds for its own facilities," he said. Site work on a Sheraton Hotel, to be built within the 100-acre parcel on which Enterprise Towers sits, is under way, he said, adding, "when banks are ready to lend, we will start construction."
Confidence in the continued growth of the Route 8 corridor was demonstrated by Zell-Merrill Lynch II, which bought a 162,000-square-foot office building at 2 Trap Falls Road for $5.25 million last month. The new investment fund with $500 million at its disposal was formed by Sam Zell, a real estate investor from Chicago. The sale was negotiated by Jeffrey Dunne and Mr. Fagan at CB Commercial.
John Morrow of CB Commercial arranged the purchase in July of the Philips Medical Systems building at 710 Bridgeport Avenue by Auguste-Thouard of Greenwich, the American arm of a major French real estate firm. The 450,000-square-foot office and industrial complex on 36 acres was sold for $22 million, with 300,000 square feet leased back to Philips for 10 years.
ALAIN LeBLEU, president of Auguste-Thouard, said "we have made only two acquisitions in the last two years and both of them are in Shelton." The company has acquired some $75 million worth of commercial real estate on Long Island, in Westchester County and Connecticut since it opened here in 1982.
In 1990 it bought the 155,000-square-foot former ITT building on 15 acres at 1 Research Drive. After a total renovation, the two-story building is 75 percent rented.
"We've done well here, and I don't see why we would not do more," Mr. Le Bleu said. "We plan to build an addition to the Philips complex to accommodate a second corporate tenant with a combination of office and industrial space. We are in the design phase, but we will not go ahead until we have a commitment from a tenant."
Mark Lauretti, Shelton's new Mayor; Alton Russell, the new chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission, Mr. Scinto and local officials and businessmen met in December to discuss the city's future.
"Route 8 is doing well, but downtown is badly in need of revitalization, with a better balance of housing and retail," the Mayor said. A new plan of development focusing on that issue will be presented at public hearings in March, Mr. Russell said.
Howe Avenue, the principal downtown street, overlooks the Housatonic River, but is separated from it by old brick factories, nondescript stores, and a grubby, debris-filled site where the Goodrich Rubber Company burned down in 1975.
Until developers can be found to recycle the historically significant street of 19th century buildings into apartments, shops and offices, Shelton remains a divided city. Its downtown is shunned by employees, residents and customers of Route 8's modern office parks, houses, condominiums and shopping centers.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Recalling a Year of Mostly Pluses

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
EVEN as we prepare to greet the New Year, it might be useful to look back at some of the cultural events that brightened (or dampened) the Westchester music scene in 1991.
Among other happenings, for instance, the county gained a shiny new chamber orchestra: the Hutchinson River Chamber Players. Founded and directed by Jeffrey Levine, a Pelham resident, the ensemble made its debut a month ago. 
 "It is rare to have professionally played chamber music brought right into our community spaces," Mr. Levine said. He added that he expects the group to perform in libraries, churches, synagogues and town halls countywide, and perhaps in Connecticut. For further details, call 738-6905.
What used to be An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford reappeared last March as the sumptuously appointed Westchester Broadway Theater. Musical comedies remain the primary production focus of this performing space, but concerts and children's shows also spice the schedule. Call 965-5232.
After four years of June recitals, the Dobbs Ferry Chamber Festival expanded into a fall-spring season as the Festival Chamber Music Society. The opening program of the new concert series took place in October and will be followed by recitals on Jan. 26 and April 12. Call 693-2506.
Mount Sinai has a medical recommendations service, so why not a musicians referral agency for performing artists? Since March, the Westchester Conservatory's Musical Entertainment Bureau has brightened dozens of corporate and private functions around the county by providing faculty groups, ranging from a flute and harp duo to a full jazz band. "People have found out that we're reliable and good," said the coordinator, Robert Arthurs, himself a jazz trumpeter, "so the bureau is really flourishing." Call 761-3715.
The Hudson Opera Theater began life in February with an all-star gala and followed it up with a Cole Porter evening in July, but the new opera company's plans to stage the American premiere of Bellini's "Zaira" have not materialized. "Getting the score from Sicily proved to be more complicated than we thought," said Margaret Cicogna, one of the founders of the company, "and while we've raised some of the necessary funds, we don't yet have enough. We're hoping for 1992." Call 633-2929.
In April, the scheduled orchestral concert of Philharmonia Virtuosi turned into a chamber recital. "We can't continue to provide our customary programs when the income flow stops," said the music director, Richard Kapp. Call 693-5595.
The following month, in a similar budget-cutting maneuver, the Westchester Choral Society changed its concert venue from the State University of New York at Purchase to the Presbyterian Church of White Plains and used organ instead of orchestral accompaniment. "I'd hate to say we were broke," said the music director, Lyndon Woodside, "but we're trying to be prudent about spending money." The financial crunch eased somewhat in October when the choir won the $10,000 grand prize in Pepsi-Cola's nationwide home video talent contest. Call 693-2453.
Deteriorating economic conditions and the shrinking availability of corporate financing were cited as reasons for discontinuing the much-admired June festival of Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence. "We feel we made a valuable contribution to the community," said Kenneth Wentworth, who had directed the series since its founding in 1977, "but now it's time to move on to something else."
The Phoenix Award for Rising From the Ashes goes to the Chappaqua Orchestra, which disbanded in 1990 but will re-emerge on Jan. 11 as the Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra.
The Lone Ranger Prize for Riding to the Rescue goes to the Prague Guitar Quartet, which flew to Yonkers when the Amsterdam Guitar Trio abruptly canceled its January concert at the Hudson River Museum.
The Authenticity at All Costs Medal goes to Richard Kapp for importing two theorbos (double-necked lutes with two sets of strings) for a Vivaldi concerto performance by Philharmonia Virtuosi. "Their use will be a first in Westchester," said the conductor, "and hopefully a last."
And the Salieri Citation for Courageous Programming in this Mozart Bicentennial Year: a tie between Sarah Lawrence College, which mounted a Schubert Festival in May, and Bard College, which devoted most of its August Festival to the works of Felix and Fanny Mendelssohn.
Finally, congratulations to some of the organizations that celebrated anniversaries in 1991, a group that included the following:
The Camerata (5 years), under the founding director, Victor Lionti, bringing fine chamber orchestra performances to Westchester Community College.
Thom Wolke's Twin Cloud Productions (5 years), a major presenter of folk artists in various locations around the county.
The Master Singers of Westchester (10 years), which has grown from a group of 15 into a choir of more than 90 under the founding ministrations of the conductor Les Robinson Hadsell.
The Paramount Center for the Arts (10 years), which is entering its second decade with Mark Hough as its new (as of August) executive director.
The Pelham Arts Center (15 years), which has added a Summer Arts Day Camp to its other cultural services.
The Old Mill Singers (20 years), known for community as well as musical good deeds.
The Concert Society of Putnam and Northern Westchester (20 years), an outstanding example of the musical scene in the northern part of the county.
The Tappan Zee Chamber Series (20 years), still enticing many Westchesterites across the Hudson.
The SUNY Purchase Performing Arts Center (20 years), a true hub of cultural activity in the county.
The Taghkanic Chorale (25 years), 120-voices strong and flourishing under the direction of Dennis Keene. It began its silver-anniversary season earlier this month with a performance of Bach's B minor Mass.
The Westchester Chamber Music Society (40 years), which gave its Rye audience a Champagne reception marking its birthday last April.
The Westchester Choral Society (50 years), justly proud of its commitment to "cultivating musical appreciation in Westchester."
The Westchester Symphony (65 years), which marked its anniversary with a new conductor. "Martin Canellakis brought us a long way, and we are eternally grateful to him," said the orchestra's president, Henry Oppenheimer. "However, we now have an opportunity to introduce a vibrant, upcoming star, Anthony Aibel."
Manhattanville College (150 years), celebrating all year with a wide spectrum of arts presentations. The most ambitious: the Westchester premiere in April of "Epithalamion," described as "a collaborative performance blending dance, poetry and song."

HEADLINE: More Layoffs at Stake if State Makes Cuts in Aid

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
LAYOFFS of county government workers mandated by passage of the 1992 budget could exceed the hundreds expected if the state seeks to solve its fiscal problem as it did a year ago, by reducing aid to local communities, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week.
Mr. O'Rourke, pleased with the few changes imposed by the Board of Legislators on his $1.18 billion no-tax- increase spending plan, said in an interview that the Westchester budget "was based on us not getting hit by Albany any more than we were last June" when state support for schools and local government was slashed. 
 "We may have some leeway in our budget through our own economies," he said, "but we can't take much of a hit without it resulting in people getting laid off." This would be in addition to more than 500 county jobs, some filled and some vacant, that are to be eliminated after Jan. 1.
 
200 County Jobs Trimmed
 The 1992 Westchester budget submitted in November by Mr. O'Rourke was trimmed by $186,000, less than 0.02 percent of the total, and was approved by the Board on Dec. 19 by a 15-to-2 margin. The legislators, who had cut millions of dollars from each of the last two budgets, said they were pleased with Mr. O'Rourke's having made the cuts himself this time.
But the fiscal plan cut 200 county jobs and called for the elimination of another 300 positions, which Mr. O'Rourke said could be saved only if the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents 6,500 county workers, sacrificed a 5.25 percent wage increase that is to take effect in 1992. The union refused to do so.
More than half the layoffs could be avoided, county officials said, if enough long-term employees leave by Jan. 1 through an early-retirement plan. Mr. O'Rourke said he would be working on that aspect of the budget in the days leading up to the new year.
He said the association had made a pragmatic decision in declining to renegotiate its 1992 salary increase. "From a human standpoint, however, I would disagree with their choice. What they've done, in effect, is throw the 500 names to me and say 'go ahead, fire them.' "
Cheryl Melton, president of the Westchester unit of the association, said: "O'Rourke is putting pressure on the union to take the heat off himself. He spends millions of dollars on parklands, outside contractors and on political appointments, then expects to balance the budget by firing employees earning $20,000 a year."
 
'You End Up Dislocating Hundreds'
 The procedure is complicated, Mr. O'Rourke said, "with two-thirds of them having the right of 'bump and retrieval," a process that enables employees slated for dismissal to take the place of other employees doing similar work but with less seniority. "You end up dislocating hundreds and hundreds more," Mr. O'Rourke said. The disruption could be compounded, he added, if the economy fails to improve next year and if the State Legislature imposes reduced levels of support to balance its own budget.
"The schools, I think, are going to get hit again," he said, "and I don't think there's going to be much Medicaid reform," a change that would reduce an expense mandated by the state.
Mr. O'Rourke, who is awaiting confirmation hearings for a Federal judgeship, said he felt that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made the right decision in saying he would forgo a run for the Presidency. "I didn't think he should run; the state is in enough difficulty, requiring his attention here, and that's a conclusion he reached, too," Mr. O'Rourke said.
The County Executive also said Westchester should be "in good shape, certainly better off than any other county I can think of, once we get through this business of the layoffs." But the county's fiscal situation also depends "on what the state does to us," he added.
Mr. O'Rourke was pessimistic about any real fiscal reform in Albany this year, predicting, "They will be doing another paper-the-cracks job because they've already got lots of problems with local governments." The legislators in both houses will be running for office in 1992, making reform even less likely.
"There's lots of talk about Medicaid reform," Mr. O'Rourke said, "but many members of the Assembly have constituents in large numbers" depending on Medicaid "with the result that the legislators won't touch the issue."
 
Automobile Fleet Funds Cut
 In reducing the O'Rourke spending plan, the Board of Legislators cut $100,000 from the amount designated for the county's fleet of automobiles, eliminated a $24,000 increase in financing for the Information Center, cut $30,000 from the Westchester County Cooperative Extension program and eliminated $650 stipends provided for the Tax Commission.
It authorized the Department of Law to hire 10 new county attorneys, a revenue-saving measure in that it should enable the county to reduce its contracts with outside lawyers. The Board said the funds for the new jobs should come out of the $4 million set aside for outside counsel.
Financing for Lyme disease prevention was halved, leaving $83,000 available for use next year. It also cut in half, to $250,000, the amount designated for medical services and equipment for handicapped children but called on Mr. O'Rourke to restore the 10 percent cut in assistance to neighborhood health centers.
 
Capital Expenditures Also Approved
 The Board also approved a $73.9 million capital budget, which includes the start of major improvements at the County Airport, which is to get a new terminal and parking structure and improved access roads. The county will begin work on rehabilitating the County Courthouse complex, beginning with recovering the "skin" of the low-rise structure between the courthouse and the County Office Building.
Lynn Oliva, the Acting Commissioner of Planning, said that while some capital projects were being deferred because of cost cutting, the same tough economic times that prompted legislators to trim some projects "makes a capital budget an important element in providing jobs."
"It's also an excellent time to borrow money because interest rates are low," she said. "The economic situation now is sluggish, but when things get better we want to be in a position to attract and retain business."

PUB-DATE: December 29, 1991

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1586 words

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
IN the early autumn of 1990, 7-year-old Shawn Fernandez returned home from playing tag and found his father and a few relatives at the family's house in the Hill section of New Haven. When he asked where his mother was, "everyone got nervous and said they didn't know," the boy said. "After a while I just figured she had left me."
The next day Shawn's father handed him an article from The New Haven Register reporting that his mother had been seriously wounded in a gun accident involving her 16-year-old son. While reading the article, his emotions shifted from deep sadness to anger, said Shawn, whose mother has since made a slow recovery. 
 The boy recalled: "At first I thought: 'My mother's dead. She's dead!' And I started to cry. Then I got real mad, because after all this time nobody would tell me what happened. I mean, it's not like I'd never seen anyone shot before."
Several months earlier, Shawn had seen a young man gunned down on a nearby street corner, he said. Once they felt it was safe, he and some other children ran across the street and stood over the lifeless body.
"He had a bull's eye in the middle of his chest with a big circle of blood around it," Shawn said. "I still have dreams about it."
Last spring, he said, two boys he grew up with were killed by gunshots. One of them, Elvis Crnkovic, 15, was hit in a drive-by shooting as he played basketball a few yards from Shawn's front door. The boy was buried in the cemetery across the street from Shawn's house, where the two played football.
"Elvis was my best friend," said Shawn.
Born during the early 1980's, when the illegal drug trade began to take hold and build momentum in New Haven, Shawn and his playmates are growing up amid a culture of violence. Well acquainted with the sounds of gunshots and sirens, and street savvy about the workings of drug gangs, the children of the city's poor neighborhoods often describe their lives in a fairy tale fashion: danger lurks around every street corner, and safe havens are hard to come by.
From an early age, several children said in recent interviews, they are taught by their parents or peers how to take cover when they hear gunshots, what to do if asked by a dealer to deliver drugs and how to react if someone aims a gun at them. Fear and helplessness pervade their young lives.
"I've been afraid to leave my house for a long time," said 8-year-old Tyrone Fernandez, who is not related to Shawn. "There are bad people out there with all kinds of weapons who might try to chase me."
Romon Lockman, 11, said: "They don't chase me, but they hit me with their fist and stuff. They'll corner me and tell me that if I live on the street, I have to be in their gang." Darrell Sawyer, 9, spoke about a recent encounter with drug dealers. "They said they'd give me $200 to run an errand for them," he said. "When I said no, they pulled a long gun on me like the police use, and I ran home as fast as I could."
Sitting around a table recently at the Hill Cooperative Youth Services center, the children talked about their contempt for drugs and described how they had watched cocaine and crack destroy many people they loved. Some said the behavior of addicted siblings made it difficult for them to concentrate on their homework or to find any privacy. Others said they feared the personality changes that drugs induced.
"I can always tell when my uncle's on cocaine," said one 9-year-old boy. "He beats me with a stick."
Kimiko Archer, 10, described drug dealers. "First they give you that real nasty look," said the boy, whose imitation sparked laughter from the others, "then come up and put their arm around you and start flashing their cash."
 
Drugs' Harsh Toll
 The youth center, the children said said, is one of the few places where they feel secure and do not have to face dealers. Equipped with a basketball court, game rooms and classrooms, the center offers recreation, tutoring and counseling for children from 2 1/2 to 13.
Sherill E. Moore, who helped start the center in the early 70's, said that in those days violence among teen-agers in New Haven took the form of occasional fistfights. But by the early 80's, he said, drugs had already begun to take a harsh toll, and "everyone assumed that things couldn't get any worse."
Four years ago, however, the smuggling of guns into city neighborhoods intensified an already explosive environment among drug gangs, he said. And though educational campaigns by the schools and the media have gotten the message to young children that drugs can destroy, "we're now starting to lose kids to the glory of cops and robbers," he said. "The guns are shadowing out the drugs."
Mr. Moore added that when the center closes at 5:30, children will often linger or cry because they do not want to walk home.
"I never thought I'd see New Haven like this," he said. "People have become prisoners in their homes. They are afraid to sit outside or walk to the store after 5 o'clock. And nobody seems to be able to control what's happening out there. It's absolutely heartbreaking."
 
Threats and Foul Language
 Shawn's parents, Herbie and Leona Fernandez, said that when their family first moved into the Hill section seven years ago, the neighborhood was closely knit. People watched out for each other, they said, and children played without fear. Neighborhood barbecues and holiday dinners were common. But since the advent of drugs and guns, they said, the neighborhood spirit has shifted to an atmosphere of mistrust and greed.
Other residents, who insisted that their names not be used, said that the drug dealers had taken over their neighborhood and often threatened them with guns.
On a street corner in the Hill Section one recent afternoon, several young men in hooded parkas or ski caps openly sold drugs to a steady stream of customers who pulled up to the curb in cars like Jeeps, Saabs and minivans. Each transaction took about 60 seconds. One dealer pulled out a large wad of bills several times and counted the money.
Mrs. Fernandez said that more than a year ago a suspected drug dealer attacked her in front of her home. When her 16-year-old son saw this, she said, he ran into their house and got a shotgun. In the scuffle, she said, she tried to grab the gun from him, and she accidentally pulled the trigger, and she was shot in the abdomen.
She said that the son who was involved in the gun accident recently served a prison term for drug charges, and a 14-year-old son has been arrested on several charges, including car theft and trespassing. She wants to move out of the neighborhood before the same thing happens to Shawn, she said.
"My boys are good boys," she said. "But there's just too much going down out there for them to take. All I want is to scoop them up and get them out of this hell."
 
Workshops for Self-Esteem
 Sheryl Burack-Lynch, the director of the Coordinated Council for Children in Crisis, said the economy and the lack of affordable housing in New Haven have made it harder for families in violent neighborhoods to move to safer environments. She added that children who grow up surrounded by violence often have difficulty later in life developing attachments to people and a sense of security.
For five years the director of the Dixwell-Newhallville Community Health Center in New Haven, Robert Page, has tried to help children in the city cope with their environment. The center holds workshops in public school classrooms aimed at developing self-esteem and improving skills of negotiation and judgment, he said. In one simulated exercise, children develop a sense of control over their environment by discussing ways to respond to drug dealers who intimidate them or offer them money.
Like others who work with young children, Mr. Page said that the next phase in fighting the drug war should be a campaign to teach children how to resolve disputes without resorting to violence. What children see on the street is reinforced by television, martial-arts films and video games, he said, which may help them build hand-eye coordination, but they need alternatives to enable them to develop higher thinking skills.
"So much of what they do and see is all about escaping danger," Mr. Page said.
Like many of the children who live in the Hill section, Shawn Fernandez said he often dreams about escaping danger. In one, he said, he dreamed that an older man he knew, who had been shot and killed, came back from the dead to shoot Shawn. To assuage his fears about drug dealers, he said, he turns on music and choreographs dances that resemble a cross between those of Michael Jackson and the rap singer Hammer.
A self-taught gymnast, Shawn blends in back flips, handstands and the splits. He is one of the few youngsters who can do this, he said, and he likes to fantasize that all the neighborhood children follow him to a giant playground, where he teaches some his dance stunts and becomes their leader.
When he grows up, he said, he wants to become President, so he can help children on the street who want to escape violence. Otherwise, he would like to be a surgeon like the one who operated on his mother when she was shot, he said. Sitting with his legs folded on his living room floor, the boy grew silent, as he finished drawing a picture of a man flying away on top of a giant bumblebee.
"I think that I just want to grow up to make everyone proud of me," he said finally. "I just want to grow up to be a nice man."

HEADLINE: Funds Pared, Civil Courts Fight Rise In Backlog

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. HICKERSON

 BODY:
THE axiom that justice delayed is justice denied is being put to the test on Long Island as backlogs pile up in civil courts at a time of state budget cutbacks.
Some lawyers in Nassau and Suffolk estimate that a civil case filed in State Supreme Court may now take up to six years to be heard, mostly because of state-imposed reductions in court personnel. 
 According to a court official, 115 people were laid off in late September in Suffolk and another reduction of at least 125 is scheduled next month.
"We are down approximately 110 positions from where we were six months ago," said Arthur M. Cromarty, Suffolk's administrative judge for the Supreme Court. "As a consequence, it is safe to assume we have been falling behind. The impact has been chiefly in the civil part of the Supreme Court, the jury trial part."
Robert P. Bennett, the chief clerk to the Supreme Court in Suffolk, said 20 percent more cases have been filed in Supreme Court than last year and that with the staff reductions, 28 percent of the county's total cases are overdue to have been heard. "We are losing ground every day," Mr. Bennett said.
"Half of what we do goes on in the back office," Mr. Bennett said. "The judges are working in their chambers, getting out opinions and decisions. It's not all in the courtroom, Perry Mason stuff. There are literally mountains of paperwork in the back offices."
In Nassau, the administrative judge, Leo F. McGinity, said that if the next round of cutbacks occurs, 132 positions will be lost. "It will be devastating," Judge McGinity said. About 93 percent of the court's budget goes to personnel.
Court financing is at the heart of a feud between Gov Mario M. Coumo and the state's chief judge, Sol Wachtler. After a $966 million request for court financing was reduced by $77 million, Judge Wachtler sued the Governor, arguing that the cuts placed an unconstitutional burden on the judiciary system. The Governor responded with a lawsuit of his own.
Without further financing, Judge Wachtler is threatening to shut down the civil side of the Supreme Court.
"The governor and legislature have a constitutional obligation to provide the funds the judiciary needs to survive," said A. Thomas Levin, president of Nassau's bar association. "It's an independent part of government and can't be subjected to legislative whims. They could wipe out the judiciary as a branch of government."
"People think this is a lawyer problem and it doesn't affect the general public, but it does," he added. "If you look at the ripple effect out on the economy, it's going to affect everybody."
The Suffolk County Bar Association estimates that if the civil side closes, the Suffolk economy alone could lose up to $225 million yearly that would have been distributed through lawsuit settlements. "If the tide of settlements stops," its president, David H. Besso, said, "that would further damage the Long Island economy and severely impact projections for sales tax revenues."
Mr. Besso said the civil side of the Supreme Court is bearing the brunt of the cuts because the criminal side must function in a timely fashion to avoid violating defendants' constitutional rights. He also said family and matrimonial matters take precedent as well.
While judicial districts differ in size, which makes comparisons difficult, Long Island's case backlog appears to be high. Mary DeBourbon, of the state Office of Court Administration, said that in the ninth judicial district, encompassing Westchester County and others counties to the north, 4.3 percent of the cases are past the state's recommended timetable to be heard. In Brooklyn, that figure is 13 percent. In Suffolk, 28 percent of the cases are overdue, and in Nassau 30 percent.
"The effect of the budget cuts and the shortfalls really has only begun," Ms. DeBourbon said.
Many said the long delays are affecting legal strategies. Normally, both counties encourage parties to meet and try to settle before a case gets to court; more out-of-court settlements help decrease the backlog.
"The possibility for trial is what gets a settlement in cases," Mr. Besso said. "Most cases are settled under that area of coercion, so to speak. So when the court system can't bring the parties together in court in an expeditious fashion, that's when you will have cases that will languish."
In Nassau, 90 percent of the civil cases filed request a jury trial, which consumes a lot of time, Judge McGinity said. But he added that in normal times, 9 out of 10 of those cases are settled before the jury reaches a verdict.
Judge McGinity said he will continue to bring parties together in pretrial conferences, which can foster settlements. "But what I'm hearing," he said , "is insurance companies are saying to plaintiffs, 'You had better settle this because you are not going to get a trial for a while.' So that works against the plaintiff. That's not always the case, but the threat is there."
Eugene J. O'Brien, a lawyer who specializes in civil cases and is co-chairman of the Supreme Court committee of the Suffolk bar, says he tells clients to be prepared to wait as long as six years for trial of an automobile accident lawsuit.
"The paperwork is bogged down so bad that there are mounds and mounds of it on the county clerk's desk," Mr. O'Brien said. "It looks like a mountain of snow. They just don't have the bodies to handle it."
Judge Cromarty, who will step down from his position as Suffolk's administrative judge at the end of the year, expressed some relief at not having to deal with those duties anymore.
"Honestly, it's been a bad year for me," Judge Cromarty said. "I have been an administrative judge for 18 years. I have been building and building and building, not only physical structures but the staff and all. It's not a pleasant feeling to have to tear it down."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Troupes in Transition With an Air of Promise

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
IT has been a year of beginnings, of disappointment, of transition. The choice depends on one's outlook -- bullish, negative or charitable. However it is perceived, 1991 can be recorded as unexceptional in New Jersey theater annals.
But not uneventful. Although it is futile to search for a best play and wearying to sift through several contenders for the worst, interesting reproductions, noteworthy performances and, most of all, an air of promise rescued the year from the edge of disaster. 
 And what could be more promising, enlivening and affirmative than a brand-new theater? The fuss made over a new home for Crossroads in New Brunswick, reportedly the first expressly built for a black company in this country, was far-reaching. But most of the excitement created by the inaugural play, "Black Orpheus," was in the expectation. Clearly, for Crossroads, the new space represents a beginning, a disappointment and a transition.
For sheer arousal, consider the debuts of two artistic directors: Emily Mann (the McCarter Theater) and Bonnie J. Monte (the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival). Semantics aside, James N. Vagias (American Stage Company) makes three. Although Paul Sorvino, ever visible in films and on television, remains the nominal artistic director of the theater in Teaneck and is reportedly not uninvolved in it, Mr. Vagias, as executive director, is its new presence up front.
Given transitional circumstances, it would be more merciful than charitable to defer comment on Mr. Vagias's artistic judgment. The first two productions under his aegis -- "Williams and Walker" and "Billy Bishop Goes to War," both two-man shows -- appeared to be consequences of economic expediency rather than esthetic choice. But don't ask why the revue "White Lies" was selected as this season's opener. Just write it off.
By contrast, Ms. Mann and Ms. Monte wasted no time asserting themselves. Each took over a lethargic, complacent institution with a bored audience, and promptly shook things up.
Although the results were spotty, the outlook is optimistic. Ms. Mann, who has a cavernous theater in Princeton to contend with, directed a controversial, spacious "Glass Menagerie," with a penetrating performance by Shirley Knight. A finely acted production of an excellent play, "The Film Society," revised for the McCarter after an Off Broadway production three years ago, concluded her first season.
Ms. Monte, encumbered by a technically archaic and altogether inadequate, restrictive theater in Madison, unblocked it, presumably for the first time. She lured accomplished actors (Laila Robins, Elizabeth McGovern and Edward Herrmann in "Twelfth Night") and encouraged inventive direction (Dylan Baker's antic "Midsummer Night's Dream").
If Mr. Herrmann's idiosyncratic performance as Malvolio was more indicative of individual forethought than ensemble spirit, that was the positive flip side of limited rehearsal time. And while star power is not what repertory theater is about, who's to argue with incandescent star power?
Or transcendence? Given the Paper Mill Playhouse's penchant for overproducing and undercasting, George Grizzard, a consummate character actor in his prime, and Judy Kaye, who does everything in musicals, from high kicks to high C's -- and she's funny, too -- had a grip on real human and theatrical values amid surrounduing ostentation.
Besides "To Kill a Mockingbird" with Mr. Grizzard and "The Merry Widow" with Ms. Kaye, revivals at the Millburn showplace were enhanced by the Tony and Maria of Scott Carollo and Laurie Landry in "West Side Story" and Jane Lanier's Cassie in "A Chorus Line."
Though the value of names -- Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson in "Sparky and the Fitz" and Estelle Parsons in "Forgiving Typhoid Mary" -- could not transfuse listless new works, Harriet Harris made a striking impression as an adversarial doctor, the best-written role in "Typhoid Mary."
Other performances gave lingering pleasure: Woody Romoff in "Cantorial" and Bruce Adler and Lori Wilner in "The Immigrant," all transmitting homey warmth, at the Forum in Metuchen, and Jordan Baker exuding sensuality and intelligence as Rosalind in "As You Like It" at the Rutgers Arts Center in New Brunswick.
Among the season's disappointments, count such small professional companies as the Rivoli Stage in Rutherford and T-3 Productions in New Brunswick to come up with reasonable plays, and the failure of the three-play alliance between the Princeton Repertory and the Loaves and Fish Company, the Jersey City company now in limbo, to continue beyond the second production.
But promises persist. Speculation that the ineffable Ms. Robins may return to the Shakespeare Festival in Madison next summer is cheering indeed. Laura San Giacomo, Linda Hunt, Mary Stuart Masterson, Frances McDormand as cast members and Lanford Wilson as translator are sparking interest in Ms. Mann's production of "The Three Sisters" next month.
Add to that the return of Ms. Knight in a new play by Edward Albee, a month later, and you have a vital, long-absent anticipatory element of theater -- a real buzz.

HEADLINE: What Business Leaders Predict for 1992

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
IN assessing the county's economic prospects for the new year, the mood of Westchester business leaders is somber. In interviews with eight people across a spectrum of the business community, there was no expectation that the economy would show much improvement in 1992. Although they cited a few reasons for optimism, they suggested that the tools for ending the recession were woefully inadequate.
S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association: 
 Washington once had a favorite adage: "A rising tide raises all boats." For several years, however, Westchester's tide has been falling, and it will continue to do so next year as well. That means more unemployment, reduced local job opportunities, greater financial problems for more families, increased taxpayer resistance.
During 1991 Westchester lost over 10,000 jobs, the third year of that pattern. The trend will continue in 1992, mostly due to downsizing by companies increasing their efforts to become lean and mean. Even some local governments are starting to follow that new -- for them -- prescription for fiscal survival.
The economic news in Westchester is not as bad as in the state as a whole, in the metropolitan region or in New York City. The latter now has about 10 percent unemployment, almost twice the Westchester rate. Deteriorating conditions in Gotham reduce economic opportunities for Westchester commuters, and the bottom will not be reached in 1992. Instead, New York City employers -- notably the banking and securities and insurance sectors -- continue to reduce jobs as they attempt to sustain their competitiveness.
There are a number of bright spots in the county: corporate successes like Pepsico, Texaco, MBIA, A & W Brands, Melville, Reader's Digest, Ciba-Geigy and the New York Power Authority. But their luster tends to be dimmed by the dark news elsewhere.
Good news during 1992 will flow from the almost universal condition of peace on earth -- certainly more so than at any other time in the last few decades. Westchester does not have a major defense-oriented economy as Long Island does, so there will be limited impact s from defense cutbacks.
The next year will also witness irresistible pressures to cut government expenses -- by the county, cities, towns, villages and school districts -- so that taxes can be brought under some semblance of control. The taxpayer revolt has reached Westchester.
Peggy Tomarkin Greenawalt, president of the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners:
Members see tighter belts, an economy that is unlikely to recover in 1992, very hard work just to stay even and a lack of faith that the success they may be enjoying will hold up.
The mood is unlike that of past years. Hard work is producing good results, but unemployed family members, friends and business associates drain confidence in the economy's recovery. Customer bases are shrinking. The consulting pool is overflowing under the competitive plunge of fledgling swimmers, many of whom are former corporate executives.
There is also a feeling of some optimism. The economy eventually will recover. The United States will not become yesterday's economic superpower, because Americans work harder and fight harder and become more creative and productive when the chips are down.
To make it through the shaky economy, our members count on support from each other and patience. Our organization seems stronger than ever. We have lost fewer members and gained more new members this year than in recent memory.
John Tartaglione, chairman of the Building Trades Employers Association:
Westchester construction-industry employers will face a difficult year in 1992. The downward trend may flatten out, but no significant upturn is expected until 1993.
The industry is made up of about 350 contractors, employing about 30,000 tradesmen and women. About 30 percent of the work force is presently unemployed. It is expected that the number of contracts, or employers, will also be reduced by 30 percent within the next six months.
The private sector -- residential and commercial projects -- normally accounts for 70 percent of the total building-construction volume. This sector has been the hardest hit as a result of overbuilding, the credit crunch and new and proposed environmental regulations. The glut of commercial space and residential units may take two years to work off. But even if this happens, the regulatory problems will still remain.
The one bright spot is public construction and the major infrastructure improvements such as roads and bridges. This sector should remain firm, but not enough to offset the weakness in the private sector. On the plus side, building projects like the Westchester County Airport development, the U.S. Post Office General Mail Facility, the Federal Courthouse and the Fashion Mall in White Plains could begin in 1992, and that will create much-needed activity.
Richard Esposito, president of the Builders Institute of Westchester:
In our 1990-91 forecast we told our 1,300 members there would be a strengthening of home buyers' interest in the last quarter of 1991. That forecast failed to materialize; in fact, the new housing market is virtually nonexistent with no more than 100 units started in the last quarter.
Resales appear to have more support as sellers continue to reduce prices.
Despite falling interest rates, housing starts in Westchester County in 1992 will continue the downward trend from the peak in 1987-88, when about 4,000 dwelling units were started. By this year's end, only about 750 starts are expected to be counted.
While the overall Westchester economy is relatively strong, real estate will continue to lag. Negative consumer attitudes add to the uneasiness.
In the commercial sector, the industry is characterized by strong developers with the ability to ride out what is clearly a bear market. Very attractive tenant deals are being made. Yet it might be as late as 1993-94 before the market turns around.
A serious problem continues to be the lack of financing or refinancing interest by lenders. The credit crunch is stifling what little demand there is for housing and commercial development in the Westchester region. Additionally, balloon mortgages are becoming due on profitable investments and are not being renewed by lenders. Even the strongest builders, developers and real estate investors cannot pay these mortgages off from reserves or cash flow. As a result, needless foreclosure actions are taking place -- further depressing the market.
The unsold inventory of cooperative apartments -- estimated at about 2,600 units -- remains the largest source of moderate-income housing in the county. It is likely that this sector will begin to move in 1992. Moderating interest rates and the steady reduction of inventory should make for a firmer market in late 1992 and early 1993.
Myles McCabe, chairman-elect of the Owners Advisory Council:
Our 400 owners of 28,000 apartment units in Westchester see a number of problems coming together in 1992. The rental market is very soft, and for the first time in many years vacancies are beginning to appear. The result is a serious profit squeeze on many buildings.
With building conversions no longer a viable option, now more than ever the buildings must support themselves with tenant rental income. But as the tenant rent-guidelines process remains heavily politicized, owners find that increases granted are woefully inadequate. Since 1986 increases in rents on one- and two-year leases have averaged 3.75 percent and 5.5 percent, respectively, while building costs have increased on average 6.5 percent per year.
By contrast, apartments not under rent controls (about 5 percent of the total) appear to be doing significantly better. Those owners can get market rents.
First to go are maintenance and repairs. The banks, labor and utilities all get paid, but discretionary expenditures get put on the back burner. The result is a steadily declining quality of the rental-housing inventory.
Because of all these factors, 1992 will see no construction of new rental housing except for those projects that are federally or state subsidized.
The smaller building owners are the most vulnerable, and 50 percent of all the units in the county are held by owners of fewer than 25 units.
Judith J. Deickler, president-elect of the Westchester County Board of Realtors:
The new year, 1992, is the year to attack the devastating effect on real estate of the 1986 Tax Act. In New York State we will have to deal with the capital-gains tax, the so-called Cuomo mansion tax, which is 1 percent of the price of property selling for $1 million or more, and attempts to increase the real-property transfer tax, bankruptcies, government waste and inefficiency and rent control. Let's put excess government lands back on the tax rolls.
Housing affordability is better than it has been in a long time, with low interest rates and moderate pricing in Westchester. But it is, in part, offset by high real estate taxes, tight credit and slowing job and income growth rates.
As land becomes more scarce and undevelopable, we need to increase our efforts to preserve and/or rehabilitate our housing stock.
Fewer new homes being built and realistic pricing will help to lower the inventory of existing housing and produce a slow but steady increase in sales. Westchester has weathered the recession better than most in actually a high-volume year. Activity shifted to moderate-price properties, and we expect more of the same in 1992.
Raymond E. Sacher, president of the Westchester County Bankers Association:
As a result of the Depression-like economy, banks in Westchester and the Northeast continue, for the most part, to report depressed earnings. They struggle to reconstruct their loan portfolios after making provisions for nonperforming assets, mainly in the form of real estate loans.
In many instances, banks are being viewed by the public as restricting the availability of credit as they reinforce existing credit policies, thus assuming a role of "villain" contributing to an already weak economy.
This year, 1991, was to have been the year that Congress passed significant banking-reform legislation. Unfortunately, with the exception of the provision that increased the borrowing authority of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by $70 billion, the defeat of the other key issues may hamper reform efforts for years to come.
In 1992 Westchester banks will make Herculean efforts to restore profitability through downsizing, consolidation and mergers. Even with the reduction in overcapacity, bank profitability will return slowly until banks are permitted to compete on a level plain. The business community will continue to exercise caution regarding capital-expenditure decisions, even though interest rates are at their lowest level in 15 years.
Val Reyes, president of the Westchester Hotel Association:
This year our 21 member hotels will be down approximately four occupancy points -- or 150 fewer rooms sold per night -- amounting to a revenue loss of $5 million, and many jobs will be lost as well. The year will end with a 62 percent occupancy rate for 1991 versus 66 percent in Westchester in 1990.
Most hotels in our association submitted their 1992 forecasts in August, optimistic that the free fall would end. From a forecast of zero growth, a decline in occupancy is now likely for 1992.
Average daily room rates may decline even further in Westchester as corporate clients try to extract better deals. Corporate downsizing will idle hotel inventory. In the catering area, heavy shopping around for prices will probably lead to discounting for social and corporate functions.
The Stamford factor now plays a crucial role. With UPS departing for Atlanta, a rate war with Westchester is foreseeable. Unfortunately, the tax situation in Westchester does not help our hotels: guests must pay a 14.75 percent surcharge here and only 6 percent in Connecticut.
The outbound Manhattan market will dry up as New York City hotel rates drop. Leisure travel into Westchester is also at risk: Manhattan has never been as attractive as it is now.

HEADLINE: Job Seekers Keep Beating a Path To Town Agencies

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE personnel administrator in Waterbury, John S. Schlosser, expected a lot of interest when the town placed advertisements for police officers recently. He thought he might see as many applications as he did last year, when more than 700 people answered a similar advertisement, he said. But this time he was deluged with more than 1,700 applications.
The same thing happened when he advertised for a clerk-typist, he said. He expected 40 applications; he received 170. 
 "Because of the general downturn in the economy, and the layoffs by the state government, we've been seeing a lot more applications for all positions," Mr. Schlosser said.
 
Most Secure Employment
 Municipal officials around the state report similar experiences. The state government was once seen as the most secure employment, they said, but recent state layoffs, and the threat of more to come, have tarnished that image. And many businesses in the state are in fiscal disarray.
Towns and cities have had their own problems, with employees being asked to accept diminished salaries and benefits and some of the hardest-hit towns laying off workers. But the state's 169 municipalities are increasingly seen as some of the most secure employers left, local officials say.
"We haven't had anyone breaking down our door looking for employment," said Edward T. Went, First Selectman of Roxbury, a town of 1,800 people with a half-dozen general government employees. "But part of it is because people know we don't have any openings."
In larger towns, though, job seekers are overwhelming the personnel departments.
"If we advertise for a police officer, we get 150 applicants," said the town manager in Southington, John Weichsel. "And if we advertise for a laborer, we get 100. The problem now is how to pick people fairly, when you have so many."
Mr. Weichsel said the last position he advertised, a clerk-typist job, brought 55 applications. When evaluating applicants for a typing job, "at least you can give a speed and accuracy test," Mr. Weichsel said. "So it's easier to be objective." But when he is looking for a police officer, he said, how does he weigh the relative strengths of someone who has an advanced degree in law enforcement versus an applicant with 10 or 12 years' experience?
Mr. Weichsel said the advent of binding arbitration in 1985 helped change attitudes toward municipal employment. Salary and benefit awards to town workers have been generous, he said, noting that many towns argue that the awards have been too generous and are supporting attempts in the legislature to change the arbitration process.
"Now we pay more than many private industries," he said, "and our benefits are much better."
Two years ago many municipalities left an engineer's or building official's position vacant for months at a time, because people with those skills could make so much more in private employment. But when the first selectman of Clinton, Paul W. Austin, advertised for a town engineer recently, about 50 resumes quickly piled up on his desk.
"A lot of engineers in private practice aren't too busy, because there aren't any construction projects moving forward," Mr. Austin said. "A lot of them would like the security of full-time work with a municipality. It's not as subject to the whims of the marketplace."
Cari Zimber-Forrest, Norwalk's principal personnel analyst and a director of the state chapter of the Society for Human Resources Management, said that thanks to the recession she has finally been able to find people for formerly hard-to-fill positions like public health nurses and social workers. Many of the applications are coming from laid-off state workers, she said, noting that when she advertised for two truck drivers recently, she had several applications from former employees of the State Transportation Department.
"We've been looking for a operator for our waste water treatment plant for more than a year," Ms. Zimber-Forrest said. "Because of the recession, some other towns have had to let plant operators go. So we finally got some interest, including one very qualified applicant."
Even towns that cannot promise any more job security than private employers have more than enough applicants. Bridgeport, which filed for bankruptcy last summer, hired 26 seasonal laborers to pick up leaves and yard waste and saw the number of applications for those jobs jump to 12 to 15 a day in November, from 6 or 7 a day in October, said Judy C. Creatore, an administrative assistant in the city's Civil Service Department.
 
Higher-Quality Applicants
 Ms. Creatore said Bridgeport recently received eight applications for a dental hygienist job in a city-run clinic.
"We have a lot of people come to our counter looking for work, any work," Ms. Creatore said. "But we don't have anything right now."
Mr. Schlosser in Waterbury said the increase in applications means that towns can have their pick of higher quality employees.
"Just because you're expanding the pool that much, you end up with more good candidates," he said. "When you've got 1,700 applications for a police officer's job, you know you can eliminate a lot of them right off the bat. But you'll also have more at the upper end of the scale. We can be much more confident with 1,700 than we could be with 35."
Mr. Weichsel of Southington also said the economy means more stable town government.
"People aren't leaving city jobs,' he said. "They're so precious now."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
